Name: 01-MTF
Content: [[Image]]MTF Vault.png|Running into MTF in a [[Storage]] vault[[/Image]]A friendly bot that rarely shows up in [[Storage]] in an already opened vault. Will join Cogmind as an uncontrollable purple ally for the duration of the map and uses [[01-MTF's Autohacker]] to automatically open any other vaults it can see. It will assimilate or destroy most enemies it encounters extremely quickly with its high spectrum high damage EM gun [[01-MTF's Shockpuncher]]. The Shockpuncher is a very powerful weapon that is strong throughout the majority of the game as long as you can deal with its short range if you can get it to drop. [[Spoiler]]Presumably stole exiles prototypes.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: 0b10
Content:
This is the main complex. Cogmind starts from the bottom [[Scrapyard]] level at depth -11. Every level have stairs to an upper level until level -1 where the surface [[Access]] can be found. The levels can also contain other doorways which lead to different branches that eventually connect to the main complex. Read more about all levels at [[Locations]].

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Complex 0b10[[/Lore]]
Entrances to new levels are implied to be long uneventful corridors where Cogmind loses all pursuers.
0b10 means 2 (0b - binary representation, 10 - 2 in decimal). [[Spoiler]]This means Complex 0b10 is the second complex, 0b1 presumably being first.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: 0b10 Alert Chip
Content: Analyzes ambient [[0b10]] signals to guess the alert level. The best part of this item is the reduction of influence by 20%. This item is obtainable from the exiles.

Name: 0b10 Bots
Content: 0b10 Bots are a large [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of bots that are found in nearly all maps in the game, and are particularly numerous in [[0b10|Complex 0b10]]. There are a large variety of [[0b10 Combat Bots|combat]] and [[0b10 Non-combat Bots|non-combat]] bots.

Name: 0b10 Combat Bots
Content: 0b10 Combat Bots are a large [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of bots that make up the fighting force of [[0b10|Complex 0b10]]. They are most commonly found [[Patrol Squad|patrolling]] or [[Security Squad|guarding]] areas within 0b10.

Name: 0b10 Decoder Chips
Content:
[[Heading]]List of 0b10 Decoder Chips[[/Heading]]
[[PartGroupTable]]

Name: 0b10 Non-combat Bots
Bots: K-01 Serf,N-00 Fly,N-01 Spotter,N-04 Retriever,T-07 Excavator,U-05 Engineer

Name: 12-ASH
Content:
[[GameText]]Hail to the king![[/GameText]]
12-ASH is a member of the [[Heroes of Zion]] equipped with [[12-ASH's Boomstick]] and [[Ripper]].

Name: 6S-H0T
Content:
6S-H0T is a part of the deadly group of [[Unchained]] [[Derelict|Derelicts]] that work for [[0b10]] to track down threats to the complex. Its signature weapon, [[6S-H0T's Six Shooter]], is a powerful perfectly accurate gun with a high blast critical chance. With a [[Exp. Reaction Control System]], [[Exp. Propulsion Shielding|Exp. Propulsion]] and [[Exp. Weapon Shielding|Weapon Shieldings]], and an incredibly low 15% core exposure, 6S-H0T is no defensive slouch either. Trying to pin this Unchained down is a tall order.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]Cyclists Records|UC/6S-H0T[[/Lore]]

[[Heading:2]][[FarCom]] Lore[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has aligned with the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]] and has FarCom, the following message will be broadcast about 6S-H0T:
[[GameText]]At least this one runs out of ammo quickly, but they're also really aggressive and if you're caught in range they are going to tear you to pieces. Maybe just be dodgy?[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
6S-H0T is a hit-and-run type of Unchained that only engages in short bursts of combat. Its gun is only able to fire with the use of [[6S-H0T's SS Cartridge|6S-H0T's SS Cartridges]], which 6S-H0T carries 5 of. After showing up on the map, it will chase Cogmind down, burn through all 5 Cartridges, then head for the nearest [[Garrison Access]] to restock. A few hundred turns later, it will pop out, fully repaired, ready to shoot again with another 5 Cartridges.
[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
6 projectiles at 25% Blast crit each is a terrifying prospect. Fighting 6S-H0T without a [[Graphene Brace]] is likely to lead to many parts on Cogmind's body being blasted off and onto the ground. 2 or more slot parts can mitigate this to some degree, though it's still quite likely to get multiple parts blasted off.
Thanks to the Six Shooter's high targeting bonus, evasion utilities are unhelpful against 6S-H0T. Instead, focus on reducing damage through other parts. Kinetic damage resistance via [[Resistance Devices]] or [[Resistance Armor]] work well, particularly when combined with [[Hardlight Generators]]. [[Shield Generators]] and [[Force Fields]] are always useful, though they may require some [[Energy Wells]] to support the fast drain considering the high immediate damage.
As with all Unchained, allies are extremely helpful when fighting 6S-H0T, both as damage dealers and as distractions to take some fire off of you. In a pinch, even a basic [[Drone Bay]] can be useful as a distraction. If 6S-H0T spots the [[Drone|Drones]] before Cogmind, it will shoot them first. A single bay can potentially waste 2 out of the 5 volleys, with each Drone most likely dying in a single volley.
6S-H0T doesn't have any particular defensive weaknesses, though it does sport a slightly annoying 25% kinetic and very high 90% EM damage resistance. Because of this, Thermal is the best conventional damage type, although most forms of damage work reasonably well against this bot. [[Explosive Launchers]] may kill all chance of salvage, but they are a good choice at quickly dealing a lot of damage in a short period of time, even while missing the otherwise evasive 6S-H0T. If not using Launchers, [[Core Analyzers]] are incredibly valuable thanks to its extremely low base core coverage.

Name: A Bots
Content: A bots are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[Programmer]]-like bots that are aligned to the [[Architect]]. A few are friendly to Cogmind, but the majority of them are hostile and can only be encountered at their home base in [[Access_0]]. They have a variety of different offensive and defensive armament and boast some powerful unique parts. They are all formidable opponents in combat.

Name: A-27 Freighter
Content: Informally known as a yauler (yellow Hauler). In the main complex, appears as part of a [[Cargo Convoy]].

Name: A7
Content: Drops the [[A7 Data Core]] when killed. Gives a code when shown the Cetus Mainframe in [[Cetus]].

Name: A7 Data Core
Content:
Allows entrance into [[Lab]] and [[Redacted]]reveals the hidden intruder-detecting lasers.[[/Redacted]]

Dropped by [[A7]] on death.

Name: AWS/Thermal
Content: If the AWS/Thermal is repaired with a [[Recalibrators|Recalibrator]], it will break down in fewer shots than it did the first time. After several repairs, it will consistently break down within a few shots of being repaired.

Name: Access
Content:
Access is the last [[0b10]]-controlled main floor that only appears on -1. Access is the most challenging main map with increased patrol density, number of bots per patrol, map size, and level and difficulty in hackable machines compared to [[Research]]. These maps have a 150x300 tile size, either being a tall vertical level or a wide horizontal level. Access maps tend to be fairly well connected across corridors and rooms, and have fewer large rooms and larger hallways more similar to [[Factory]] than the cramped maze-like layout of Research. There are only 2 exits in Access, and locating and taking the desired exit can be especially challenging.
In contrast with the small number of exits, Access has the highest number of [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] with 6 machines spread throughout the level. Shutting or destroying Garrisons is always a good idea, but there is a special interaction in Access: [[Spoiler]]If all 6 Garrisons are shut down or disabled, [[Maximum Security]] will be triggered, sending huge waves of hostiles at Cogmind. Either be prepared to fight your way out, or have an escape route planned for a fast airborne build to avoid engaging in combat.[[/Spoiler]]
The biggest bot upgrade in Access is the [[Behemoth]] change. All Behemoths will become [[B-99 Colossus|Colossi]], extremely dangerous and hard to kill threats. They have some incredibly good loot, but trying to kill them with conventional methods is difficult due to their high damage output, high integrity, and [[Adv. Force Field]] reducing damage they take. Avoiding them or running if spotted is usually the best plan.
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There is one special machine in Access. The Energy Cycler is a large explosive machine that appears in rooms with a 2 tile wide doorway. When it is destroyed, several [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]] will spawn from Garrisons and start roaming around the map. Additionally, all of the sealed heavy doors on the map will retract, allowing access to exits.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Access Level[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Access Energy Cycler.png|Energy Cycler machine|Access Surface Exit.png|Exit to [[Surface]]|Access Command Entrance.png|Exit to [[Command]] guarded by [[H-88 Terminator|Terminators]] and [[B-99 Colossus|Colossi]][[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of exits on Access floors. Both exits can be identified by long 2 tile wide corridors leading to the [[Terminal]]-locked side of the exits. They are both identifiable by look alone:
[[List]][[Surface]] exit: There are 2 sides to this Surface exit. One side is locked behind an 80 armor Sealed Barrier locked by a [[Terminal]] with a base 7% open chance. The other side has Sealed Heavy Doors that are much easier to break through, but is guarded by 2 Colossi. Blowing up the Energy Cyclers will open only the side with the Sealed Barrier. Trying to rush head-on past the Behemoths is usually not recommended due to their extreme damage output and heavy knockback.|[[Redacted]][[Command]] exit: There are 2 sides to this Command exit. One side has a 2 tile snaking corridor that has 3 consecutive Sealed Barriers. Each has a base 30% open chance. The other side has a single row of Sealed Heavy Doors, a guard area with 2 Terminators and 2 Colossi, and 3 more Sealed Heavy Doors blocking the exit. Blowing up the Energy Cycler will only open the side with the 3 Sealed Barriers.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]
There are some effective ways at getting through the unguarded parts of each exit:
[[List]]Blowing up the Energy Cyclers|A reasonable stack of offensive and defensive [[Hackware]]|Powerful thermal cannons like [[Cld. Nova Cannon]], [[Null Cannon]], [[Core Cannon]], [[Potential Cannon]], or [[Imp. Potential Cannon]]. The Sealed Barriers have 80 armor and high damage resistances to all common types except for Thermal damage.|The Terminal hacking utilities [[Skeleton Box]] or [[01-MTF's Autohacker]]|The digging [[Alien Artifacts]] [[Matter Drive]] or [[Terrabomb]] or the digging weapon [[LU-1G1's Laser Shovel]]|The Alien Artifact [[Spacefold Activator]]|Using an EM [[Launchers|Launcher]] on a high rating [[Reactors|Reactor]] dropped on the floor next to the Sealed Barrier to explode it[[/List]]
Last updated: Beta 15

Name: Access_0
Content:
Access_0 is a non-[[0b10]] [[Branch]] off of [[Command]] that only appears on -1. It is the home to the [[Architect]], the [[A Bots]], and several types of Enhanced bots. Access_0 is a very heavily combat-oriented map that has 2 unique wintypes available and has the Architect present, a special boss bot that will award a + on the scoresheet when defeated. It features a multitude of unique bots, a unique bossfight mechanic, and many of the strongest hostiles in the game to fight.
The overall structure of Access_0 can be split into 2 groups with a small bridge connecting section guarded by [[A2]].

[[Heading]]Layout[[/Heading]]
The bulk of the map is on the right side, with the bridge dividing a small section of the left side of the map. Overall, the layout is comparable to a more maze-like [[Caves]]. There are many dead ends and nearly-connected areas that can be safely dug out when noticed with terrain scanning. Cogmind spawns on the right side of the map along with the Architect, [[A8]], and 2 [[Enhanced Grunt|Enhanced Grunts]]. The right side of the map can contain [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]]-containing Workstation machines, large item caches on the ground or in Reinforced Shells, random bits of machinery, and Subspace Access Nodes. Typically, there are 4 Access Nodes on the right side of the map, although very rarely one can appear on the left. Otherwise, the left side can contain all the same things that the right side has and a few more. The left side will always contain a Singularity Gate machine along with a Gate Controls Terminal that can control it. At the bottom left of the map, there is an Architect Logs Terminal wrapped in a 120 armor Architect Shell.
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Subspace Access Node[[/Heading]]
There are 4 of these Access Nodes, also known as "pads" on the map. They serve as nodes for the Architect to appear at after teleporting out. Destroying all 4 is required to fight the Architect normally.
[[Heading:3]]Singularity Gate[[/Heading]]
A large and fragile machine on the left side of the map. If this machine is intact when the Architect is destroyed, a countdown of 10 turns will begin. If Cogmind is still on the map and the gate is not destroyed in that timeframe, Cogmind will be instantly destroyed. It is possible to activate the machine by performing the Gate Test 138-A and Gate Test 138-B hacks. This will an approximately 5 tile radius singularity that draws bots and parts in and destroys them instantly if the center is reached. This singularity will stop if the gate is destroyed. The Architect will intentionally target the gate to break it while in this state. The Gate Test 138-END will shut down the singularity. One additional hack, 138-C, requires the [[A2 Data Core]] which can be achieved by destroying A2. Performing this hack will immediately end the run and result in a [[Wintypes|W5 Wintype]]. If the singularity gate is still intact when the Architect is destroyed, the gate will be activated and can not be shut down by normal means. Cogmind must exit the map within 10 turns or destroy the singularity gate or else Cogmind will be instantly destroyed. If Cogmind exits the map while the countdown is going off, this will result a W6 wintype.
[[Heading:3]]Architect Logs[[/Heading]]
The Architect shell has 120 armor and is extremely difficult to break through by force. However, defeating the Architect will drop the [[Architect Data Core]] which will result in the shell retracting and revealing the inner Terminal that contains a large number of unique lore entries.
[[Heading:3]]Dimensional Slip Node[[/Heading]]
There is a Dimensional Slip node installed near the top of the map. Using a [[Transdimensional Reconstructor|regular]] or [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor]] will always go to this location. An exit is a few tiles away from this spot. If the Architect is still alive when Cogmind appears here, the log message [[GameText]]I have more important things to do than play hide-and-seek. Deal with this piece of junk if it returns.[[/GameText]] will appear, and the Architect will disappear off of the map and will not return.

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Access_0 Sigix Corpse.png|Analysis Chamber machine with [[Sigix Corpse]]|Access_0 Alien Artifact.png|Workstation machine containing Alien Artifact|Access_0 Subspace Access Node.png|Subspace Access Node machine|Access_0 Singularity Gate.png|The Singularity Gate machine|Access_0 Active Singularity Gate.gif|Active Singularity Gate destroying parts|Access_0 Architect Logs.png|Architect Logs Terminal with shell|Access_0 Cache 1.png|Sealed Reinforced Shell (40 armor) cache|Access_0 Cache 2.png|Open Reinforced Shell cache|Access_0 Cache 3.png|Another sealed cache variant|Access_0 Cache 4.png|Another opened cache variant|Access_0 Cache 5.png|A cache variant with all items on the ground|Access_0 Entrance.png|Entrance assault with the Architect, A8, and 2 Enhanced Grunts|Access_0 Bridge.png|The "bridge" guarded by A2|Access_0 Enhanced Sentry.png|Guard post with [[Enhanced Sentry]]|Access_0 Enhanced Grunts.png|Guard post with Enhanced Grunts[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Caches[[/Heading]]There are several types of caches in Access_0, although they all draw from the same pool of potential items. This pool contains all rating 6-9 [[Prototype Part|Prototype]] parts accessible normally in 0b10 in stockpiles. It does not include any unique parts such as items found in [[Testing]] shells. These Prototype parts will never be faulty.
[[Heading:2]]Alien Artifacts[[/Heading]]
There are typically multiple Alien Artifacts held in 40 armor Workstation machines. If there are any, one will be guaranteed to be a Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor. The full list of available Alien Artifacts are:
[[List]][[Core Expander]]|[[Core Regenerator]]|[[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor]]|[[Integrated Dissipator]]|[[Integrated Mediator]]|[[Integrated Reactor]]|[[Integrity Redistributor]]|[[Sigix Broadsword]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]There is a single exit in Access_0. A [[Surface]] exit is buried behind several dozen tiles of earth near the top of the map. It can be accessed via the Dimensional Slip Node by using a regular or Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor or by digging deep into the earth.

[[Heading]]Special bots[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]The [[Architect]][[/Heading]]
The Architect is the true final boss of Cogmind. It has a multitude of strong offensive and defensive parts, resistances to most common damage types, 400 core, innate core and part regeneration, perfect always-active tracking on Cogmind's position, and a whopping 28 speed to top it all off. There is also a unique mechanic where the Architect will teleport to a nearby Subspace Access Node under various conditions. This includes: falling to 80% of core integrity (320/400), losing 2/3 Modified Sigix Shearguns, or becoming overweight. It will always have [[Perfect Tracking]] on Cogmind and never give up pursuit. It also has "Behemoth AI", where it will try to shoot Cogmind through several layers of tiles. This can be exploited by moving behind walls where repeated shots will take out wall tiles instead of hitting Cogmind.
The Architect can not be destroyed by most methods unless all 4 of the subspace access nodes are destroyed first. The one exception to this rule is that dealing 400 core damage in a single turn can destroy the Architect. While technically possible with a large enough weapon volley, this method of killing is primarily reserved to a few unique weapons, like the [[BFG-9k Vortex Edition]], the [[L-Cannon]], a [[Sigix Exoskeleton]]-boosted [[Core Cannon]], or 2 Core Cannons.
[[Heading:3]]Special Weapon Interactions[[/Heading]]
There are a few weapons that have special interactions with the Architect.
[[Heading:4]][[Sigix Terminator]]/[[Supercharged Sigix Terminator]][[/Heading]]
Using either of these weapons will cause the Architect to wrap to the nearest subspace node, resulting in the log message [[GameText]]I'm all too familiar with what that does.[[/GameText]] This effect will only occur if one or more subspace nodes are intact. Due to the way the Architect teleports, it is possible to hit it with the explosion, but only if the pad that the Architect teleports to is within range. This can be used to take out the last pad and land a hit on the Architect at the same time.
[[Heading:4]][[L-Cannon]][[/Heading]]
Similar to the terminators, it is not possible to hit the Architect with the L-Cannon unless the subspace nodes are all destroyed. The log message [[GameText]]I'm aware you stole the capacitor, you know...[[/GameText]] will accompany the Architect teleporting to the nearest subspace node. Even if the nodes are taken down, destroying the singularity gate is required before using the L-Cannon for the killing blow. Otherwise Cogmind will be crushed in the 10 turn countdown since the weapon itself takes 10 turns of delay after firing.
[[Heading:3]]Self-destruct codes[[/Heading]]
If any Enhanced bots or A bots are assimilated by disruption and rewiring or via the [[Field Lobotomy Kit]] and the Architect spots them, a log message [[GameText]]Architect flashes a signal at [Bot Name].[[/GameText]] will appear, and the bot will self-destruct. Bots that self-destruct will drop loot normally according to their salvage. This usually results in some pretty large loot pile explosions, especially for some of the lower numbered A bots. Although these bots cannot be used as allies, assimilation is a good way to let the Architect get rid of them rather than fighting them yourself.
[[Heading:3]]Defeat[[/Heading]]
The Architect is a sore loser. If destroyed, the Singularity Gate will be activated (if intact) and trigger a 10 turn countdown. Cogmind must either use a Transdimensional Reconstructor and escape out the exit at the top of the map near the Slip Node or destroy the Gate machine within these 10 turns to avoid instant death.
[[Heading:2]][[A Bots]][[/Heading]]
The A bots are a series of very powerful and unique enemies, most of which only appearing in Access_0 or are allies on other maps. A8 appears at the entrance to the map and A2 guards the "bridge" to the left side of the map. [[A7]] does not appear on this map at all. Other than that, [[A6]], [[A5]], [[A4]], and [[A3]] all appear after Cogmind has explored a certain percentage of the map. They appear at roughly 10-15%, 25-30%, 45-50%, and 70-75% map exploration respectively. This is only affected by tiles seen by Cogmind and not other forms of intel such as drones or terrain scanning. If A8 was destroyed in [[Zion]], or A5 was in [[Lab]], they will not appear in Access_0. All A bots also maintain perfect tracking on Cogmind and can not be shaken.
[[Heading:2]][[Enhanced Programmer|Enhanced Programmers]][[/Heading]]
Enhanced Programmers are a unique type of bot that can show up in Access_0, but only under certain conditions. Using the [[Data Miner|Data Miner's]] [[Data Conduit]] or bringing more than 2 combat allies (bots with weapons) into the map will trigger these bots to spawn. They are extremely tough bots with many resistances and carry an [[Adv. Remote Force Field]] that will shield other allies. They will roam around the map as lone patrol bots.

[[Heading]]Unlockable Architect Logs[[/Heading]]
Similar to the Lab orders, there are some unique lore entries in the Architect Logs that can only be obtained by performing specific actions before that point. To read these logs, Cogmind must either defeat the Architect or have a strong enough weapon to break through the 120 armor shell that also doesn't break the frail Terminal inside it.
[[List]]Log L.L98W4A5V: Use the Data Miner's Data Conduit.
|Log L.MJH3MJHF: Save [[Revision 17]] in [[Cetus]] by defeating all of the [[Cetus Guard|Cetus Guards]]. Revision 17 must die before Cogmind exits the map.
|Log L.NV345OIG: Save Revision 17 in Cetus while keeping the manufacturing module intact and exiting while Revision 17 is still alive, triggering the -3 Revision 17 invasion event. Revision 17 must also survive until Cogmind exits the map on -3.
|Log L.PLVSNE0F: Trigger the Revision 17 invasion event, but Revision 17 must die in -3.
|Log L.SWO95LD1: Expose [[Zhirov]] by destroying the Cloak Generator machine at [[Zhirov (Location)]], and kill Zhirov himself before he teleports away.
|Log L.T4KTHQWA: Expose Zhirov by destroying the Cloak Generator machine, but he must survive the attack and teleport away.
|Log L.UHGC2ASH: Fail to ally with [[Warlord]] in [[Warlord (Location)]] by either being [[Imprint|Imprinted]] or by not visiting Warlord in the map. Warlord must not have died at his base.
|Log L.VFLK3RLK: Ally with Warlord at his base and Warlord must survive the -2 assault.
|Log L.WEK5AVLJ: Ally with Warlord at his base and Warlord must die at the -2 assault.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Defeating the Architect Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Bosses/Defeating Architect]].

Name: Achievements
Content:
[[Comment]]                       ---NOTE FOR EDITORS---
Once Beta 16 releases, if you decide to update any of the Achievements pages, please consider whether it would be better to separate the new achievements from the old ones or not.
I think that, ideally, whatever you choose to do, that decision should be applied to all Achievements pages, for the sake of consistency.[[/Comment]]

There are currently 256 achievements in Cogmind, which can be viewed in-game through the Achievements records submenu. They are divided into several categories organized by color, with the appearance of their borders sometimes providing additional information. 81 of the 256 Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them.

Visually, Achievements are tile-based 5x5 squares. While an Achievement is locked, the inner 3x3 square is made out of question marks. Unlocking an Achievement changes the inner 3x3 square to visually represent the Achievement's requirements/results. The tiles on the border of the 5x5 square almost never change when the Achievement is unlocked. [[Comment]]Those achievements are "Stardust" and "Planet Killer". this is because Wins Achievements' inner art isn't a square but more of a cog, so some of the outer border tiles are part of said art, even if it's just a matching background. This dark green background is the same for all Wins Achievements, except those two. The locked versions, however, still have that dark green background.[[/Comment]]

[[Table]]
Type|Color|Total|Hidden|Sub-types||
[[Mechanics Achievements]]|Orange|72|15|No specific sub-type||
[[Style Achievements]]|Blue|46|12|-Reaching a high statistic in a specific category
-Using specific rare/unique items and/or their mechanics||
[[Progress Achievements]]|Yellow|33|2|-Earning enough points
-Visiting/exiting specific areas
-Visiting multiple areas, possibly of a specific type
-Reaching a high peak rating
-Reaching/earning 25/50/75/100% of lore collection/gallery collection/achievements||
[[Challenges Achievements]]|Red|27|2|No specific sub-type||
[[Events Achievements]]|Purple|41|40|-Triggering/witnessing a specific event
-Reaching a specific important branch/meeting a specific important character
-Destroying a specific hostile character||
[[Wins Achievements]]|Green|37|10|-Winning the game with a specific ending
-Winning the game with any ending under certain conditions
-Winning the game with any ending while a challenge mode is active
(Challenge mode achievements will eventually be removed from the game)
[[/Table]]

Almost all achievements can and have to be completed within a single run, with the exception of "Back For More", "True Cogmind", and all achievements that require reaching/earning 25/50/75/100% of lore collection/gallery collection/achievements.
In addition, some achievements are exclusive to other achievements (for example, all "Specialist" are mutually exclusive to one another), and some are seed-dependent and as a result may not be completable on some seeds (For example, "Exterminator" is not completable on all seeds).


This article was last updated during Beta 14.
Subpages: Challenges Achievements,Events Achievements,Mechanics Achievements,Progress Achievements,Style Achievements,Wins Achievements

Name: Acronyms
Content:
The following is a list of common acronyms in the Cogmind community:
[[List]]A: [[Access]]|A0: [[Access_0]]|A7: [[Alpha 7]], also applies to the bot [[A7]]|AA: [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]]|ACA: [[Active Cooling Armor]]|AIA: [[Armor Integrity Analyzer]]|ASS: [[Active Sensor Suite]]|BC: [[Blast Cannon]]|CAS: [[Component Analysis Suite]]|C: [[Command]]|CC: [[Core Cannon]]|CE: [[Core Expander]]|CM: [[Core Membrane]]|CML: [[Chain Missile Launcher]]|CPC: [[Core Physics Calibrator]]|CR: [[Core Regenerator]]|CRM: [[Core Reset Matrix]]|CS: [[Core Stripper]]|DAS: [[Deploy-a-Sentry]]|DC: [[Data Conduit]]|DoCo: [[Redacted]]Doom Corridor, the location in [[Command]][[/Redacted]]|DM: [[Data Miner]]|DLC: [[Drained L-Cannon]]|DNS: [[Deep Network Scanner]]|DNI: [[Dimensional Node Initializer]]|DSS: [[Deep Structural Scanner]]|ECA: [[Encrypted Comm Array]]|EEK7: [[Redacted]]A name for the exit on the right side of Command. When the exit is viewed in ASCII mode, it represents the 2 [[Executioner|Executioners]], a [[Striker]], and an Alpha 7[[/Redacted]]|FF: [[Force Field]]|FF7: [[Flying Fortress v7]]|FFF: [[Redacted]][[Fortress]], named for the ASCII representation[[/Redacted]]|FLK: [[Field Lobotomy Kit]]|FRG: [[Protoforge]]|FRU: [[Field Recycling Unit]]|GBA: [[Gamma Bomb Array]]|GRD: [[Gui. Name: Active Cooling Armor
Content: Obtainable only from a [[Cargo Convoy]].

Name: Active Sensor Suite
Content:
The Active Sensor Suite is the most powerful type of [[Sensor Arrays|Sensor Array]]. It can detect all bots, even inactive ones like the [[Exp. Signal Interpreter]] can. Additionally, it cannot be jammed by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or [[Heavy|Heavies]] like normal Sensor Arrays. It also has a unique effect of showing the paths that bots typically travel in, or "desire paths". These paths typically lead through busy corridors and into exits and interactive machines.

[[Heading]]Active Scanning Reported[[/Heading]]
After a certain number of hostile bots are detected using the Active Sensor, an [[Investigation Squad]] will be dispatched to Cogmind's location. This accompanied by an alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Active scanning activity reported from Zone [zone], dispatching Investigation squad[[/GameText]]. The number of bots needed to be scanned varies by the type of bot that has been detected. Once the total detection % reaches 100%, an investigation is summoned, Cogmind's [[Alert]] goes up by 100, and the detection % is reset to 0. Bots not listed in the below table don't count toward an active scanning penalty.
[[Table]]
Bot type|Number of bots of this type scanned to be fully detected|Detection %||
[[Alpha 7]]|4|30%||
[[Armor Guard]]|4|30%||
[[Behemoth]]|4|30%||
[[Brawler]]|15|7%||
[[Cetus Guard]]|4|30%||
[[Combat Programmer]]|10|10%||
[[Cutter]]|20|5%||
[[Duelist]]|15|7%||
[[E-15 Imp]]|20|5%||
[[Executioner]]|10|10%||
[[Fortress]]|4|30%||
[[Grunt]]|15|7%||
[[Heavy]]|7|15%||
[[Hunter]]|10|10%||
[[Programmer]]|7|15%||
[[Q-Series]]|10|10%||
[[Quarantine Guard]]|4|30%||
[[S7 Guard]]|4|30%||
[[Sentry]]|7|15%||
[[Specialist]]|15|7%||
[[Striker]]|10|10%||
[[Swarmer]]|20|5%||
[[Watcher]]|10|10%
[[/Table]]

Name: Adv. Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Advanced Drone|Advanced Drones]].

Name: Alarm Trap
Content:
Alarm Traps are the only [[Traps]] that can appear in all [[0b10]] maps that can contain 0b10 traps. Like [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]] and [[Chute Trap|Chute Traps]], they cannot be extracted using a [[Trap Extractors|Trap Extractor]].

[[Heading]]Effects[[/Heading]]
When an Alarm Trap is triggered, it and all other Alarm Traps in the array will be spent, a special alert sound will play, accompanied by the alert message [[GameText]]ALERT: Alarm triggered, dispatching investigation squad[[/GameText]]. This will cause an [[Investigation Squad]] to be dispatched to the location of the Alarm Trap, and nearby combat bots will be informed of the victim's position. If an Alarm Trap is triggered far enough from Cogmind, there will be no alert sound or message, but an investigation squad will still be dispatched. 
In [[Garrison|Garrisons]], triggering an Alarm Trap does not play an alert sound, do not trigger an alert message and instead only the log message [[GameText]]An alarm sounds[[/GameText]], no investigation squad is dispatched, and instead the only effect is that nearby combat bots will be informed of the victim's position.

[[Heading]]Alarm Trap-Specific removal strategies[[/Heading]]
Like Ambush Traps, successfully hacking Alarm Traps using a [[Melee Datajacks|Melee Datajack]] will always disable them, never reprogram them. It still possible to reprogram Alarm Traps through [[Terminal]] hacking, though this is not recommended as this will cause any hostiles that move onto the traps to trigger them, which will still dispatch an investigation squad.
If Cogmind has a [[Transmission Jammers|Transmission Jammer]] or [[Spoiler]]the Signal Jamming [[RIF]] ability[[/Spoiler]] and an Alarm Trap is triggered within jamming range, the trap array will still be spent, but will have no effect and grant the "No Signal" [[Mechanics Achievements|Mechanics Achievement]] if it wasn't already unlocked. [[Allies]] are incapable of using a Signal Jammer even when they have one attached, so do not rely on them to jam Alarm Traps.

In Garrisons, if there are no combat bots nearby, for example if they have already been dealt with, Alarm Traps will have no meaningful effect.

This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Alert
Content:
Alert is an underlying mechanic throughout the game that describes Cogmind's apparent threat level to [[0b10]]. It only comes into play in 0b10-controlled maps, primarily on main floors like [[Materials]] or [[Factory]] or a few 0b10 branches. It can be increased by many ways, most often by getting spotted or destroying bots or parts of the level. Alert does naturally dissipate over time, although combat-oriented strategies will almost always generate much more alert than the dissipation rate.
Alert is normally hidden throughout the game, although it can be revealed through a few different ways. [[RIF]]-alignment gives a permanent influence number and alert level indicator on the UI at all times. The [[0b10 Alert Chip]] gives the same indication when equipped. Additionally, alert level can be checked by using the [[GameText]]check_alert[[/GameText]] hack when using a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] on an [[Operator]], or by using the [[GameText]]Alert(Check)[[/GameText]] hack at a [[Terminal]].
There are 2 aspects of the Alert level. The first is the "influence" number, which is the numeric representation of alert. This can only be seen when using RIF or the Alert Chip. The other, the alert level, is an approximation of the influence. Low security is the lowest level of alert when the influence number is less than 200 and does not have any additional information. However, alert levels 1 through 4 are all divided into 26 alphabetical subsections. For example, alert level 1 begins at 200 and ends at 399 influence. Checking the alert level while at 200 influence will report "1-A", and checking at 399 will report "1-Z". This can be used to approximate the influence number, although the exact number does not really matter.

[[Heading]]Alert levels[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Alert level|Minimum Value|Maximum Value||
Low Security|0|199||
1|200|399||
2|400|699||
3|700|1199||
4|1200|1599||
5|1600|No Max
[[/Table]]
Alert level controls only a few aspects of the game: [[Assault Squad|Assaults]], [[Patrol Squad|Searches]], and [[High Security]]. Alert level does not increase the number of patrols or guards on the map in any way. Alert below level 2 does not have any impact on the game. At alert level 2/400 influence, Assaults and [[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]] can start being dispatched. From this point onward, alert is a sliding scale. Increased alert will also increase the overall frequency of Assaults and the number of [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]] that will be dispatched as part of an Assault. Alert level 2 typically only sends a single Heavy ARC per Assault wave, but higher alert levels can see two or more being sent frequently.
[[High Security]] is the other affect of alert. It is a special alert level that can only be triggered when at level 5 alert when combat hostiles are destroyed. The higher the influence value, the higher the chance of triggering High Security. [[Maximum Security]] has similar effects as High Security, but is not related to alert except that it sets influence to 1600 if it is lower than that.

[[Heading]]Ways to raise alert[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Method|Alert Influence increase||
Destroying a wall/door in -10 through -6|1||
Destroying a wall/door in -5 through -3|2||
Destroying a wall/door in -2 through -1|3||
Destroying most green bots/[[Operator|Operators]]|5||
Destroying a [[Hauler]]/[[Watcher]]|7||
Destroying a Reinforced Barrier|10||
Being forgotten by a combat hostile|10||
Setting a trap that is triggered by an 0b10 bot|10||
Successful hack at a level 1 terminal|Up to 12 [[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Being spotted and forgotten by a combat hostile|15||
Being partial spotted by any "Guarding" combat hostile or Watcher.
Most common guards are [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], [[Heavy|Heavies]], and [[Sentry|Sentries]].|15||
Destroying Sealed Heavy Doors|15||
Destroying most machines|15||
Successful hack at a level 2 terminal|Up to 18 [[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Destroying most combat hostiles|20||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Download)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a [[Fabricator]]|20||
Successful hack at a level 3 terminal|Up to 24 [[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Destroying a squad leader, guard, or intercept|30||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Extract)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a [[Scanalyzer]]|30||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Tunnel)[[/Spoiler]] on a [[Recycling Unit]]|30||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Eject)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a [[Garrison Access]]|30||
Getting traced on any Terminal inside a Garrison (no Alert from Terminals outside of Garrisons)|40||
Destroying a Garrison Relay|50||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Sabotage)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a Terminal and failing|50||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Overload)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a Fabricator|50||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Override)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a Garrison Terminal|50||
[[Active Sensor Suite]] scanning detected (only after certain number of bots depending on bot type)|100||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Sabotage)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a Terminal and succeeding|100||
[[Garrison]] interior compromised alert|100||
Destroying a Garrison Machine|150||
Getting spotted by a [[N-01 Spotter]]|150 Alert when entering next map, stacks up to 3 times per Spotter||
Using a [[Spoiler]]Force(Jam)[[/Spoiler]] hack on a Garrison Machine|200||
Entering Maximum Security|If influence < 1600, set immediately to 1600
[[/Table]]
[[List:Ordered]]Successful hacking increases alert more if the hack is less likely to succeed. Alert does not increase at all from hacks with a success rate of >= 30%.[[/List]]
There are also modifiers that can affect how much alert is gained by a certain percentage. The 0b10 Alert Chip reduces all influence gains by 20%, and the RIF ability Threat Obfuscation reduces all gains by 25%, 40%, or 50% depending on level. All alert reduction is rounded down, and reduction will not take place unless the value is at least 1. For example, gaining 3 influence from destroying a wall on -2 with the Alert Chip equipped results in 0.6 reduction which rounds down to 0. With this 20% reduction, only influence gains of 5 or more will have any reduction applied. On the other hand, having blue or purple allies within a 20-tile radius will increase alert gain from destroying bots. The gain is roughly 12.5% per ally, capping out at an additional 100% alert gain at 8 nearby allies. This effect can be cancelled out by the RIF ability Alert ID Control. In general, be cautious of taking large groups of allies into combat or else alert can quite easily skyrocket.

[[Heading]]Ways to lower alert[[/Heading]]
Lowering alert tends to be quite a bit more difficult than gaining it in the first place for most builds. The best way to dissipate large amounts of alert is to exit the map, as a large percentage of current alert is taken away immediately. Going into [[Caves]] in [[Factory]] branches is even better. By the end of several Caves maps, alert will most likely have dropped down to 0. This alert reduction effect lessens the higher up Cogmind is in the complex, and the amount varies depending on whether Cogmind is exiting into a branch map or a new main depth. Some maps always have fixed alert reduction percentages regardless of floor.
[[Heading:2]]Exit alert influence reduction[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Branch|Next main floor|Garrison exit to depth||
-10|61%|57.8%|N/A||
-9|61%|57.8%|N/A||
-8|57.8%|54.5%|51.25%||
-7|54.5%|51%|47.5%||
-6|51%|51%|47.5%||
-5|51%|51%|47.5%||
-4|51%|47.5%|47.5%||
-3|47.5%|43.75%|43.75%||
-2|43.75%|40%|43.75%||
-1|36%|N/A|40%
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Special exit alert influence reduction[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Exit|Reduction||
Unique Caves Branch exit (e.g. [[Zion]])|100%||
Exit from [[Scraptown]]|100%||
Exit from [[Lab]]|100%||
Exit to [[Quarantine]], [[Testing]], [[Section 7]], or [[Protoforge]]|51.25%||
Exit to [[DSF]]|30%||
Exit to Garrison|30%||
Main floor to Caves exit|37%||
Caves to Caves exit|19%
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Passive alert reduction[[/Heading]]
The most substantial alert reduction method aside from exiting the map is a passive alert reduction over time. Every 20 turns, influence will decrease by a slowly diminishing value.
[[Table]]
Turn range|Alert Influence reduction per 20 turns|Total cumulative reduction over range||
20-380|10|190||
400-780|8|350||
800-1180|6|470||
1200-1580|4|550||
1600-1980|3|610||
2000-2780|2|690||
2800-4380|1|770
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Other alert influence reduction[[/Heading]]
There are a few other miscellaneous ways of decreasing alert:
[[Table]]
Method|Alert influence reduction||
Cogmind part destroyed by combat hostile|10||
Non-combat ally destroyed by combat hostile|10||
Combat ally destroyed by combat hostile|20||
Alert(Purge) [[Terminal]] hack|150||
purge_threat [[Operator]] RIF hack|150 [[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
[[Search Patrol]] dispatched|150
[[/Table]]
[[List:Ordered]]Each purge_threat hack reduces the amount of influence reduced by 25 until the minimum value of 50 is reached. So purging will reduce by 150, 125, 100, 75, and remain at 50. This number resets back to 150 with each new map.[[/List]]

Name: Alignment
Content:
Alignments are a major part of Cogmind's journey each run. They can provide unique capabilities or trigger certain events, but often lock other pieces of content out as inaccessible. Some factions change large aspects of Cogmind's normal interaction with the game world, while others only trigger a specific event in the game. Some can provide unique [[Wintypes]]. Selecting factions wisely is an important part of a run.

[[Heading]]List of alignments[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Core Reset Matrix]] (CRM), [[Sigix]] alignment: The CRM is a lategame consumable [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] that provides a variety of unique abilities, with the most substantial benefit being the instant detection of all other Alien Artifacts upon consumption or entering a new map. The major downside is a memory wipe that removes most of Cogmind's knowledge. Consuming it also angers a few other factions and locks out certain events.|[[FarCom]], [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]] alignment: An early game alignment that provides a permanent 18-tile radius combat bot sensor in all [[0b10]]-controlled floors as well as 1 type of unique Exile prototype. Its major downsides are locking out Imprint and a harsh penalty when entering [[Research]] branches; [[Testing]] and [[Quarantine]] become quite difficult, and [[Section 7]] and [[Protoforge]] are locked out entirely.|[[Imprint]], [[Zion]] alignment: A midgame alignment that dramatically changes [[Terminal]] hacking. All standard Terminal hacks are removed and replaced with special random Zion ally summons and intel. Imprint is a powerful but tricky alignment to use due to the loss of standard Terminal hacking. Imprinting also locks Cogmind out of gaining the aid of several other Derelict factions.|[[Redacted]][[MAIN.C]] surrender - 0b10 alignment: This lategame alignment only becomes available in [[Command]] after defeating the [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C Shell]] and enables a particular win, w8 by fighting off waves of [[Enhanced Q-Series]]. Surrendering to MAIN.C locks Cogmind out of several ending types, as well as the ability to enter [[Access_0]].[[/Redacted]]|[[Relay Interface Framework]] (RIF), 0b10 alignment: An alignment available as early as [[Materials]], RIF allows for much greater control of 0b10 complex bots through the use of special hacks via [[Relay Couplers]]. RIF also provides many unique abilities that make traversing the complex safer or easier. The major downside of RIF is that several [[Derelict]] factions will be unable to identify Cogmind as friendly and will instead turn hostile.|[[Revision 17 (Alignment)|Revision 17 Alignment]]: [[Revision 17]] is a quite unique Derelict that can be rescued in [[Cetus]]. Revision 17's role is not a large one, but its -3 Research invasion can stir up some trouble and hopefully provide some aid in Research.|[[Redacted]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]], Sigix alignment: The Sigix Exoskeleton is an immensely powerful and gamechanging build type available late in the game in Section 7. It provides Cogmind with lots of firepower, a massive amount of map intel, and fast and high integrity and coverage exoskeleton part. The downsides to the Exoskeleton are reduced slot count (down to 1-3-3-2 initially), a decently low maximum support, and the full weight of 0b10's [[Maximum Security]] sent after Cogmind whenever spotted. This item is very powerful, but drastically changes gameplay for the rest of the run compared to most other alignments.[[/Redacted]]|[[UFD|United Federation of Derelicts]] alignment: The UFD is a Derelict group whose home is in the 0b1 Old Recycling map [[Scraptown]]. Their major benefits include some unique parts available on the map and their ability to summon [[Scrapoid|Scrapoids]] and [[Scraphulk|Scraphulks]] from [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]]. They also have a unique lategame event and wintype where [[Redacted]]they begin an assault on the lategame map [[Protoforge]].[[/Redacted]]|[[Warlord (Alignment)|Warlord Alignment]]: [[Warlord]] is a unique and much beloved Derelict that wages war on 0b10 whose help can be obtained in the midgame. His -2 Research assault is similar to Revision 17's but on a much grander scale. Lots of loot can be found wherever Warlord goes. He can also make an appearance in the [[Redacted]][[Command]] cave seals[[/Redacted]], which can even lead to a unique wintype. The [[Encrypted Comm Array]] also falls under this alignment and turns destruction of 0b10 [[Garrison|Garrisons]] and [[DSF|DSFs]] into more powerful Warlord forces.|[[Zhirov (Alignment)|Zhirov Alignment]]: [[Zhirov]] is another unique Derelict who can provide a big help in the lategame. Grabbing the [[SGEMP Prototype]] in Testing provides a few temporary allies (including Zhirov himself) and full map intel of [[Access]], a notoriously difficult map. His quest can continue on in [[Redacted]]Command, where his Modified SGEMP can disable the whole map's worth of 0b10 bots when the MAIN.C Shell is defeated.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Alignment Compatibility[[/Heading]]
Below is a list of all faction alignments available in the game and their compatibility. The row is for the first alignment, and the column is for the second. Each cell indicates whether the two alignments are compatible in a particular order.

[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Orders[[/Heading]]
Robots will by default follow [[Cogmind]] (you) and attack any hostile if combat capable. Orders can be issued to any robot [[B]]in sight[[/B]] listed in the allies menu [[B]](F6)[[/B]]. [[I]](Orders can also be issued directly on the map: Shift-right click on a robot, or press 'o' then its corresponding number, or in keyboard look mode, by moving the cursor over the bot and pressing 'o'.) [[/I]]
[[List]][[GameText]]STAY[[/GameText]] - Remain at the current position, only moving aside to let allies pass. Combat-capable bots will still chase after hostiles and return to their position later. If you move into a bot with the stay command active you will swap positions with that bot, which can facilitate precise positioning of bots. Note that a swap may not occur if other friendly bots are also trying to swap with them.|
[[GameText]]ROAM[[/GameText]] - Wander and do whatever.|
[[GameText]]FOLLOW[[/GameText]] - Follow [[Cogmind]].|
[[GameText]]GUARD[[/GameText]] - Follow the specified bot and prioritize attacking anything harming the specified bot. Telling bots to guard cogmind can be used to bring them in closer than follow. Multitile bots will try to keep several tiles away from cogmind.|
[[GameText]]AID[[/GameText]] - Follow the specified bot and prioritize attacking anything the specified bot is attacking. For Mechanics, tells that bot to repair that bot and allies nearby. Mechanic pathing will behave erratically if there is no valid path to their aid target. Telling bots to aid cogmind can be used to bring them in closer than follow.|
[[GameText]]TUNNEL[[/GameText]] - Tunnel to the specified location, if capable of digging (bots such as [[T-07 Excavator]]).|
[[GameText]]DROP[[/GameText]] - Drop everything in the bots inventory, then wander in a small area.|
[[GameText]]PICKUP[[/GameText]] - Collect everything near [[Cogmind]], and then [[GameText]]Follow[[/GameText]] once inventory is full. If an item is directly under the bot, it gets picked up first.|
[[GameText]]COLLECT[[/GameText]] - Wander and collect items until inventory is full, then set to [[GameText]]Follow[[/GameText]]. If an item is directly under the bot, it gets picked up first.|
[[GameText]]EXPLORE[[/GameText]] - Explore unexplored areas, giving info to [[Cogmind]].|
[[GameText]]RETURN[[/GameText]] - Return this [[Drone]] to its bay. Drones only, obviously.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Benefits[[/Heading]]
[[Operator]] class robots will give you a diminishing hacking bonus starting at +10% (10%, 5%, 2%, 1%..), and will reveal any hidden door or trap, provided the operator is within 20 tiles range of you. Operators will also report changes in security level.
[[Mechanic]] class robots when set to [[GameText]]AID[[/GameText]] will repair core integrity [[B]](but NOT for Cogmind)[[/B]], broken parts, non-functional parts, and part integrity of their repair target (Cogmind is prioritized over allies) in that order. Mechanics cannot repair a part above 50% integrity.
[[Protector]] class robots shield nearby allies including Cogmind and potentially help with intercepting remote datajacks and launcher projectiles.
[[Programmer]] class robots can cleanse corruption from allies and hack hostile bots.
[[Recycler]] and [[Hauler]] class robots can pick up and store items for cogmind. Note that there is no warning message for crushing parts when dropping items.
[[T-07 Excavator]] bots can dig for cogmind using the Tunnel command. Unlike the related [[RIF]] hack, this does not guarantee the tile will be stable.

Name: Ambush Trap
Content:
Ambush Traps are [[Traps]] that can appear in various [[0b10]] maps. Like [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] and [[Chute Trap|Chute Traps]], they cannot be extracted using a [[Trap Extractors|Trap Extractor]]. Some of the maps that Ambush Traps cannot appear in are [[Materials]] maps and [[Garrison|Garrisons]].
[[Comment]]
This table is within a comment, which prevents it from appearing.
Ideally, once the table is eventually filled out, the comment tags (and this explanation) will be removed.
-Mines can contain 0b10 traps, either because of the trapped "shop" or because of a Derelict placing traps, and can also contain stashes of uninstalled traps (not sure if those should be counted? For other 0b10 Trap pages, i mean.)
-(Proximity Caves are a special case, as exactly one prefab can have 0b10 traps in it. There is no reason to mention other non-0b10 maps)
If the answer is the same for all research branches, perhaps they could be grouped together as "research branches" to avoid naming them? Speaking of, i know Ambush Traps used to exist in at least some research branches, but there was a fix to prevent friendly derelicts from emerging from them there, as accidental allies can cause too much chaos due to researchers, and i don't know if that fix just prevented friendly derelicts from appearing there, or removed ambush traps in those branches altogether.

List of all maps that can contain 0b10 traps and whether they can contain Ambush Traps:
[[Table]]
Location|Ambush Traps?
||[[Materials]]|No
||[[Mines]]|No 
||[[Storage]]|Yes
||[[Garrison]]|No
||[[Factory]]|Yes
||[[DSF]]|???
||[[Proximity Caves]]|No
||[[Extension]]|???
||[[Hub_04(d)]]|???
||[[Armory]]|???
||[[Research]]|Yes
||[[Testing]]|???
||[[Quarantine]]|???
||[[Section 7]]|???
||[[Protoforge]]|???
||[[Access]]|Yes
||[[Command]]|I don't think so?
[[/Table]]

[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Effects[[/Heading]]
When an Ambush Trap is triggered, it and all other Ambush Traps in the array will be spent, and up three 0b10 combat bots will emerge from some of the Traps. Each Ambush Trap can only reveal a single 0b10 combat bot, either a [[Swarmer]], a [[Grunt]], a [[Duelist]] or a [[Brawler]], so if there are only one or two Ambush Traps left in the array, fewer than three bots will appear. The Ambush Trap that was triggered will always spawn a bot. If there is currently a bot on an Ambush Trap that spawns a combat bot, that combat bot will appear on the side of the Trap instead. Unless the Traps were triggered manually, the bots will take their turn immediately, which can be particularly dangerous if some of them are Brawlers and appear next to Cogmind. However, if any of the bots that appear are Duelists or Brawlers, then, out of all the Ambush Traps that do reveal bots, they will always be appear from the farthest ones from Cogmind. For example, in a horizontal row of 6 contiguous Ambush Traps, if Cogmind triggers the one farthest west, then it and two of the other Traps, chosen at random, will all reveal bots. If one of those bots is a Brawler, then out of the three Traps, it will emerge from the one farthest from Cogmind.

On some rare occasions, Ambush Traps will have been infiltrated by friendly [[Thug|Thugs]]. This cannot happen in [[Research]] branches. Up to three Thugs can appear, the only possible limitation being the number of functional Ambush Traps in the array when a Trap is triggered. [[Spoiler]]The [[Encrypted Comm Array]] is capable of detecting nearby Derelict-infiltrated Ambush Traps, even from inventory.[[/Spoiler]]
On rarer occasions, Ambush Traps may have been infested by [[Assembled]], in which case the Ambush Trap that was triggered will remain and three Assembled will emerge from it immediately, while the other Ambush Traps in the array will be spent and up to three broken 0b10 combat bots will emerge from them. A [[Demolisher Squad]] will be dispatched, and Assembled will keep emerging from the Ambush Trap that was triggered until it is destroyed by an explosion. [[Comment]]Can it be destroyed by something else? Are there multiple types of Assembled Ambush Trap infestations? I *think* i remember a type where far more than three had emerged at the same time, but it's been a while. Lastly, will more Demolisher squads be dispatched if the trap isn't destroyed early enough? I think so, but i'm not sure.[[/Comment]]

Like Alarm Traps, successfully hacking Ambush Traps using a [[Melee Datajacks|Melee Datajack]] will always disable them, never reprogram them. It still possible to reprogram Alarm Traps through [[Terminal]] hacking, though this is not recommended as this will cause any hostiles that move onto the traps to trigger them, which will still cause the robots below to emerge and roam the map.

This article was last updated during Beta 15.

Name: Architect Data Core
Content: Provides access to the Architect Logs terminal in [[Access_0]] without having to destroy the 120 armor Architect shell that normally encases it. Dropped by [[Architect]] on death.

Name: Archives
Content:
Archives is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Factory]] [[Branch]] that appears between -6 and -4. It is part of the [[Extension]] branch line and can only be entered through [[Cetus]]. It is a lightly guarded static map that has the same layout every time. There are 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] and a large number of [[O-32 Director|Operators]]. Except for 1 special map variation, all 4 of the Archive Hub machines are useless and contain no data. No normal squads can spawn on this map.
This is a safe map to to wait around to dissipate [[Alert]] and purge corruption with the [[Imp. System Restoration Module|System Restoration Modules]] dropped by the Operators. It is also a great place to build up [[Hackware]] dropped by the Operators.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Archives[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Variations[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Archives Explosions.webp|Explosives set off by Zhirov[[/Image]]There are 2 variations of the Archives map:
[[List]]Standard: In the normal map, the Archive Hub machines only contain corrupted data. There are 4 Sentries and many active Operators.|[[Zhirov]] infiltrated map: Rarely, Zhirov will infiltrate Archives. In seeds where this occurs, he will not be found in his normal [[Zhirov (Location)|location]] This variant is recognizable by the lack of Sentry guards and the Operators all being broken. In these variants, the Archive Hub machine closest to Zhirov can be decoded for some Lore records. Soon after speaking with Zhirov, the intrusion will be detected and a large amount of 0b10 bots will be sent to investigate. Don't join in the fight and instead grab the Terminal lore (if not gotten yet) and make a beeline for the exits. After a second wave of bots are sent, Zhirov and friends will teleport out and rig some explosives to go off soon. You don't want to get caught in the blast.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 3 exits on this map but only 2 kinds of exits:
[[List]]Main access exits: The exit on the top of the map will lead to the next main Factory or Research floor.|[[Hub_04(d)]]: The exits on the bottom and right of the map lead to Hub.[[/List]]

Name: Arm. Scrap Engine
Content: Created from a [[Scrap Engine]] when a [[Armor|Protection]]-type part is fed. See the Scrap Engine page for more details. When destroyed, reverse back into a normal Scrap Engine.

Name: Armageddon Trap
Content: Often found uninstalled in garrison caches and rarely elsewhere, these traps have twice the radius of conventional launchers and very low falloff.

Name: Armor
Content:
Armor protects other parts, and the core, by having high coverage and integrity. The coverage makes attacks less likely to hit other parts or the core; the integrity allows the armor to tank many hits before being destroyed.

Some armor provides additional functionality, like granting resistance to a certain damage type [[Spoiler]]or regenerating integrity over time while powered[[/Spoiler]].

Any part with high coverage and integrity can act like armor. Parts often used for this include [[Treads]] and [[Ballistic Cannons]]. The difference is that dedicated "armor" parts have little other purpose than their protective role, whereas losing a tread or a cannon can disable critical aspects of a build.

Name: Armory
Content:
Armory is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Factory]]/[[Research]] [[Branch]] that appears between -4 and -3. It is a tough map with tight corridors, few available paths, an above average number of patrols, and special dormant and guard bots. There are several unique types of patrols on this map as well, with a [[Demolisher]] leading a squad of [[Grunt|Grunts]] and [[Duelist]] squads with a [[Protector]] in tow. Stealth builds will have a difficult time of sneaking past unnoticed and combat hostiles must be ready to do a lot of killing to get by. If Cogmind can survive, some of the rewards are rewirable allies, a high number of [[Fabricator|Fabricators]], and large stockpiles of out-of-depth parts.
The overall map structure varies, but there are some common features of Armory maps. There are usually corridors running horizontally on the bottom and top of the map that contain large rooms next to each other connected by Emergency Access doors. The map can be a little maze-like although heading to the left and crossing from bottom to top or top to bottom will usually lead to an exit.
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There is one type of special machine in Armory. The Energy Cycler is a large explosive machine that will open all Sealed Heavy Doors on the map and summon several patrols. These Sealed Heavy Doors have hackable Terminals and contain high rating part stockpiles, sometimes full of entirely non-faulty [[Prototype Part|Prototype Parts]].

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Armory Guard Corridor.png|Small corridor of guards|Armory Dormant Bots.png|Dormant hostile bots|Armory Rewirable Bots.png|Rewirable bots|Armory Grunts.png|Large number of Grunts that will power up friendly|Armory Energy Cycler.png|Energy Cycler machine behind 2 tile door|Armory Shell Stockpile.png|Parts cache inside Reinforced Shell|Armory Prototype Stockpile.png|Prototype part cache on ground|Armory Sealed Vault Stockpile.png|Sealed vault part cache|Armory Authchips.png|A sealed cache of various [[Authchips]]|Armory Obliterator.png|[[Disassembled Obliterator]] and [[PL-3XN's Ring of Power]], guarded by [[Armor Guard|Armor Guards]]|Armory Central Exit.png|Central main access exit guarded by Sentries|Armory Left Exit.png|Left main access exit|Armory Lab Exit.png|Hidden [[Lab]] exit[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Disassembled Obliterator[[/Heading]]
There is a special portion of Armory near the left side of the map. This area is heavily guarded by 2 pairs of 2 Armor Guards, with many [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] getting in the way of entry. It is sealed off by 50 armor Sealed Blast doors that can be opened with a 30% success rate Terminal. The inner area has an unavoidable special alarm that triggers when entered. The log message [[GameText]]Weapon containment breached. Dispatching heavy reinforcements to the area.[[/GameText]] will appear and 2 assault [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]] will be dispatched to the location. Additionally, many standard [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] are here. 2/4 of the inner Reinforced Shells will be filled. One will always have a PL-3XN's Ring and another will always have a Disassembled Obliterator.
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 3 types of exits in Armory:
[[List]]Center main access: This exit is guarded by 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] and appears in the center of the map. There are 2 tile wide corridors that extend in opposite directions coming from the exit.|Left main access: This exit is unguarded and is found behind a set of double doors on the left side of the map.|[[Lab]] exit: This exit is hidden behind a wall on the far-left side of the map. It will always be adjacent to a 1 tile wide hallway. [[Redacted]]There is a [[Dimensional Node Initializer]] installed at the exit to Lab. Using a [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]] or [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor]] will always cause Cogmind to end up next to this exit.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[VL-GR5]]: VL-GR5 can appear the entrance of Armory, challenging Cogmind to a competition. If Cogmind can get 15 kills before VL-GR5, they will hand over [[VL-GR5's Timing Chip]]. Watch out for misses and explosions, as hurting them too many times will cause them to attach a [[Multinova Projection Cannon]] and turn on Cogmind. VL-GR5 may drop the Multinova cannon for Cogmind if they hang around long enough. VL-GR5 will make a comment about leaving the map, then drop the cannon at the exit.

Name: Army-in-a-Box
Content: 6 slot utility piece that can assist in difficult situations. Be aware of causing some disturbance in the sector raising the alert level. For this reason this utility is most often best utilized in the caves.

Name: Assault Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Assault Drone|Assault Drones]].

Name: Assault Squad
Content:
Assault squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are most frequently dispatched as a result of Cogmind having too high [[Alert]] on most 0b10-controlled maps. Assaults are sent to Cogmind's initially reported position but will roam around an expanding search area after that. They consist of a single [[C-45 Heavy ARC]] typically containing 5 bots inside. If Cogmind has 3 or more allies, up to 2 additional bots may be sent to escort the ARC as additional firepower. Assault squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert indicates whenever an Assault squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Significant disruption in zone 9B, assault force dispatched[[/GameText]]. If more than one ARC was sent, the message will instead indicate [[GameText]]multiple assault carriers dispatched[[/GameText]].

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Assault Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Frequency and Number[[/Heading]]
Assaults may be dispatched regularly as long as Cogmind is at least Alert level 2 or 400 influence on -9 or above, although at lower Alert levels Assaults are rare. At Alert levels well above 1000, Assaults may be sent out at nearly opportunity. A higher Alert level also increases the chances of multiple ARCs being dispatched. In [[Materials]], Assaults can be dispatched every 400 turns on -9 and -8. In [[Factory]] and above, this changes to be every 250 turns. Most assault waves consists of 1-2 ARCs, but at Alert levels in excess of 5X/1600 influence, 3 or even more ARCs can be sent.
[[Heading:2]]During [[High Security|High]] or [[Maximum Security]][[/Heading]]
The frequency, number, and contents of ARCs changes. Assault forces with stronger compositions than usual may be dispatched in these conditions, although these ARCs only have 4 bots inside rather than the typical 5. 4 ARCs will be dispatched 100 turns into High Security and after another 100 turns. After that, 2 more ARCs will be added to each wave, but 50 more turns will be added in between the dispatch of each wave. The sizes of the Assault waves will also start to increase each wave, and the duration between each wave will increase. Maximum Security is similar, but with 6 ARCs to start the first 2 waves. The 2nd wave of Assaults in High Security and all subsequent waves, and all waves of Maximum Security may contain stronger than usual bots in them.

[[Heading]]Assault Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Assault Contents.png|Example contents of an Assault squad ARC[[/Image]]
Assault contents can vary by depth, but their makeups are always similar. Assaults will always contain 4 combat bots and 1 support-type bot. The combat bots may become stronger under heavy assault conditions, but the possible support bots are always the same.

[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Data Miner]] redirection[[/Heading]]
The Data Miner can redirect Assaults if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Assaults will roam around a random area of the map rather than head directly to Cogmind's location. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each ARC as part of an Assault about 15 turns after each Assault is dispatched, if Cogmind is determined as "needing assistance". Redirection can only occur when High/Maximum Security is not active. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting assault.[[/GameText]] will be displayed. If an Assault is not redirected, there is a further 50% chance that the contents may be redirected after the ARC opens up. This can happen within 30 turns of the ARC opening. This effect will only redirect the squad leader, and the squad leader will only leave if currently unable to see Cogmind. All the remaining squad bots will continue to follow Cogmind. The true practical effect here is that if the squad forgets where Cogmind is, they will patrol around the redirected location rather than the location that the ARC opened.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Assembled
Content: The Assembled are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of small swarming [[Hover Units|hovering]] robots that can be found in various infestation-related events. Due to the fact that they always appear in groups, have low core, and have high core exposure, using explosive [[Launchers]] is the best way to deal with them. [[Spoiler]]If a [[Core Reset Matrix]] was used, the Assembled will no longer be hostile and will instead be purple uncontrollable allies.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Assembler
Content: Produces [[Assembled]] every 10 turns. Otherwise harmless.

Name: Authchips
Content: Authchips are single-use items that allow printing the relevant type of item at a [[Fabricator]]. They can be acquired at a [[DSF]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], corrupted in [[Storage]] or by using [[Spoiler]][[GameText]]Force(Recompile)[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]] on a Fabricator.
