Name: Behemoth
Content:
Behemoths are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of heavily [[Armor|armored]] [[Treads|treading]] [[0b10]] bots that are much more durable and powerful than the majority of standard bots. They typically guard machines or valuable part stockpiles while sitting slightly indented in the wall. Similar to [[Hunter|Hunters]], Behemoths will fire through walls in order to hit an enemy, which makes it hard to hide or run from them. Behemoths can even make use of [[Special Propulsion Modes#Siege mode|Siege Mode]] to become more accurate and durable in combat. This combination of traits can make Behemoths terrifying encounters if not adequately prepared.
Behemoths have innate EM resistance as well as corruption resistance through [[Dynamic Insulation System|Dynamic Insulation Systems]], so EM weaponry is a subpar weapon choice to get a quick kill. Melee weapons are undesirable to use because most Behemoths pack [[Ballistic Cannons]] that will frequently cause knockback. Behemoths have a minor thermal weakness, though that is slightly mitigated by thermal [[Resistance Armor]]. Meltdown criticals from thermal cannons can instantly destroy a Behemoth from full core integrity (100+), which can save a lot of damage and provide some good undamaged loot. Thermal guns are not effective in smaller numbers, but given enough heat transferring weapons (4+) it is possible to overload their standard cooling and [[Coolant Injectors]] to get the melt instant kill.
Behemoths can be a desirable looting target for their weapons, cooling, treads, and armor. For this reason, applying some positive salvage via Electromagnetic weaponry or [[Salvage Targeting Computers]] can be a good idea. However, it can often be a better idea to run the other way. Even slow treads builds can get away from a pursuing Behemoth with good tactics. Despite their ability to tear through walls in their way, they have a tendency to get stuck unable to path through 1 tile wide corridors. If such corridors are nearby, use them to your advantage. Otherwise, try to cut between connected rooms to avoid traveling through so much of the line of fire. Behemoths will only shoot through up to 3 walls to cut a path, so if Cogmind can turn a corner or get a good angle on the Behemoth where it is unable to shoot, it is possible to wait out the memory.
Behemoths are often found in their own spot inside a wall as a [[Security Squad]]. In [[Caves]], they can be found in a small square open area.
[[Gallery]]Behemoths.png|All Behemoth variants and colors|Behemoth Guarded Stockpile.png|A Behemoth guarding a stockpile of parts, sitting in a recognizable "Behemoth nook"[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Line of Sight Reference[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Behemoth Facing Right.png|A Behemoth facing right|
Behemoth Facing Down.png|A Behemoth facing down|
Behemoth Facing Left.png|A Behemoth facing left|
Behemoth Facing Up.png|A Behemoth facing up
[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]][[CR-A16's Pointy Stick]]/[[CR-A16's Behemoth Slayer]][[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]]A Pointy Stick has a chance to transform into a Behemoth Slayer when used to attack a Behemoth. A Behemoth Slayer will instantly destroy any Behemoth and leave it in pieces.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Bolteater
Content: Bolteaters are fast [[Wheels|wheeled]] [[UFD]] combat bots armed with [[Ripteeth]]. Valuable for a wheels build with their [[Rocket Booster|Rocket Boosters]]. Their ripteeth can rip off a component ignoring armor, so keep them away from you. Slightly resistant to Kinetic, Thermal, Electromagnetic and Explosive damage.

Name: Bomb Drone
Content: Fast disposable drones that attempt to melee hostiles, which will cause them to explode. Deployed by a [[Bomb Drone Bay]]

Name: Bomb Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Bomb Drone|Bomb Drones]].

Name: Bot Groups
Content:
Bots of the same class have different parts from type to type, but behave similarly when considered as a single class. This page categorizes common bots by class as well as grouping a few other unique bots by faction.
[[BotGroups]]

Name: Branch
Content:
Branches are side locations from the main [[0b10]] complex, often with its own unique rewards and sights to behold. All of them lead back to main locations.
Read more at: [[Locations]].

Name: Brawler
Content:
Brawlers are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Armor|armored]] [[Treads|treading]] [[0b10]] combat bots that wield an [[Impact Weapons|Impact weapon]] to smash parts of their enemies. They can only attack at short range, but they are frightening for most builds to face head-on due to their Impact weapons being capable of smashing off important utilities while ignoring coverage. Their slow speed means that they have major difficulty in closing the gap on long ranged units without getting killed first.
Brawlers don't have any particular damage type weakness and any ranged weapon types are useful against them. Unlike their cousins [[Duelist|Duelists]], Brawlers don't suffer from a weakness to knockback because the Treads negate any knockback. Since they can easily destroy highly important but low integrity utilities, fighting Brawlers in melee range should be avoided at all cost.
[[Gallery]]Brawlers.png|All Brawler variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Squads[[/Heading]]
Brawlers may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Assault Squad]]|[[Garrison Squad]]|[[Patrol Squad]] - [[Squad Leader]] only|[[Security Squad]] - [[Armory]] only[[/List]]

Name: Butcher
Content: Butchers are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Legs|legged]] [[Derelict]] combat bots, armed with Derelict [[Slashing Weapons]] capable of severing parts. They are the Derelict version of the [[0b10]] [[Duelist]] bot but are generally less effective than their counterparts. Butchers are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: C-40 Crusher
Content:
Crushers are heavy-duty [[Treads|treading]] trash (you) compacting machines plated in [[Damper Plating]], rendering them nearly immune to electromagnetic damage. Crushers will attempt to compact anything that is not a Crusher, and their Compactor is a VERY formidable melee weapon (does not drop) that will either [[B]]destroy or drop a few of your parts[[/B]]. Weak to explosions and strong against melee (which would be a bad idea regardless).

Due to their extreme lethality in melee, stay out of their range at all costs, and maybe just run the hell out of [[Wastes]]. Alternatively pack a good launcher or a good critical weapon, as their plating will tank most of your shots.

Name: CL-0N3
Content:
CL-0N3 is a part of the deadly group of [[Unchained]] [[Derelict|Derelicts]] that work for [[0b10]] to track down threats to the complex. It is a shapeshifter robot, capable of disguising itself as other innocuous-looking bots before bursting out to attack. CL-0N3 is harmless in its true form, only carrying the unique [[CL-0N3's Metamass Displacer]] with no offensive capabilities. Uniquely, CL-0N3 has an extremely high core exposure at 75%, but high damage resistances of 75% or higher for all standard damage types.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]Cyclists Records|UC/CL-0N3[[/Lore]]

[[Heading:2]][[FarCom]] Lore[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has aligned with the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]] and has FarCom, the following message will be broadcast about CL-0N3:
[[GameText]]They could be anywhere, or anyone. Be very ware of anything that moves. Destroying their true combat form damages their core, but you can cause the most damage once they're fully revealed, though they'll definitely run in that case, and fast.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
CL-0N3 has two ways it can appear after being dispatched on a map. The first method is possession of an existing bot, for example, a [[K-01 Serf]]. That Serf will behave unusually, heading toward Cogmind when there is otherwise no reason for it to do so. Once it comes close enough, CL-0N3 will turn into a random combat bot several tiers above the standard depth and there will be an accompanying log message [[GameText]][Bot name] form shifts and reconstitutes itself, revealing [New bot name].[[/GameText]] If the possessed bot is instead destroyed, a slightly different message [[GameText]][New bot name] reconstitutes self from the rubble and scrap.[[/GameText]] will appear instead. Note: While transformed, CL-0N3 cannot be accessed with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]].
The second method of CL-0N3 appearing is by forming a new copy of an existing ally on the map. This method is only used when there are non-controllable allies around (i.e. not blue-colored). CL-0N3 will appear as a copy of an ally, follow Cogmind around for a few turns, then surprise attack shortly after.
CL-0N3 will mimic the AI of its combat bot. For example, as a [[Demolisher]] they will avoid friendly fire.
When the combat bot that CL-0N3 has transformed into is destroyed, a new log message will appear: [[GameText]]CL-0N3 reconstitutes true from from the rubble and scrap.[[/GameText]] When this occurs, the real CL-0N3 will appear, losing core integrity equal to 10% of previous form's core integrity. After this, it will run away to a nearby [[Garrison Access]] or exit. A [[CL-0N3 Data Core]] is dropped when CL-0N3 is fully destroyed.

[[Heading:2]]List of Transformations[[/Heading]]
Note: bolded entries are CL-0N3-exclusive bots.
[[List]]
[[B]][[Access Guard]][[/B]]|
[[Armor Guard]]|
[[Alpha 7]]|
[[Bouncer]]|
[[Cetus Guard]]|
[[Combat Programmer]]|
[[Demolisher]]|
[[Executioner]]|
[[Heavy]]|
[[Grunt]]|
[[Guerrilla]]|
[[Hotshot]]|
[[Hunter]]|
[[Immortal]]|
[[Infiltrator]]|
[[Lightning]]|
[[Martyr]]|
[[Mutant]]|
[[Programmer]]|
[[Quarantine Guard]]|
[[Sentry]]|
[[Specialist]]|
[[Striker]]|
[[B]][[Thunder]][[/B]]|
[[B]][[V2]][[/B]]|
[[Wizard]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
CL-0N3 is the most unpredictable Unchained and is difficult to fully prepare for thanks to its many potential forms. Your best bet is to have different weapon types at your disposal to take advantage of any particular form's weaknesses. EM is great at killing most of CL-0N3's potential transformations. For heavily EM resistant or immune forms, either kinetic or thermal damage usually round out the coverage fairly well. Other than that, it's hard to have a consistent strategy that works against all possible transformations.
Once CL-0N3 is dropped back to base form, it will run away at 40 speed and be hard to get much damage off on. If you know which way the nearest Garrison is, try to reposition and/or dig to open sightlines so that you can keep shooting while it runs away. [[Explosive Launchers]] are great choices for both digging and being able to deal lots of damage in the limited attack window. The 75% resistances to all standard forms of damage makes dealing any substantial damage in this form quite unlikely. An important note is that [[Phasic Weapons|Phasic]] and [[Vortex Weapons]] bypass the standard resistances and can take it out quite easily.

[[Heading:2]]Melee flight[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]https://i.ibb.co/kVxPDLHq/clone-bounce-flight-kill.png|One example of bouncing CL-0N3 between two shortest paths to a garrison at the left.[[/Image]]
Once CL-0N3 is in base form, they will path to the nearest Garrison, or exit if all are sealed. If there is only one path to the nearest Garrison or exit, CL-0N3 will hop over Cogmind to reach it, but if there are more paths they will not hop regardless of the distance and instead take the second shortest path. If lured into this position ahead of time, a sufficiently fast flight build can go back and forth between the two paths, block off CL-0N3 and melee them when they reach the choke point. 

Alternatively, with a long 1-tile corridor that has paths in both directions to Garrisons, CL-0N3 can be lured into the corridor, then Cogmind can hop them and melee as they move towards each end of the corridor.

Name: CR-A16's Behemoth Slayer
Content: Transformed from [[CR-A16's Pointy Stick]]. The Behemoth Slayer will always instantly kill any [[Behemoth]] it hits. Note: This only applies to standard [[0b10]] Behemoth-class bots. [[Marauder|Marauders]] and the [[Superbehemoth]] are immune to this effect. When its effect activates, the game log [[GameText]][Behemoth] suddenly blasts apart at the seams.[[/GameText]]

Name: CR-A16's Pointy Stick
Content:
Given by the [[Derelict]] CR-A16 in [[Zion]]. When used to attack [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], there is a chance that this will transform into [[CR-A16's Behemoth Slayer]]. When this occurs, the log message [[GameText]]CR-A16's Pointy Stick's crusty surface crumbles away to reveal its sleek core, which hums to life.[[/GameText]] will appear.
Note: This transformation effect only applies to standard [[0b10]] Behemoth-class bots. [[Marauder|Marauders]] and the [[Superbehemoth]] are immune to this effect. However, it will still transform if used on an allied Behemoth or disabled one, such as the Behemoths that sometimes appear in [[Zhirov (Location)]].

Name: Cargo Convoy
Content:
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy.png|Intact cargo convoy[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy Deployed.png|A cargo convoy with ARCs deployed[[/Image]]
Cargo convoys are a special form of [[Transport Squad|transport squads]] that can be found from -7 to -2 on main [[Factory]] and [[Research]] floors. They consist of a single [[A-27 Freighter]], a [[Protector]], and two [[C-45 Heavy ARC|C-45 Heavy ARCs]] full of 4 combat bots and an extra utility bot, similar to strong [[Assault Squad|assaults]]. The parts contained within a Freighter are all [[Prototype Part|prototype]] or [[Authchips]], never faulty, and can be up to 3 ratings out of depth. For example, on -7, regular Haulers can contain up to rating 4 prototype parts. A cargo convoy Freighter can carry rating 5-7 prototype parts.
Cargo convoys are always preceded by 3-5 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] that scout out the path of the convoy before it appears. The alert [[GameText]]Cargo convoy en route, clear transfer corridor.[[/GameText]] will indicate when this is happening. A few turns later, the Freighter and guards will appear and take the same route.
Cargo convoys will always appear at a 0b10 controlled exit and head to a [[Garrison Access|Garrison]]. Typically the Freighter leads the way and stays ahead of the Protector and ARCs, which normally trail a few tiles behind. A [[Transport Network Coupler]] or [[Modified TNC]] will reveal the planned path of the Freighter. The Modified TNC will also show the contents of the Freighter. The Manifests hack will also show all the parts contained by the Freighter.

[[Heading]]Unique parts[[/Heading]]
There are 2 fully unique Cargo Convoy drops as well as one semi-unique drop:
[[List]][[Active Cooling Armor]]: Only obtainable from Cargo Convoy|[[Exp. Thermic Cannon]]: Only obtainable from Cargo Convoy|[[PL-3XN's Ring of Power]]: Only obtainable from one Cargo Convoy per run. Can be found in other locations.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Attack response[[/Heading]]
If a cargo convoy is attacked, a message will indicate this, as well as an alert: [[GameText]]ALERT: Cargo convoy interrupted, initiating access lockdown.[[/GameText]] 100 turns after this, a [[Heavy]] will spawn at an 0b10 controlled exit or Garrison every 100 turns until all exits are guarded by a Heavy. Heavies may head toward a far away [[Caves]] exit in order to guard it. The Freighter will begin running away in a random direction when attacked. If it is not destroyed, it will head toward another nearby 0b10 controlled exit.

[[Heading]][[Derelict]] attack[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Cargo Convoy Attack.png|Derelicts from a Garrison ready to assault a convoy[[/Image]]
There is a chance that Derelicts will decide to attack a cargo convoy. The chance is higher at lower depths. If they attack, they will appropriate a Garrison machine, rig some [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bomb Traps]], and attack the convoy guards. If they are successful, they will retreat and leave the loot available for Cogmind. This may happen even if Cogmind is nowhere near the convoy. It may be a good idea to track the Freighter position in case this happens, even if not planning to attack the convoy directly, since this can often result in lots of powerful free loot. If Cogmind is not close enough to grab the loot, [[Recycler|Recyclers]] may have carried it off to a nearby [[Recycling Unit]]. Make sure to check these if the Freighter's stash can't be found nearby.

[[Heading]]Convoy contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|[[E-15 Imp]]|[[Executioner]]|[[Hunter]]|[[Mechanic]]|[[Programmer]]|Protector|[[Specialist]]|[[Striker]]||
-7|N/A|N/A|[[H-55 Commando]]|[[M-28 Smith]]|[[P-60 Hacker]]|[[I-36 Angel]]|[[X-57 Shotgunner]], [[X-62 Marksman]], or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]|N/A||
-6|Yes|N/A|[[H-66 Slayer]]|M-28 Smith|P-60 Hacker|I-36 Angel|X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]|N/A||
-5|Yes|N/A|H-66 Slayer|M-28 Smith|[[P-70 Sage]]|[[I-47 Archangel]]|X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]|N/A||
-4|Yes|Yes|[[H-77 Assassin]]|[[M-36 Artificer]]|P-70 Sage|I-47 Archangel|X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]|Yes||
-3|Yes|Yes|H-77 Assassin|M-36 Artificer|[[P-80 Master]]|I-47 Archangel|X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]|Yes||
-2|Yes|Yes|[[H-88 Terminator]]|M-36 Artificer|P-80 Master|I-47 Archangel|X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro|Yes
[[/Table]]

Name: Cave-ins
Content:
Cave-ins are a [[Game Mechanics|Game Mechanic]] where dug-out tiles will collapse and instantly deal a large amount of Impact damage to anything on the tile. It is safe to dig up to 3 tiles or even 4 tiles safely in some circumstances, but long distance digging is almost always unsafe.
For the purposes of this article, "stable tile" means regular tiles which can't ever cave-in, "dug-out tile" means tiles that used to be Walls or Earth tiles, were destroyed and now glow red, and "unstable/destabilized tile" means a dug-out tile that was destabilized in some way.

[[Heading]]Causes of cave-ins[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Destabilized Tiles.png|Destabilized tiles are bright red as shown by a Structural Scanner[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Destabilization[[/Heading]]
Destabilized tiles are tiles that will always collapse if given enough time. They may collapse instantly or they may last a hundred turns or more. Destabilized tiles can be viewed with a [[Structural Scanner]]. A tile can become destabilized in two ways:
[[List]]Explosive damage - Explosive damage (namely from [[Launchers]]) is likely to cause tiles to become destabilized. Note that most, if not all Thermal and EM explosions do not have this effect.[[Comment]]I didn't test all of them, but i'd be surprised if that wasn't a damage type thing. I have not checked Kinetic, Special, or Entropic explosions, or Blasthammer directional, but if none of those are capable of destabilizing tiles, then EX damage should be noted as the only explosion damage type capable of destabilizing tiles, instead of mentioning all other types.[[/Comment]][[Comment]]Also, i'm not sure, but i think whether tiles get destabilized or not might be a chance dependent on the amount of damage that tile receives?[[/Comment]]
|Attacking from a dug out tile - If Cogmind or any other bot fires a weapon inside of a dug out tile, the tile will destabilize. This tile may collapse instantly before Cogmind gets a chance to move, so digging from inside these tiles is never completely safe.
In terms of destabilization, melee attacks are the least likely to collapse right away. Guns have a slightly higher chance, and then cannons and launchers have the highest chance.[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Dug-out tile traversal[[/Heading]]
It is possible to safely travel through dug-out tiles (that are not destabilized) for up to 1-4 tiles, depending on the type of tiles traversed. If the warnOnCaveinMove option in the advanced.cfg file is set to 1, the game will warn you when trying to move onto a dug-out tile that could collapse due to that movement. The safety of digs is follow (assuming the relevant tiles are not destabilized):
[[List]]
1-tile digs - Always safe.
|2-tile digs - Safe, unless both tiles are dug-out earth tiles (rarely relevant).
|3-tile digs - Safe, but only if no more than one of the tiles is a dug-out Earth tile.
For example, the most common safe 3-tile dig is Wall-Earth-Wall,
whereas Wall-Earth-Earth or Earth-Earth-Wall would not be safe and could collapse on the third and second tiles respectively due to having traveled through more than one earth tile. 
|4-tile digs - Only safe if all four tiles are dug-out Wall tiles. 4-tile digs are only rarely useful, usually to move barely out of visual range of a Heavy or Sentry.
|5-tile or more digs - Never safe.[[/List]]
One way to think about it is to consider that moving through a dug-out tile has a "cost", 2 for Wall tiles and 5 for Earth tiles, and that having reached a "cost" of 10 or more during a single dig can cause a cave-in on the current tile. [[Comment]]I feel like there's a better way to word this sentence.[[/Comment]]

Each step into an unsafe tile has a 10% chance of instantly causing a collapse of the tile moved into.


[[Heading:2]]Closed-off Tunnels[[/Heading]]
If a bot sits in a closed off area of the map, there is a chance each turn that a cave-in will occur. As long as there is a path to the main area of the map, it is safe to sit indefinitely in a dug out area. However, if the path closes due to something like an [[U-05 Engineer|Engineer]] rebuilding a wall, it will suddenly become dangerous.

[[Heading]]Example digs[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Wall Earth Wall Dig.png|Safe 3-tile dig with a ranged weapon: Wall-earth-wall|Wall Dig.png|Safe 1-tile dig with a melee weapon: Wall only|Wall Wall Dig.png|UNSAFE 2-tile dig: Digging within a dug out tile is unsafe|Wall Earth Earth Wall Dig.png|UNSAFE 4-tile dig: Wall-earth is safe, second half earth-wall is unsafe[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Avoiding cave-ins[[/Heading]]
Here are some strategies to avoid cave-ins:
[[List]]Don't use melee attacks to dig more than 1 tile - Melee weapons need to be adjacent to the next tile to dig out. This means Cogmind will have to be in a dug out tile to dig two consecutive tiles which allows a chance for an immediate destabilization cave-in.
|Don't use Explosive Launchers to dig - While Explosive Launchers can dig out a lot of tiles at once, many of those tiles have a chance to collapse as Cogmind walks through. It is safe to do this with a Structural Scanner equipped, as destabilized tiles will be visible and are avoidable.
|Use Thermal or Kinetic cannons - These cannons have a high base damage that is typically strong enough to dig through most non-reinforced walls. It is safe to dig a 3 tile path ahead of time and then walk through at no risk of cave-in.
|Be wary of [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]] - Engineers may seal off your path and leave you stuck in the wall, forced to dig again to escape and risk immediate cave-in.[[/List]]

[[Heading:3]]Stable Digging[[/Heading]]
There are a few ways to dig out tiles in ways that cause the resulting tile to be stable, but all of them are very limited. They include:
[[List]]Most wall-opening/destroying events, such as opening the [[Exiles (Location)]] Vault or the [[Wastes]] Derelict incursion event. Note that if those tiles are dug out in any other way, they will act like regular dug-out tiles instead of stable tiles, even after the related event is triggered.
|Behemoths, when breaking walls through movement. However those tiles will only temporarily stay stable.
|Earth tiles that would normally be dug out by [[T-07 Excavator|T-07 Excavators]], such as many of those in Scrapyard.
|Certain prefab-specific Earth tiles that can be dug out to create stable tiles, such as a few of those in [[Subcaves]].
|[[Spoiler]]The [[GameText]]randomize_corridors[[/GameText]] [[RIF]] hack, which causes a T-07 Excavator to start randomly creating fully stable corridors.[[/Spoiler]]
|[[Spoiler]]The [[Vortex Shredder]] wielded exclusively by [[Borebot|Borebots]], which causes any tiles destroyed this way to be stable. Tiles that were already dug out in other ways will not become stable.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Non-standard Movement[[/Heading]]
Because only standard movements count towards the safety limit when traversing dug-out tiles, non-standard movement types can be used to bypass the safe dig limit, usually at the cost of some kind of damage, which may be preferable to the chance of high Impact damage from cave-ins. Some non-standard movements include:
[[List]]Being pushed into a dug-out tile by a friendly [[Behemoth]].
|Being knocked back by [[Ballistic Cannons|Ballistic Cannon]] projectile, usually from hostiles.
|Being knocked back by [[Concussive RPG]], including any used by Cogmind. Note that the explosion may cause dug-out tiles to become destabilized. [[Comment]]Since using one that way would push you away from the tile you fired from, i think that would make you immune to collapse due to attacking from a dug-out tile, but i haven't done thorough testing.[[/Comment]]
|Being knocked back by hostile [[Impact Weapons]], which would hardly be beneficial since it would mean taking Impact damage to avoid the possible Impact damage of a cave-in.
|[[Flight Units|Flying]] over robots, but only if that would move Cogmind onto a stable tile. Attempting to fly over robots onto a dug-tile will result in an "invalid move" message.
[[/List]]

[[Comment]]Some late-game AAs can make it possible to dig more safely/farther/better, they should probably be mentioned here? I'm not sure myself on how they function in regards to cave-ins due to movement.[[/Comment]]

Name: Caves
Content:
Caves is the most frequent [[Branch]] map throughout all of [[Factory]] depths. It is a non-[[0b10]]-controlled map where [[Derelict|Derelicts]] often roam free and hostile 0b10 squads patrol and can be taken out without fear of reinforcements. Non-patrolling 0b10 outposts guarded by a [[Sentry]] and dormant bots are common. Every depth has 2 guaranteed Caves exits and each Caves map is a part of a series of 3 maps in a row. Not counting event-based exits, all first Caves maps of each depth can only be exited by entering the second Caves map. Caves maps do not have very many regular parts on the ground, but piles of [[Scrap]] contain usable but partially damaged parts and [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]] can give unique intel about upcoming floors.
There are different names for the different types of Caves maps and they have slightly different characteristics. Lower Caves is the name given to the first 2 Caves maps on -7 and -6, while Caves maps on -5 and -4 are named Upper Caves. The third caves map is accessible only by exiting the depth-specific special branch at the left side of the second caves map and is called Proximity Caves, regardless of depth. Lower and Upper Caves are very similar in all but [[Robot Tier]], but Proximity Caves tends to be more densely populated with patrols, in addition to potentially having higher-tier robot variants due being one depth above the Caves that lead to them. They also contain [[N-01 Spotter|Spotters]] that will report armed hostiles on sight, causing a 150 alert increase per spot when entering the next map. This caps at 900 alert gained.
Caves are patrolled lightly by hostile 0b10 bots compared to the main floors. [[Infowar]] utilities are a good option to avoid unnecessary encounters as many patrols can be avoided with a bit of patience. Caves have a unique mechanic where parts dropped from 0b10 bots will automatically self-destruct after a few turns. Looting must be done quickly or else the dropped parts will be lost forever. The only 2 ways around this mechanic are [[Self-destruct Interrupter|Self-destruct Interrupters]] and [[Electromagnetic Weapons]]. The interrupters will prevent the parts from frying while active and EM damage will interfere with the self-destruct mechanism. While EM will give [[Corrupted Parts]], it is far better to end up with corrupted parts than to end up with no parts at all.
Due to the low rate of good parts spawning on the floor and the overall difficulty in looting hostile 0b10 bots, it is very easy for an unprepared build to fall apart in these maps. Bringing plenty of spares into Caves is highly recommended to avoid running out of essentials like propulsion, weapons, and armor. [[Launchers]] are a must here to handle ambushes of large numbers of 0b10 bots hiding in outposts. Launchers are also incredibly useful when entering a Caves map because the standard spawn protection that is present in 0b10 maps doesn't apply here. That means that one (or more) patrols can appear right in Cogmind's face on entering a map.
Caves are also the most common place to encounter the [[Decomposer|Decomposers]], [[Packrat|Packrats]] and [[Samaritan|Samaritans]] neutral Derelict bot classes. They tend to appear in single-class groups of three. Decomposers will collect all stray debris, parts, Scrap piles and [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]] they happen to find and will break them down into matter they then leave on the floor, potentially destroying valuable parts or intel. In some cases, the matter yielded this way may be useful, but in most cases destroying these bots as quickly as possible is highly recommended.
The 0b10 [[Minesweeper]] class can also be found in caves near Derelict [[Traps]], guarded by 0-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]]. If destroyed, the Traps they extracted will be dropped and won't self-destruct, and can be re-used to deal with 0b10 patrols or plan attacks on outposts.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Caves[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Navigation[[/Heading]]
Cave maps all have a very similar overall layout. While the paths within the caves are unpredictable, these maps can typically be divided into 6 equal chunks. Top left, top middle, top right, bottom left, bottom middle, and bottom right. Cogmind will always spawn from the top right or bottom right chunks in Lower and Upper Caves or the top left or bottom left chunks in Proximity caves. One exit will always be in the chunk furthest from Cogmind. In the second Lower or Upper Caves map, the unique branch exit will be in that furthest chunk and the exit back to the main floor will always be on the same side. A good rule of thumb is that left is away from 0b10 while right is toward 0b10.

[[Heading:2]]Checkpoints[[/Heading]]
Caves checkpoints are square-shaped open spaces with a guard positioned at the center with possibly other robots stationed nearby.
There are three types of checkpoints:
[[Table]]
Central guard|Alignment|Square size|Possible additional guards|Formation||
[[Mutant]]|Friendly (Warlord)|7x7|0, 2 or 4 [[Thug|Thugs]], [[Butcher|Butchers]] or [[Savage|Savages]]|X, / or \\\\-shaped||
Sentry|Hostile (0b10)|7x7|[[Swarmer|Swarmers]], [[Grunt|Grunts]], [[Duelist|Duelists]] or [[Brawler|Brawlers]]|Chaotic||
[[Behemoth]]|Hostile (0b10)|6x6|None|N/A
[[/Table]]
[[Gallery]]
Caves Hostile Guards.png|0b10 checkpoint|
Caves Friendly Derelicts.png|Warlord checkpoint[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:2]]Outposts[[/Heading]]
Outposts make up the most common type of guarded structure found within Caves. There are a lot of types of outposts, differing in shape, size, guards, rewards and sometimes events. Although their walls are visually identical to regular cave walls, outpost structures are always fully disconnected from regular cave walls. While some are controlled by friendly Derelicts, most outposts are controlled by 0b10 bots (or rarely by hostile Derelicts). Most Caves map will have exactly one functional 0b10 outpost.
[[Transmission Jammer|Transmission Jammers]] are highly recommended to take bots in these hostile outposts out one at a time without getting overwhelmed. In some hostile encounters, [[Sentry|Sentries]] can call for a reinforcement [[Assault Squad]]. In the first Caves map each depth only no reinforcements will come as there is no 0b10-controlled exit. Killing the Sentries as quickly as possible is highly recommended in all other cases. Sentries capable of calling reinforcements will only do so when they are both tracking Cogmind and in Cogmind's field of view. Whether the Sentries themselves see Cogmind is irrelevant. In addition, Sentries in 0b10 outposts are one variant tier higher (if possible) than the current depth's Sentries. Fighting these outposts is a bad idea for an unprepared build, but larger outposts with [[Terminal]] intel are very valuable. This intel can be the same as the intel found in [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]]. Outpost Terminals' hack lists are entirely composed of "report" hacks, some of which yield intel, while the others yield only fluff text. Fluff records will always be listed first, so it's a good idea to hack the records at the bottom of the list.
Avoiding confrontation with most hostile outposts is usually fairly simple, especially with help from infowar utilities, though be wary of [[Corruption]] effects such as IFF bursts or weapon misfires that could attract unwanted attention, as well as nearby 0b10 patrols that could alert the dormant bots inside.

[[Heading:3]]0b10 Outposts (Small)[[/Heading]]
The most common type of outposts are small 0b10 outposts. They are square-shaped, have 1-2 hidden doorways on their sides, and are separated from regular cave walls by a minimum distance of 1 tile. Their main entrance is guarded on their outside by a Sentry, and contain a random mix of 4-6 dormant bots, which can be Swarmers, Grunts, Duelists or Brawlers. Those guards are stationed in front of the internal machinery. These outposts also contain 1-2 slightly damaged rewireable disabled robots. The Sentry will always try to call for a reinforcement Assault Squad.
These are also tend to be the most difficult type of 0b10 outposts to avoid attracting the attention of, due the the Sentry guarding it from the outside, as well as the usually close distance to cave walls that makes going around these outposts dangerous as well due to the hidden doorways. Using [[Terrain Scanners|Terrain Scanning]] and/or a [[Structural Scanner]] can help identify the position and field of view of the Sentry, as well as the location of hidden doorways.
[[Gallery]]Caves Outpost 2.png|Small 0b10 outpost, with 6 dormant bots, 2 rewireable bots, and a hidden doorway.[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:3]]0b10 Outposts (Medium)[[/Heading]]
Like all 0b10 outposts, medium 0b10 outposts are square-shaped. They contain an intel Terminal, some hidden doorways, dormant Grunts and/or Swarmers and are separated from regular cave walls by a minimum distance of 2 tiles. There are two primary variations of medium 0b10 outposts. The first has an Outpost Generator inside, and may not contain a Sentry. The second is guaranteed to have a Sentry, as well as a cache of 4 weapons (all the same) in a corner, which can be accessed without risk of getting spotted by destroying the outside wall.
There are two additional variations based on the second's structure. One has been "reappropriated" by friendly derelicts, with all of the outpost's structure left intact, aside from the weapon cache's shell. A broken and heavily damaged 0b10 bot remains, the weapon cache contains four different parts, and the 0b10 intel Terminal has been replaced with a Derelict intel terminal, which can be freely hacked. The last variation is a largely destroyed version of the outpost, where the terminal is useless and the weapon cache mostly pillaged.

[[Gallery]]Caves Outpost 1.png|Medium 0b10 outpost with no Sentries, with an explosive Outpost Generator, a hidden doorway, and 7 dormant bots guarding an intel Terminal.|Caves Reappropriated Outpost.png|"Reappropriated" Derelict outpost.|Caves Outpost 3.png|Abandoned 0b10 outpost.[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:3]]0b10 Outposts (Large)[[/Heading]]
Like all 0b10 outposts, large 0b10 outposts are square-shaped. They contain 1-2 Sentries, an intel Terminal, a weapon cache, 6 dormant Grunts and 6 dormant Swarmers, and are separated from regular cave walls by a minimum distance of 2 tile. Like medium 0b10 outposts, weapon caches can be accessed from the outside without drawing attention by breaking the outer wall.
There are two primary variations of large 0b10 outposts. The first has one sentry and a cache of 4 weapons. The other is separated into two main parts, contains 2 Sentries, an Outpost Generator, and a large cache of 8 weapons.
There are also largely destroyed sub-variations of these, in which the terminal is useless and the weapon cache largely pillaged. In addition, some of these destroyed variants may rarely get suddenly infested by [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]], making them unsafe to explore without a Launcher. In case of infestation, blowing up the Outpost Generator if there is one could destroy a large portion of the Assembled.

[[Gallery]]Caves Mega Outpost 2.png|Large 0b10 outpost with 1 Sentry, 6 dormant Swarmers, 6 dormant Grunts, a weapon cache and an intel Terminal.|
Caves Mega Outpost.png|Large 0b10 outpost with 2 Sentries, 6 dormant Swarmers, 6 dormant Grunts, an Outpost Generator, a large weapon cache and an intel Terminal.|
Caves Outpost Assembled Invasion.png|[[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] infesting an abandoned outpost.[[/Gallery]]


[[Heading:3]]Warlord Outposts[[/Heading]]
Warlord outposts are circle-shaped, with a main entrance controlled by a Door Terminal. They are guarded by a [[Commander]] and several other Derelict bots that wander around the inside, and contain a few parts as well as an intel Terminal. The inside of the outpost is also reinforced by a "Wall Reinforcements" structure, which has an armor of 35. There are two main structural variants, one of which has a centered orthogonal entrance.

The Derelicts inside these outposts are friendly, and the Commander can even dispatch an escort for Cogmind. This escort will leave when reaching the next map, even if the next map is also a Caves map.

There are two additional sub-variants of Warlord outposts. The first is a sub-variant of the centered orthogonal entrance variant that has been invaded by 0b10 forces, including two [[Programmer|Programmers]], two Swarmers and one Sentry that cannot call for reinforcements but will identify Cogmind as "Derelict reinforcements". The intel Terminal can be safely accessed from the outside by destroying one of the walls, and while the bots inside will most likely spot Cogmind, they will not be able to exit the Outpost if no other entrance was opened. The other sub-variation is largely destroyed, where the Terminal is useless.

[[Gallery]]Caves Friendly Warlord Outpost.png|Warlord outpost (centered orthogonal entrance variant)|
Caves Invaded Warlord Outpost.png|0b10-controlled Warlord outpost|
Caves Attacked Warlord Outpost.png|Attacked Warlord Derelict outpost[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:3]][[Sapper]] Outposts[[/Heading]]
Sapper Outposts are structurally very similar to regular Caves layouts and as such can be difficult to identify with purely visual means. They are separated from regular cave walls by a minimum distance of 1 tile. They are fairly rare, and contain several friendly Sappers and Sapper parts, including [[Thermoblaster|Thermoblasters]], [[Mak. Ablative Armor|Mak. Ablative Armors]] and [[Sapper Charge|Sapper Charges]].
These outposts may get attacked by two [[Assault Squad|Assaults]]. Since these Assaults can only enter the map from 0b10-controlled exits, they will always approach from the eastern side of the map, likely making them easy to avoid. 

[[Gallery]]Caves Sapper Base.png|Friendly outpost of Sappers[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:3]]Hostile Derelict Outposts[[/Heading]]
Hostile Derelict outposts are structurally inelegant and are separated from regular cave walls by a minimum distance of 1 tile. They have 1-2 hostile Derelicts standing guard outside the structure, sometimes from positions far from any entrances, preventing them from getting quick help when spotting intruders. These outposts contain several active hostile Derelicts, some disabled Derelicts, and a few Derelict parts.
[[Gallery]]Caves Hostile Derelicts Outpost.png|Hostile Derelict outpost, with two disabled Butchers, and a Thug standing guard at the bottom-left, far from any entrances, preventing them from getting quick backup from the Derelicts inside.[[/Gallery]]


[[Heading:2]]Huge 0b10 Bases[[/Heading]]
Huge 0b10 bases are fairly rare, can only appear within Proximity Caves, and will only ever appear at the upper-right corner of the map. These bases have a enormous size of 46x46, a main four-door entrance on their left side, a secondary two-door entrance on their bottom side near the right edge of the map, and are mostly or completely made out of [[Reinforced Walls|Reinforced Barriers]]. If one of these prefabs appears, its top-right corner will contain the map's only exit as part of the prefab, forcing Cogmind to infiltrate the base.
These huge two-entrance prefabs tend to constrain the map generation process and noticeably affect the rest of the map, potentially creating unusual layouts such as extremely long corridors. There are two variations of huge 0b10 bases, both very different from the other.
[[List]]
Incomplete well-defended base - A large structure guarded by multiple 0b10 bot classes and maintained by two [[R-10 Processor|R-10 Processors]] and two [[U-05 Engineer|U-05 Engineers]].
Four lone combat bots patrol the interior, each either a Grunt, a Duelist or a Brawler.
The main entrance leads to a trapped room guarded by a Sentry and a Behemoth, making it the toughest way to enter the structure.
The secondary entrance leads into a long corridor with two indents each containing a [[Watcher]]. The room in front of the corridor is empty. The room to the right contains five rewireable Swarmers or five rewireable [[E-15 Imp|Saboteurs]], guarded by three Sentries which will be alerted by the secondary entrance's Watchers if those are not jammed.
In the middle of the two entrances is the incomplete Matter storage room, whose southern walls are regular cave walls. Some of the Earth tiles near the bottom-left of the prefab can be dug out and traveled freely without risk of [[Cave-ins|cave-ins]] (as they do not glow like regular dug-out tiles), making it possible to easily access the base through the incomplete Matter storage room.
In the center of the base is the explosive Base Generator, guarded by a Protector and a Sentry.
The top-left corner of the base is mostly unfinished, featuring incomplete machinery and walls, as well as a functional [[Fabricator]] near a few matter pods and a [[Recycling Unit]].
The two completed rooms in the upper-middle of the prefab each contain three different part stockpiles. Below these rooms are two incomplete rooms. The one to the left contains two dormant [[Hunter|Hunters]], and the one to the right contains four unpowered [[C-30 ARC|C-30 ARCs]], as well as four rewireable Grunts and two rewireable Hunters OR four rewireable Duelists and two rewireable [[Specialist|Specialists]].
The top right room of the base contains four dormant Swarmers or four dormant Grunts, two caches of two stockpiles of three parts each, and the map's only exit. The room's lower entrance can be accessed from the outside by opening the Sealed Heavy Doors using the associated Door Terminal.
Additionally, the base might get attacked by a large number of Derelicts when Cogmind first enters it.

|[[Demolisher]] testing base - Contains a large empty space used for testing Demolishers, at the center of which [[Target Drone|Target Drones]] are periodically launched. There are four active groups consisting of one Demolisher and one [[Protector]] each, each guarding one of each side of the Target Drone Dispatcher[[Comment]]I think there was a better way to word that sentence about the location and composition of active units within the base.[[/Comment]]. The Demolishers will attempt to destroy the Target Drones launched, though sometimes those will sometimes escape to the outside of the base. The top-left room of the base contains five unpowered or disabled Demolishers, as well as two caches of Launchers. The room opposite the base's main entrance contains a large stockpile of matter. There are several unpowered C-30 ARCs near the exit at the top-right corner of the base.

[[/List]]


[[Gallery]]Caves Huge Base.png|Proximity Caves huge 0b10 base exit.|Caves Demolisher Base.png|Proximity Caves Demolisher testing base exit.[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:2]]Ambushes[[/Heading]]
Some hostile Derelicts and 0b10 robots will wait in ambush to attack enemies or sometimes specifically Cogmind as they pass through.
[[List]]
Thug-guarded hostile Derelict ambush - A hostile Thug guards the entrance to a small recess in the cave walls containing three dormant hostile Derelicts, which will be woken up by the Thug without a Transmission Jammer.
|[[Thief]] base ambush - A Thief base containing several presumably stolen parts, one of which may be placed just outside the entrance to lure in potential victims. A Transmission Jammer may allow fighting each thief one by one, though attacking these bases may not be worth getting parts stolen.
|0b10 ambush - Two Hunters and one Programmer hidden behind a solid wall. When Cogmind approaches, the wall will break open to let the 0b10 bots attack. This ambush can only reliably be detected through the use of a [[Sensor Array|Sensor Arrays]], a Terrain Scanner with good [[Terrain Scan Processors|Terrain Scanner Processing]], or a [[Deep Structural Scanner]].
|Random Thief ambush - A lone Thief suddenly appears from outside FOV.[[Comment]]I'm not entirely sure about that one. Is that a real  ambush, or just a wandering Thief? It's hard to tell sometimes.[[/Comment]]
|[[Spoiler]][[Master Thief]] ambush - If Cogmind has stolen from the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]], Master Thieves may appear near the entrances or exits of Caves maps and will only target and attack Cogmind. Their ambushes may cause some nearby prefabs, such as [[Caves#0b10_outposts_small|small 0b10 outposts]], to wind up empty of bots. This can sometimes be used to predicts exit-of-Caves-map ambushes and prepare accordingly, though by the time an empty prefab is noticed, the attack may already have started. When attacking near the end of Caves maps, they appear from outside Cogmind's FOV, which may potentially draw in nearby 0b10 patrols. Master Thieves are nearly undetectable through Sensor Arrays due to their level 4 Scan Cloak trait, and cannot be detected through a [[Seismic Detector]] due to their airborne Propulsion.[[/Spoiler]] 
[[/List]]
[[Gallery]]Caves Hostile Thug.png|Hostile Derelict ambush - 1 [[Thug]], 3 dormant [[Savage|Savages]].|Caves Thief Base.png|[[Thief]] base with some presumably stolen parts.|Caves Hunter Programmer Ambush.png|0b10 ambush - The walls on the southern side of the bots will break if Cogmind gets too close.[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:2]]Other Caches/Hidden Locations[[/Heading]]
There are a lot of possible hidden prefabs in Caves maps. Some are hidden behind solid walls, others around corners, and some others are mostly in plain sight but somewhat out of the way.

[[Heading:3]]Hidden Research Stations[[/Heading]]
Four of the hidden prefabs are research stations, where a Derelict does science of some kind. Each of these prefabs may only appear once across all Caves maps, and they are not guaranteed to appear. [[Comment]]There's probably a better way to phrase that these prefabs are "unique but not guaranteed".[[/Comment]]
[[List]]
[[Tinkerer]] hiding behind some [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] - Fluff encounter. There is no other place to encounter broken Assembled within Caves.
[[GameText]]<Name>: "I like it here. It's the perfect spot where no one bothers me, for obvious reasons."[[/GameText]]

|[[Spoiler]]Tinkerer PL-HR7, hiding behind Sealed Heavy Doors, near [[Warlord Statue (Bot)]] - The Door Terminal is called "W-Fans Enter Here" and can be heard from far away. Upon entering, PL-HR7 greets Cogmind and offers their [[Heart of Steel]] prototype.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Comment]]Dialogue (incomplete): A derelict excitedly rushes up: "Another fan!"[[/Comment]]

|[[Spoiler]]A Tinkerer hidden behind a Locked Door - Sometimes the cave walls won't fully surround the machinery, making it possible to spot the Tinkerer inside without intending to. When spotting the Tinkerer, they will explain that they are about to be attacked, and entrust Cogmind with their [[Molecular Deconstructor]] prototype, as well as the password to access it. Some time after this, 0b10 hostiles including Programmers, Specialists and Hunters will appear nearby along with an announcement: [[GameText]]PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENT: Unaware incursion detected. Likely classification: Search and Destroy. And maybe Retrieve. Something like that, yeah.[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]"They're coming to take away my research again!"[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]"You're not Unaware, and look menacing enough... take it and get as far away from here as you can. Quickly!"[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]"The password is <CODE>."[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]]

|[[Spoiler]]Derelict C-55 Analyst and [[Core Expander]] concealed behind a solid wall - One of the most well-hidden prefabs. Sometimes another Derelict can be encountered near the C-55 Analyst's hiding spot, explaining that they were following a lone Researcher but lost track of them. Upon entering, the [[Researcher]] will explain their situation, and will then roam the map aimlessly. The [[Core Expander]] is so powerful that it alone can be a good reason to go into Caves, even though this prefab isn't guaranteed to show up.
[[GameText]]C-55 Analyst: "How did you find me??? Please don't shoot, I'm a Derelict like you now! I just had to learn more about this intriguing device..."[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading:3]]Delusional Mutants[[/Heading]] [[Comment]]I'm not sure, but i think only one of these can appear in each run?[[/Comment]]
A hostile Mutant hidden behind walls and a Locked Door, guarding either parts or rewireable Unaware. Their hideout is not guaranteed to be fully enclosed by walls. They are referred to as "delusional" by scoresheets' "History" section.

[[Gallery]]Caves Hostile Mutant 1.png|Hideout of a hostile [[Mutant]] guarding a stash of parts, with an alternative entrance on the lower-left side.|Caves Hostile Mutant 2.png|Hideout of a hostile Mutant guarding a collection of rewireable Unaware.[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:3]]Hidden Caches[[/Heading]]
There are a lot of hidden cache prefabs, each hidden in one of many ways:
[[List]]Some caches are fully hidden behind solid walls. These will contain either only [[Dirty Datajack|Dirty Datajacks]] or only [[Self-destruct Interrupter|Self-destruct Interrupters]]. They can only be detected through Terrain Scanning, Structural Scanning or rarely Caves map layout derelict intel. The Self-destruct Interrupters inside those caches are capable of preventing the self-destruction of nearby unaware parts, possibly indicating their presence.
|Many caches are hidden inside of difficult-to-spot paths, usually requiring diagonal movement to enter. The paths may be trapped with friendly Derelict Traps[[Comment]]Part of what i'm saying here is effectively "trapped with traps", maybe there's a way to avoid that repeat?[[/Comment]], so be careful when corrupted. These will either contain a handful of parts, in which case the cache may be additionally protected by a Sealed Door and the relevant Derelict Door Terminal, or several Dirty Datajacks.
|Some caches contain a large amount of [[Scrap]]. These Scrap rooms aren't very well hidden, and sometimes have a functional door separating them from the rest of the caves. Fully looting these Scrap piles may be difficult, as they will quickly fill the small space they're contained within, possibly preventing some Scrap piles from yielding everything they otherwise would have.
|Some caches are hidden behind a Sealed Door and its relevant Derelict Door Terminal, and contain a large number of parts. These may occasionally contain a friendly dormant Derelict guard.
|[[Spoiler]]DNI cache - A unique prefab protected by Reinforced Barriers and Sealed Doors, containing a [[Dimensional Node Initializer]] and a fluff lore Terminal.
[[GameText]]>>Record "Note to 6F-MQ2"
I took this from a Hauler that was behaving strangely. This was all it had in its inventory, and to be sure I also checked the local manifest, but found it wasn't even listed! See what you can make of it.[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading:3]]"Out of the way" Robots[[/Heading]] [[Comment]]There's probably a better title for this heading.[[/Comment]]

"Remains of a fight"[[Comment]]There's got to be a better name for this[[/Comment]] - A dead end containing damaged parts and broken 0b10 and/or Derelict bots, as though there had been a fight. Both common and easy to find. Those bots' parts can be helpful if Cogmind is in a bad state, though be wary if corrupted, as the area may contain friendly Derelict Traps.
Non-combat Derelict bot graveyard - A small slightly hidden room containing lots of broken non-combat Derelict bots, including Decomposers[[Comment]]It's been a while, i'm not sure Decomposers can appear in those graveyards, but they probably can? [[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are primarily 2 types of exits in Caves, depending on which types of caves map it is:
[[List]]Main access exit: There is always a single main floor exit on the second Caves map and in Proximity Caves maps, and it always leads to the next standard depth map (Factory or Research). This exit is typically on the far right side of the map. Sometimes this exit is heavily guarded and part of an 0b10 base.|Caves exit: In the first Caves map, the only exit available is to the second Caves map.|Special Branch exit: Depending on the type of map, each caves exit will have a special Branch exit typically on the left side of the map. For Lower Caves, this exit goes to [[Zion]] or [[Data Miner (Location)]]. For Upper Caves, this exit goes to [[Warlord (Location)]] or [[Zhirov (Location)]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Notes[[/Heading]]
Caves has one of the largest collections of prefabs of all the maps in the game, with a wide mix of good and bad prefabs. One of the strongest prefabs, the derelict [[Researcher]] with a [[Core Expander]], is so strong that it alone can be a good reason to go into Caves.

Friendly Derelicts will not move from their guard position, but they will engage any 0b10 forces they see. Leading hostile squads into them can let them do the fighting for you. This is particularly easy to do for fast airborne builds who don't want to engage in combat and can use the Derelicts as a distraction. These Derelicts can also be safely salvaged for parts and will not retaliate.

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Caves Huge Base Assault.png|Derelicts attacking a huge 0b10 base exit[[/Image]][[Image]]Caves Outpost Assembled Invasion.png|[[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] infesting an abandoned outpost[[/Image]]
[[List]](++) [[Z-Hero]] Rescue: If Cogmind is low on core integrity and under fire, a Z-Hero can appear and fight off the attackers. The hero will also spawn an exit that leads to the next main floor.
|(++) Annoying [[Tinkerer]] "Woof" hack: Only appears in Proximity Caves. A Tinkerer will appear and give a long-winded speech about a hack they have been working on. This is a manual datajack hack that will reprogram any [[Behemoth]]. Only works twice.
|(+) [[Zion]] shortcut: A Derelict will appear and create an exit. This may skip a depth if [[Spoiler]]Zion[[/Spoiler]] is not on the same depth.
|(+) [[Data Miner (Location)]] shortcut: A Derelict will appear and create an exit. This shortcut can not skip depths.|(+) [[Warlord (Location)]] shortcut: A Derelict will appear and create an exit. This shortcut can not skip depths.
|(+) Derelict assault on huge 0b10 exit base: Squads of Derelicts will appear and attack the exit|(-) [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] Infestation: An abandoned outpost can become infested with Assembled that will roam the map and attack anything nearby.
|(-) [[Molecular Deconstructor]] reclamation: A mix of 0b10 bots will be dispatched after opening the containing vault
|(-) Freighter cargo recovery: Upon sighting the broken Freighter, a new Freighter and smaller than usual escort of a [[Protector]] and [[C-45 Heavy ARC]] will be sent to retrieve the parts. The broken Freighter will carries a full inventory of Prototype parts.
|(--) [[Sapper]] base attack: Two [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] can be dispatched directly to a Sapper base|[[N-01 Spotter]] spawn: 2 Spotters will appear near the 0b10 exit to caves. If any armed hostile appears in visible range, they will be scanned and reported as a threat. Each scan results in +150 alert heading into the next map, capping at 900 alert maximum.[[/List]]

Name: Cep. Impact Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Impact Drone|Impact Drones]]

Name: Cetus
Content:
Cetus is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Factory]] branch between -6 and -4 that can only be entered through [[Extension]]. This map is the same every game with no variation. There are 2 groups of a [[Watcher]] + 4 [[Cetus Guard|Cetus Guards]]. One is on the bottom left side of the map and the other is on the top right. In the center is the Cetus Manufacturing Module machine, a few scattered lore [[Terminal|Terminals]], and a Terminal that locks up the Cetus Mainframe.
If [[A7]] is rescued and kept alive, they will provide a special Terminal hack for the manufacturing module that will create 5 Cogmind-controlled [[Enhanced Grunt|Enhanced Grunts]]. A7 also has a special interaction upon seeing the Cetus Mainframe. After exiting the map, they will give a special robot hack that [[Redacted]]decreases the reaction time of [[MAIN.C]], causing them to take much longer to attack[[/Redacted]].
One special bot appears on this map: [[Revision 17]]. After destroying all 8 Cetus Guards, they will appear and thank Cogmind for freeing them. If both Revision 17 and the Cetus Manufacturing Module are still intact when leaving the map, it is possible to [[Revision 17 (Alignment)|align with them]] and cause a special -3 [[Research]] event where Revision 17 attacks the map.
There are no standard [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]] or [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] on this map. However, there is a special patrol [[C-30 ARC|ARC]] spawn. 750 turns after entering the map and every further 250 turns, 2 ARCs will spawn from random exits and roam around the map. It is best to exit the map before too many of these ARCs start showing up.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]Cetus Records|Cetus Mainframe[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Maps/Cetus]]

[[Heading]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 3 exits on this map but only 2 kinds of exits:
[[List]]Main access exits: The exits on the top left/right corners of the map will lead to the next main Factory or Research floor.|[[Archives]]: The exit on the bottom right corner leads to Archives.[[/List]]

Name: Challenges Achievements
Content:
[[Comment]]                       ---NOTE FOR EDITORS---
Once Beta 16 releases, if you decide to update any of the Achievements pages, please consider whether it would be better to separate the new achievements from the old ones or not.
I think that, ideally, whatever you choose to do, that decision should be applied to all Achievements pages, for the sake of consistency.[[/Comment]]

Challenges [[Achievements]] are earned by completing certain challenging feats, demonstrating the player's large experience with the game. Only some of them are likely to be obtained naturally by players not actively trying to earn them. 2 of the 27 Challenges Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Challenges Achievements tend to indicate their general difficulty as a Challenges Achievement[[Comment]]Rincewind being the biggest exception. Why is that one considered "easy"? It's basically the most difficult one in here.[[/Comment]], with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Comment]]Important note : A lot of Challenges Achievements' descriptions mention by name some spoiler-tier stuff, such as the Cetus Guards or Transdimensional Reconstructors.
Normally, these names would be contained within a Link tag.
However, because those Achievements' descriptions are not hidden by the game (the descriptions themselves aren't spoiler-tier), these names should not be contained within a Link tag, because that would cause them to appear spoilered to anyone with a spoiler setting of "None".[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 1[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Exterminator: Destroy 15 [[Assembled]] in the [[Mines]].
Strategy: This Achievement is seed-dependent, and may be impossible on some seeds. When attempting to get this Achievement on a random seed, visit the Mines and bring at least one [[Launchers|launcher]]. If an Assembled infestation occurs, try to find and reach the source as quickly as possible, to be able to blow up the Assembled while they are still in a somewhat large group. Having a [[Seismic Detector]] can help locate the Assembled faster.
|Killing Spree: Achieve a kill streak of 20 hostiles.
|Preemptive Strike: Destroy a visible [[Carrier|ARC]] before it deploys.
|Left-hand Path: Destroy all Cetus Guards without any help from allies.
|Below: Visit and survive 2 [[Wastes|Waste]] areas.
|Streaker: Enter a main complex map at -5 or above as a naked core, and find an exit (do not have to remain naked).
|Rincewind: Use at least 10 Transdimensional Reconstructors (any variant).
|Leap Before You Look: Enter 10 unidentified exits.
Strategy: It is possible to deduce the identity of exits without actually "identifying" the exit, through various means. For example, successfully hacking branch exits would cause all remaining unidentified exits to be main exits, and vice-versa. It is also possible to identify some exits by where they are or what's around them, such as [[Mines]] exits, which are always surrounded by mining equipment. This is especially true in branches, where all exits are distinguishable from each other. This can allow entering exits the game considers "unidentified", while actually knowing where they lead, making this Achievement much easier. If you have a [[Signal Interpreters|Signal Interpreter]] attached, remember to deactivate it before approaching any exits you would want to take while unidentified, as it would automatically identify them.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 2[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Boltbath: Achieve a kill streak of 35 hostiles.
|Torch: Inflict 30,000 thermal damage across an entire run.
|Magneto: Inflict 30,000 electromagnetic damage across an entire run.
|Punisher: Inflict 30,000 kinetic damage across an entire run.
|Gladiator: Destroy 200 hostiles via melee.
|Infiltrator: Enter and survive 2 [[Garrison|Garrisons]] on a single floor.
|Desperate Times: Enter a main complex map at -3 or above as a naked core with no inventory items, and find an exit (do not have to remain naked).
|Monster: Kill at least 20 inhabitants of Zion.
|Equal Opportunity Bot: Destroy 30 different classes of robot.
Notes: What counts as a "class" isn't immediately obvious. For example, the in-game examination window classifies [[Thug|Thugs]] as "Thug (Derelict)" and [[Grunt|Grunts]] as "Grunt", but they are considered the same class for scoresheet purposes. This achievement relies on the scoresheet definition, making it somewhat confusing.
As a general rule, robots with different sprites will count as different classes (with the exception of unique NPCs, which do not count at all).
The exact definition is likely related to the "build type" and purpose of each robot. For example, both [[Packrat|Packrats]] and [[Recycler|Recyclers]] have the purpose of collecting parts and have similar parts. Both Thugs and Grunts are two-legged, have a [[Cooling Devices|Heat Sink]], and use thermal guns. [[Cobbler|Cobblers]] and [[Mechanic|Mechanics]], however, are completely different in both build and purpose, and as such count as different classes.
The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Classes Destroyed".
|Giant Slayer: Destroy 5 [[Behemoth|Behemoths]].
|Artifact Hunter: [[Spoiler]]Attach or use 15 different alien artifacts.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Challenge difficulty level 3[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Fearless: Enter a [[Garrison]] with below 10% core integrity and survive it.
|Shutout: Seal, jam, or destroy all [[Garrison Access|Garrison Access machines]] in Access.
|WMD: Destroy 100 robots in a single turn.
|Rambo: Earn 10,000 bonus points for high alert combat kills.
|Most Wanted: Trigger [[High Security|high security]] 4 times.
|404: Destroy 4 Network Hubs and escape to the next floor.
|Full Golem: [[Spoiler]]Become a complete Golem.[[/Spoiler]][[Comment]]TODO: This is the achievement with a description that i just guessed. I know it to be technically accurate, but it isn't the same as the actual achievement's description. Once the description is corrected, please remember to delete the warning at the top of the page.[[/Comment]]
|Traitor: Personally kill Warlord in his base and escape. Must initiate hostilities before incursion begins.[[/List]]


This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Chronowheel
Content:
The effect of the Chronowheel allows Cogmind to rewind time as a one time save/load effect. Attaching saves, and after 30 turns (if not destroyed/removed) the load will occur.

[[Heading]]Timeline of Effects[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
1 - [[GameText]]Spacetime feels off.[[/GameText]] log message. Random part art, map sections, and lore text will briefly flash on screen. The frequency of these effects increases as time goes on.|
20 - [[GameText]]Chronowheel is disintegrating...[[/GameText]] log|
28 - [[GameText]]Spacetime is rapidly distorting...[[/GameText]] log|
29 - [[GameText]]Spacetime reconverges on this point.[[/GameText]] log. Turn before attaching the Chronowheel is loaded, Chronowheel is gone.|
When ripping the Chronowheel off instead - [[GameText]]Spacetime feels normal again.[[/GameText]] log
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Possible Uses of Chronowheel[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Determining what map an exit goes to (a very expensive one time [[Signal Interpreter]], not really recommended)|
Scouting out a new map or running through a dangerous area (only really viable if fast)|Getting multiple attempts at killing specific NPCs like the [[Data Miner]]|
[[Spoiler]]Using the [[Data Conduit]] and finding the locations of all locations in the game without the negative side effects[[/Spoiler]]|
Getting the chance to reroll a [[RIF]] ability from a RIF Installer|
Attaching unknown [[Alien Artifacts]] or [[Prototype Part|Prototype Parts]] without downsides. This is especially useful if used with a [[Spoiler]][[Core Reset Matrix]], since it will show where all other Alien Artifacts are on the current map.[[/Spoiler]]|
[[Spoiler]]Completing [[Zhirov|Zhirov's]] [[SGEMP Prototype]] quest and obtaining the [[Access]] map intel without actually getting Zhirov to spawn in Access.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Secret second effect[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]]The Chronowheel also has a hidden secondary effect when paired with the [[Subatomic Replicator]]. First, the warning [[GameText]]Chronowheel temporarily destabilized by failed replication attempt, a second attempt will likely cause a devastating explosion.[[/GameText]] will appear in the log. A second attempt will give the message [[GameText]]Local interference in replication process, triggered subspace vortex.[[/GameText]] A 20 tile radius explosion will then occur at the point of replication, dealing 1000 vortex damage in 10 damage chunks with 0 falloff.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Chute Trap
Content:
Chute Traps are the only way to access [[Wastes]]. They are [[Traps]] found exclusively in the first [[Factory]] map of each depth from -7 to -4. In other words, additional Factory maps reached via Wastes or [[Garrison]] looping do not have any Chute Traps. Like [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] and [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]], they cannot be extracted using a [[Trap Extractors|Trap Extractor]]. Unlike them, however, Chute Traps can be reprogrammed using a [[Melee Datajacks|Melee Datajack]], not only disarmed.

If [[High Security]] is triggered, all Chute Traps on the map will disappear after 50 turns.

[[Heading]]Effects[[/Heading]]
When triggered, a Chute Trap will bring the victim to the array's Wastes map, permanently sealing itself afterwards. Victims can be followed by triggering a different Chute Trap from the same array. This is because each Chute Trap array leads to a different Wastes map. If Cogmind falls victim to one, Cogmind's [[Alert]] will drop enormously, and any allies currently following Cogmind will fall into Wastes one after the other following Cogmind, so long as they are not immobile, even if there weren't enough remaining Chute Traps for them to follow. If Cogmind follows a purple allied [[Derelict]] into Wastes, the Derelict will thank Cogmind for not abandoning them.
Standing on a known Chute Trap then manually triggering will grant the "Wheee!" [[Mechanics Achievements|Mechanics Achievement]] if it wasn't already unlocked.

[[Heading]][[K-01 Serf|K-01 Serf]] Interactions[[/Heading]]
On Factory maps containing Chute Traps, K-01 Serfs sometimes spawn carrying disabled 0b10 bots towards Chutes, and some disabled 0b10 bots can sometimes be stored inside rooms. If a disabled bot is within range of a Worker, the Worker will try to latch onto the bot and push them into the nearest Chute Trap, even if the bot is only temporarily disabled. If a Worker successfully pushes a disabled robot into a Chute Trap, the disabled bot will fall through but the trap will [[I]]not[[/I]] permanently seal itself afterwards. [[Comment]]If Cogmind witness this,[[/Comment]] The Chute Trap will then be revealed (due to a bug in Beta 15, Chute Traps are revealed this way even if Cogmind doesn't witness this happening).

Because Serfs use Chute Traps, the [[GameText]]find_chute[[/GameText]] hack can be used when hacking one using a [[Datajacks|Datajack]], which reveals the nearest Chute Trap the Serf can use.

[[Spoiler]]The [[RIF]] hacks [[GameText]]hold_bot[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]start_disposal[[/GameText]] can be used together to make a Serf latch onto and move a bot into a Chute Trap, so long as the Serf is not currently evacuating and has access to a Chute Trap. While the [[GameText]]hold_bot[[/GameText]] hack normally has a turn limit of 25, the [[GameText]]start_disposal[[/GameText]] hack overrides it.[[/Spoiler]]
