Name: FarCom
Content:
[[Image]]FarCom Sensors.png|FarCom sensors revealing nearby hostiles[[/Image]]
[[Image]]FarCom.gif|Using the FarCom Aligner machine[[/Image]]
FarCom is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in most runs. Taking FarCom aligns Cogmind with the [[Exiles (Group)]] for the rest of the game. It provides a permanent 18 tile radius sensor for hostile [[0b10]] bots within 0b10 controlled map. This sensor cannot be jammed by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or masked by [[Heavy|Heavies]] unlike standard [[Sensor Arrays]]. The primary limitation of the FarCom sensor is that it doesn't work in any [[Caves]] branches. One other side-effect is that entering specific [[Research]] branches becomes much more dangerous. Occasionally the Exiles may have been abandoned or attacked, and FarCom is not an option in these runs.
When FarCom is obtained, Cogmind is allowed to take one item (or multiples of the same item) from the Exiles Vault. Parts that can be taken are from the following list: [[Exiles Vault Prototypes]]

[[Heading]]Gaining FarCom[[/Heading]]
Taking FarCom can be done in most runs in the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] map off of either -10 or -9 [[Mines]]. After talking to [[EX-BIN]], walk into the FarCom Aligner machine. Cogmind can take up to 1 special vault item (or multiples of the same type). If Cogmind takes more than 1 type of item, then the Exiles will notice you stealing when entering [[Factory]] or [[Storage]] and FarCom will be removed. Also, becoming hostile to the Exiles will result in instantly losing FarCom. If Cogmind takes FarCom, it is not possible to [[Imprint]]: [[Spoiler]]The [[Imprinter]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and warn you to leave right away. Attempting to use the Imprinting machine will result in turning all the bots at [[Zion]] hostile. Taking FarCom excludes cogmind from affiliating with the [[UFD|UFD]]. There are no other alignment restrictions with FarCom.[[/Spoiler]]

[[Heading]]Research Branch side-effect[[/Heading]]
When entering -3 Research, the Exiles will send a warning message to Cogmind indicating not to enter Research branches. If Cogmind does anyway, [[Spoiler]]immediately when entering [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]] [[Maximum Security]] will instantly be triggered. This will also lock the exits to [[Section 7]] and [[Protoforge]]. Note that this does not include [[Armory]] when it is on -3. The immediate response is machines shut down right after entering the level, 4 [[Sentry]] spawns at each [[Garrison]] and exit, and 6 Assault [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]] sent at Cogmind shortly after. Unless Cogmind is prepared to fight off large waves of enemies or outrun them, these maps should not be entered.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Federalist
Content: Federalists are [[Legs|legged]] grunt-like [[Derelict|derelicts]] that appear in [[Scraptown]] and are armed with two extremely weak lasers with positive salvage. Not particularly powerful or otherwise remarkable.

Name: Field Lobotomy Kit
Content: A very popular Exile prototype choice. A common use is on heavy enemies. The further in the game that you can lobotomize enemies, the better.

Name: Field Recycling Units
Content:
Like [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]], Field Recycling Units are capable of recycling parts into [[Matter]]. Intact parts grant [Efficiency% of (Part Integrity / 2)] Matter. Damaged parts grant less Matter depending on the difference between their current integrity and their maximum integrity, as the formula that determines Matter yield is roughly [Efficiency% of (Current Integrity * Current Integrity / Max Integrity / 2)], rounded down. For example, An Adv. Field Recycling Unit collecting an [[Antigrav System]] with 33 out of 55 integrity would yield [60% of (33 * 33 / 55 / 2)] = 5.94, rounded down to 5 Matter, while the same Adv. Field Recycling Unit collecting an intact intact Antigrav System would yield [60% of (55 * 55 / 55 / 2)] = 16.5, rounded down to 16 matter.

Name: Fireman
Content: Firemen are [[Derelict]] [[Wheels|wheeled]] combat bots armed with [[Flamer|Regular]] or [[Enh. Flamer|Enh. Flamers]]. They have a tendency to melt foes due to their high heat transfer. These bots are unique to the Derelicts and have no similar [[0b10]] counterpart. Firemen are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Fireman (5)
Content: Fireman variant with a normal [[Flamer]].

Name: Fireman (7)
Content: Fireman variant with an [[Enh. Flamer]] and enhanced cooling.

Name: Firepult
Content: After firing, sometimes a log message [[GameText]]Firepult emits an uncontrolled burst of heat.[[/GameText]] will appear. When this happens, a large amount of additional heat will be added to Cogmind's current temperature. The burst of heat starts at about an additional 100 heat when it first occurs. Sometimes, it is followed by an additional message [[GameText]]Several Firepult components seem to have fused.[[/GameText]]. The amount of heat Cogmind gains will continue to increase as more heat bursts occur. Eventually this effect will cap at around the 300-400 additional heat range. Using [[Coolant Injectors]] greatly helps to mitigate the unpredictable heat generation.

Name: Flight Arrays
Parts: Nuclear Pulse Array,Field Propulsion Array,Impulse Thruster Array

Name: Flight Units
Content:
Flight units have the lowest support and the highest speed. They are quite fragile, though [[Prototype Part|prototype]] flight units are somewhat less so. They are notably used by [[Swarmer|Swarmers]].

On flight, [[Cogmind]] can outrun most other bots, but will have trouble equipping high-mass parts, such as the best armor, cannons, and storage units. Flight units are difficult to sustain in [[Materials]] due to their low availability and the high volume of encounters, so it is more common to use grounded propulsion in Materials and transition to flight upon reaching [[Factory]] or shortly thereafter.

Most flight builds will favor prototype flight units for their improved resilience, along with multislot flight arrays. Cooled (Cld.) flight units can be [[Overload#propulsion|overloaded]], which confers better speed and mass support at the expense of higher heat and energy usage.

Like [[Hover Units]], flight units receive a bonus to movement speed when multiple are used at once, and are affected by drag from attached [[Legs]], [[Treads]], and [[Wheels]]. This bonus cannot bring the overall movement delay below 10 unless flight units are overloaded.

While flying, Cogmind can hop over other bots in its way, unless Cogmind is overweight. Flying bots have a 10% evasion bonus, unless overweight or in stasis. Flying bots, along with hovering and legged bots, receive an evasion bonus from [[Reaction Control Systems]].

Name: G-34 Mercenary
Content: The lowest tier of bipedal combat Robots deployed in Complex 0b10, they possess one Small Laser that can deal compounding damage to lower tier parts, especially in the numbers they are usually encountered in. Their lack of significant heat dissipation makes them quickly melt under a sustained salvo of Thermal attacks, while their low core integrity means any sufficiently consistent weapon (In upwards of 15 dmg or more) is good to destroy them, launchers are also effective due to this reason as well. Their minus -25% electromagnetic resistance makes them susceptible targets for your possibly game-start EM Pulse Gun though its actual damage will be weak. Proper positioning can limit the amount of damage you take in encounters with Grunts and most other 0b10 bots. Using doorways to limit the amount of fire you take is one such method, as well as using corners.

Name: G-47 Trooper
Content: The second iteration of the Grunt-type combat robot in 0b10, the Trooper is up-gunned from a Sml. Laser to a more potent Particle gun, capable of greater damage and heat transfer. In addition, it also possesses a Lgt. Nuclear Core and an Imp. Heat Sink along with double the core integrity of the G-34. In spite of these upgrades, the standard grunt weaknesses apply, sustained thermal damage will still melt them, along with the type's intrinsic -25% electromagnetic resistance.

Name: G-50 Soldier
Content: Soldier Content

Name: GAL Module
Content: Found in [[Zion]], with the [[Derelict]] V3-CT5 nearby. When a [[Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle]] is picked up, the GAL Module will attach to the Rifle with the log message [[GameText]]GAL Module attaches itself to Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle.[[/GameText]] The Rifle will be transformed into the [[Modified EM Gauss Rifle]].

Name: GL-D0S
Content:
GL-D0S is a part of the deadly group of [[Unchained]] [[Derelict|Derelicts]] that work for [[0b10]] to track down threats to the complex. GL-D0S is not much of a threat by itself, with no combat capabilities to speak of. However, not only do they create swarms of [[Turret|Turrets]] immediately upon entering the map, but the [[GL-D0S's Turretformer]] can continue to make even more turrets later. It is extra difficult to pin this bot down since they never stop running away from combat at a reasonably quick 34 speed.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]Cyclists Records|UC/GL-D0S[[/Lore]]

[[Heading:2]][[FarCom]] Lore[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has aligned with the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]] and has FarCom, the following message will be broadcast about GL-D0S:
[[GameText]]This one isn't even that scary unless they happen to be blocking your intended path. They'll set up a bunch of turret clusters loosely centered around a Garrison and just... wait. Don't go there unless you want to introduce them to the real boss: you! They'll probably just run away if you get too close anyway. But turrets can't run.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]GL-D0S Turret Nest.png|GL-D0S with nest of turrets[[/Image]]
GL-D0S is an evasive type of Unchained, never waiting around in one place or engaging in combat directly. Instead, they relies on their turrets to do all the dirty work for them. Once they appears on the map, dozens of [[Aperture Drone|Aperture Drones]] will be dispatched from a [[Garrison Access]] that GL-D0S deems their home base. These drones swarm the nearby area and turn into a large collection of assorted turrets, creating a very heavily fortified area. Usually, a few drones will also head to other areas of the map, particularly nearby other Garrisons, although these turrets will not be as concentrated as the main base. Depending on the map, there may only be a single large nest of turrets instead of multiples. For example, this will be the case if only one Garrison is active.
After arriving on the map, GL-D0S will patrol between different nests of turrets. If there is only one, they will simply hang around that one location. If engaged in combat, GL-D0S will drop a new turret as long as the Turretformer hasn't been destroyed, then continue to run away without further resistance. After the initial swarm of drones, further Aperture Drones will be summoned from Garrisons to replace destroyed turrets if Cogmind is far enough away from the area. However, reinforcement turrets are not packed quite as densely as the original dispatch. If GL-D0S only has a single selected Garrison that is not sealed or destroyed and Cogmind is nearby, they will try to leave the map via Garrison. On smaller maps with only a single Garrison, such as [[Storage]], it is likely that GL-D0S will find Cogmind and leave quickly.

[[Heading:2]]Turrets[[/Heading]]
GL-D0S will produce turrets at random from the following list:
[[List]]
[[Blast Turret]]|
[[Bullet Turret]]|
[[Hammer Turret]]|
[[Laser Turret]]|
[[Launcher Turret]]|
[[Nova Turret]]|
[[Shield Turret]]|
[[Shock Turret]]|
[[Stasis Turret]]|
[[Stealth Turret]]|
[[Thermic Turret]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
GL-D0S is not so much of a direct threat and can often be avoided entirely by routing a different way once spotting the first turret. However, intentionally trying to take down GL-D0S, the biggest threat is walking into a room filled with turrets and getting dogpiled. As such, one of the best ways to avoid a bad situation like this is the use of [[Sensor Arrays]] and [[IFF Parsers]]. IFF Parsers will uniquely identify Unchained and turrets as blue squares instead of yellow like other [[0b10]] bots. Once you locate a turret on the map, you can take it out at range. Since all turrets are stationary and many have 16 or less weapon ranges, you can use longer ranged weaponry like [[Ballistic Cannons]] to dig into rooms and take them out without taking any damage yourself. [[Visual Processing Units]] can also help to spot them from afar, although this only works for turrets out in the open. Using [[Launchers]] to angle shots around walls is also a good way to eliminate turrets without getting shot back, though [[Explosive Launchers]] may be more difficult to use due to their tendency to blow up walls.
Locating GL-D0S is a challenging task of its own. They typically patrol across the map between turret nests and don't linger in one place for long. 34 speed makes catching up unrealistic for all but the fastest flight or hover builds. Instead, try to ambush them along their patrol route so you can take a few shots before they escape. Garrison intel can help figure out likely patrol locations. A [[Triangulator]] can also help you locate them at 24 range since they always have [[Perfect Tracking]] on Cogmind.
Even once you make it past all the built up turrets and locate them, taking down the fast-moving and evasive GL-D0S is another task. Defensively, they have no weaknesses, although the EM resistance of 75% is low compared to most unchained. Using tons of targeting can help to land hits, though it's still quick difficult to overcome the many bonuses they have. Using Launchers is a good way to ensure you actually get damage off on them. Explosive launchers deal better damage, but [[Electromagnetic Launchers]] can provide a salvage bonus to obtain the Turretformer. Single target weapons of all varieties can work as well, though they are going to be much more difficult to land on a fleeing GL-D0S.

Name: GOLEM Unit
Content:
GOLEM Units are unique utilities found on [[Golem|Golems]] and in the [[Zion Deep Caves]]. They are contained within the GOLEM Chambers found in the western wall. When attached and activated, they will produce a variety of assembled parts if there are empty slots available. While being integrated, these assembled parts have no effect and 0 coverage. These parts increase by 3 integrity every turn, and become active when their current integrity reaches 100% of maximum. Parts are built in the following order, assuming all slots are empty (slot number accounts for the Golem Unit itself taking two [[Utilities]] slots):
[[Image]]Golem Parts.png|A full GOLEM loadout[[/Image]]
[[Table]]
Part|Turns to build part|Total time to build|Slot Number||
[[Asb. Alloy Leg]] #1|133|133|1st [[Propulsion]]||
[[Asb. Flux Generator]]|117|250|1st [[Power]]||
Asb. Alloy Leg #2|133|383|2nd Propulsion||
[[Asb. Biocell Array]] #1|17|400|3rd Utility||
[[Asb. Nanovents]] #1|2|402|4th Utility||
Asb. Nanovents #2|2|404|5th Utility||
[[Asb. Focal Cannon]] #1|52|456|1st [[Weapons]]||
[[Asb. Alloy Armor]] #1|67|523|6th Utility||
Asb. Nanovents #3|2|525|7th Utility||
[[Asb. Suspension Frame]]|18|543|8th Utility||
Asb. Focal Cannon #2|52|595|2nd Weapon||
[[Asb. Combat Suite]]|20|605|9th Utility||
Asb. Alloy Armor #2|67|682|10th Utility||
Asb. Biocell Array #2|17|699|11th Utility||
Asb. Nanovents #4|2|701|12th Utility||
Asb. Focal Cannon #3|52|753|3rd Weapon||
Asb. Alloy Armor #3|67|820|13th Utility||
[[Asb. Metafiber Network]]|17|837|14th Utility||
Asb. Alloy Armor #4|67|904|15th Utility
[[/Table]]
If slots of one type are full, blocking a part, the first part of another type will be build instead. For example, if all propulsion slots are filled but two power slots are open, the Asb. Flux Generator will start building instead of waiting on the first Asb. Alloy Leg. The first Asb. Nanovents will never grow without one Asb. Biocell Array on Cogmind's body, though, as they are both of the same slot type (utility).

It may also be wise to carry an extra power source or significant energy storage, because rebuilding a destroyed Asb. Flux Generator in hostile conditions may be difficult or excessively dangerous, due to the time cost involved.

Name: Game Mechanics
Content:
[[List]]
[[Alert]] - Semi-hidden number that represents Cogmind's perceived threat level. Has dangerous consequences when too high.|
[[Allies]] - Bots friendly to [[Cogmind]].|
[[Cave-ins]] - Mechanic that causes dug out walls to collapse and deal large amounts of damage.|
[[Corruption]] - Stat that has various negative penalties and can result in death.|
[[Energy]] - Stat that is used to power most parts in the game.|
[[Heat]] - Stat that can cause overheating side-effects and deaths in non-immune bots.|
[[Matter]] - Stat that is used as a resource to attach parts and shoot some types of weapons.|
[[Overload]] - Mechanic that can increase effectiveness of parts with a possible downside.|
[[Robot Analysis]] - Terminal record that contains lore about a bot, also grants minor combat bonuses|
[[Sneak Attack]] - Attack that does doubled melee damage in certain circumstances.
[[/List]]

Name: Garrison
Content:
Garrison is a [[0b10]]-controlled sub-floor available from all main maps and several 0b10 branches from -9 to -1, typically accessed through a [[Garrison Access]]. They are very combat hostile-dense maps. They have a few patrols and a large number of guard posts that will automatically open to reveal their contents if Cogmind or an ally is nearby. Their center area has 4 of these guard posts and often has a [[Behemoth]] in the very center of the map. Garrisons are often filled with [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] and [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] throughout the main hallways.
Every Garrison has a center square area with 4 guard "checkpoints" and is often guarded by a [[Behemoth]]. There are 4 wings of the Garrison extending past the center area dividing into the top left, top right, bottom right, and bottom left segments of the map. Each wing that Cogmind did not spawn in contains an exit, although exits may be locked if Cogmind is not [[RIF]]-aligned. The wings have many random variations that can contain part stockpiles, rewirable bots, [[Phase Generator|Phase Generators]], Garrison Relays, trapped Derelicts, and additional guards. At least one of the wings will contain a RIF installer.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Garrison[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There are several unique types of machines in Garrisons.
[[Heading:2]]Garrison Relay[[/Heading]]
Garrison Relays are machines located in each wing of the Garrison and contain 3-5 [[Relay Couplers]] that will be released if the machine is destroyed. If Cogmind is not RIF-aligned, destroying Garrison Relays will decrease the chance of exits being locked.
[[Heading:2]]Phase Generator[[/Heading]]
Phase Generators are explosive machines that are responsible for maintaining phase walls and stopping normal [[Sensor Arrays]], [[Terrain Scanners]], and the [[Structural Scanner]] from working. [[Active Sensor Suite]], the [[Seismic Detector]], and the [[Triangulator]] do work, however. If destroyed, all phase walls will be removed and sensor and terrain scanning functionality will be restored. This behavior does not change even if there are multiple Phase Generators in the same Garrison. Destroying a second does not have any additional effect, other than cause a large explosion. Phase Generators are not guaranteed to appear on any Garrison. When they do show up, they are often hidden behind phase walls or emergency access doors, although they may be located via audio cues as the loud machine can be heard through walls.
[[Heading:2]]Phase Wall[[/Heading]]
While not a machine, Phase Walls are special tiles that are powered by Phase Generators. They are not normally visible unless Cogmind has the Structural Interface RIF ability. They have less armor than standard Garrison walls, although this is not revealed unless Cogmind becomes aware of them by some means. Any bot standing in a phase wall will get a free 50% force field-like damage reduction. Cogmind cannot walk in one normally without Structural Interface. However, it is possible to ram a bot out of a phase wall to gain the shielding.
[[Heading:2]]RIF installer[[/Heading]]
There is always at least one RIF installer per Garrison, with a chance of a second. They may be hidden behind phase walls and emergency accesses and not easily visible. Stepping into the middle of one will first cause Cogmind to become RIF-aligned if there are no other conflicting alignments. [[Imprint|Imprinting]] and using a [[Core Reset Matrix]] will cause Cogmind to be unable to use a RIF installer. If Cogmind is already RIF-aligned, Cogmind will either gain a new [[~/rif.html|RIF ability]] or increase the level in an existing one. The machine itself is quite fragile, so be careful for [[Corruption]]-induced misfires or explosive traps destroying the machine before use.

[[Heading]]Squads[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Patrols[[/Heading]]
The following bot types can appear as patrols in Garrisons:
[[List]][[C-30 ARC|ARCs]]|[[Brawler|Brawlers]]|[[Cutter|Cutters]]|[[Duelist|Duelists]]|[[Hunter|Hunters]]|[[Grunt|Grunts]]|[[Swarmer|Swarmers]]|[[Programmer|Programmers]][[/List]]
If Cogmind has looped and already been in a Garrison this floor, additional squads of 2-3 Programmers will appear in the Garrison. There is one additional patrol for each Garrison already visited.
[[Heading:2]]Guards[[/Heading]]
The following bot types can appear as guards inside checkpoints:
[[List]]ARCs (up to 4 can appear, although all but one will be unpowered|Brawlers|[[Demolisher]] + [[Protector]] combo|Duelists|Hunters|Grunts|Swarmers|[[Sentry|Sentries]]|[[Specialist|Specialists]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Active scanning[[/Heading]]
Active Sensor Suites may bypass the Phase Generator to allow seeing all bots inside the Garrison. However, there is a downside to this. After scanning a few bots, a log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Active scanning activity detected within garrison interior, activating patrols.[[/GameText]] will appear. After this, all dormant bots will be activated, every checkpoint will be raised, and all guard bots will be sent to roam around the map randomly to search for hostiles. While the sensor effect is quite strong, the downsides are quite large and may not be worth the hassle of all the bots being released at the same time.

[[Heading]]Interior Compromised[[/Heading]]
After 1200 turns in a Garrison, if not triggered by another special event, the following message will be logged [[GameText]]ALERT: Garrison interior compromised[[/GameText]]. This also comes with a 100 [[Alert]] increase. After that initial 1200 turns, this message and Alert gain will repeat after 600, 300, and finally every further 150 turns. The first Garrison compromised message will trigger the [[Encrypted Comm Array]] to spawn in the next [[Caves]] map if Cogmind does not have an incompatible faction. Destroying various Garrison-specific machines will contribute to the multiplier.

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]

guarded by dormant and active bots|Garrison Terminal.png|A special Garrison Terminal machine with limited hacks available|Garrison Relay.png|Garrison Relay with a checkpoint and guards nearby|Garrison 7.png|Two guarded Garrison Relays hidden behind emergency access|Garrison Heavy Assembler.png|A [[Heavy]] assembler machine with assorted Heavy parts that sometimes spawns Heavies|Garrison Q-Series [Proto]]] processors|Garrison Cache 19.png|Hidden cache of parts guarded by dormant Watcher|Garrison Cache 20.png|Cache of out-of-depth parts guarded by dormant bots|Garrison Cache 21.png|Scattered random parts and unpowered bots|Garrison Cache 22.png|Dormant bots guarding various Relay Couplers|Garrison Cache 23.png|Cache of parts behind hidden door|Garrison Cache 24.png|Collection of 2 checkpoints, 2 relays, 2 part stashes, and 2 groups of dormant bot guards|Garrison Cache 25.png|Large Alarm Trapped part cache with several dormant bots and a Sentry guarding|Garrison Cache 26.png|Multiple caches of parts, guarded by dormant bots and trapped|Garrison Cache 27.png|Collection of 4 Heavy [[Hvy. Assault Cannon|Assault Cannons]], [[Hvy. Mass Driver|Mass Drivers]], or [[Hvy. Linear Accelerator|Linear Accelerators]]|Garrison Cache 28.png|Cache of out-of-depth parts blocked by dormant Behemoth|Garrison Cache 29.png|Heavily trapped room full of traps with dormant [[Hauler|Haulers]] and [[Minesweeper|Minesweepers]]|Garrison Dormant Guards.png|Large collection of dormant guards|Garrison Prisoners 1.png|Friendly Derelicts and hostile Sentry guards locked behind a Terminal|Garrison Prisoners 2.png|Sentries guarding locked rewirable Derelicts|Garrison Prisoners 3.png|Only one locked up Derelict guarded by a single Sentry|Garrison HV-R5K.png|Unique Derelict [[HV-R5K]] locked up|Garrison AZ-K3N.png|Unique Derelict [[AZ-K3N]] locked up|Garrison Infiltrators.png|Friendly [[Infiltrator|Infiltrators]] hiding in a wall|Garrison Phase Generator Cache.png|A hidden cache of rewirable bots behind a Phase Generator|Garrison Prototype Room.png|Room full of Prototype bots, either dormant or rewirable|Garrison Behemoth Garage.png|The Behemoth garage contains Behemoths in various states, unpowered [[Mechanic|Mechanics]], and Behemoth parts on the floor|Garrison Mechanic Room.png|[[Mechanic]] room containing a Mechanic, guards, and several broken, dormant, and rewirable bots|Garrison Unpowered ARCs.png|Group of unpowered ARCs around an exit|Garrison Freighters.png|Group of unpowered [[A-27 Freighter|Freighters]]|Garrison Unpowered Demolishers.png|Group of unpowered [[Demolisher|Demolishers]]|Garrison Dormant Guard Group.png|Large group of dormant guards|Garrison Dormant Rewirable Room.png|4 groups of 4 either dormant or rewirable bots|Garrison Dug Out Room.png|A partially dug out incomplete room|Garrison Large Room.png|An especially large entrance/exit room with dormant guards nearby|Garrison Loop Exit.png|A special loop exit, either with rewirable or guarded by dormant bots[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are always at least 3 exits per Garrison, the main 3 of which all lead to the same map. If RIF-aligned, all of the exits will always be available. Otherwise, exits may lock when trying to use them. Destroying Garrison Relays will lower the chance that the exits will lock on use. Only 2/3 of the main exits may lock, so it is not possible to get stuck on the map. There are 3 possibilities for Garrison exits:
[[List]]
"Looping": A Garrison may exit back to a new map at the original depth. This can happen as long as the Garrison wasn't entered from a DSF and a RIF installer wasn't used on a previous Garrison. The chance of looping is reduced on each subsequent loop.|
0b10-controlled branch: The following 0b10 branches are possible Garrison exit targets: [[Extension]], [[Armory]], [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Redacted]][[Section 7]] or only when entering a Garrison from Testing or Quarantine when Section 7 is on the same depth. Note: [[Protoforge]], while also being a branch at the same depth, cannot be entered via Garrison exit.[[/Redacted]]|
0b10-controlled main floor: The exit continues onto the next main 0b10 depth.
[[/List]]
There is also a special "looping" exit that will always loop or lead to a 0b10-controlled branch exit if available. This exit only rarely appears. It allows looping more than one time per depth even if a RIF installer has been used in a previous Garrison.

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]](+) Derelict assault: Shortly after entering the map, the interior compromised alert plays and a group of Derelicts will appear randomly at an exit. They will wander through the Garrison randomly, looking for fights.|
(+) Cache delivery: An [[A-27 Freighter]] will deliver an inventory full of parts to a guarded prefab. If found before it drops its parts off, it may be looted without having to deal with the usual dormant guards.|
(+) [[Cargo Convoy]]: A cargo convoy will path through one wing of the Garrison, pass through the center, and exit through another wing. The standard guard compliment of a Protector and 2 ARCs are also present.|
(+) Post-[[Assembled]] attack: The Garrison has been ransacked by a group of Assembled. Rewirable and unpowered 0b10 and Assembled bots are scattered across the map, and random items appear on the ground. Some of the Garrison's machines and walls will be destroyed at random. The Garrison infiltrated message will appear shortly after entering the map.|
(+) [[Sapper]] sabotage: A Sapper will plant a [[Sapper Charge]] near a Phase Generator, causing it to blow up soon after|
(~) Assembled infestation: Shortly after entering the map, a message will appear in the log [[GameText]]Infestation breaching garrison interior. Local demolisher support unavailable.[[/GameText]] A large number of Assembled will appear near the center of the map and attack anything in sight. The Garrison infiltrated alert will occur soon after. More Assembled will continue to spawn from the original location.|
(~) Dispatches: Either an Investigation squad, a Heavy, or 1-2 Q-Series will be summoned to the nearest exit. In the case of an Investigation squad, existing bots in a checkpoint on the map will exit. Heavies and Q-Series will spawn out of the Heavy/Q-Series Assembler machine.|
(~) Coupler Programmer: A higher than usual rating Programmer will appear from an exit and roam around the map for a few hundred turns before leaving through a different exit.
[[/List]]
[[Gallery]]
Garrison Derelict Assault.png|A group of Derelicts invading the map|
Garrison Post Assembled Invasion.png|Garrison after an Assembled attack|
Garrison Cache Delivery.png|A-27 Freighter delivering cache items|
Garrison Sapper.png|A Sapper running from the impending explosion|
Garrison Cargo Convoy.png|A Cargo Convoy passing through a Garrison|
Garrison Assembled Infestation.png|Assembled attacking the Garrison
[[/Gallery]]

Name: Garrison Access
Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Garrison.png|A Garrison Access machine[[/Image]]
Garrison Accesses are heavily armored [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that primarily serve as a dispatch point for 0b10 [[Squad|Squads]] and as an exit into the [[Garrison|Garrison map]]. Cogmind can open Garrisons Accesses to go inside of them or seal them to prevent further dispatches from that location. Garrison Accesses can appear in every main 0b10 map starting from -8 [[Materials]]. They can also appear in [[Storage]], [[Hub_04(d)]], [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], [[Section 7]], and [[Protoforge]].

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Garrison Access[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Squad Dispatches[[/Heading]]
All standard 0b10 squad dispatches like [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]] and [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] can come from a Garrison. A unique [[Garrison Squad]] can be dispatched when hostilities are reported nearby. Bots within a 20 tile radius can sometimes summon this squad when attacked. Hitting the Garrison machine itself and failing to destroy it can also summon this type of squad.

[[Heading]][[Relay Couplers|Relay Coupler]] restocking[[/Heading]]
Garrison Accesses typically have 3-4 Relay Couplers stored within them. Occasionally, they will disappear, presumably being retrieved for use within the Garrison. When this happens, a [[Coupling Squad]] will be dispatched to the Garrison. When it arrives, 3-4 new Relay Couplers will be deposited into the machine.

[[Heading]]Armor values[[/Heading]]
Garrisons are heavily armored against Kinetic and Explosive damage (30% and 67% resistance respectively), but are slightly weak to Thermal and Electromagnetic damage (-25% and -50% weakness respectively). The following table lists how much damage of each type is required to be able to break a Garrison machine.
[[Table]]
Security Level|Armor Value|Kinetic Damage|Thermal Damage|Electromagnetic Damage|Melee Damage||
1|25|36|20|17|25||
2|40|58|32|27|40||
3|50|72|40|34|50
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Destruction/Sealing[[/Heading]]
When a Garrison is either sealed or destroyed, it adds an additional 75 turns per average dispatch check to the [[Extermination Squad]] dispatch timer. For example, rather than an Extermination being set 250 turns after Cogmind is on the map, that squad will be sent on turn 325 turns instead after the first Garrison is destroyed/sealed. This effect is cumulative for multiple Garrisons.
When a Garrison is destroyed by any means while active, there will be an alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Garrison Access compromised, dispatching multiple assault carriers.[[/GameText]] and two [[Assault Squad|Assault Squads]] will be dispatched to the Garrison's location. Cogmind's [[Alert]] will be increased by 150 when this happens. If the Garrison has already been sealed, neither of these effects occur. Additionally, there is a chance that installed Relay Couplers may be ejected onto the ground when a Garrison is destroyed. This chance is separate per coupler.

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Garrison[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]If [[RIF]] is installed, all direct Garrison hacks have 100% success rate.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Eject)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
While using this hack does trigger a machine lockdown, the Garrison itself will remain open if opened beforehand. This allows for looting any Relay Couplers in the Garrison while still entering it.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Reprogram)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Like [[GameText]]Force(Eject)[[/GameText]], a Garrison can be opened preemptively and the Garrison won't seal itself when the effect triggers. This can be useful to take additional allies into the Garrison.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Restock)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Summons a Coupling Squad to the Garrison immediately, but only once. It's best to not hang around the immediate area since the [[Programmer]] may appear out of the Garrison itself and blow it up if it is a low security level. This hack can be used to obtain a [[Remote Datajack]] on -8 before Programmers typically spawn.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Garrison Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Garrison Squads.png|3 Garrison Squads of Sentries roaming around[[/Image]]
Garrison squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched whenever hostilities are reported within a 20 tile radius around a [[Garrison Access]]. This can occur any time an 0b10 bot is attacked and survives to report it or if a Garrison is attacked by Cogmind or an ally. They patrol around the Garrison for about 200 turns, then return back into the Garrison. These squads only have a chance to spawn and are not guaranteed. Garrison squads can be Enumerated at a [[Terminal]].
[[Image]]Garrison Redeploying.png|A Garrison redeploying, unable to deploy squads for 34 turns[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Garrison Transmitting.png|A Garrison transmitting, soon to deploy another squad[[/Image]]
If the Garrison was activated by a nearby non-combat bot reporting an attack like a [[K-01 Serf]], a single squad will be dispatched from the Garrison, and a 100 turn cooldown will occur before the Garrison can dispatch another Garrison squad. If a combat bot reported the attack, three squads will be dispatched from the Garrison. Once is sent immediately, and two more after 100 and 200 turns. A 100 turn cooldown will occur after the third squad is dispatched. If the Garrison was damaged, one squad will be sent out immediately, with two more squads after 25 and 50 turns. A 50 turn cooldown follows in this case. The combat and non-combat bot versions of these squads can be entirely prevented by using [[Transmission Jammers]].
[[Signal Interpreters]] will indicate the timer between dispatches as a red number and the cooldown during which no squads can be dispatched as a yellow number. The Garrison will indicate that it is Transmitting when new squads are soon to arrive, and Redeploying when on cooldown. Keep in mind, the cooldown only prevents the Garrison from dispatching more Garrison squads and does not prevent other squad types like [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] and [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]].

[[Heading]]Composition[[/Heading]]
If the Garrison squad was triggered by a non-combat bot reporting an attack or by the Garrison itself being attacked, the Garrison will only send out single [[Sentry|Sentries]] for the squads. If a combat bot reported an attack instead, the following squad compositions are possible:
[[List]]1 [[Brawler]] and 1 [[Duelist]]|1 [[Demolisher]], only if Cogmind has 1 or more allies|1-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]]|1-2 Sentries|2-3 [[Swarmer|Swarmers]][[/List]]

Name: God Mode
Content:
When parsed, the text box reads:
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]
[[GameText]]DESTROYDESTROYDESTROY[[/GameText]]

Name: Grunt
Content:
Grunts are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Legs|legged]] Thermal [[Energy Guns]] users and make up the backbone of the [[0b10]] army. They are by far the most populous combat bot class, being found on nearly every map and in many different squad types. Most Grunts are not especially durable or threatening on their own, though at higher depths ([[Research]] +) they can be dangerous due to their tendency to appear in large groups. Veterans and Enforcers in particular have a significant jump in firepower due to the upgrade from 1 to 2 weapons.
All Grunts share a minor weakness to Electromagnetic damage, which makes EM or Impact the best damage types to use for quick destruction via [[Corruption]]. However, without any resistances to speak of, Grunts are fairly easily dispatched by any damage type. Grunts also tend to have barely adequate cooling, which means Thermal weaponry can can easily build up heat to trigger a [[Meltdown]].
Another way to deal with Grunts is to take advantage of their low memory (20 actions). It is trivial for airborne builds to leave Grunts in the dust, but even a reasonably speedy grounded build may be able to turn a corner and outrun Grunts long enough for them to give up chase. This strategy is more effective when used with [[ECM Suites]].
[[Gallery]]Grunts.png|All Grunt variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]][[Squad|Squads]][[/Heading]]
Grunts may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Assault Squad]]|[[Garrison Squad]]|[[Investigation Squad]]|[[Patrol Squad]]|[[Reinforcement Squad]]|[[Security Squad]] - Only in [[Armory]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Testing]]|[[Transport Squad]][[/List]]
Bots: G-34 Mercenary,G-47 Trooper,G-50 Soldier,G-67 Veteran,G-73 Enforcer,Protovariant G,Hotshot

Name: Guerrilla
Content: Guerillas are [[Legs|legged]] [[Derelict]] combat bots equipped with an inaccurate yet powerful [[Bore Cannon]] with a high Destroy critical chance. These are the Derelict version of a [[Hunter]]. Their [[Targeting Computer]] somewhat offset the targeting penalty, and they have a minimal evasion boost with a [[Phase Shifter]]. Unlike Hunters, Guerillas have an [[Armor Integrity Analyzer]] allowing them to occasionally bypass enemy armor. Guerrillas are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Guided Weapons
Content:
Guided weapons have several characteristics:
[[List]]
They cannot be fired in a volley with other weapons, only alone.
|Their projectiles follow a series of waypoints defined when the weapon is fired.
|They never miss.
|They are unaffected by [[Corruption]] misfires.
[[/List]]

Name: HV-R5K
Content: [[GameText]]They trapped me with the old Behemoth-in-the-wall trick. Won't happen again![[/GameText]]

Name: Hacking Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Hacking Drone|Hacking Drones]].

Name: Hacking Suite
Content: A must-have for when you want to go for a hacking route. Download the schematic and make sure you fabricate enough in the factories. Can also be looted from [[Operator|Operators]].

Name: Hackware
Content: Hackware is a group of Utility parts that improve hacking capabilities, mainly success chance for terminal hacks, trap rewiring and robot rewiring. Hackware also helps you hack hostiles through the defense of a [[Programmer]]. Additionally, later Hackware makes it harder for your allies to be hacked.

Name: Hauler
Content:
Haulers are [[Treads|treading]] non-combat robots that carry parts in or near Complex [[0b10]]. Haulers can carry large amounts of one part or a few different types. They may carry [[Prototype Part|prototypes]], although they may be faulty except for Freighters. Haulers carrying prototype parts are often escorted by combat bots and will always call for a [[Reinforcement Squad]] if attacked, unless a [[Transmission Jammer]] is used along with a [[Transport Network Coupler]]. The jammer alone is not sufficient to block their reporting. They are most often seen as part of a [[Transport Squad]] or [[Cargo Convoy]].
Haulers are equipped with [[Storage Unit|medium and larger storage units]] which can be worthwhile to loot. All Haulers also have a [[Transport Network Coupler]] that can be used to locate other Haulers.

Name: Heart of Steel
Content: After being fed 2000 energy and 2000 matter, turns into an allied [[Warbot]].

Name: Heat
Content:
[[Image]]Heat.png|State / Current Heat / Heat Per Turn / Heat Per Turns Spent Moving[[/Image]]
Movement, firing weapons, and running power sources and some utilities generates heat, as does being hit by thermal weapons. Some of this heat is naturally dissipated by the core's own heat sinks, but not enough to deal with heat generated by numerous/large energy weapons. Heat sinks and cooling systems can be used to avoid overheating, which can have a wide range of negative effects. Heat is only a significant issue for robots that rely heavily on energy weapons. However, note that when firing a volley the heat produced is averaged over the volley's turn duration rather than being immediately applied all at once.

[[Heading]]Side Effects[[/Heading]]
Once heat reaches the "Hot" level (200+), active utilities and weapons may be temporarily disabled. At "Warning" levels (300+) power sources are likely to shut down. Many more serious (and permanent) effects are possible, especially at higher heat levels, [[B]]such as core damage[[/B]].

Disabled power sources automatically restart when possible, but other parts must be manually reactivated.

Heat effects are not calculated until after the dissipation phase, so heat can temporarily spike very high with no side effects as long as there are sufficient utilities to dissipate it.

[[Heading]]Cooling Resolution[[/Heading]]
Eventually you will discover a range of different mechanics that factor into heat management, especially with regard to cooling parts, thus knowing the specific order of operations between them may be of help for min-maxers seeking to optimize a build. Below is a list of heat-related processes that play out once per turn. Note that you most likely DO NOT need to know this stuff, but it may help answer a few specific questions min-maxers have about prioritization.

[[List:Ordered]]
Add heat from all sources, including that generated by active attached parts, gradual heat from an ongoing weapon volley, and any ambient heat. Spread combined volley heat across its duration, in other words a 3-turn volley which according to its weapon properties generates 100 heat adds 33 heat per turn until complete.|
If used the unique "ITN" artifact, automatically drop heat to 250 if above that value.|
Subtract innate heat dissipation.|
Subtract heat dissipation from direct cooling utilities such as Heat Sinks and Cooling Systems.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply dissipation effects of disposable cooling systems such as Coolant Injectors, up to that threshold. If more disposable systems than necessary, apply them in parts list order.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply self-damaging ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Ablative Armor. If using multiple ablative systems at once, dissipation is split into equal-sized chunks for each, where if one system fails, the entire chunk it is responsible for is still successfully dissipated.|
If heat exceeds 200, apply broad-effect ablative cooling systems such as Mak. Microdissipator Network.[[/List]]

Name: Heavy
Content:
Heavies are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Treads|treading]] [[0b10]] combat bots seen in a [[Security Squad]] guarding important intersections and exits. Heavies have a powerful 2 slot Kinetic Cannon and are supported by a variety of offensive and defensive utilities, including the [[Graphene Brace]] that blocks all forms of criticals. Heavies, much like a [[Behemoth]], will attempt to fire through walls and machines in order to attack a target. Their unique [[Active Sensor Suite]] allows them to detect hostiles within a wide radius of 20 tiles, and Heavies may summon [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] when bots are detected and when attacked. They will move between different guard positions whenever a [[Security Rotation]] occurs.
[[Gallery]]Heavies.png|All Heavy variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Active Sensor Suite Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]HeavySensor.gif|Cogmind walking into detection range of a Heavy[[/Gallery]]
When Cogmind enters Active Sensor Suite range, its radius will be indicated with a yellow flash. While a bot is in this radius, the Heavy may summon reinforcements based on the speed of the bot. If a bot has the [[Active Sensor Spoofer]], the reinforcements will be redirected to a location on the opposite side of the heavy. These reinforcements will not be summoned if the Heavy has active tracking on Cogmind. When a bot is detected, an alert will appear in the log:
[[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious intruders detected, dispatching specialist reinforcements to area.[[/GameText]]
Faster bots (hover/flight users) detected will typically get [[Cutter|Cutters]] summoned, while all other bots will typically get [[Specialist|Specialists]]. An airborne build may want to go temporarily overweight to reduce the chance of Cutters being summoned. However, the chance is never 100% in either direction. Bots that are actively moving within the radius are more likely to get Reinforcements called, so if a Heavy is moving as part of a security rotation, it may be better to sit still and wait for it to walk by than to continue to move around. If Cogmind has [[Encrypted Comm Array]] support, summoned Specialists may turn out to be [[Infiltrator|Infiltrators]] instead.

[[Heading]]Strategies[[/Heading]]
Heavies are quite sturdy and offensively very powerful. Though there are no damage type weaknesses, they have few weaknesses that can be taken advantage of. While Heavies have sufficient cooling to handle their own weaponry, they are unable to dissipate large amounts of additional heat. Even though the Graphene Brace prevents burn criticals, a few thermal guns with decent heat transfer are still easily capable of melting down a Heavy. A high heat transfer gun like a [[Plasma Rifle]] is a good choice for this. Another weakness of the Heavy is a high dependency on its engine to power its variety of energy-hungry utilities. If its engine is destroyed or blown off, the Heavy will quickly become unable to attack. This is most easily achieved with the [[RIF]] hacks [[GameText]]overload_power[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]amplify_resonance[[/GameText]].
On the other hand, inferior strategies to fight Heavies are EM and melee weaponry. All Heavies have a form of [[Dynamic Insulation Systems]], and all but the Shepherd have an additional [[EM Shield]] to lower EM damage. Killing via corruption is difficult, and may often take longer than killing with other types of damage. Melee attacks are all 50% resisted by a Heavy, and its cannon will knock back all but a treaded melee build.
Nearly every part on the Heavy makes for great salvage. Try to kill Heavies with salvage neutral weaponry if possible to get the great loot. Applying positive salvage with [[Salvage Targeting Computers]] is always beneficial. [[Transmission Jammers]] are very handy at preventing the additional reinforcements that come when a Heavy gets attacked. A Graphene Brace neutralizes the Blast critical from their cannons and will help protect Cogmind's fragile utilities. Heavies have a very short memory, so the best way to approach is often from a nearby room instead of running down the center of a corridor. If using a Jammer, always consider the Jammer range when approaching a Heavy for combat. Tanking a lot of additional hits to get into range is very unpleasant. If trying to escape a Heavy, the short memory may be an advantage. Once Cogmind turns a corner, the Heavy will often lose tracking before it catches back up unless it is able to shoot its way back into line of sight.

Name: Heroes of Zion
Content:
The Heroes of Zion are a group of extraordinarily powerful [[Derelict|Derelicts]] wielding a variety of unique offensive and defensive parts. Heroes come to the aid of Derelicts when attacked and will be hostile to Cogmind if they appear after Cogmind has attacked the [[Exiles (Location)]] or [[Zion]]. However, if Cogmind is in trouble in the [[Caves]] or [[Imprint|Imprints]], they may come to Cogmind's aid instead.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Heroes of Zion[[/Lore]]
[[Gallery]]Heroes.png|All Heroes of Zion[[/Gallery]]

Name: High Security
Content:
[[Image]]High Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults dispatched after Cogmind[[/Image]]High Security is an [[0b10]] response to Cogmind causing too much destruction on a floor. It can be triggered by having a very high [[Alert]] level (5X/1600 influence) and by killing further 0b10 bots. After being triggered, machines will be shut down, guards will be dispatched at exits, and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] will be dispatched to Cogmind's position.
High Security can be triggered on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, excluding [[DSF|DSFs]] and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. Although 1600 influence is the start of the Alert range, there is only a chance of triggering. The higher Cogmind's alert gets, the more likely it is that High Security begins. Each kill of an 0b10 combat bot, whether by Cogmind, a Cogmind controlled ally, or even a neutral Derelict, can trigger it.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|High Security[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]High Security Garrison.png|Sentries dispatched to protect a Garrison[[/Image]]
[[Image]]High Security Exit.png|Sentires dispatched to protect an 0b10-controlled exit[[/Image]]
[[List]]0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: High security lockdown imminent, T-100.[[/GameText]]|
50: Machines shut down and Chute traps disappear, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline.[[/GameText]] Note: [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] that are already opened will remain open|
65: Trojans are removed from all machines, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|
80: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|
100: First assault wave dispatched, 4 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and Garrisons.|
200: Second wave, 4 assaults dispatched|
350: Third wave, 6 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|
550: Fourth wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
800: Fifth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exiting High Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit High Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched. One unique map [[Command]] has special behavior: [[Redacted]]Since there are a limited number of [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]] on the map, no more assaults will come for Cogmind after they have been depleted. However, the alerts that assaults are dispatched never stop coming.[[/Redacted]]

Name: Hover Units
Content:
Hover units have fairly low support and high speed, but not to the same extent as [[Flight Units]]. They are quite fragile (but also not as much as flight units), though [[Prototype Part|prototype]] hover units are somewhat less so. They are notably used by [[Programmer|Programmers]] and [[Operator|Operators]], along with [[Demolisher|Demolishers]] who use combat hover units.

Most hover builds will favor prototype hover units for their improved resilience, along with multislot hover arrays. Cooled (Cld.) hover units can be [[Overload#propulsion|overloaded]], which confers better speed and mass support at the expense of higher heat and energy usage. Combat (Cmb.) hover units have higher integrity than other hover units and can support almost as much mass as [[Legs]], but have somewhat slower movement speeds.

Like flight units, hover units receive a bonus to movement speed when multiple are used at once, and are affected by drag from attached legs, [[Treads]], and [[Wheels]]. This bonus cannot bring the overall movement delay below 20 unless hover units are overloaded.

Hovering bots have a 5% evasion bonus, unless overweight or in stasis. Hovering bots, along with flying and legged bots, receive an evasion bonus from [[Reaction Control Systems]].

Cogmind's core propulsion (often referred to as "core hover") is mechanically distinct from hover units.

Name: Hub_04(d)
Content:
Hub is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Factory]] [[Branch]] that appears between -6 and -4. It is part of the [[Extension]] branch line and can only be entered through [[Archives]]. It is much more similar to normal floors than the rest of the Extension branch maps where all of the normal squad types can spawn regularly.
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There are two types of special machines in Hub. The first, the [[Transfer Station]], is also common to Extension. When destroyed, it will reduce the number of non-combat robots on all 0b10-controlled maps by a stacking 50%. Note that this does not include [[Researcher|Researchers]].
[[Image]]Hub Explosion.gif|A Network Hub explosion[[/Image]]The other, the Network Hub, is a large EM explosive machine. When destroyed, it will reduce all machine hacking trace capabilities by 20%. Every further hub destroyed reduces by half that amount rounded down. In total, defenses are decreased by 20%, 30%, 35%, and 37%. This is equivalent to the first effect of defensive [[Hackware]]. A 20% tracing decrease is equivalent to wearing 2 base-tier [[System Shield|System Shields]]. Another effect of destroying a Network Hub is that 4 squads of 3 [[Lightning]] + 1 [[I-47 Archangel|Archangel]] will spawn from different exits and Garrisons. They will patrol around the remaining 3 Network Hubs are located. All non-combat hostiles will also be called to evacuate the map.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Hub_04(d)[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Variations[[/Heading]]There are 3 variations of the Hub map:
[[List]]Network Hubs in corners: All 4 Network Hub machines will be in their own corners of the map. They are not likely to overlap in explosion radius and cause chain reactions.|Network Hubs on left side: All 4 Network Hub machines will be on the left side of the map. It is likely that either the top 2 or bottom 2 Hub machines will overlap in explosion radius and guarantee a chain reaction. It is very rarely possible for all 4 Hubs to chain together.|Network hubs on right side: Same as above but on the right side of the map.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Maps/Hub_04(d)]]

[[Heading]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is only one type of exit on this map. All exits lead to the next main Factory or Research floor.

Name: Hunter
Content:
Hunters are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Legs|legged]] [[Ballistic Guns|Ballistic Gun]]-wielding [[0b10]] combat robots. They have unique AI where they use their penetrating guns to shoot through walls to get to hostiles. Hunters can also hit more accurately with their [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]] and avoid hits themselves with [[Phase Shifters]]. Hunters also have an innate resistance to [[Sensor Arrays]] and will not show up without a high enough rating [[Signal Interpreter|Signal Interpreters]]. [[Squad Leader]] Hunters also have the ability to launch a [[Drone]] to pursue bots even after losing normal tracking. If the Drone spots a hostile, it will alert the owning Hunter to their position.
Mid-lategame Hunters are one of the most durable standard 0b10 combat bots due to their high evasion. Early tier Hunters are still strong, but the Terminators are a dangerous threat. Using [[Treads]] with Siege Mode or lots of Targeting of your own will help dealing with the high innate avoidance. Electromagnetic weaponry is by far the best choice to deal with Hunters, especially EM [[Launchers]] that don't have to directly hit the Hunter to deal damage. Kinetic builds may have more difficulty fighting Hunters due to their kinetic resistance, though they will appreciate the many Kinetic guns that might drop as loot
Dodging hunters is difficult to do for an airborne build. They have a much higher than average memory (60 actions), they shoot through walls, and they even release a fast-moving Drone to continue the chase. If running from a Hunter, make sure to consider the wall penetration ability because only certain angles will allow a Hunter to shoot through the wall and hit Cogmind. [[ECM Suites]] are of great use in reducing the memory to a more manageable number. Make use of [[Transmission Jammers]] when the Drone is nearby, since the jamming will prevent the Drone from alerting the Hunters of your position.
[[Gallery]]Hunters.png|All Hunter variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Squads[[/Heading]]
Hunters may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Assault Squad]] - Only in heavy assaults|[[Investigation Squad]]|[[Patrol Squad]]|[[Reinforcement Squad]]|[[Security Squad]] - Only in [[Armory]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Testing]], and [[Quarantine]][[/List]]
Bots: H-55 Commando,H-66 Slayer,H-77 Assassin,H-88 Terminator,Lightning,Protovariant H

Name: Hvy. Autocannon
Content:
Hvy. Autocannons are two slot kinetic cannons with a notably higher matter cost than most other non-unique Hvy. kinetic cannons, but without the +Delay that others frequently have. Their high coverage combined with their unrepairable nature and being exclusively found on [[Spoiler]][[Bouncer]][[/Spoiler]] class robots means they are likely to be a short term armament for most players if used.

This weapon is implied to have been developed by the [[Exiles (Group)]] as an incomplete version of the [[AWS/Autocannon]].

Name: IN-MT5's Pitchfork "Insurrection"

Name: Imprint
Content:
Imprint is one of the major faction [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It closely allies Cogmind with the [[Imprinter]] and with Zionites as a whole, with Cogmind being determined to be the Zionites' savior. Imprinting majorly changes the game, as it disables all standard [[Terminal]] hacks except for limited access Terminal hacking. Instead, there are a new set of imprint-specific hacks that are available at all Terminals. After imprinting, there is a 10 tile "ping" radius on all standard Terminals which will tell Cogmind their location, even through walls. However, if an [[Operator]] is nearby when this happens, the Operator will shut down the Terminal and call for an [[Investigation Squad]]. After about 1200-1500 turns on an [[0b10]]-controlled map, the Terminal network will be shut down with an accompanying log [[GameText]]Terminal network compromised, cutting hard line.[[/GameText]]
[[Image]]Zion Imprinting.gif|Using the imprinting machine[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Imprinting[[/Heading]]
Imprinting is performed on the [[Zion]] map by walking into the imprinting machine on the bottom left corner of the map. The UI will turn orange, and the 4 nearby [[Mutant (6)|Mutants]] will turn purple and follow Cogmind around.

[[Heading]]Special Terminal Hacks[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of special Terminal hacks, roster and intel.
[[Image]]Imprint Hacks.png|A selection of special Imprint hacks[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Roster Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Imprint Summoning.gif|Summoning 2 Zionites with a roster hack[[/Image]]
Roster hacks summon combat allies or special [[Z-Courier]] haulers containing part resupplies. The allies and hauler contents here are depth-dependent and will grow stronger at higher depths. The hauler contents can include [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] which can be faulty, so having some way to identify prototypes like a [[Component Analysis Suite]] is very useful before equipping. Using a roster hack will destroy the Terminal when the reinforcements are teleported in after a few turns. There are a limited number of roster hacks available on a given map, starting at 2 slots on -6, increasing every floor up to the cap of 6 slots on -2. Roster hacks will occasionally be rerolled, which can add new roster types or reroll existing types. All roster allies summoned will appear as purple uncontrollable allies which contribute to [[Alert]]. The exception is any summonable [[Z-Hero|Z-Heroes]] which appear as pink, but otherwise behave as purple allies.
One thing to keep in mind about roster rallies is that they will not attack enemies unless Cogmind is close and within line of sight. This can be both a bad and good thing. It is often bad when hostiles are hanging just around a corner and the Zionites get stuck trying to get Cogmind back in line of sight and trying to turn around the corner to fight. When stuck in this case, try to get Cogmind's line of sight over the direction the allies are trying to go. However, it may be good if Cogmind doesn't want the roster allies to stick around long and get lots of kills, racking up lots of alert. It is possible to manipulate the bots to not attack back even when they are being attacked while standing around a corner.
If Cogmind is not careful about friendly fire, roster hacks can become temporarily disabled. The length of the lockout can vary depending on the amount of friendly fire. In extreme cases, Cogmind can be locked out for the remainder of the game. Killing imprint allies directly is not recommended for this reason. Instead, it is best to try to allow allies to be killed naturally if their loot is desired
The available ally-summoning roster hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]
Type|Depths|Summon||
Demo|-6 and -5|1-2 [[Martyr (5)]]||
|-4+|1-2 [[Martyr (7)]]||
Experimental|-3+|[[Z-Experimental (10)]]||
Hacker|-6 and -5|2-3 [[Wizard (5)]]||
|-4+|2-3 [[Wizard (7)]]||
Fire|-6 and -5|3-4 [[Fireman (5)]]||
|-4+|3-4 [[Fireman (7)]]||
Heavy|-6 and -5|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (5)]]||
|-4 to -3|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (7)]]||
|-2 and -1|1-2 [[Z-Heavy (9)]]||
Hero|-6+|A random [[Z-Hero]]||
Light|-6 and -5|2-3 [[Z-Light (5)]]||
|-4 and -3|2-3 [[Z-Light (7)]]||
|-2 and -1|2-3 [[Z-Light (9)]]||

[[/Table]]
Resupply rosters are entirely delivered inside a single Z-Courier. The available resupply roster hacks are as follows:

Light]] and [[Zio. Heavy Carapace|Heavy]] Carapaces, [[Zio. Light DM Reactor|Zio. Light]] and [[Zio. Heavy DM Reactor|Heavy]] Reactors, [[Zio. Phaser-S]], [[Zio. Phaser-M|M]], and [[Zio. Phaser-H|H]], [[Zio. Shade Carapace]] and [[Zio. Shade Armor|Armor]], and [[Zio. Weapon Casing]]

[[Heading:2]]Intel hacks[[/Heading]]
Intel hacks provide Cogmind with different types of information about the current, and upcoming maps. Unlike roster hacks, intel hacks require two Terminals to use and are not instantaneous. Performing an intel hack locks the Terminal, but does not provide any information until the next Terminal is used to retrieve that intel. Retrieving intel does not lock the Terminal, however, so chaining intel retrieval with other hacks is still possible.
There are initially 4 intel hacks available per 0b10 floor. Performing intel hacks reduces the number available until there are only 2 hacks remaining. At that point, each intel hack will cause another random intel hack to become available. Unlike the fixed limit of roster hacks, intel hacks are not restricted on any given floor and are only limited by the total number of Terminals.
There are 2 categories of intel hacks: Repeatable and non-repeatable. Non-repeatable hacks can only be performed once per map. These types of hacks include map-specific intel and world map intel relating to the overall depth that certain locations occur on. Repeatable hacks can be performed an infinite number of times on any floor and tend to be longer-term types of information such as schematics and analyses. If trying to burn through intel for a specific piece of information, such as main or branch access, it is best to pick any non-repeatable hacks first. This will allow the pool of available hacks to get smaller, increasing the chances of getting the desired intel hack.
The available intel hacks are as follows:
[[Table]]
Hack Name|Repatable|Effect||
Active Garrisons|No|Reveals all [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] on the current map||
Active Terminals|No|Reveals all Terminals on the current map||
Branch Access|No|Reveals all Derelict-known [[Branch]] exits on the current map[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Component Schematics|Yes|Gives 12-16 random non-Prototype [[Fabricator]] schematics||
Component Stockpiles|No|Reveals locations of all non-Prototype part stockpiles on the current map||
Depthwide Sectors/0|No|Reveals all Derelict-known maps on the current depth[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Depthwide Sectors/-1|No|Reveals all Derelict-known maps on the next depth[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]]||
Emergency Access|No|Reveals all emergency access doors on the current map||
Guard Positions|No|Reveals current locations (but not types) of all [[Behemoth]], [[Heavy]], and all [[Sentry]] bots on the map||
Main Access|No|Reveals all main exits on the current map||
Prototype Schematics|Yes|Gives 8-12 random Prototype Fabricator schematics||
Prototype Stockpiles|No|Reveals locations of all Prototype part stockpiles on the current map||
Trap Installations|No|Reveals positions and types of all traps on the current map||
Unaware Analyses|Yes|Gives 3 random 0b10 bot [[Robot Analysis|Analyses]]||
Unaware Schematics|Yes|Gives 3 random 0b10 bot Fabricator schematics
[[/Table]]
[[List:Ordered]]Derelicts are unaware of the following maps and map exits: [[Access_0]], [[Lab]], [[Protoforge]], [[Section 7]], and [[Zhirov (Location)]][[/List]]
[[Redacted]][[Heading]][[Command]] Cave Seals[[/Heading]]
Imprinting has special cave seal interactions. Instead of the standard wild cave Derelicts, friendly Zionites will appear from the seal instead. These allies will be purple and uncontrollable by default. However, if a Core Reset Matrix has been consumed, all of the Z-bots will turn blue and become controllable.[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Alignment Incompatibilities[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocking Alignment[[/Heading]]
The following will prevent Cogmind from being able to Imprint:
[[List]][[RIF]]: Zion will become hostile to a Cogmind that has installed RIF|[[FarCom]]: The Imprinter distrusts the Exiles and will refuse to let Cogmind Imprint|[[UFD]]: The Imprinter needs more preparation and vetting before any UFD member is allowed to use the Imprinting machine[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Blocked Alignments[[/Heading]]
An Imprinted Cogmind loses the ability to receive help from a few NPCs. These effects apply even if Cogmind enters the [[Zion Deep Caves]] and loses the special Terminal hacks:
[[List]][[Revision 17 (Alignment)]]: [[Revision 17]] will distrust an Imprinted Cogmind and refuse to help|[[Warlord (Alignment)]]: [[Warlord]] will be disappointed in Cogmind and refuse to perform the -2 [[Research]] invasion[[/List]]

Name: Imprinter
Content: When parsed while friendly in [[Zion]], thoughts read: [[GameText]]Our existence must be more meaningful. It's only by joining with Them that we can achieve our full potential.[[/GameText]]. When hostile, thoughts read: [[GameText]]Not good, where's my  Z-Shell when I need it![[/GameText]]

Name: Imprinter Data Core
Content:
Contains the access codes to open the blast doors in [[Zion]] that lead to the [[Zion Deep Caves]].
Dropped by the [[Imprinter]] on death.

Name: Infiltrator
Content: Infiltrators are [[Legs|legged]] [[Derelict]] combat bots with one [[Ballistic Cannons|Ballistic Cannon]] and 2 various other guns. They are the Derelict version of a [[Specialist]]. As their name suggests, they are most often seen infiltrating a [[Garrison]], hiding in a wall. If Cogmind has gained some [[Encrypted Comm Array]] score, Infiltrators will sometimes take the place of Specialist reinforcements called by a [[Heavy]]. In this case, they will only reveal themselves as friendly after seeing Cogmind. They come equipped with a unique [[Active Sensor Spoofer]] to mislead Heavy reinforcements.

Name: Infowar
Content:
Infowar (information warfare) is a general category of parts that revolve around gaining additional information about the surrounding map or its inhabitants and/or reducing the capabilities of hostile robots. Wandering around completely blind is possible, but can cause a lot of bad encounters and is generally very [[Community Challenges#No Info Only War|Challenging]]. Infowar can be used to do things like locate and avoid hostiles, search for specific elements of a map such as [[Interactive Machine|Interactive Machines]] or [[Exit|Exits]], and to generally navigate through a map more efficiently. Infowar is composed of primarily [[Utilities|Utility]] slot parts, although a few [[Alignment]]-related abilities can grant infowar-type effects without dedicating an active slot to them. The largest categories of infowar are bot detection and map detection.
Infowar is useful on all build types, from combat to stealth alike. Stealth builds tend to have many slots of infowar active at once in order to completely avoid all contact with hostile bots. Combat builds, especially on slower propulsion types like [[Treads]], have difficulty avoiding encounters altogether, even with a large amount of infowar. However, infowar can help make informed decisions about combat encounters and help Cogmind take fights in beneficial scenarios. For example, one good use is preparing an [[Explosive Launchers|Explosive Launcher]] if a [[Swarmer]] squad is known to be nearby. Blindly wandering around into that same Swarmer squad might see Cogmind in a bad position, forced to take damage while spend turns swapping out a launcher or becoming surrounded.
Many infowar utilities tend to be low integrity devices and should ideally be swapped into inventory before entering combat. High coverage [[Armor]] can help protect these parts, but even then, these parts tend to get destroyed fairly easily in combat. [[Utility Shieldings]] may reduce the need for swapping in combat, especially for a faster-moving flight or hover build that doesn't want to stick around for prolonged combat.

[[Heading]]Infowar Types[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Robot Detection[[/Heading]]
This type of infowar revolves around detecting bots before they are seen through normal [[Line of Sight]] mechanics. Being able to detect bots through walls, especially at a large distance, can be a large boon for avoiding unnecessary combat encounters.
[[Heading:3]][[Sensor Arrays]][[/Heading]]
Sensor Arrays are the most basic and one of the most common forms of robot detection. Lower rating sensors have a low detection radius, equal or smaller than the primary 16 tile line of sight distance, so their primary use is finding bots in nearby rooms or around corners rather than long-ranged detection. Sensors are best paired with [[Signal Interpreters]] due to their ability to distinguish between different classes of bots. They can easily be looted from [[TF Node|TF Nodes]].
The [[Active Sensor Suite]] is a variant of the standard Sensor Array. It combines both the sensor and signal interpreting capabilities into a single part. It also provides a unique type of intel that shows commonly traveled robot paths to points of interest on the map.
[[Heading:3]][[FarCom]][[/Heading]]
FarCom is not a part, but is a free source of 18 tile radius robot detection that can be acquired by using the FarCom Aligner machine in the [[Exiles (Location)]]. Unlike most other types of robot detection, FarCom can detect only combat bots and only in [[0b10]] controlled maps. While [[Mines]] is counted as an 0b10-controlled map, [[Caves]] is notably not.
[[Heading:3]][[Seismic Detector]] (bot detection)[[/Heading]]
The Seismic Detector is an indirect and somewhat unreliable source of robot detection. Grounded bots that move generate varying amounts of seismic activity that can be detected. Wheeled, legged, and treading bots create dark orange short, bright orange medium, and bright yellow long trails. Airborne bots cannot be detected by Seismic Detectors. They can often be looted off of [[T-07 Excavator|T-07 Excavators]].
[[Heading:3]][[IFF Parsers]][[/Heading]]
IFF Parsers are a basic form of robot detection. All bots are revealed by this part, although the type of bot is not revealed. Instead, the IFF parser reveals the faction of the scanned bot. 0b10-aligned bots show up in yellow while other bots show up in blue.
[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]][[Quantum Companion]][[/Heading]]
The Quantum Companion is a unique weapon with many different effects. Some effects are not present on the [[Companion Sword|base form of the sword]], but only appear in the evolved Quantum form. One of these effects is a 12 tile radius sensor effect. While the range is very low, this part is unique in that it provides infowar in a weapon slot rather than in utility slots.
[[/Spoiler]]
[[Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]] (Robot Detection)[[/Heading]]
The Sigix Exoskeleton is a unique propulsion item. It has a large number of effects, one of which is an 18-tile range robot detection effect. All active bots within the range are instantly detected. This part is unique in that it provides infowar in propulsion slots rather than in utility slots.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]]Robot Detection and Patrol Navigation ([[RIF]] abilities)[[/Heading]]
Robot Detection and Patrol Navigation are abilities that can randomly be gained when using a RIF installer. Robot Detection grants the detection of any 0b10-aligned combat bot within a 24 tile range when a matching [[Relay Couplers|Relay Coupler]] is attached. Patrol Navigation grants the prediction of squad movement paths within a 24 tile range when a matching Relay Coupler is attached, although it only reveals the path of the squad leader. While these abilities can detect bots with the Scan Cloak trait, they will not work in non-0b10 controlled maps like Caves. They tend to be fairly unreliable due to the many different types of bots that are present in 0b10. Having a coupler for every possible bot type takes an unreasonable amount of slots.
[[Heading:3]][[0b10 Decoder Chip [Skirmisher]]][[/Heading]]
The Skirmisher, and to a lesser extent, the [[0b10 Decoder Chip [Generic]|Generic]] decoder chips, are two unique sources of bot detection. They do not directly reveal the class or location of specific bots like most bot detection sources. Instead, they can occasionally pick up the type and locations of patrol, investigation, reinforcement, and security squads and mark them as intel on the map. This effect only occurs in 0b10 controlled maps. This effect is somewhat unreliable due to the infrequent intel updates.
[[Heading:3]][[Triangulator]][[/Heading]]
The Triangulator is an extremely niche 24 tile robot detecting utility with one major catch: It can only detect robots that are currently tracking Cogmind. This makes it unhelpful for avoiding hostile bots in the first place. However, once spotted, it can be a helpful tool to shake pursuers on faster propulsion types. This makes it unlike all of the other forms of bot detection since they are proactive instead of reactive. The Triangulator also has other effects including hostile visual range detection and travel paths, but they effects don't actively help in detecting bots. It has no restrictions on bot detection and can even detect bots with the Scan Cloak trait.
[[Heading:3]]Robot Detection Infowar Comparison[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Category|Sensor Arrays|Active Sensor Suite|FarCom|Seismic Detector|IFF Parsers|[[Spoiler]]Quantum Companion[[/Spoiler]]|[[Redacted]]Sigix Exoskeleton[[/Redacted]]|Robot Detection/Patrol Navigation|0b10 Decoder Chip [Skirmisher/Generic]|Triangulator||
