[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Terrain Scanning[[/Heading]]
This type of infowar revolves around detecting nearby terrain, especially exits, rooms, and machines. Terrain scanning can make traversal through a map more efficient and easier. When combined with robot detection, hostile squads can often be bypassed entirely with a safe path out of sight.
[[Heading:3]][[Terrain Scanners]][[/Heading]]
Terrain scanners are the basic form of terrain scanning that reveal a random selection of nearby tiles nearby. The basic rate of terrain scanning is very low and only reveals up to a few tiles per turn. They can be combined with [[Terrain Scan Processors]] to dramatically increase the amount of tiles that are scanned per turn. Slower propulsion types tend to get more value out of terrain scanners as it provides more time for the scanners to do their work. A powerful enough processor can make terrain scanning fast enough to work well for even fast flight builds.
[[Heading:3]][[Structural Scanner]][[/Heading]]
Structural Scanners are a form of short ranged terrain scanning that operate instantly. When a wall is seen in visual range, immediately surrounding tiles are instantly revealed, including emergency access doors. [[Spoiler]]For the [[Deep Structural Scanner]], 3 tiles deep are revealed instead.[[/Spoiler]] Due to its cheap upkeep and instant scanning speed, it is a high value for faster builds. It is particularly helpful at locating short digs and emergency accesses between adjacent rooms.
[[Redacted]][[Heading:3]]Sigix Exoskeleton (Terrain Scanning)[[/Heading]]
The Sigix Exoskeleton is a unique propulsion item. It has a large number of effects, one of which is an 18-tile range terrain scanning effect. All types of terrain within that range, including hidden doors, are instantly detected.[[/Redacted]]
[[Heading:3]][[Machine Analyzer]][[/Heading]]
The Machine Analyzer is an indirect source of terrain scanning. It does not reveal random terrain tiles, but it does reveal most types of machines. Once any interactive or non-interactive machine is spotted, nearby machines are also revealed. If an interactive machine was spotted, the nearest machine of the same type is also revealed regardless of distance.
[[Heading:3]]Seismic Detector (terrain scanning)[[/Heading]]
The Seismic Detector is an indirect and unreliable source of terrain scanning. Certain machines will generate seismic activity that are picked up by this part. This only happens for a few types of non-interactive machines, and mostly in Factory maps. Interactive machines are never detected. This does not reveal any specific information about the terrain, but approximate room sizes and locations may be guessed based on the detected machines.
[[Heading:3]][[0b10 Decoder Chip [Scout]]][[/Heading]]
The Scout, and to a lesser extent, the Generic decoder chips, are two sources of indirect terrain scanning. However, their terrain scanning effect is very limited. Only exits, [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]], and hidden doors can be detected.
[[Heading:3]]Structural Interface  (RIF Ability)[[/Heading]]
Structural Interface is an ability that can randomly be gained when using a RIF installer that provides an indirect source of terrain scanning. Hidden doors and phase walls (primarily inside Garrisons) are instantly revealed on sight, similar to the Structural Scanner.
[[Heading:3]]Terrain Scanning Infowar Comparison[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]

[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Vision Manipulation[[/Heading]]
Unlike the previous larger categories, there are only 2 types of vision manipulation. [[Cloaking Devices]] reduce vision of hostile bots and [[Visual Processing Units]] increase vision of the bot using them. While they function slightly differently, they serve a similar purpose of allowing additional exploration without being spotted by hostiles.
[[Heading:3]]Vision Manipulation Infowar Comparison[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Category|Cloaking Devices|Visual Processing Units||
Range|[[CellStyle:Good]]-2 to -6, up to -9 when half_stacked|[[CellStyle:Good]]+2 to +8, not stackable||
Energy Upkeep|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Expensive: -5 to -20 energy per turn|[[CellStyle:Good]]None||
Slot requirement|[[CellStyle:Good]]1 swappable|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]1 unswappable||
Other positives|[[CellStyle:Good]]Allows sneaking into areas guarded by bots without being spotted|[[CellStyle:Good]]Allows for seeing further in combat and sniping||
Other Negatives|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Low integrity/high coverage, no use if bots are already tracking Cogmind|[[CellStyle:Good]]N/A
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Other Infowar Types[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]][[0b10 Decoder Chips]][[/Heading]]
While some of the decoder chips were mentioned in other categories, as a whole they're an oddball group. They tend to provide intel that crosses in between major categories, while also providing unique intel like part detection.
[[Heading:3]][[Drone Bays]][[/Heading]]
Drone bays send out controlled allies to explore the map. Basic drones can only be used for exploration, although other drones can be used for combat purposes as well.
[[Heading:3]][[ECM Suites]][[/Heading]]
ECM Suites are used to end tracking against Cogmind quicker. Each type of ECM Suite has a multiplier that makes hostile tracking less effective. Additionally, the [[Alert]] gain that occurs when a bot loses tracking on Cogmind does not occur when active. While this doesn't help avoid bots in the first place, it is helpful for losing pursuers.
[[Heading:3]][[Transmission Jammers]][[/Heading]]
Transmission Jammers are used for several purposes, but generally help prevent communication between hostiles, especially summoning of reinforcements. While in range, they will prevent bots from transmitting tracking data about Cogmind to other allies on spot. This can help pick off bots in a squad 1 by 1 and to eliminate or bypass Watchers even when hostiles are nearby. They can also block [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] entirely.
[[Heading:3]]Signal Jamming (RIF Ability)[[/Heading]]
Signal Jamming is a RIF ability that behaves similar to Transmission Jammers. Instead of requiring a specific part to use, 0b10 bots are jammed based on attached Relay Couplers. Additionally, Alarm Traps are blocked entirely.
[[Heading:3]][[Trap Scanners]][[/Heading]]
Trap Scanners do exactly as their name implies: They scan for traps. Trap Scanners add fixed percentage to the chance to detect a trap each turn that one is within Cogmind's line of sight.

Terrain Scan Processor]] attached|Structural Scanner Activating.webp|Structural Scanner activating and scanning|Machine Analyzer.webp|Machine Analyzer detecting a [[Terminal]] and locating nearby machines[[/Gallery]]

Name: Interactive Machine
Content:
Interactive machines are types of machines that Cogmind can hack for a variety of effects. They are most commonly found in [[0b10]]-controlled floors, although some machines, especially [[Terminal|Terminals]], can be found in many locations. 0b10 combat and non-combat bots will interact with each of these machines in different ways. Interactive machines have a security level between 1 and 3 that determines how difficult it is to hack at them.

[[Heading]]Types of Interactive Machines[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]../game_sprites/Fabricator.png|[[Fabricator]]: Create parts and bots from schematics|../game_sprites/Garrison.png|[[Garrison Access|Garrison]]: Dispatches 0b10 squads, also serves as an entrance into the [[Garrison|Garrison map]]|../game_sprites/Recycling Unit.png|[[Recycling Unit]]: [[Recycler|Recyclers]] deposit parts into this machine and recycle them into matter|../game_sprites/Repair Station.png|[[Repair Station]]: Can repair parts, refit backup parts, and serves as a home point of [[Mechanic|Mechanics]]|../game_sprites/Scanalyzer.png|[[Scanalyzer]]: Scans parts in inventory to create schematics that can be used for fabricating|../game_sprites/Terminal.png|[[Terminal]]: Provides many miscellaneous hacks, sometimes are guarded by [[Operator|Operators]][[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Hacking[[/Heading]]
Each type of machine has a number of hacks that can be used that are listed in the hacking interface, labeled from A up to Y at most, called direct hacks. Hacks can be performed on Terminals specifically that are not listed by manually typing the name of the hack in. Performing a hack this way is called manal or indirect hacking and has an additional penalty added to it. This penalty is an additional -15% per security level.
[[Heading:2]]Being Detected[[/Heading]]
As Cogmind hacks a machine, there is a chance of detection on each hack. The chance of detection can be reduced by [[Defensive Hackware]], but not lower than 10%. [[Spoiler]]Blowing up Hub machines in [[Hub_04(d)]] provides a stacking reduction along with defensive hackware.[[/Spoiler]] If detected on a hack that was successful, the machine's trace percent will start at 0%. If detected on a failing hack the trace percent will be anywhere from 1% to (100% - (hack success rate). The initial trace percent can also be reduced by defensive hackware. Once tracing has begun, subsequent hacks will increase the trace progress until reaching 100%. The amount of progress depends on the security level of the machine, whether a hack was successful or not, and the amount of defensive hackware equipped. Defensive hackware can reduce the trace percent gained per hack to no fewer than 15% on a successful hack and 25% on an unsuccessful hack.
[[Heading:2]]Being Fully Traced[[/Heading]]
If a machine's trace percentage reaches 100%, Cogmind will be fully traced. If this happens, the log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious activity at [machine name]. Dispatching Investigation Squad.[[/GameText]] will appear and there are three negative consequences:
[[List]]Machine lockout: The machine will become locked and further hacking will not be possible. [[Spoiler]]Trojans with effects over time will generally still remain operational when applied to the machine, with the exception of Trojan(Skim).[[/Spoiler]]|[[Investigation Squad]]: A squad is dispatched to the location of the machine.|Feedback: Feedback may inflict 1% [[Corruption]] on Cogmind and fry hackware attached to Cogmind. This feedback may be prevented with Defensive Hackware.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Security level[[/Heading]]
Security level has different effects on machine hacking. Some are specific to certain kinds of machines, but the following effects are common between all machines:
[[List]]Hacking penalty: Direct hacks on security level 2 machines have a 50% success rate compared to level 1 machines, and level 3 machines have a 25% success rate compared to level 1 machines. Indirect hacks suffer an additional -15% success rate per security level.|Detection rate: The base chance of being traced is 20 or 25% on a level 1 machine, 50% on a level 2 machine, and 60, 70, or 80% on a level 3 machine.|Trace rate: Once detected at a machine, the trace rate is increased at a higher rate on higher rating machines.|Higher armor value: The exact value varies per machine type, but higher security level machines always have more armor than lower security level machines.[[/List]]
Security level frequency scales based on depth. At lower depths, the vast majority of machines are security level 1. By -1, nearly every machine is security level 3.
[[Heading:2]]Hacking Success[[/Heading]]
There are several major components of hacking success rates. The formula is [[GameText]](base success rate) + ([[Offensive Hackware] bonus) - (Cogmind's [[Corruption]] % / 3) + (Operator hack bonus) + ([[Spoiler]]Botnet hack bonus[[/Spoiler]])[[/GameText]].
[[Heading:3]]Operator bonus[[/Heading]]
Each allied Operators within 20 tiles provides a bonus to hacking success rate. The bonus varies depending on the total number of Operators. There is a +10% bonus to hacks for the first Operator, +5% for the second, +2% for the third, and +1% for all others.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]]Trojan(Botnet)[[/Heading]]
Installing Botnet trojans on other Terminals within the same map provides a hacking bonus. There is a +6% bonus to hacks for the first botnet installed, +3% for the second, and +1% for all others. Note that a botnet will not affect hacking success chance on the terminal it is installed on.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]]Base Hacking Success Rate Examples[[/Heading]]
Example hacking success calculations. All final values are truncated.
[[Table]]
Level 1 direct|Level 1 indirect|Level 2 direct|Level 2 indirect|Level 3 direct|Level 3 indirect||
80%|80% - (15% * 1)|80% / 2|(80% / 2) - (15% * 2)|(80% / 4)|(80% / 4) - (15% * 3)||
80%|65%|40%|10%|20%|-25%
[[/Table]]

[[Heading:2]]Central Database Authorization[[/Heading]]
Indirect hacks for lore records, prototype IDs, part or robot schematics, Scanalyzer studies, and robot analyses, are all considered "database hacks". Successfully hacking any of them has a base 25% chance to instead cause a map-wide central database lockout, preventing further indirect database hacks. However, direct hacks of those types remain possible after a central database lockout, and they cannot cause one in the first place. The first indirect database hack on a map cannot cause a database lockout.
Not all lore records, part schematics, studies, robot analyses or robot schematics can be indirectly hacked on all Terminals. Terminals have a level of database authorization dependent on security level and current depth, equal to (10 - current depth + security level). It is only possible to indirectly hack a part/robot schematic or analysis if the Terminal's authorization level is equal to or higher than the rating/tier of the relevant part/robot (prototype parts are considered to have a +1 to their rating for this purpose).
For example, at -5/Factory, level 2 Terminals have an authorization level of (10 - 5 + 2) = 7, which would allow hacking for standard rating 7 parts or prototype rating 6 parts.
Lore records also have a hidden rating/tier stat. This value can only be determined by attempting and failing to access a particular record.

[[Heading:2]]Unauthorized Hacks[[/Heading]]
There are certain unauthorized spoiler hacks can also be used on different machine types. These are a class of hacks known either as [[Spoiler]]Trojans or Force hacks[[/Spoiler]]. The names and effects of these hacks can be discovered from a variety of [[Derelict]] sources.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]]Trojans[[/Heading]]
Generally, Trojan hacks have a permanent or long term duration effect. Trojans can only be applied once per machine. Other than that limitation, they are not dramatically different from most other hacks on machines.
[[Heading:3]]Force Hacks[[/Heading]]
Force hacks are much more dramatic in terms of effects compared to other hacks. They can only be used once on a machine, and if successful, they will immediately lock the machine and summon an [[Investigation Squad]] to the area. Most Force hacks have an additional [[Alert]] penalty that is unique per hack that can be found on the Alert page.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Intercept Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Intercept Squad.png|2 Trackers and 2 Combat Programmers from Intercept squads chasing Cogmind[[/Image]]Intercept squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when Cogmind gets detected and recognized in a few specific scenarios. They consist of one or more [[Tracker|Trackers]] that each summon an additional [[Combat Programmer]] upon visual contact with Cogmind. Both Trackers and Combat Programmers have [[Perfect Tracking]] on Cogmind. Intercept squads are dispatched depending on the number of tiles moved on a map. Once Cogmind takes enough moves, a squad will always be dispatched. They squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], although due to their high speed, this is relatively useless.
An alert will indicate whenever an an Intercept squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Reliable intel has pinpointed LRC-V3, intercept squad en route.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]How to get Intercepts[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can start being sent after Cogmind if any of the following 3 scenarios occurs:
[[List]]Cogmind uses the Data Conduit in [[Data Miner (Location)]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by the lasers in [[Lab]][[/Redacted]]|[[Redacted]]Cogmind gets scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Section 7]][[/Redacted]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Frequency and number[[/Heading]]
Intercept squads can have a variable number of bots. Initially when entering a floor, they consist of 1-2 Trackers that summon Combat Programmers. Each further intercept has a chance of increasing the number of Trackers initially dispatched. For example, the third dispatch on a floor can have up to 4 Trackers dispatched at once, which will further summon up to 4 Combat Programmers.
Intercept squads will appear after a certain number of moves after entering the floor or after the previous dispatch. There are three possible move counts that can be chosen from, and the first two spawns are much more likely than the third one. Either the squad will spawn after n (depth-dependent) tiles moved 2 times n moves, or 2.5 times n moves. The following table shows the number of moves required for each spawn:
[[Table]]
Depths|Tiles for first dispatch chance|Tiles for second dispatch chance|Tiles for third dispatch chance||
-6|500|1000|1250||
-4 and -5|400|800|1000||
-1 through -3|300|600|750
[[/Table]]
After an intercept is dispatched, the move counter is reset. There is no maximum number of intercepts dispatched per floor.

[[Heading]]Where Intercepts Appear[[/Heading]]
Intercepts appear in the majority of 0b10 controlled maps that also have [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]]. Here is a comprehensive list of maps:
[[List]][[Factory]]|[[Hub_04(d)]]|[[Armory]]|[[Research]]|[[Quarantine]] Note: Intercepts even spawn when two Cryocooling Ducts have bee destroyed|[[Testing]]|[[Redacted]]Section 7[[/Redacted]]|[[Protoforge]]|[[Access]][[/List]]

Name: Investigation Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Investigation Squad.png|Two Grunts investigating a locked out Terminal[[/Image]]
Investigation squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is suspected in an area. They are very similar to [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and do not stick around permanently. Investigation squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. Grunts are more common than Hunters in squads. They roam around the area that they were summoned to for 300-400 turns, then exit the map. Investigation squads can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever an Investigation squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Suspicious activity at Terminal F014. Dispatching Investigation squad[[/GameText]]. Depending on the method triggering the Investigation, a different reason may be given in the alert.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Investigation Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]How to get Investigations[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected using an [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being traced at any [[Interactive Machine]], including [[Spoiler]]Force()[[/Spoiler]] hacks|Triggering an [[Alarm Trap]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Investigation Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Grunt Squad|Hunter Squad||
-10|1-2 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A||
-9|1-3 G-34 Mercenary|N/A||
-8|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|1 [[H-55 Commando]]||
-7|2-3 G-47 Trooper|1-2 H-55 Commando||
-6|3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]||
-5|3-4 G-50 Soldier|2 H-66 Slayer||
-4|3-4 [[G-67 Veteran]]|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]||
-3|4 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin||
-2|4-5 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|2-3 [[H-88 Terminator]]||
-1|5 G-73 Enforcer|2-3 H-88 Terminator
[[/Table]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading]][[Data Miner]] redirection[[/Heading]]
The Data Miner can redirect Investigations if his help is obtained by visiting his [[Data Miner (Location)|hideout]]. If redirected, Investigations will roam around a random area of the map rather than head to the location they were summoned to. The Data Miner has a 50% chance to direct each Investigation about 15 turns after one is dispatched. If a redirect happens, the alert [[GameText]]Higher priority target acquired, redirecting investigation.[[/GameText]] will be displayed.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: K-01 Serf
Content:
Serfs are [[0b10]] [[Wheels|wheeled]] non-combat bots that clean machines and decorative scrap tiles. They are equipped with a [[Matter Compressors|Matter Pod]], which could be useful if you need more matter storage. K-01 Serfs are extremely weak and will usually almost immediately die to whatever you shoot it with. As such, they're a decent source of low-rating wheels.
Serfs can also be seen in [[Factory]] dragging incapacitated bots to a [[Chute Trap]].

Name: LC Capacitor
Content: Found in [[Lab]]. Loses integrity when not attached. Merges with the [[Drained L-Cannon]] to create the [[L-Cannon]].

Name: LV-01A
Content:
Found in [[Spoiler]][[Warlord (Location)]][[/Spoiler]].

Wants to blow it up. All of it.

Name: Lab
Content:
Lab is a [[Factory]]/[[Research]] branch between -4 and -3 that is only accessible from [[Armory]]. This map is fixed every game, with the only variations being variations in the guaranteed items. This secret lab is used as a safe spot by the [[A Bots|A bots]] to plan and coordinate as well as research stolen [[Sigix]] technology. This area has a special effect where Cogmind's [[Alert]] drops to 0 upon entering the map.
Lab has a small square entrance and a 1 tile corridor that leads to the next main access exit and a Sealed Barrier with a [[Terminal]] locking it. There are a few different ways to get inside:
[[List]]Breaking in: The main Sealed Barrier blocking the way has 80 armor and high resistances. Cutting through this is difficult without a strong overloadable thermal [[Energy Cannons|Energy Cannon]] backed with a [[Particle Chargers|Particle Charger]] or a [[Plasma Cutters|Plasma Cutter]]. Coming in this way will result in being scanned immediately.|[[Zhirov (Location)]] code: One of the Terminals at Zhirov contains an access code to open up this barrier. Opening the Lab this way not result in being scanned instantly.|Picking up the [[A7 Data Core]]: [[A7]] drops this item when destroyed. The doors will automatically open when approaching, and the message [[GameText]]A0_COM: WELCOME A7[[/GameText]] will appear in the log. This will also reveal the intruder detection lasers, but Cogmind will not be scanned immediately.|Using the [[Data Conduit]]: Using the Data Conduit in [[Data Miner (Location)]] will result in the doors opening automatically, the scanning lasers being visible, and no immediate scan.[[/List]]
[[Table]]
Mode of entry|Breaking in|Zhirov code|A7 Data Core|Data Conduit||
Immediately scanned|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]No||
Lasers revealed|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes||
Terminals readable|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Bad]]No|[[CellStyle:Good]]Yes||
[[Intercept Squad]] dispatches|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Yes|[[CellStyle:Good]]Only if scanned|[[CellStyle:Good]]Only if scanned|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Yes
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]Getting Scanned[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Lab Visible Lasers.png|Visible Lab intruder detecting lasers[[/Image]]
The scanning lasers are invisible by default, although the A7 core and using the Data Conduit will reveal them. They are 3x3 squares of yellow tiles that move randomly. Every turn there is a chance that they will move in one of the cardinal directions. The [[I]]center tile[[/I]] of a laser cannot overlap with other lasers or move through walls, machines, or past the entrance of the Lab (but the other tiles in the 3x3 square can).
Being within the 3x3 area will result in being scanned immediately. This will cause an announcement [[GameText]]A0_COM: INTRUDER ALERT[[/GameText]] and [[A5]] will show up and fight. This scan will also cause [[Intercept Squad|Intercepts]] to appear on most [[0b10]]-controlled floors. The other way to get scanned is to break either the outer wall of Reinforced Barriers or to destroy the Active System Cloaker machine on the right side of the map. Other machines are safe to break.
The inside of the Lab contains many unique item spawns. In counter-clockwise order starting from the entrance:
[[List]]Big machine on top right: [[Core Reset Matrix]]|[[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] shell on top right of map #1: [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]]|Shell #2 (middle): [[Integrated Dissipator]], [[Integrated Mediator]], or [[Integrated Reactor]]|Shell #3 (left): [[Core Expander]] or [[Core Regenerator]]|Top left item spot #1: [[Deep Network Scanner]] or [[Quantum Router]]|Item spot #2: [[AEGIS Remote Shield]], [[Exp. Powered Armor]], [[Hvy. Regenerative Plating]], or [[Med. Regenerative Plating]]|Item spots #3/4: [[Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle]], [[Potential Cannon]], [[Tachyon Dispersion Ray]], or [[Warp Cannon]]|Item tucked into bottom right wall: [[Gui. Remote Datajack]][[/List]]
There is also a locked chamber at the bottom of the map. Accessing it requires walking through a scan laser positioned in the bottom left corner of the lab. The Blast Barrier that locks the door has 45 armor and no Thermal resistance, but 50% resistance for most other major damage types. Inside is a machine that contains the [[LC Capacitor]].
[[Heading:2]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
Not counting the entrance Terminal, there are 3 unique interactive Terminals on this map. They will only be understandable if the Data Conduit has been used this run, otherwise they will just be garbled text. The Active System Cloaker machine on the right has some lore records and will summon a squad of [[Grunt|Grunts]] when destroyed. The A0 Command machine on the left only has lore records. Some of these records can only be unlocked if certain gameplay actions were performed this game. The hidden Storage 04-B machine has some lore records explaining the LC Capacitor and has a hack that will drop the Capacitor on the ground where it can be used.

[[Heading]]Unlockable Lab Orders[[/Heading]]
While most of the Lab Orders in the A0 Command machine are available all of the time, there are a few that have special conditions to achieve:
[[List]]Order 6-0321: Destroy the [[Cetus]] Manufacturing Module machine|Order 6-0323: [[Warlord]] must be destroyed in his [[Warlord (Location)|base]]. Cogmind does not need to be the one to destroy Warlord or attack him at all.|Order 6-0324: Warlord must be met in his base, survive, and plan to attack -2 [[Research]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]L2 Power Cell code[[/Heading]]
Order 6-0319 will provide a manual Terminal hack that can be used in [[Section 7]] on the Power Cell Monitoring machine. Using it will create a powerful explosion that will destroy any combat bots in its 20 tile range.

Name: Latent Energy Streamer
Content:
The Latent Energy Streamer uses a unique mechanic called latent energy to fire. At maximum latent energy capacity (100), the true damage potential is 90-100, with 1% disruption and +4 salvage.

[[Heading]]Latent Energy[[/Heading]]
Latent Energy is present all around the map but only in generally small quantities. The most latent energy is present in the various machinery. This means that the Streamer tends to be unimpressive in [[Caves]], but much stronger in [[0b10]]-controlled locations. Each type of machine has a different amount of latent energy it can provide to the Streamer. Generally, larger machines provide more latent energy. Attaching the Latent Energy Streamer allows visualization of how much latent energy is in an area.
[[Image]]Latent Energy Visualized.png|Latent energy visualized[[/Image]]
Latent energy will gradually return to an area after being used to power the Streamer. Generally, all latent energy will be restored within about 30 turns. Some explosive machines will either become destabilized or explode instantly when used to power the Streamer. Any resulting destruction will contribute to Cogmind's [[Alert]] level.

Name: Launcher Loader
Content:
The Launcher Loader is the equivalent to the [[Quantum Capacitor]] for [[Launchers]] of all kinds.

The turns-per-volley table in the Quantum Capacitor article also applies to the Launcher Loader. But there is a higher proportion of launchers with delay modifiers, compared to [[Energy Guns]] and [[Energy Cannons|Cannons]], so it's more likely that the numbers in the table (which assume no delay modifiers) will be slightly inaccurate for a Launcher Loader build.

Name: Legs
Content:
Legs strike a middle ground in terms of support, speed, and structural integrity. They are commonly used by (and available from) light combat 0b10 bots, including [[Grunt|Grunts]], [[Hunter|Hunters]], and [[Specialist|Specialists]].

While on legs, [[Cogmind]] is immune to damage from ramming hostile bots, and instead has a 20% chance per active leg slot to kick them out of the way (unless they are huge).

While moving on legs, Cogmind is in the Running state, which increases evasion (unless overweight) but decreases ranged accuracy, by 5% per level of [[Momentum]]. Some legs, such as the [[Thunder Leg]], provide improve running bonuses. Legged bots, along with those using [[Flight Units|Flight]] and [[Hover Units]], receive an evasion bonus from [[Reaction Control Systems]].

A few specific legs are capable of [[Special Propulsion Modes]].

Name: Lightpack 2.0
Content: Each time a part is added to inventory, there is a chance that the Lightpack will lose a random part. When this happens, the log will display a message [[GameText]][Item] swallowed by quantum anomaly within Lightpack 2.0.[[/GameText]] Occasionally, the same part may be spit out later with another message [[GameText]]Quantum anomaly discharges [Item].[[/GameText]]. These effects occur more frequently when the inventory is more full. Roughly, one item is discharged for every 4 items eaten. The discharge effect can occur for any part that has been eaten.

Name: Locations
Content:
Locations in Cogmind are unique styles of maps to visit. The main floors (Scrapyard, Materials, Factory, Research, and Access) are always located on the same depths every run. These main floors often can be visited in multiple depths. Branches, on the other hand, are typically found on only a single depth per-run and are often mutually exclusive with other branches. For example, Mines can always be found on -9, but Storage may also appear on -9, forcing a decision about which branch to take, or whether to take one at all.
The majority of maps are randomly generated, meaning no two runs or two depths will have the exact same layout. However, the overall structure of each location type is very similar. Some maps tend to be more open with large rooms and wide corridors, while others are more maze-like with tiny rooms and many small corridors leading into dead-ends. A few branches are partially or entirely static in layout and tend to be much more predictable in contents than main floors.
Branches do not progress upward toward the exit and can often be harder than the main floors. However, branches can offer unique challenges and have similarly unique rewards that can dramatically change a run. This could be powerful unique items, special events, gameplay-altering alignment, or rare permanent buffs.
The following is a list of all locations in Cogmind:
[[AllLocations]]

Name: Mapping Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Mapping Drone|Mapping Drones]].

Name: Marauder
Content: Marauders are [[Treads|treaded]] [[Derelict]] combat bots armed with kinetic weaponry. They are the Derelict versions of [[Behemoth|Behemoths]]. They have unreliable firepower, but their [[Slug Cannon|Slug Cannons]] can easily destroy hostiles with their high critical rate. In comparison to [[0b10]] Behemoths, they tend to be more fragile with low integrity in their armor, and are less susceptible to EM damage.

Name: Martyr
Content: Martyrs are [[Hover Unit|hovering]] [[Derelict]] combat bots armed with [[Launchers]]. They are the Derelict version of [[0b10]] [[Demolisher|Demolishers]]. They tend to be dubious allies due to their high destructive potential, and quite frequently end up skyrocketing [[Alert]] if kept around. Martyrs are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Content:
[[Heading]]List of Mass Support Devices[[/Heading]]

Mass Support Devices|

Name: Master Drone Bay
Content: Deploys a [[Master Drone]]

Name: Master Thief
Content:
Master Thieves will sometimes appear in groups near entrance or exits[[Comment]]I don't think they can appear from both?[[/Comment]] in [[Caves]] maps if Cogmind has stolen from the Exiles. They are slightly slower than regular [[Thief|Thieves]]. Whether or not they appear in any given Caves map start is not truly random, but is instead dependent on the world seed and the number of allies Cogmind enters the map with, and sometimes Master Thieves are guaranteed to appear. When Master Thieves do appear, hostile/neutral bots are prevented from spawning near the Master Thieves' ambush. This may cause nearby prefabs, such as 0b10 outposts, to end up empty, indicating an incoming ambush. One of the Master Thieves of an ambush may appear with a [[CPS Tube]] in their inventory.


[[Heading]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
Master Thieves dash towards Cogmind to try to steal one of their parts using [[Master Tearclaws]]. Unlike regular Thieves, they are capable of stealing parts from inventory, as well as choosing which parts they steal. They will prioritize high rating parts and [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] prototypes. Because of their ability to choose parts, they are also capable of stealing [[Armor]] in spite of the description of their Master Tearclaws. Upon successfully obtaining a part, they will start fleeing. If a fleeing Master Thief goes outside Cogmind's field of view, they will exit the map.

Despite only having a "memory" of 20, Master Thieves will not normally stop tracking Cogmind. Unlike regular Thieves, Master Thieves will only attack Cogmind, as well as Cogmind's [[Drone (Group)|Drones]], and will ignore all other robots unless they are rebooted by a [[Programmer]] or disrupted, in which case they may switch to a different target.

As allies, Master Thieves will try to steal parts from hostiles and return to Cogmind whenever they succeed to deliver the part they stole.

[[Heading]]Strategies[[/Heading]]
Master Thieves are incapable of taking parts on the ground, so dropping important parts you don't want to lose keeps them safe from them. Dropping your [[Storage Unit|Storage Unit]] can help drop a lot of parts quickly, at the cost of not being able to choose which parts remain in inventory. However, this strategy can backfire if there are [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bomb Traps]] or [[Decomposer|Decomposers]] nearby, or if Cogmind or other robots carry [[Launchers]] or [[Electromagnetic Weapons]] capable of triggering chain reactions in power sources.

In order to actually destroy Master Thieves, Launchers can work well when aimed at walls next to them, though at close range the collateral damage might not be worth it if you don't have high-value parts. Targeting utilities can help actually hit them while they are approaching, and a Stasis Beam/Projector can prevent a single Master Thief from attacking or escaping while also making them easier to hit, at the cost of making them take 50% less damage. Having a lot of [[Allies]] always helps, though they are very likely to miss and hit each other in the process.

If Cogmind is fast enough, fleeing is also an option, for example to lead the Master Thieves into allies, [[Warlord]]-aligned [[Derelict|Derelicts]], [[0b10]] robots, or [[Traps]]. Internally, the game considers wild Derelicts, Thieves and [[Assembled]] to all be part of the same "hostile derelicts" faction, meaning those robots will not attack Master Thieves.

As Master Thieves will also attack them, Drones (even disconnected) can function as a temporary distraction, though as Drones from [[Drone Bays]] cannot be looted, even if Master Thieves rip off Drone parts, they will not obtain them, meaning Master Thieves will keep attacking.

[[Heading:2]]Limited Use Strategies[[/Heading]]
Some strategies to defend against Master Thieves cannot be used in every possible ambush, due to using up unique/limited items. Some of those strategies include:
[[List]]
[[Chronowheel]] + Allies - Before Entering a Caves map, attach a Chronowheel and let some of its time go by, then enter the map.
If there is no Master Thief ambush at the start of the map (Master Thieves may appear outside visual range, so account for that), discard the Chronowheel.
If there are Master Thieves, let the Chronowheel deplete naturally to go back in time, then enter the map again with a different number of allies. Because whether Master Thieves appear is based on world seed and the number of allies Cogmind enters a Caves map with, this can potentially prevent Master Thieves from appearing.
This strategy is unreliable, uses up the unique Chronowheel part, requires having allies and can only work on start-of-map ambushes.
[[/List]]

Last edited during Beta 16.

Name: Materials
Content:
Materials is the first real level of the game. These maps are small, cramped and have few paths forward. This is the first map with hostile [[0b10]] patrols hanging around, comprised mainly of low level [[G-34 Mercenary]] and [[G-47 Trooper]] grunts and [[S-10 Pest]] swarmers. There are also a few special special mechanics such as [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]] not calling for reinforcements when attacked while trying to build structures in -10 and -9 and [[A-02 Transporter|Haulers]] not calling for reinforcements at all.
Trying to play flight or hover is not easy in Materials due to many forced encounters with combat robots, little room for maneuvering and few slots yet available for good utilities. The usual recommended way to play these maps is to grab some legs or treads and start blasting. Most players prefer not to transfer to airborne propulsion until [[Factory]] where it is much easier to stealth around and avoid combat. In Materials, it's good to fight enemies one at a time by leading them to one of the many doorways around the map. Use of launchers is very effective whenever there is more than a single bot grouped up close.
[[Alert]] is not a big issue in these maps because of the relatively small map size and number of total patrols. If making a mess of the floors on -10 and -9, entering the [[Mines]] is a good way to lose all of the alert gained from the early Materials maps.
Full list of depth-specific mechanics that apply in Materials:
[[List]]-9: [[Y-45 Defender|Sentries]] start to appear on the map|-9: [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] will start to be summoned above Alert level 2|-9: [[Scanalyzer|Scanalyzers]] begin to appear on the map|-8: [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]] begin to summon reinforcements when attacked while rebuilding|-8: [[H-71 Marshal|Heavies]] begin to appear on the map|-8: [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] begin to appear on the map[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Materials[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]][[Gallery]]Materials Main Exit.png|A 3 tile corridor leading to a main access|Materials Mines Exit.png| A [[Mines]] exit prefab|Materials Mines Exit 2.png|A second Mines exit prefab|Materials Subcaves Exit.png|A dug out exit to Subcaves|Materials Subcaves Exit Predug.png|An exit to Subcaves surrounded by dirt, before being dug out|Materials OOD Cache.png|An out-of-depth parts cache|Materials Storage Cache.png|A cache full of [[Sml. Storage Unit|Small]], [[Med. Storage Unit|Medium]], and [[Lrg. Storage Unit|Large]] storage units[[/Gallery]]The storage cache prefab can be very important early on in the game. Cogmind only starts with a [[Sml. Storage Unit]] with very little room for important backup parts and should upgrade ASAP. While not guaranteed, these storage caches will appear on almost every Materials map. [[Hcp. Storage Unit]] and [[Huge Storage Unit]] can both be commonly found on the floor in these maps, but they are not included in the standard storage cache prefab.
The other important cache is the out-of-depth parts cache. These caches contain 3 groups of 4 parts that will be one rating out of depth and can include prototypes. For example, on -9 Materials the standard highest rating part is a 2, while the cache will contain rating 3 or 3* [[Prototype Part|Prototype Parts]]. This is one of the best ways to become very strong in Materials. For example, getting a stockpile of [[Enh. Autogun|Enh. Autoguns]] on -9 can help set a combat up for multiple floors to come.[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]There are 3 types of normal exits in Materials:[[List]]Main access exits: These always lead to the next main floor, either Materials or [[Factory]]. These exits can be recognized by their distinctive 3 tile corridor leading to a dead-end exit along the edges of the map. There are always 3 of these per Materials map.|[[Mines]] exits: These exits are almost always distinguishable by a few specific prefabs of some machinery and a cache of items. Occasionally Mines exits will spawn without the prefab and look like standard exits. There are either 1 or 2 Mines exits on -10 and -9.|[[Storage]] exits: These exits do not have a prefab at all and look like standard exits. There is often a [[Y-45 Defender|Sentry]] guarding these exits, but it is not guaranteed. Storage only spawns on 1 depth between -9 and -7 and 1-2 exits can be found to Storage on that map.|[[Subcaves]] exits: Hidden behind a large area of diggable dirt where a new room is planned. [[T-07 Excavator|Excavators]] will dig this area out over time, revealing the exit. It is also possible for Cogmind to dig this area out to find the exit ahead of time.[[/List]][[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]][[Image]]8R-AWN in Materials.png|8R-AWN passing through Materials[[/Image]]
[[Spoiler]][[Image]]Materials Subdwellers Attack.png|Subdwellers attacking 0b10[[/Image]][[/Spoiler]][[List]](++) [[8R-AWN]]: 8R-AWN can appear in -10 or -9 Materials, passing through to the nearest Mines exit. They will shoot any hostile 0b10 bots on the way and often leave large piles of loot in their wake. If encountered, they will tell you to follow them to the Mines and then to the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] map.|(++) [[Spoiler]][[7R-MNS]]: 7R-MNS will appear on -8 Materials, roaming around the map and killing 0b10 combat bots. After a few hundred turns, they will head to a main exit and head to Factory. They can be followed through the exit.[[/Spoiler]]|(++) [[Federalist]] party: 6 Federalists will appear on -10 Materials and head directly for the Subcaves exit. They will continue exploring Subcaves until they find a shortcut to [[Scraptown]].|(--) [[Spoiler]]3 [[Subdweller|Subdwellers]] can appear from the Subcaves exit, attacking Cogmind and 0b10 alike, with the announcement of [[GameText]]Derelict incursion detected, dispatching patrols to target area.[[/GameText]] When this occurs, two patrols will be dispatched from a nearby main exit.[[/Spoiler]][[/List]]

Name: Matter
Content: Matter is used to attach components, and is consumed by ballistic weapons and launchers, which convert it to the appropriate type of ammunition. It can be salvaged from robot remains, though the available amount varies depending on how the robot was destroyed. Robots hit with [[Ballistic Cannons]] will drop a small amount of matter nearby. Matter also appears randomly on the ground. Cogmind automatically recycles 5 matter from each attached part that is destroyed.

Name: Maximum Security
Content:
[[Image]]Maximum Security Assaults.png|A wave of Assaults and Sentries dispatched during Maximum Security[[/Image]]
Maximum Security is a special [[0b10]] response to a few specific threats that results in immediate shutdown of machines and increasingly large waves of [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] dispatched to Cogmind's position. Unlike the similar-behaving [[High Security]], Maximum Security is unrelated to [[Alert]] mechanics. Maximum Security can be triggered on most main and branch 0b10-controlled floors, excluding [[Command]], [[DSF|DSFs]], and [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. It can be triggered only by the following scenarios:
[[List]]
Cogmind has taken [[FarCom]] and enters [[Quarantine]] or [[Testing]]|
The [[Sigix Containment Pod]] is inserted into the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] (instant)|
Cogmind attaches the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] and is spotted by an 0b10 combat bot|
All the [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] in [[Access]] have either been shut down or destroyed
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
0: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: [reason for Max Security]. Maximum security lockdown in progress.[[/GameText]]|
1: Machines shut down, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Machine network offline[[/GameText]]|
2: Log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Performing unscheduled system reset.[[/GameText]]|
3: 4 [[Sentry|Sentries]] dispatched at each 0b10-controlled exit and Garrison, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Lockdown in effect, collecting threat data.[[/GameText]]|
5/100: First assault wave dispatched, 6 assaults dispatched from nearby 0b10-controlled exits and [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]]. The first wave will be dispatched after 100 turns for FarCom-triggered Maximum Security and 5 turns for other reasons.|
105/200: Second wave, 6 assaults dispatched|
255/350: Third wave, 8 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults with stronger bots|455/550: Fourth wave, 10 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
705/800: Fifth wave, 12 assaults dispatched including heavy assaults|
Etc. - Delay between assaults continues to increase by 50 and number of assaults per wave continues to increase by 2
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exiting Maximum Security[[/Heading]]
The only 2 ways to exit Maximum Security are to trigger [[Sterilization]] after killing enough combat hostiles or to exit the map. Otherwise, an infinite number of Assaults will continue to be dispatched.

Name: Mechanic
Content:
Mechanics are [[Wheel|wheeling]] [[0b10]] non-combat bots that repair the parts and core of damaged allies. They tend to hang around a home [[Repair Station]]. Mechanics will head toward damaged allies as soon as they are hurt but will not repair them while in combat. Mechanics carry [[Recalibrators]] and [[Machine Analyzer|Machine Analyzers]] that can be good to salvage. They also carry a set of backup parts in their inventory based on the bot tier. These backup parts will be refitted on bots if they have empty slots.
If a hurt bot is not shot at for a few turns, the Mechanic will repair core integrity up to 85% and part integrity up to 50%. Allied Mechanics will also repair Cogmind's parts up to 50% integrity but will not touch core integrity. Blue allied Mechanics must be set to Aid before they will repair integrity.
Mechanics can refit parts if a bot has a slot available and fewer than 2 power, propulsion, utility, or weapon slots. 0b10 aligned Mechanics can resupply on backup parts at their home Repair Station. The available refittable parts are based on the type of Mechanic:
[[Table]]
Slot/Count|M-13 Machinist|M-28 Smith|M-36 Artificer||
Power (2 available)|[[Backup Power I]]|[[Backup Power III]]|[[Backup Power VII]]||
Propulsion (4 available)|[[Backup Propulsion I]]|[[Backup Propulsion III]]|[[Backup Propulsion VII]]||
Utility (2 available)|[[Backup Plating I]]|[[Backup Plating III]]|[[Backup Plating VII]]||
Weapon (4 available)|[[Backup Laser I]]|[[Backup Laser III]]|[[Backup Laser VII]]
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Integrity repaired[[/Heading]]
The type of Mechanic determines how much total integrity they can repair:
[[List]]
M-13 Machinist: 800|
M-28 Smith: 1400|
M-36 Artificer: 2600
[[/List]]

Name: Mechanics Achievements
Content:
[[Comment]]                       ---NOTE FOR EDITORS---
Once Beta 16 releases, if you decide to update any of the Achievements pages, please consider whether it would be better to separate the new achievements from the old ones or not.
I think that, ideally, whatever you choose to do, that decision should be applied to all Achievements pages, for the sake of consistency.[[/Comment]]

Mechanics [[Achievements]] are earned by interacting with and/or using many of the mechanics of the game. They are largely used as a way to teach players about some of said mechanics. Most of them will be simply eventually be obtained by players as they make mistakes and/or learn new mechanics. 15 of the 72 Mechanics Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Mechanics Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements of the same sub-type, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Comment]]I don't know how to best categorize "Various"-type achievements.
They're still somewhat grouped, like "Part-time Excavator" and "Unlikely Earthworm", but making a heading for just two achievements seems like a bit much.
I also don't want to just bundle all "Various" achievements together, because that would disrupt the achievement order given by the game when using the "grouped" sorting option.
[[/Comment]]

[[Heading]]Various[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Close Call: [[Spoiler]]Evolve after being reduced to less than 10% of core integrity.[[/Spoiler]]
|Universal Adapter: [[Spoiler]]Use every form of propulsion across an entire run.[[/Spoiler]]
|Hehehe: Reprogram a [[Traps|trap]] using a [[Datajack]].
Strategy: Find some hostile Traps, attach a melee Datajack, and attempt to move into one of the Traps with the Datajack active. This won't actually cause you to move onto them, and will instead attempt to hack the Trap. On a successful attempt, the Trap will either be disarmed or reprogrammed. Only the latter will trigger the Achievement.
|Wheee!: Manually trigger a [[Chute Trap]].
Strategy: Find some Chute Traps in [[Factory]] either through luck or by using the [[GameText]]find_chute[[/GameText]] [[Datajacks|Datajack]] hack on a [[K-01 Serf]]. Note that the Achievement requires [[I]]manually[[/I]] triggering the Chute Trap, which means pressing '>' while on top of a known Chute Trap (or left-click on self) to force it to trigger. Triggering a Chute Trap by moving into a known one is not enough. If possible, reprogram the Traps using a melee Datajack or a nearby Terminal. When using [[Treads]] or while overweight, the Chute Traps will need to have been reprogrammed, as it is otherwise impossible to move onto them without triggering them.
|It Was An Accident, I Swear: [[Spoiler]]Destroy 10 machines in a single turn.[[/Spoiler]]
Strategy: [[Spoiler]]Find a large array of explosive machines, most likely in [[Factory]], and destroy one of them through either destabilization or a powerful cannon to start a chain reaction. A melee weapon also works, but at the cost of taking damage. Alternatively, this Achievement can also be unlocked by accident.[[/Spoiler]]
|Part-time Excavator: Use a melee weapon to dig through 10 walls or earth.
|Unlikely Earthworm: [[Spoiler]]Get crushed by a [[Cave-ins|cave-in]].[[/Spoiler]]
|Hey, That's Mine!: Attack 5 [[Recycler|Recyclers]] attempting to collect parts.
|Loot Pinata: Destroy a [[Hauler]].
|Treasure Hunter: Destroy 20 [[Hauler|Haulers]].
|Use The Force: [[Spoiler]]Collect 100 [[Matter|matter]] via [[Tractor Beams|Tractor Beam]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Attaching parts[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Risk Taker: Attach an unidentified prototype.
|Ooh, Shiny!: [[Spoiler]]Attach 20 unidentified prototypes.[[/Spoiler]]
|Alien Tech: [[Spoiler]]Attach or use an [[Alien Artifacts|alien artifact]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Corruption[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
System Compromised: Reach 10% system [[Corruption|corruption]].
|Z1$+NX3F=JRE3_ZNQR: [[Spoiler]]Reach 50% system [[Corruption|corruption]].[[/Spoiler]]
|Maybe Next Time I'll Detach My [[Launchers|Launcher]]: [[Spoiler]]Misfire an explosive launcher.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various 2[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Backstab: [[Spoiler]]Murder a friendly NPC.[[/Spoiler]]
|Short-term Sacrifices: Escape a [[Stasis Trap]] with help from an explosion.
Strategy: Find and trigger a Stasis Trap, preferably while using non-[[Treads|threaded]] propulsion, then blow up the Trap with a [[Launchers|Launcher]] or nearby explosive machine. Note that the Achievement will only be unlocked if the Trap itself is destroyed; If the stasis field gets depleted by the explosion first, the Trap will disappear, preventing it from being destroyed by the explosion. This Achievement is there to teach players that destroying a Stasis Trap causes the stasis field to disappear. Getting rid of a stasis field this way is rarely a good idea, but in some situations, taking a bit of damage to avoid getting spotted by powerful hostiles may be run-saving. 
|Just Shoot The [[Terminal]]: [[Spoiler]]Open a locked door by destroying its Terminal with an electromagnetic weapon.[[/Spoiler]]
|Release The Drones!: Have 6 drones at once.
|Subspace Traveler: Find a way to teleport.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Fighting[[/Heading]]

[[List]]Storm Trooper: Miss 5 shots in a row.
Strategy: You'll earn it eventually, probably more times than you would like. 
|Crack Shot: Hit 10 shots in a row.
|Please Form A Line: Hit 2 robots with a single projectile.
Strategy: Requires a weapon with penetrative capabilities, such as a [[Gauss Rifle]]. It is easiest to earn this Achievement by shooting robots in a small corridor, where robots would be naturally aligned.
|Quick And Dirty: Destroy 5 hostiles via explosions in a single turn.
Strategy: Use [[Launchers]] or nearby explosive machines. Especially easy against [[Assembled]] or [[Swarmer|Swarmers]], as they are both weak to explosions and easy to find in groups.
|Power Corrupts: Terminally [[Corruption|corrupt]] a robot.
|It's Just You: Cause a robot to [[Meltdown|meltdown]].
|Fist Fight: Destroy a hostile by ramming.
|Overkill: Fire 10 [[Overload#weapons|overloaded shots]].
|Batter Up: Knock a hostile robot into an explosive machine via melee impact damage.
|Watch This!: Sneak attack a [[Watcher]] and destroy it in one hit.
|Deadly Force: Melee attack a hostile using 4 [[Momentum|momentum]].
Strategy: The only way to attain 4 momentum is with the help of a [[Reaction Control Systems|Reaction Control System]], which does not work if overweight. Move three times in the same direction (to attain the base maximum of 3 momentum) while you have a Reaction Control System (+1 momentum), then attack a hostile robot. [[Comment]]Maybe there should be an explanation here for why momentum is useful for melee attacks?[[/Comment]]
|Ambidextrous: Destroy 2 hostiles with one melee volley.
|Oops: [[Spoiler]]Attempt to fire a [[Matter|matter]]-consuming volley without enough matter.[[/Spoiler]]
|No Explosion For You: Shoot down a [[Launchers|launcher]] projectile with a [[Point Defense Systems|defensive utility]].
|Oh No You Don't!: Destroy a [[E-15 Imp|Saboteur]] before it succeeds.
|Ride The Lightning: Use a [[Fabricator]] to destroy an enemy.
Strategy: [[Spoiler]]While hostiles are approaching or are already close to a Fabricator, use Force(Overload) on said Fabricator. Consider moving away to avoid becoming one of the Fabricator's targets.[[/Spoiler]]
|Let's See Who's Tougher: [[Spoiler]]Fire a [[Launchers|launcher]] at an enemy at point blank range.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Stealth[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Uninvited Guest: Be spotted by an [[Operator]] that then summons [[Reinforcement Squad|reinforcements]] from its [[Terminal]].
|One Hack Too Far: Trigger an [[Investigation Squad|investigation]] by being traced to a [[Terminal]].
|Troublemaker: Cause a robot to call for [[Garrison Squad|help or reinforcements]] from a nearby [[Garrison|Garrison Access]].
|Party Time: [[Spoiler]]Cause 3 active [[Investigation Squad|investigation squads]] at once.[[/Spoiler]]
|Significant Disruption: Raise [[Alert|alert]] high enough to trigger an [[Assault Squad|assault dispatch]].
|Slippery One: [[Spoiler]]Go from being tracked by 10 hostiles to having no pursuers without destroying any of them.[[/Spoiler]]
|Hunted: Simultaneously tracked by 20 hostiles.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Hacking[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
My Command Is Your Wish: Build an ally via [[Fabricator]].
|Just What I Needed: Build a part via [[Fabricator]].
|Part-time Mechanic: Repair a part via [[Repair Station]].
|Safety First: Identify a prototype via [[Scanalyzer]].
|Dynamic Key: Use an [[Operator]] [[Data Core]] before it expires.
|Novice Programmer: Hack 10 machines.
|Librarian: Hack 10 different [[Terminal]] records.
|Armchair Analyst: Download 3 robot analyses from [[Terminal|Terminals]].
|Everything Is Under Control: Lower alert using a [[Terminal]]'s Purge Threat hack.
|GoHome(): Use a [[Terminal]] to recall an active squad.
|Shopping List: Hack [[Hauler]] Manifests at a [[Terminal]].
|Brute Force: Use a Force() hack.
|True Hacker: Install a Trojan().
|Quantum Hacking: Set up a three-[[Terminal]] botnet.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Bothacking[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
A New Friend: Rewire a robot.
|Factory Defaults: Reset a hostile robot using the reboot_system hack.
|Error 47: Cause a hostile robot's power to go critical with an overload_power or amplify_resonance hack.
|Assimilation Complete: Assimilate a hostile robot using the format_system hack.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Infowar[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
No Signal: Block an [[Alarm Trap]] transmission.
|Total Silence: Jam 10 [[Distress Signals|distress signals]] or other communications.
|I Spy: Use an [[Imp. Sensor Array]] (or better) with [[Imp. Signal Interpreter]] (or better).
|Omniscient Cartographer: Use an [[Imp. Terrain Scanner]] (or better) with [[Imp. Terrain Scan Processor]] (or better).
|Knowing Is Half The Battle: Enter 10 identified exits.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various 3[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Can't Catch Me: Reach a speed of FASTx3, or 4 spaces per turn.
|Cya!: Fly over a row of 3 robots.
|The More The Merrier: Have 5 allies.
[[/List]]


This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Microwarp Drive
Content:
Microwarp Drives are attachable non-consumable two-slot utility [[Alien Artifacts]] that allow warping across any number of open spaces nearly instantly, at the cost of Cogmind's core integrity equal to 2 per space traveled. "Open spaces" means any tile Cogmind would be able to freely move onto, which includes tiles occupied only by items or doors[[Comment]]Does this include undiscovered hidden doors? If not, what if Cogmind has the Structural Interface RIF ability? What about phase walls?[[/Comment]]. A microwarp will only end upon reaching a non-open space. Microwarp Drives can be found exclusively in the western side of [[Section 7]] as unguarded Artifacts.

Neither hostiles nor Cogmind are able to see any moment of a microwarp, meaning hostiles will not spot Cogmind if a microwarp passes through their FOV but ends outside of it. Cogmind will not be able to see anything while microwarping either, be it robots, items, or map structure, though the specific tiles Cogmind has traveled through will be added to the map as if they had been scanned[[Comment]]Does it only add "empty" tiles to map intel regardless of what type of tile was actually there, or does it add each tile's current state?[[/Comment]]. Microwarps always takes one full turn[[Comment]]I'm not sure if it's exactly 100 time units, but i would guess so?[[/Comment]], regardless of current regular propulsion speed or distance traveled.


[[Heading]]Uses[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Faster movement - When using slow propulsion such as [[Treads]], microwarps allow moving much faster than otherwise possible, making it easier or just feasible to close in on hostiles, strategically reposition, or flee. 
|Stealth - Since Cogmind cannot be spotted during microwarps, clever microwarping can make it possible to go past patrols and guards without getting spotted.
|Digging - Since microwarps are near instantaneous, they be used to cross any number of dug-out/unstable tiles without any risks of [[Cave-ins|cave-ins]]. For example, this can be used to consistently get from one quadrant of a [[Garrison]] to another without having to go through the Garrison's center.
|Super-cannon digging - By combining microwarps with a cannon capable of [[GameText]]x* Unlimited[[/GameText]] penetration capable of digging very far in one shot, such as a [[Core Cannon]] or a [[Hyp. Alpha Cannon]], it is possible to dig and travel really quickly through long tunnels, and even chain cannon shots and microwarps together repeatedly (at a risk of cave-ins) to quickly move large distances by going around the complex layout itself. For example, with a Core Cannon, this combo can be used to realistically reach [[Redacted]]the western side of [[Command]] without going through [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C]]'s chamber[[/Redacted]].

|Lower move count - Each microwarp counts as a single "move" action, regardless of how many tiles were traveled, which can be used to delay or even avoid the dispatch of [[Intercept Squad|Intercept Squads]].[[Comment]]Source: A Beta 11 run i did, where i didn't get any Intercept Squads in Access despite having been scanned by an S7 Researcher. I had traveled 629 spaces, but only done 572 move actions. 568 of those moves were treaded, and 5 were microwarps (yes i know it should add up to 573, don't ask me why it's counted this way).[[/Comment]]
[[/List]]

Name: Mines
Content:
Mines is one of the first [[Branch|Branches]] of the game and is guaranteed to appear on -10 and -9 of [[Materials]] in every game. These maps have several unique early-game rewards that can pay off throughout the whole run, but also has some very dangerous events. The assembled infestation event is a common cause of early death in runs. Aside from the events, the map is sparsely populated with early game patrols of [[G-34 Mercenary]] and [[G-47 Trooper]] grunts and [[S-10 Pest]] swarmers. Several types of friendly and occasionally hostile Derelicts can also be found here. [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]] and [[Scrap]] can be found randomly on the ground.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Mines[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Mines Subcaves Exit.png|A dug out exit to [[Subcaves]]|Mines Subcaves Exit Predug.png|An exit to Subcaves surrounded by dirt, before being dug out|Mines Shop Type 1.png|Derelict shop with out-of-depth parts that summons a [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARC]] when opened|Mines Shop Type 2.png|Trapped Derelict shop with [[Imp. Trap Extractor]] dropped by Derelict|Mines Shop Type 3.png|Derelict shop with a unique drone bay|Mines Sentry Cache.png|Small cache of parts with [[Y-45 Defender|Sentry]] guards, sometimes with friendly Derelicts|Mines Storage Cache.png|Matter pod and storage unit cache|Mines Assorted Damaged Parts.png|Assorted partially damaged parts on ground|Mines Friendly Grunts.png|Friendly [[G-34 Mercenary]] and [[G-47 Trooper]] grunts that activate automatically|Mines Exiles Entrance.png|Hidden entrance to [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]][[/Gallery]]
The 3 different types of Derelict shop events are all great events to get. The out-of-depth parts will usually provide an immediate buff and the early [[Imp. Trap Extractor]] can be very strong for anybody who wants to use a lot of [[Traps]]. The drone bay shop gives one of the following unique parts that aren't accessible anywhere else:[[List]][[Bomb Drone Bay]]|[[Decoy Drone Bay]]|[[Sensor Drone Bay]]|[[Splice Drone Bay]]|[[Thief Drone Bay]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 3 types of exits in Materials:[[List]]Main access exits: These always lead to the next Materials floor. There are 2 of these per Mines map and these exits will always be out in the open.|[[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] exit: Exiles exits will always be down a 1 tile corridor with a wall that will fade away when close. This will be accompanied with the Log text [[GameText]]No threat detected, you may enter[[/GameText]]. The Exiles exit will only be on one of the two Mines depths. The following Log message will be shown when entering the Mines map with the exit: [[GameText]]Something is scanning the area.[[/GameText]]|[[Spoiler]][[Zion]] shortcut: A event with a friendly Derelict will create an exit leading to Zion. This will always skip a depth to -7 and is only available on -8 Mines after exiting a -9 Exiles map.[[/Spoiler]][[/List]][[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
There are a mix of friendly and hostile events that can occur in the Mines. While the friendly events can be very nice, some of the bad ones can easily be run-ending.
[[Image]]Mines Lost Derelicts.png|Friendly lost Derelicts[[/Image]][[Image]]Mines Collapse.png|A ceiling collapse burying Cogmind, friends, and Assembled[[/Image]][[Image]]Mines Assembled Invasion.png|Assembled Infestation, with Demolishers on the way[[/Image]][[List]](++) [[Exp. Sensor Array]] in [[Scrap]]: A seemingly ordinary Scrap pile may contain a partially damaged Exp. Sensor Array.|(++) [[Thug (5)|Derelict]] that drops a [[Rocket Launcher]]: A Derelict will appear, trash talk mining lasers, drop a Rocket Launcher, then disappear back into the shadows.|(++/--) [[YI-UF0]]: YI-UF0 will appear and start out friendly but will turn hostile to everything when attacked by a Derelict. When friendly, you can loot this bot freely for some strong unique parts. If aggressive, they will be quite deadly and may just end your run if you stand around and fight.|(+) Friendly lost Derelicts, a [[Thug (5)]] and a [[Zionite]], will follow Cogmind around, looking for a safe exit|(+) Various Derelict weapons in [[Scrap]]: A seemingly ordinary Scrap pile may contain a Derelict weapon like a [[Slug Cannon]], [[Plasma Flamer]], or [[Hvy. Machine Gun]].|(+) A stash of traps in Scrap: A seemingly ordinary Scrap pile may contain a stash of early game traps like [[Blade Trap|Blade Traps]], [[Explosive Trap|Explosive Traps]], and [[EMP Trap|EMP Traps]]|(+) [[Scrap Suit]] in Scrap: A Scrap Suit is hidden in Scrap. A message in the log indicates that it is stolen from [[Scraptown]].|(+) Derelict that drops a [[Mining Laser]]: A Derelict will appear, talk about how handy Mining Lasers are, then follow you around for a while. Eventually they will disappear back into the shadows.|(+/-) [[Signal Generator]] Derelict: A Derelict will activate a Signal Generator and summon an assault to your location. The generator can be picked up and used later.|(~) Megawrench audio recording: A Log message will say that Megawrench has relocated to [[Zion]].|(-) Ceiling collapse and [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]]: The walls will suddenly collapse in on Cogmind and anything around in a wide area. A few Assembled will also show up buried in the walls. Squads of [[T-07 Excavator|Tunnelers]] guarded by [[G-34 Mercenary|Grunts]] will be dispatched continuously every several hundred turns to dig out the collapsed tiles. Using a digging tool like a [[Mining Laser]] or [[Mining Claw]] is recommended to escape quicker.|(--) Assembled Infestation: A large number of Assembled will appear and start attacking everything nearby. A [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARC]] containing 2 [[D-53 Grenadier|Demolishers]] will be dispatched from the closest Materials exit and sent to the initial spawn location. A [[Guerrilla (5)|Derelict]] will appear next to you and tell you to run away as they provide a distraction. This infamous event is extremely dangerous so early in the game as both the Assembled and Demolishers can deal a lot of damage very quickly. Usually, most of the Assembled and Demolishers end up destroying each other.
[[GameText]]ALERT: Infestation in the Mines, dispatching Demolisher response squad.[[/GameText]][[/List]]

[[Heading]]Surviving the [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] Infestation[[/Heading]]
The assembled infestation is a very dangerous early-game event and kills many runs. Both the Assembled and the [[D-53 Grenadier|Demolishers]] and require different tools to deal with them effectively. Here are some tips to help avoid untimely demise when this event occurs:

[[Heading:2]]Avoid the Assembled[[/Heading]]
Unless the infestation happens right after entering the map, the Assembled will appear only when Cogmind steps close enough to their initial spawn location. Most of the time, the easiest way to avoid them is to backtrack the way you came. Assembled get distracted attacking non-combat 0b10 bots and can take a few turns before they start roaming the map.

[[Heading:2]]Avoid the Demolishers[[/Heading]]
The Demolishers will appear at the 0b10 exit closest to the infestation and head directly to where the Assembled appeared. If both exits are identified it should be pretty easy to figure out the path that the Demolisher ARC will take. Try to hide out of line of sight of that path if possible. A [[Seismic Detector]] can be used to identify the ARC path from a distance as well as identify the explosions from their [[Explosive Launchers|Launchers]].

[[Heading:2]]Dig to Safety[[/Heading]]
Depending on the layout, digging may save you from both groups at once. Melee weapons like a [[Mining Claw]] or a [[Mining Laser]] are early ways to dig. Digging into the corner of the room and hiding may be a way to avoid getting spotted. In desperate situations like if you're trapped in a corner, you may want to perform a longer unsafe dig to make it to another room.

[[Heading:2]]Let Them Fight it Out[[/Heading]]If left alone, the Demolishers and Assembled will beat each other up pretty badly. The Assembled win most of the time, though most of them are wiped out in the process. If there are only a few Assembled left, they can be picked off one at a time much more easily. Look out for sounds of combat as they continue to harass non-combat bots. If the Demolishers are the victors instead, there won't be any signs of them roaming the map and Cogmind might be in for a big surprise.

[[Heading:2]]Kill the Assembled[[/Heading]]
If you're trapped with no way out, the easiest way to kill the Assembled is with any kind of explosive Launcher. [[Grenade Launcher|Grenade Launchers]] and [[Rocket Launcher|Rocket Launchers]] are the most common early game Launchers and can usually be found on the floor in -10 and -9 Materials. If Launchers aren't an option, try to run into a more enclosed area, ideally a 1 tile wide corridor so you can't be swarmed. With 20 core integrity, most rating 1-2 weapons will kill them in 2 hits to core.

[[Heading:2]]Kill the Demolishers[[/Heading]]
There are only 2 Demolishers that appear from this event, but they are quite formidable. Their [[Mni. Grenade Launcher|Mni. Grenade Launchers]] deal a lot of damage in a short period of time, far more than any other bot at the depth. It's hard to take them out one at a time since they easily destroy walls with their explosions. The best offensive are cannons like the [[Lgt. Cannon]] and [[Imp. Light Cannon]] which can kill in 2-3 core hits. They do have a 75% resistance to explosive damage, but don't count explosives out entirely. If you stand in their face, they will hit themselves with their own AOE damage which can often help kill faster.

[[Heading:2]]Core Hover Away[[/Heading]]
If worst comes to worst and it looks like you might be at danger of not making it through the fights in one piece, core hovering is always an option. Don't purge to core since you will instantly end up with 100% core coverage and likely die immediately. Instead, rip storage, power, and weapons off as needed until underweight. Disable any active propulsion and hover away at 50 speed. The propulsion is massless but still provides valuable coverage and integrity while fleeing.

Name: Minesniffer Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Minesniffer Drone|Minesniffer Drones]].

Name: Minesweeper
Content: Minesweepers are [[Wheels|wheeled]] [[0b10]] non-combat bots that are primarily found in [[Caves]], often guarded by 1-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]]. They use their [[Datajacks]] to reprogram hostile [[Derelict]] [[Traps]] and extract them with their [[Trap Extractors]]. Minesweepers are always found near patches of [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bomb Traps]] and [[Fire Trap|Fire Traps]]. Unlike Cogmind, their reprogram attempts are always successful and they will never accidentally explode a trap while trying to reprogram it.

Name: Mni. Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Mini Drone|Mini Drones]].

Name: Mobile Assembly Unit
Content: Creates 1 [[Assembled]] for -10 [[Matter]], +100 [[Heat]], -100 [[Energy]]

Name: Modified EM Gauss Rifle
Content:
Created by combining a [[Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle]] with a [[GAL Module]].
The following RIF hacks can be performed:
[[List]]amplify_resonance|disable_weapons|overload_power|overwrite_iff|reboot_system|spike_heat[[/List]]

Name: Molecular Deconstructor
Content: When a bot is hit with the Molecular Deconstructor, they will take the 20-50 damage over a period of 2-5 turns, with 10 damage being dealt per turn. Multiple instances of the damage over time effect do stack with each other.

Name: Momentum
Content:
Moving multiple consecutive spaces in a row in the same direction adds momentum, up to a maximum of 3. Momentum has several effects, most notably improving the effectiveness of attacks with [[Melee Weapons]].

A bot gains 1 momentum each time it moves in the same direction. It loses 1 momentum when it turns 45 degrees; for instance, if a bot has 3 momentum while moving east, and then moves southeast, it will have 2 momentum. Taking any other action, including stopping or moving in a different direction, resets momentum.

Name: Multitool
Content:
When reconfiguring a terminal, Multitools apply a modifier between -20% and +50% with no known weighting. This combines very well with defensive hackware as you have the option to only put it on once you've gotten a high roll on a reconfigured terminal.

Multitools are mainly found by looting [[Artisan|Artisans]], but they can also be found in other assorted places, such as [[Subcaves]] scrap piles, occasionally falling from subcaves twisted machinery, a dropped item that a [[Subdweller]] was carrying, a rare creation from a [[Cobbler Unit]], and as a recipe from [[Spoiler]][[Tech Extrapolator]][[/Spoiler]].

Name: Mutant
Content: Mutants are [[Treads|treading]] [[Derelict]] combat robots that wield a large variety of offensive and defensive parts. They are not exactly the same, but are quite similar to the [[0b10]] [[Sentry]] class of bots as offensive treading guard bots with mixed weaponry. Mutants are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: N-00 Fly
Content: Not currently used in game. [[Hunter|Hunters]] launch [[Drone|Drones]], not N-00 Flies, when they lose track of Cogmind.

Name: Navigation Efficiency Matrix
Content:
The Navigation Efficiency Matrix (NEM) is a single use [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] that will cause Cogmind to teleport at random intervals. When attached, the log message [[GameText]]Navigation Efficiency Matrix installed, partial failure due to system anomalies.[[/GameText]] will appear.
[[Image]]NEM.gif|Effect of the Navigation Efficiency Matrix[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Teleport effects[[/Heading]]
An NEM teleport behaves similarly to a standard [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]] effect. All bots that are tracking Cogmind will instantly lose tracking, even including some [[Perfect Tracking]] mechanics. However, unlike a standard teleport, the NEM can teleport Cogmind through solid walls. This can sometimes be useful for escaping squads as it will place Cogmind out of sight in a different room. One downside of this effect is that teleporting can repeatedly trigger the [[Watcher]] [[Alert]] increase on sight, as it will forget Cogmind each time the teleport occurs.
[[Heading:2]]Frequency[[/Heading]]
There are 2 "timers" that can activate an NEM teleport. One is based on tiles moved, and the other is based on non-moving actions.
The non-moving actions timer will count up whenever Cogmind performs any action other than moving. This includes waiting in place, so it is not possible to avoid teleports altogether. The non-moving action timer will trigger every 36-48 actions.
The moving actions timer will count up for every move Cogmind makes. This timer is much shorter, and will occur 20-32 tiles moved.
[[Heading:2]]Distance[[/Heading]]
A single NEM teleport will move Cogmind anywhere between 8-12 tiles from the original location. If a [[Subatomic Replicator]] is used on the NEM and two are consumed, this effect doubles to 16-24 tiles moved.
