Name: Operator
Content:
Operators are [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[0b10]] non-combat bots that guard a single nearby [[Terminal]]. Upon seeing a hostile, Operators will run to their Terminal, summon a [[Reinforcement Squad]] to their location, and disable the machine. [[Spoiler]]The same effect occurs if an [[Imprint|imprinted]] Cogmind pings a Terminal and the Operator is nearby.[[/Spoiler]] As such, Operators should ideally be avoided or prevented from summoning reinforcements in some way. Operators are good looting sources of [[Datajacks]], both offensive and defensive [[Hackware]], and [[System Restoration Modules]]. When destroyed, they drop a [[Data Core]] that provides a one-time hacking bonus on the Operator's assigned Terminal and reveals nearby traps.
Operators make good allies due to their unique ability to increase Cogmind's hacking power and detect [[Traps]]. Operators within a range of 20 tiles will contribute a 10% (then 5%, 2%, and 1%) stacking offensive hacking bonus per Operator. Additionally, allied Operators will report all trap locations that Cogmind encounters in visual range as long as the Operator is within a 20 tile radius.
Operators can be blocked from summoning Reinforcements in a few different ways:
[[List]]Bot destruction: A destroyed bot will be unable to report Cogmind|[[Spoiler]][[Scraptown#abandonware_association|Scraptown hack]] [[GameText]]HACKBUD.EXE[[/GameText]]: Turn the Operator instantly friendly[[/Spoiler]]|Terminal destruction: A destroyed Terminal is unusable|[[Spoiler]][[GameText]]Trojan(Assimilate)[[/GameText]]: If used on an Operator's assigned Terminal, the Operator will become a blue controllable ally when it tries to report Cogmind[[/Spoiler]]|[[RIF]] hacks [[GameText]]block_reporting[[/GameText]], [[GameText]]summon_haulers[[/GameText]], or [[GameText]]formatsys_high[[/GameText]]: Either avoid reporting altogether, turn the reporting to instead summon [[Hauler|Haulers]], or turn the Operator friendly respectively[[/List]]
[[Gallery]]Operators.png|All Operator variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

Name: Overload
Content:
Overloading is a [[Game Mechanics|Game Mechanic]] available on [[Overloadable Parts]], primarily cooled (Cld.) parts, that allows for a temporary increase in effectiveness with additional heat costs and potential downsides based on the stability of the part. It is possible to perform for Power, Propulsion, and Weapon type items.

[[Heading]][[Overloadable Power|Power]][[/Heading]]
Some power parts (e.g. [[Cld. Ion Engine]]) support overloading. Overloading power causes the following changes:
[[List]]Doubled energy generation|Doubled heat generation|Chance to shut down for ~5-10 turns and be damaged ~30-40% of the maximum integrity, based on the Stability % stat[[/List]]

[[Heading]][[Overloadable Propulsion|Propulsion]][[/Heading]]
Some propulsion types (mainly [[Flight Units]] and [[Hover Units]]), e.g. [[Cld. VTOL Module]], support overloading. Overloading propulsion causes the following changes:
[[List]]Doubled energy cost|Tripled heat generation|50% additional support|Speed is calculated as if there are twice the number of active Flight/Hover units (e.g. an overloaded Cld. VTOL Module will gain an additional -3 speed modifier)|Overload propulsion has a chance to suffer 1 point of damage each move that the part is active or each melee attack, based on the Burnout % stat[[/List]]
One special case, the [[Potential Leg]], does not have any of the above effects except for the burnout damage. Overloaded Potential Legs instead have their base speed halved.

[[Heading]][[Overloadable Weapons|Weapons]][[/Heading]]
Some energy weapons (e.g. [[Cld. Pulse Rifle]]) support overloading. Overloading weapons causes the following changes:
[[List]]Double damage|Doubled energy cost|Tripled heat generation|Additional level of heat transfer (e.g. Medium (+37) is turned into High (+50)|Chance of negative effect based on Shot Stability %.[[/List]]
If an overload side effect occurs, one of the following effects will occur:
[[List]]Energy Bleed (~40% chance): Cogmind loses anywhere from 10-50% of total energy capacity|Heat Surge (~40% chance): Cogmind gains between 100 and 200 heat|Short Circuit (~20% chance): A random part breaks[[/List]]

Name: Overtuned Parts
Content: Overtuned (Ovr.) parts have a chance to malfunction, which temporarily disables them. This can be mitigated by attaching a [[Scrap Suit]] (activated or not). Compared to their base parts, overtuned parts generally have better characteristics in exchange for higher support requirements.

Name: P1-3CE
Content: Very powerful bot that you [[I]]really[[/I]] don't want to be trying to kill you especially after attacking [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]], due to low core from the level, attacking Exiles in general and less slots at that level.

Name: PL-3XN's Obliterator
Content: Created from a [[Disassembled Obliterator]] and 3 [[PL-3XN's Ring of Power]].

Name: PL-3XN's Ring of Power
Content:
When 3 are combined with the [[Disassembled Obliterator]], creates [[PL-3XN's Obliterator]].
Up to 4 can be found, 2 of which are guaranteed:
[[List]]
In [[Scraptown]] in the Fellowship of the Rings room, carried by one of the bots (if that room appears)
|In Scraptown in the Curators Association room, either in an exhibit or carried by the Curator (if that room appears)
|Carried by a [[Cargo Convoy]] (guaranteed on the first convoy that appears; if not obtained, random chance for subsequent convoys to carry it)
|In [[Armory]] in the same room as the Disassembled Obliterator (guaranteed)
[[/List]]
Rings can be duplicated by the [[Subatomic Replicator]], yielding a total of 5 rings. Or the fully assembled Obliterator can be duplicated.

Name: Partial Spot
Content: Partial spotting is when you move through a (hostile) bots field of vision while its not its turn. The bot will investigate where it saw you, look a few tiles further then head back to whatever it was doing.

Name: Patrol Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Patrol Squad.png|A patrol squad of Swarmers[[/Image]]
Patrol squads are typically [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that patrol between points on the majority of 0b10-controlled maps, as well as [[Caves]]. They can be composed of a variety of bot types, all with slightly different patrolling behavior. Most patrol squads appear at the start of the map and will not appear over time, with the exception of [[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]] and temporary patrols. Their presence is generally unrelated to [[Alert]]. Patrols can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]]. Their frequency varies based on the type of map, but generally they are more common the higher up in the complex Cogmind goes.

[[Heading]]Patrol Contents[[/Heading]]
The following are the possible contents of patrol squads. At -9 and above, a [[C-30 ARC]] can also make up a single patrol squad. If it encounters a hostile, it will open up to reveal the contents of any other random patrol squad composition listed below:
[[Table]]
Depth|[[Grunt]]|[[Hunter]]|[[Programmer]]|[[Swarmer]]||
-10|1 [[G-47 Trooper]] squad leader and 1 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|N/A|3 [[S-10 Pest]]||
-9|1 [[B-36 Bruiser]], [[L-31 Rogue]], or G-47 Trooper squad leader and 1-2 G-34 Mercenary|N/A|N/A|3-4 S-10 Pest||
-8|1 B-36 Bruiser, L-31 Rogue, or [[G-50 Soldier]] and 2 G-47 Trooper|1 [[H-55 Commando]]|N/A|3-4 S-10 Pest||
-7|1 [[B-48 Gladiator]], [[L-41 Fighter]], or G-50 Soldier squad leader and 2-3 G-47 Trooper|1 H-55 Commando|1 [[P-60 Hacker]]|3-4 [[S-27 Virus]]||
-6|1 B-48 Gladiator, L-41 Fighter, or [[G-67 Veteran]] squad leader and 2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|1 P-60 Hacker|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-5|1 [[B-60 Warrior]], L-41 Fighter, or G-67 Veteran squad leader and 2-4 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|1-2 [[P-70 Sage]]|4-5 S-27 Virus||

[[Heading:2]]Advanced Fortification Protocols[[/Heading]]
When [[Superfortress]] is destroyed or the [[UFD]] assault is started against Protoforge, subsequent maps will have more patrols (50%) and stronger patrol makeups. The following new patrols are possible:
[[List]]4-6 [[C-57 Dissector]]|
1-2 [[D-83 Annihilator]]|
2 [[Executioner]]|
2 [[Striker]]|
4-5 X-87 Electro[[/List]]
[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Patrol behavior[[/Heading]]
There are essentially 2 types of patrol behaviors. ARC and Hunter squads are fast patrollers, which navigate between their patrol points at max or near max speed. They quickly move in and out of areas so they can be hard to avoid if in the way, but are easier to navigate around without waiting long periods of time. Grunts, Programmers, and Swarmer squads all patrol much slower. They meander along the way and spend far more turns resting than moving forward along their route. It is easier to run away form these types of patrols if you know they are coming, but they can clog rooms or hallways for long periods of time.

Map|Number of patrols||
-10 [[Materials]]|3||
-9 Materials|5||

-7 [[Factory]]|8||

[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Special patrol-summoning events[[/Heading]]
There are a few special events that can trigger patrol dispatches when already on a level.

[[Heading:2]][[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]][[/Heading]]
Search Patrols are a special type of patrol that is related to Alert. These squads can be dispatched if Cogmind generates a lot of non-combat Alert. They consist of a single [[C-30 ARC]] that roam across the entire map instead of just between two points like most patrols.

[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading:2]][[Lightning]] squads[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Lightning Squad.png|A Lightning squad patrolling Quarantine[[/Image]]
Lightning squads consist of 3 Lightnings and an [[I-47 Archangel]]. They can be summoned in one of two ways:
[[List]]
Destroying a Hub machine in [[Hub_04(d)]]: 3 Lightning patrols will be dispatched to the map out of exits and Garrisons. They will roam in the general area of each remaining Hub.|
Opening the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] chamber: A single Lighting patrol will be dispatched to the map if Cogmind breaches the Sigix chamber. It will patrol around the location of the Sigix room.
[[/List]]
[[/Spoiler]]

[[Heading]]Temporary Patrols[[/Heading]]
Temporary patrols are a special type of patrol that are exactly what they sound like. They are dispatched to patrol the map for several hundred turns, then exit at any 0b10-controlled exit. There is no specific trigger or alert that indicates when these patrols have been dispatched.

Name: Perfect Tracking
Content: Bots with perfect tracking will know where [[Cogmind]] is at all times. Most bots with this will lose it upon sighting Cogmind.

Name: Personal Teleporter v0.10
Content: Destroys or displaces (drops on the ground near the teleport destination) 0-2 items on activation.

Name: Programmer
Content:
Programmers are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[0b10]] combat bots armed with EM weaponry and a [[Datajacks|Remote Datajack]]. Programmers will attempt to corrupt and hack any hostiles, potentially changing alliances by assimilating them. They can also remove system corruption from their allies and clear certain [[RIF]] hacks from allied bots. They are a persistent threat throughout [[Factory]] and beyond due to being sent as part of [[Extermination Squad|Extermination Squads]].
Programmers are best fought with kinetic or thermal weaponry due to their slight weakness to them. Many cannons are able to kill a Programmer with only one core shot. These weapons are ideal to use. For thermal weaponry, they are also fairly susceptible to heat transfer triggering side effects and an early meltdown. Their EM resistance coupled with their tendency to travel in packs make EM and Impact poor choices to fight them, as corruption death is unlikely.
Programmers are not initially very threatening bots. They deal small amounts of EM damage and appear only in small groups in [[Factory]] depths. However, in [[Research]] they turn into a frequent threat, appearing in larger groups and dealing significant EM damage inflicting consistent corruption to Cogmind. Having a good weapon that kill Programmers in a single core hit is ideal. For airborne builds, being able to outrun or recall Exterminations is a good strategy. Keep in mind that they are fairly fast for combat bots and have a high memory of 80. [[ECM Suites]] are very helpful for shaking Programmers more easily on the run.
[[Gallery]]Programmers.png|All Programmer variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]][[Squad|Squads]][[/Heading]]
Programmers may appear in the following squads:
[[List]]Extermination Squad|[[Patrol Squad]]|[[Security Squad]] - [[Armory]], [[Testing]], and [[Quarantine]] only[[/List]]
Bots: P-60 Hacker,P-70 Sage,P-80 Master,Combat Programmer,Protovariant P

Name: Progress Achievements
Content:
[[Comment]]                       ---NOTE FOR EDITORS---
Once Beta 16 releases, if you decide to update any of the Achievements pages, please consider whether it would be better to separate the new achievements from the old ones or not.
I think that, ideally, whatever you choose to do, that decision should be applied to all Achievements pages, for the sake of consistency.[[/Comment]]

Progress [[Achievements]] are earned by accomplishing actions that demonstrate the player's progress and experience with the game. Most of them will simply eventually be obtained by players as they explore the game world and get better at surviving and exploring it. 2 of the 33 Progress Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Progress Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements of the same sub-type, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Heading]]Uncategorized[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
First Step to Greatness: [[Spoiler]]Get terminated.[[/Spoiler]]
Strategy : [[Spoiler]]You'll likely get this one eventually.[[/Spoiler]]
|Back For More: Complete 50 runs.
Strategy : You'll get this one eventually. The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Game No."
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Earning points[[/Heading]]
The relevant scoresheet statistic is "TOTAL SCORE". See the [[Score]] page for the different ways to gain points. These Achievements are awarded at the end of a run that meets their criteria.

[[List]]
5k Club: Earn 5,000 points.
|10k Club: Earn 10,000 points.
|20k Club: Earn 20,000 points.
|30k Club: Earn 30,000 points.
|40k Club: Earn 40,000 points.
|50k Club: Earn 50,000 points.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Lore collection progress[[/Heading]]
The lore collection contains all lore records, dialogues and their source, as well as all analyses and the general robot type they are about. All start out hidden, and are revealed in the collection when found within the game world.
[[List]]
Records - There are two types of lore records : [[0b10]] database records, which can be access on any 0b10 [[Terminal]] with proper database authorization, and all other lore records, which will only ever appear in one prefab, on one specific Terminal. There are also a few records that are not part of the lore collection, mostly non-unique records from [[Caves|Cave]] outposts that contain Terminals.|
Dialogues - The only dialogues that matter for the lore collection are textbox dialogues. Dialogue lines that only appear in the log and at the bottom of the screen with no textbox (like [[Operator|Operators]]' IFF handshake text) do not count towards the lore collection.|
Analyses - There are three types of analyses : "Common" for common 0b10 bots, "Derelict" for non-0b10 bots, and "Prototype" for prototype 0b10 bots. Mechanically speaking, there are many to obtain analyses, but the only way to get them in the lore collection is to hack them on Terminals.
[[/List]]
The lore collection orders its contents first by type, then by alphabetical order. However, when viewing the lore collection in-game, it is possible to export it as a txt, html or csv file. The resulting file orders its contents differently : Type first, then source (or robot type for analyses), then by alphabetical order. Except for csv files, this includes undiscovered records, making it possible to view how many records and dialogues remain to be found from certain sources. Note that if no records/dialogues have been found from one source, then the undiscovered records/dialogues from that source will not be included within the exported file.
The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Lore%".
[[List]]
This Is Interesting...: Reach 25% lore collection.
|I Think I Know What's Going On: Reach 50% lore collection.
|I Was Wrong!: Reach 75% lore collection.
|I Wish There Was More: Reach 100% lore collection.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Gallery collection progress[[/Heading]]
The gallery collection contains all parts that have ASCII art. All parts start out as "Undiscovered Components", and each one is "discovered" and revealed upon either being attached to Cogmind or when using the [[GameText]]parse_system[[/GameText]] [[Datajacks|Datajack]] hack on any robot that currently has it attached. Inventory items are added to the collection upon being picked up. Gallery collection progress is based on how many parts have been discovered. Current gallery progress can be seen in the gallery collection.

While the majority of parts are fairly common and are relatively easy to just stumble upon or find on robots in multiple different areas, some parts are more difficult to find and add to the gallery collection :
[[List]]
A lot of parts can only be found in specific prefabs in specific [[Branch|branches]], sometimes in well-guarded, dangerous-to-access places.
|A bunch of parts can only be obtained from rare/unique robots, sometimes because the robots are carrying them in their inventory.
|Some parts can only be found on robots that will never drop them upon destruction, requiring the use of a [[GameText]]parse_system[[/GameText]] hack to add them to the gallery collection.
|Some parts cannot be found anywhere, requiring the player to instead obtain their schematic and fabricate them.
|Some parts cannot be found anywhere and have no schematics, requiring them to be created through other means.
[[/List]]

The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Gallery%".
 
[[List]]
Just Browsing: Reach 25% gallery collection.
|Tester: Reach 50% gallery collection.
|Collector: Reach 75% gallery collection.
|Curator: Reach 100% gallery collection.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Exploration[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Made in Tau Ceti IV: Enter [[Factory]].
|Dangerous Findings: Enter [[Research]].
|Denied?: Enter [[Access]].
|\\\\IAMDERELICT: [[Spoiler]]Enter [[Recycling]] via [[Storage]].[[/Spoiler]]
|I'm Back, Baby!: Exit [[Caves|Proximity Caves]].
|Tourist: Visit 3 branch areas.
|Adventurer: Visit 2 special cave areas.
|Explorer: Visit 10 branch areas.
|Great Explorer: Visit 35 areas.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Reaching a high peak rating[[/Heading]]
These Achievements require Cogmind to reach a high rating, which is mostly determined by the rating of currently attached parts. Current rating is visible when examining Cogmind. The relevant scoresheet statistic is "Peak Build Rating".

[[List]]
Serviceable Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 50.
|Respectable Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 100.
|Rockin' Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 150.
|Ultimate Loadout: Reach a peak rating of 200.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Achievement collection progress[[/Heading]]

[[List]]
Achiever: Earn 25% of achievements.
Requires 64 Achievements.
|Overachiever: Earn 50% of achievements.
Requires 128 Achievements.
|Superachiever: Earn 75% of achievements.
Requires 192 Achievements.
|Perfect Achiever: Earn all other achievements.
Requires all other 255 Achievements.[[/List]]


This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Propulsion
Content:
Propulsion units allow robots to move and carry mass.

Five types of propulsion exist: [[Flight Units]], [[Hover Units]], [[Legs]], [[Treads]], and [[Wheels]]. Flight and hover units are collectively known as fast propulsion, or "fastprop"; legs, treads, and wheels are considered slow propulsion, or "slowprop." In addition, unlike other bots, [[Cogmind]] has a built-in core propulsion system used when no other propulsion is active.

A robot can use only one type of propulsion at a time. If multiple types are equipped, activating a unit will deactivate all units of a different type.

[[Heading]]Movement Speed Math[[/Heading]]
A bot's movement speed is based on its mass and the stats of its propulsion units that are activated when it moves. This section describes legs, treads, and wheels. Flight and hover units have additional mechanics that affect movement speed, which are described below.

Each propulsion unit has three basic stats:
[[List]]
The amount of mass the unit will [[I]]support[[/I]].
|The base [[I]]speed[[/I]] of the unit (labeled "time/move").
|The speed [[I]]penalty[[/I]] for overweight bots.
[[/List]]
Propulsion units themselves have zero mass (they don't weigh anything). Bots using legs, treads, or wheels can benefit from equipping unused propulsion units as "propulsion armor," or "prop armor," using their coverage and integrity to tank hits without increasing their mass.

When a bot moves, the game determines whether it is underweight or overweight. The game adds together the mass of all equipped parts, and the support of all activated propulsion units. A bot is [[I]]overweight[[/I]] if its mass is greater than its support; otherwise it is [[I]]underweight[[/I]]. A bot can also be multiple times overweight: for example, it is two times overweight if its mass is greater than twice its support. Items in inventory do not count towards a bot's total mass.

If a bot is underweight, it moves at the average speed of all of its activated propulsion units. A propulsion unit's speed is coded as a movement delay, or time per move: how many time units it takes a bot to move one tile if it's using only that propulsion unit. If a bot has multiple propulsion units activated, their movement delays are averaged.

If a bot is overweight, it is slowed down by the average penalty of all of its activated propulsion units. Specifically, the average penalty is added to the average base movement delay, and the sum is how long it takes the bot to move one tile. If a bot is multiple times overweight, the penalty is applied that many times.

A bot's mass and support are displayed above the parts list in the HUD. Overweight status is indicated by [[GameText]]Ox#[[/GameText]], where [[GameText]]#[[/GameText]] is how many times overweight ([[GameText]]*[[/GameText]] if greater than 9 times).

[[Heading:2]]Example[[/Heading]]
For example, if a bot has equipped:
[[List]]
[[Ion Engine]] (mass: 5)
|[[Lgt. Treads]] (support: 20; time/move: 160; penalty: 80)
|[[Wheel]] (support: 10; time/move: 80; penalty: 15)
|[[Sml. Storage Unit]] (mass: 5)
|[[Assault Rifle]] (mass: 2)
|[[Med. Laser]] (mass: 2)
[[/List]]
its total mass is 14. Its movement speed depends on which propulsion unit it has activated:
[[List]]
With the treads: The bot is underweight (14  20). The time to move one tile is 160.
|With the wheel: The bot is 1 time overweight (10 < 14  20). The time to move one tile is 80 + 15 = 95.
|With neither (core propulsion): The bot is 4 times overweight (12 < 14  15). The time to move one tile is 50 + (50  4) = 250.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Formula[[/Heading]]
Mathematically, the amount of time it takes a bot to move one tile (ignoring mechanics for flight and hover units) is
[[I]]d[[/I]][[Sub]][[I]]i[[/I]][[/Sub]]/[[I]]n[[/I]] + max(0, [[I]]m[[/I]]  1)/[[I]]s[[/I]][[Sub]][[I]]i[[/I]][[/Sub]]([[I]]p[[/I]][[Sub]][[I]]i[[/I]][[/Sub]]/[[I]]n[[/I]])
where
[[List]]
[[I]]s[[/I]][[Sub]][[I]]i[[/I]][[/Sub]] is the mass support for propulsion unit [[I]]i[[/I]]
|[[I]]d[[/I]][[Sub]][[I]]i[[/I]][[/Sub]] is the base movement delay for propulsion unit [[I]]i[[/I]]
|[[I]]p[[/I]][[Sub]][[I]]i[[/I]][[/Sub]] is the penalty for propulsion unit [[I]]i[[/I]]
|[[I]]m[[/I]] is the total mass of all attached parts
|[[I]]n[[/I]] is the total number of activated propulsion units
[[/List]]
and all sums  are over all activated propulsion units.

[[Heading]]Flight and Hover Units[[/Heading]]
Flight and hover units calculate their movement speed in the same basic way as legs, treads, and wheels, but they have the following additional mechanics that affect movement speed:
[[List]]
Bots move faster with multiple units. Each unit has a [[I]]bonus[[/I]] (labeled "mod/extra"). For every active flight or hover unit beyond the first, the bonus is subtracted from the movement delay. (If the active propulsion units have different bonuses, they are averaged.) But the bonus can never bring the overall movement delay below 20 for hovering, or 10 for flying.
|Attached treads, legs, and wheels induce [[I]]drag[[/I]]. The drag from each attached unit is added to the movement delay, slowing the bot down.
|Certain flight and hover units can be [[Overload#propulsion|overloaded]]. When a unit is overloaded, speed is calculated as if there were two of that unit, and the unit's support is increased by half. Additionally, if the bot is moving at the normal fastest possible speed, each overloaded unit reduces its movement delay by 1, to a minimum of 5.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Core Propulsion[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has no propulsion units active, it will move using core propulsion (informally, "core hover"). Core propulsion is relatively fast, with a base movement delay of 50 (speed of 200%), but it has pitifully low mass support of only 3 and a harsh overweight penalty of 50. It is thus very difficult to actually use, but is necessary if Cogmind's build is destroyed or if you must core purge.

Name: Protector
Content:
Protectors are [[0b10]] [[Wheels|wheeled]] non-combat bots that specialize in protecting their allies with remote [[Shield Generators]] and [[Force Fields]]. Protectors are equipped with two power sources and [[Energy Wells]] for higher damage reduction potential. They are most often seen as part of an [[Assault Squad]] or [[Cargo Convoy]]. Later tiers are equipped with [[Point Defense System|Point Defense Systems]] that make it more difficult to use [[Launchers]] against Assaults protected by them.
[[Gallery]]Protectors.png|All Protector variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

Name: Protoforge
Content:
Protoforge is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Research]] [[Branch]] off of either [[Testing]] or [[Quarantine]] on -3 or -2. Protoforge is a highly non-standard map that has a layout much different than typical 0b10 floors. For starters, there are no standard part stockpiles on the ground. All parts are stored in specific prefab locations at the top of the map, and majority are heavily guarded by dangerous [[Prototype Robot|Prototype Robots]], including the the monstrous [[Superfortress]]. [[Recycler|Recyclers]] are also missing on the map, which can make [[Matter]] management more difficult, and in their place are [[N-04 Retriever|N-04 Retrievers]] that will steal parts off the ground at high speeds. If Cogmind can surpass all of these obstacles, a wide variety of unique parts of all types are available to loot. Like most prototypes, there is a chance they may be faulty, but they are among the strongest parts in the game.

[[Heading]]Map Makeup[[/Heading]]
The map is divided into several distinct segments:
[[Heading:2]]Opening Area[[/Heading]]
The bottom-left section of the map that Cogmind spawns in is the most "normal" section of the map. There are standard [[Security Squad|Security]] and [[Patrol Squad|Patrol Squads]] hanging around the area, and most types of usual machines are accessible here, although not [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]] or [[Fabricator|Fabricators]]. Similar to other Research Branch maps, there can be small 3-tile nooks indented into the map containing special guards. Patrols can also contain unique [[Hotshot]] [[Grunt]] variants.
One unique feature about this map is the presence of non-interactive machines that phase out of existence when passing them. These machine flash briefly on sight, but they cannot be interacted with in any way, including by dropping parts on top of them.

[[Heading:2]]Forge Plexus Area[[/Heading]]
The Forge Plexus area is located in the bottom right section of the map, with the eponymous Forge Plexus located in the center of a room. This enormous machine is impossible to be destroyed as any destroyed tiles will regenerate very rapidly. If the Forge is damaged and a bot manages to enter the Forge Plexus before it regenerates itself, the regeneration process will attempt to push that robot towards the outside. If this somehow fails and the regeneration process has no way to push the robot towards the outside, it will instead crush and instantly destroy that robot (even Cogmind). This area is very heavily guarded, with 2 [[AP7-3|AP7-3s]] standing on the left entrance to this area of the map and Superfortress blocking the path to the top entrance. Additionally, 2 pairs of dormant [[EXE-6|EXE-6s]] guard the right and bottom left sides of the map, and 2 dormant [[Decapitator|Decapitators]] or 3 [[SKR-2|SKR-2s]] guard the bottom center area. Furthermore, the prototype [[Heavy]] [[Overlord]] spawns in this area, although it will typically roam into the bottom left section.

On the top right area of the Forge Plexus area is a group of 4 Fabricators. At the bottom right is a group of 3 Recycling Units. The Recycling Machines are not used for their typical purpose since parts are returned to the Forge Plexus by Retrievers rather than inserted into Recycling Units by Recyclers. However, if Cogmind aligns with [[Optimus]] and [[UFD]], the 0bPrime attack on Protoforge can be started by performing the [[GameText]]Force(Fedlink)[[/GameText]] hack on one of these machines.
[[Heading:3]]N-04 Retrievers[[/Heading]]
N-04 Retrievers can be be created by the Plexus to pick up items dropped on the floor. The retrievers grab these items and then deposit them into the Forge Plexus. Unlike Recyclers, they are capable of grabbing multiple parts at once. If there are no loose parts, Retrievers will be re-absorbed by the Plexus. The following are safe from Retrievers :
[[List]]Parts in the vault areas behind the glass walls in the back lab, even dropped parts. These spaces can be used as safe temporary storage.
|Parts in secret corridors between two Emergency Access Doors, at least while those remain intact.
|Non-part items such as [[Traps]] or [[Sapper Charge|Sapper Charges]], regardless of location.
|All parts, if the [[GameText]]clear_recycling[[/GameText]] [[RIF]] hack is used on an [[Operator]] after those parts were dropped.
|Parts moved deep inside of Walls or other solid structures by using the [[Phasing AFG]], so long as those structures remain intact.
[[Comment]]Parts inside of functional Recycling Units if Cogmind has high enough hacking skills, because there are no Recyclers to trigger the recycling process (I'm not entirely sure if Recycling Units are truly safe, i haven't confirmed if they can trigger their recycling process on their own after a while.)[[/Comment]]
[[/List]]
Note that the [[Spoiler]]Trojan(Reject) and Trojan(Mask)[[/Spoiler]] hacks are completely useless against N-04 Retrievers.

[[Heading:2]]Superfortress Hallway[[/Heading]]
There is a long hallway that connects the top right of the Forge area with the top of the opening area. Up to 10 stockpiles of up to 4 parts per group can appear here, with 6 to the left of Superfortress and 4 to the right. In the middle is an initially dormant Superfortress, a very dangerous and intimidating Prototype bot. Nearby are one or two Researchers and a [[Terminal]] containing some lore about Superfortress.

[[Heading:2]]Back Lab Area[[/Heading]]
Behind Superfortress is a fixed prefab various rooms that immediately splits into a left and right side. 1 [[Garrison Access|Garrison]] is present on the left side of the map. To the left of that is another room containing the [[Crosscalibrator]], another item stockpile, and a Terminal containing a random selection of Prototype IDs of parts available on the map. This will grant a large number of IDs, but not all possible IDs of parts. There are also 8 different prototype vaults, 4 on each side. The locations of the vaults and their guard compositions are the same each run, but the types of parts that spawn in each vault are random. The same 8 groupings of parts will always appear somewhere on the map. At the top of the lab on the right side are CX-V1P's [[Tinkerer]] lab and one extra heavily-guarded vault with 2 AP7-3 guards.
Each vault has a different combination of guards including Researchers, Hotshots, Decapitators, and [[V-Series]]. Most of the prototype bots are dormant, but have a visual range that must be stepped into in order to loot the vault. Additionally, some Researchers have a visual range that block all attempts to shoot open the vault walls by normal approach.
The hallways between the vaults are heavily trapped with a combination of [[Stasis Trap|Stasis]], [[Segregator Trap|Segregator]], and [[EM Surge Trap|EM Surge Traps]]. The top right guarded vault also can have [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] blocking the way. There are a few nooks with pairs of [[Sentry|Sentries]] at various points in the hallways. There are 2 roaming patrols made of Hotshots, Immortals, or Decapitators that go between different vaults (though they may sometimes wander into other areas), and a possible roaming patrol of a V-Series and following Researcher that walks from one side of the hallway to the other.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Protoforge[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]

Protoforge Vault 4.png|4th left-side vault with Immortals and Researcher|

Protoforge Vault 6.png|2nd right-side vault with Decapitators, V-Series, and Researcher|
Protoforge Vault 7.png|3rd right-side vault with V-Series, Immortal, and a Researcher|

Protoforge Exit.png|Main access exit
[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is only one exit in Protoforge. A main access will be in the top left of the opening area of the map, leading to the next main Research floor or [[Access]].

[[Heading]]Superfortress[[/Heading]]
Superfortress is the defensive backbone of the Protoforge and sits in the center of the map. It is arguably the most powerful robot in the game, capable of regenerating core integrity and parts as well as assembling large numbers of allies in its defense. Fighting it head-on is one of the toughest challenges in the game, and successfully doing so will result in a hefty score bonus, a + on the scoresheet, and an immediate triggering of [[High Security]] unless the UFD attack has begun.
[[Heading:2]]Dormancy[[/Heading]]
Superfortress is initially Dormant upon entering the map. Sneaking past Superfortress into the back area in this state is trivial, so it is ideal to retain this state if possible. Many things can trigger Superfortress to begin powering up from this state:
[[List]]
Being spotted by a combat bot, [[Watcher]], or [[Operator]] without being jammed by a [[Transmission Jammers|Transmission Jammer]]. Note that some bots on the map are jamming immune. If the Transmission Jammer is used without a [[Jamming Amplifier]] attached, the random failure will also trigger the wake up.|
Being reported by an Operator at a Terminal.|
Destroying an N-04 Retriever|
Being scanned by a Researcher|
Digging through the outside Reinforced wall layer around the back lab area|
Beginning the UFD assault on Protoforge|
Superfortress taking core damage|
Superfortress being teleported by a [[Supercharged TR]] (which makes it take core damage)
[[/List]]
If any of these events occur, there will be a log message [[GameText]]Superfortress powering up for active defense.[[/GameText]] After 10 turns, Superfortress will wake up with a message [[GameText]]Superfortress completes startup sequence.[[/GameText]] if in view. After this, it will begin to assemble weapons.
[[Heading:2]]Killing Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Bosses/Defeating Superfortress]]

[[Heading]]Additional Responses[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Patrols[[/Heading]]
Certain actions can cause additional patrol squads to come from the main exit or the Garrison. If the Garrison is open, these patrols will be groups of up to 4 Decapitators, Hotshots, or Immortals. If the Garrison is closed, they will instead be [[Hunter|Hunters]] and [[Programmer|Programmers]]. They will wander throughout the map randomly once dispatched.
[[Heading:3]]Breaking Lab Walls[[/Heading]]
If the outer wall of the back lab area is breached, there will be a log message [[GameText]]Research labs perimeter wall breached, dispatching additional patrols.[[/GameText]] and 2 patrols will spawn.
[[Heading:3]]Infiltrating Tinkerer Lab[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind enters the Infiltrator Lab, a log message will appear [[GameText]]Tinkerer labs infiltrated, dispatching additional patrols.[[/GameText]] 2 patrols will spawn.
[[Heading:3]][[Plexus Tether]][[/Heading]]
If Cogmind attaches the Plexus Tether, all parts on the map will be identified and revealed. When this happens, 3-5 Decapitators will be dispatched to Cogmind's position. These bots will only be dispatched if the Garrison is intact, otherwise no bots are summoned.
[[Heading:2]]Lack of [[Sterilization]][[/Heading]]
Unlike most maps, Sterilization cannot occur inside the Protoforge. As a result, [[High Security]] can continue endlessly.
[[Heading:2]]Advanced Fortification Protocols[[/Heading]]
If Superfortress is destroyed, the UFD assault is started, or High Security is activated, all subsequent maps will have "Advanced fortification protocols" activated. This has the following effect on maps:
[[List]]50% increase in patrol density|
Patrols can have non-standard bots. See [[Patrol Squad#advanced_fortification_protocols]] page for more details.|
Garrison Accesses will be locked with no way to interact with them|
Sterilization on future maps will require double the number of kills to engage
[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]UFD Sabotage[[/Heading]]
If aligned with UFD and Optimus, UFD agents will reduce the number of 0b10 Protoforge forces on the map. All prototype patrols, including additional prototype dispatches, will be reduced in size by 1-2 bots.

[[Heading]]Available Loot[[/Heading]]
The available loot is divided into separate pools of items.
[[Heading:2]]Superfortress Hallway Loot[[/Heading]]
The following items can be found in the hallway with Superfortress. Also, 1 extra stockpile in the Crosscalibrator room will have the same possible items.
[[List]][[Cep. Antimissile System]]|[[Cep. Chromion Battery]]|[[Cep. Concussive Dispersal Blaster]]|[[Cep. Core Shell]]|[[Cep. NT7 Matterbank]]|[[Cep. Phasing Heat Sink]]|[[Cep. Recoil Nullifier]]|[[Cep. Variable Chargecaster]]|[[Cep. Weapon Articulator]]|[[Cep. XC Strikerail]]|[[Exp. Launcher Guidance Computer]]|[[Exp. Salvage Targeting Computer]]|[[Exp. Surge Thruster]]|[[Exp. System Purifier]]|[[Exp. Terror Saw]]|[[Exp. Trap Extractor]]|[[Exp. VSS Leg]]|[[Gravjet Array]]|[[Hyb. Graviton Reactor]][[/List]]

The following items can be found in the vault guarded by the 2 AP7-3s:

[[Heading:2]]Tinkerer Lab[[/Heading]]
The following items can be found in CX-V1P's lab

[[Heading:2]]Looting Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Maps/Looting Protoforge]]

[[Heading]]W9: "Defending 0bPrime"/UFD Assault[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge UFD Assault.png|Protoforge UFD assault with assorted UFD bots[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Drillbomb Target.png|A marked drillbomb target[[/Image]]
If Cogmind is both UFD and Optimus-aligned, a [[GameText]]Force(Fedlink)[[/GameText]] hack performed at any of the Recycling Units in the Forge area will trigger a massive assault on the Protoforge. Waves of UFD forces led by [[Triborg (Optimus)]] will begin to emerge from an opening in the bottom right of the Forge Plexus room. Their goal is to planet and then set off 10 [[UFD Drillbomb|UFD Drillbombs]] spaced throughout the bottom left area of the map to isolate the Protoforge from the rest of 0b10. [[Lugger|Luggers]] will be accompanied by various UFD forces to plant the bombs while Optimus remains in the forge area. Cogmind can help the Luggers by protecting them or by planting the Drillbombs alone. One of the designated Drillbomb targets will always be placed next to the only exit. Once all 10 bombs are planted in the areas marked in yellow, the UFD will announce that the bombs will go off in 100 turns. The walls separating the opening area from the rest of the map will get a red highlight, indicating the safe area of the map. Cogmind must either enter that part of the map to get the W9 wintype, or exit the map to continue the run. Doing neither will results in instant death after that 100 turns. Exiting the map at this point means that a W9 will not be possible and it will also remove the ability to surrender to [[MAIN.C]] in [[Command]].
[[Heading:2]]UFD Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
Several changes to this event can occur depending on whether or not the civil war occurs in [[Scraptown]]. If the civil war does not occur, [[7R-MNS]] will appear roughly 100 turns after starting the event and follow Cogmind around. If the civil war does occur, the maximum readiness which determines the strength of reinforcements will be capped at a lower level. The overall strength also depends on the number of resources Cogmind has built up over time and through Fedlink:
[[Table]]
Readiness|Civil War Range|No Civil War Range||
Minimal|0-79|0-39||
Very Low|80-99|40-59||
Low|100-119|60-79||
Adequate|120+|80-99||
High|N/A|100-119||
Maximal|N/A|120+
[[/Table]]
For a more detailed explanation of UFD resources, see [[UFD#resource_mechanics|this page]].
Roughly every 50 turns, a new wave of UFD bots will appear from the incursion point. Higher readiness levels result in stronger bots appearing more frequently. Low is the minimum readiness required for the strongest bots to spawn, and adequate is the minimum readiness required for the weakest bots to stop spawning. Waves can contain the following bots:
[[Table]]
UFD Readiness|Bots||
All levels|[[Elite (7)]], Lugger, [[Scrapper (6)]], [[Scrapoid (6)]], [[Scrapoid (8)]]||
Minimal/Very Low|[[Bolteater]], [[Guru]], [[Explorer]], [[Federalist]], [[Ranger]]||
Low|Bolteater, Guru, Explorer, Federalist, Ranger, [[Scraphulk (6)]], [[Scraphulk (8)]]||
Adequate/High/Maximal|Scraphulk (6), Scraphulk (8)
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]]0b10 Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
0b10 Reinforcements come in two forms: Garrison reinforcements and Main exit reinforcements.
[[Heading:3]]Garrison Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
Prototype squads will periodically be dispatched from the Protoforge Garrison if it is intact. The first time this happens, there will be a log message [[GameText]]New 0b10 prototypes are being dispatched from the Protoforge Garrison Access, destroy it to block them![[/GameText]] Squads will be one of the following:
[[List]]1 [[AP7-3]]|
3-5 [[Decapitator|Decapitators]]|
1 [[EXE-6]]|
3-4 [[Hotshot|Hotshots]]|
2-3 [[Immortal|Immortals]]|
1 [[SKR-2]][[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Main Exit Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
Squads will always be dispatched from the main exit periodically. These reinforcements cannot be stopped unlike the Garrison reinforcements. 1 or 2 squads will be dispatched at a time, and each squad will consist of 2 [[Executioner|Executioners]] or 2 [[Striker|Strikers]] and a [[C-45 Heavy ARC]] with [[Assault Squad]] contents.
[[Heading:2]]W9 Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Wintypes/W9 Defending 0bPrime]].

Name: Prototype Part
Content:
Prototype parts are generally improvements on standard robot parts. They can be found in many places that standard parts appear, including in stockpiles, in [[Hauler|Haulers]], and equipped by other robots.

Prototypes can be faulty, and initially Cogmind cannot tell what a prototype is or if it is faulty. Faulty prototypes can be harmful when equipped. In exchange, prototypes are generally slightly more effective than standard parts of the same rating. In particular, prototype [[Flight Units|Flight]] and [[Hover Units]] are considered essential because they have lower coverage and higher integrity than standard flight and hover units, giving them the durability they need to be viable.

The game will often indicate a prototype part by putting an asterisk [[GameText]]*[[/GameText]] next to its rating, and prototype parts on the ground will have a pulsating glow.

[[Heading]]Faulty Prototypes[[/Heading]]
Prototype parts have a chance to be faulty. Faulty prototypes are inoperative, often have serious side effects when equipped, and cannot be repaired at a [[Repair Station]]. They can be scanned at a [[Scanalyzer]] to obtain the schematic. [[Spoiler]]Megawrench, who sometimes appears in [[Zion]], can fix faulty prototypes.[[/Spoiler]]

In general, any prototype part has a 20% chance to be faulty. But the chance is higher for some parts. And in some circumstances Cogmind can find prototypes that are guaranteed not to be faulty; examples include the contents of a [[Cargo Convoy]] (but not necessarily other Haulers), parts that other bots were using, and [[Spoiler]]some stockpiles in [[Armory]][[/Spoiler]].

[[Heading]]Prototype IDs[[/Heading]]
When the game begins, prototype part IDs are unknown. They will appear simply as "Prototype" of a specific type, and Cogmind will not be able to tell if they are faulty.

Cogmind can learn to recognize a particular prototype in several ways. The most common are:[[List]]
By equipping the part
|Through the [[GameText]]Prototypes[[/GameText]] hack at a [[Terminal]]
|By using a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] to parse a robot that has it equipped
|With a [[Component Analysis Suites|Component Analysis Suite]]
[[/List]]Identifying a prototype will teach Cogmind to recognize other copies of that specific part and see whether they are faulty.

Equipping an unknown prototype is the riskiest option, akin to quaff-IDing in other roguelikes (and often referred to as such in Cogmind), because the prototype could be faulty. Outside of combat, Cogmind can often manage the risk. But it is smart to first detach other valuable parts, since attaching a faulty prototype can damage or break other equipment.

Cogmind can forget known prototype part IDs like any other part ID, including as an effect of [[Corruption]] or [[Spoiler]]by using the [[Core Reset Matrix]][[/Spoiler]].

Name: Prototype Robot
Content: Prototypes are a diverse set of robots that are frequently some combination of powerful, made in part of prototype technology, and rare/limited to certain areas. Some can be hacked with the appropriate prototype relay coupler, but many others are immune to hacking despite being the correct class. Other than these patterns, prototypes tend to not have much in common with each other and should be strategized around individually.
Bots: Alpha 7,AP7-3,Armor Guard,Cetus Guard,Combat Programmer,Decapitator,Enhanced Demolisher,Enhanced Grunt,Enhanced Hunter,Enhanced Programmer,Enhanced Q-Series,Enhanced Sentry,EXE-6,Executioner,Fortress,Hotshot,Immortal,Investigator,Lightning,LRC-V4,LRC-V5,LRC-V6,M Guard,M Shell/Atk,M Shell/Def,Protovariant D,Protovariant G,Protovariant H,Protovariant L,Protovariant P,Protovariant X,Protovariant Y,Quarantine Guard,S7 Guard,SKR-2,Striker,Superbehemoth,Tracker,V-Series

Name: Protovariant
Content: Protovariants are a group of prototype [[0b10]] bots that appear only in [[Testing]]. They are much stronger than the average bot of each class and can appear in one of 4 states: Unpowered, Dormant, Active, or Disabled/rewirable. They can be made berserk with a special Testing-specific [[GameText]]Control(Protovariants)[[/GameText]] [[Terminal]] hack. If this happens, a special [[Assault Squad]] will be dispatched to their location that contains an [[Investigator]]. Occasionally, Protovariants will go out of control on their own even without performing the hack.
Bots: Protovariant D,Protovariant G,Protovariant H,Protovariant L,Protovariant P,Protovariant X,Protovariant Y

Name: QV-33N
Content:
QV-33N is a part of the deadly group of [[Unchained]] [[Derelict|Derelicts]] that work for [[0b10]] to track down threats to the complex. QV-33N itself does not wield any weapons and doesn't post an immediate threat. However, its [[QV-33N's Launch Deck]] can mass produce all sorts of dangerous [[Drone (Group)|Drones]]. Defensively, QV-33N can support both itself and its drones with the [[Force Fields|Remote Force Field]]-like [[QV-33N's Drone Shield]]. [[Centrium Heavy Armor Plating]] and [[Exp. Phase Shifter]] round off the defenses with some additional coverage and evasion. While QV-33N does carry an [[Exp. Reaction Control System]], it has no effect while overweight.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]Cyclists Records|UC/QV-33N[[/Lore]]

[[Heading:2]][[FarCom]] Lore[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind has aligned with the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]] and has FarCom, the following message will be broadcast about QV-33N:
[[GameText]]They will avoid you and gradually dispatch drone squads to different map locations from which to stage indirect attacks. If you find individual drones, those are probably defensive in nature and QV-33N could be nearby.[[/GameText]]

[[Heading]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
QV-33N is an evasive type of Unchained, never waiting around in one place or engaging in combat directly. Instead, they relies on their drones to do all their dirty work for them. Once they appears on the map, they will immediately create a drone to explore the map and search for hostiles with a log message [[GameText]]QV-33N launches drone.[[/GameText]] Drones created by QV-33N behave similar to [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]] or [[Search Patrol|Search Patrols]]; they search in a general area from room to room to try to find Cogmind. Roughly every 40 turns, QV-33N will dispatch another drone to explore the map as long as the Launch Deck is intact. Every few dispatches, a squad of 3-4 drones will be dispatched instead of just one, with the associated log message [[GameText]]QV-33N launches drone squad.[[/GameText]] QV-33N itself wanders fairly aimlessly around the map without targeting any particular location.
[[Heading:2]]Drones[[/Heading]]
QV-33N can create the following drones:
[[List]]
[[Antisys Drone]]|
[[EX Drone]]|
[[Kinetic Drone]]|
[[Stasis Drone]] (only as 4th drone in a drone squad)|
[[Thermal Drone]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
While QV-33N starts off rather unimpressively with a single drone, leaving them alone for an extended period of time results in massive swarms of drones roaming around the map. This is a nuisance for combat builds and a nightmare for flimsy stealth builds, especially flight builds. Your options are to try to track down and take out QV-33N early into the map, exit quickly, or else prepare for long-term harassment by an endless swarm of drones. The drones wander very far from QV-33N, so it can also be quite difficult to locate them in the first place. The [[Triangulator]] is one of the best tools for the job due to its 24 tile radius, thanks to QV-33N's [[Perfect Tracking]] of Cogmind.
Taking down the drones themselves is its own challenge. Flying at 22 speed, they can explore all over the map in no time. Defensively, they have 30% core exposure and only have 30 core integrity, but it won't be easy to land the hits needed. Thanks to their flying and tiny size, base accuracy against them is a measly 30%. Shooting with guns or cannons is unreliable without siege mode or other large sources of targeting. Aiming at nearby walls or the ground at max range with [[Explosive Launchers]] is the best way to hit them. This works well against all but the EX Drone which has 75% explosive resistance. Try for a lucky shot at EX drones if you can, but don't be surprised when the 100+ explosive damage hits you shortly after.
Apart from the drones, QV-33N itself is still a huge chunk of integrity to take down. The 75% explosive resistance means that Launchers used to delete drones won't do much damage. 50% resistance to all melee types makes them a very impractical option, and 90% EM resistance makes corruption death unlikely too. Even though QV-33N is the slowest Unchained at 120 speed, trying to keep up while dealing with drones is quite difficult for any slower builds. Kinetic and thermal damage are fortunately both totally unresisted and are the best conventional methods of killing.
One of the best ways to follow through with the kill is to use [[Hypervelocity Weapons]] to crit off the Launch Deck and Hoverbase, 2 parts with fairly high coverage at 32 and 13% respectively. QV-33N is entirely helpless once these 2 parts are gone. Unfortunately, this method destroys the best loot available. However, dealing doing damage quickly enough is an otherwise incredibly difficult proposition without endgame [[Research]] [[Branch]] loot like an [[Omega Cannon]] or a powerful [[Scrap Engine]] construct.

Name: Quantum Capacitor
Content:
The Quantum Capacitor (QC or Qcap) drastically reduces the firing time for an [[Energy Guns|Energy Gun]] or [[Energy Cannons|Energy Cannon]], but only if it is fired in a volley all by itself. This allows a bot to do much higher damage per turn (DPT) with that single weapon.

Assuming no delay modifiers, a weapon with a Quantum Capacitor will do slightly more DPT than 3 of the same weapon, and slightly less than 4.
[[Table]]
Weapons|Time to fire|Time per weapon||
[[CellStyle:Neutral]][[B]]1 with QC[[/B]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]][[B]]100[[/B]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]][[B]]100[[/B]]||
1|200|[[CellStyle:Bad]]200||
2|300|[[CellStyle:Bad]]150||
3|325|[[CellStyle:Bad]]108||
4|350|[[CellStyle:Good]]87||
5|375|[[CellStyle:Good]]75||
6|400|[[CellStyle:Good]]66
[[/Table]]

The Quantum Capacitor has several benefits on top of firing time:
[[List]]
Equipping fewer weapons means they get damaged more slowly (but it leaves your core more exposed)
|Lower mass from wearing fewer weapons
|Only need to find one good weapon instead of several
|Can simultaneously equip weapons for different situations, such as a thermal weapon and an electromagnetic weapon, instead of having to swap several weapon slots
|No overkill: you can stop firing right when an enemy dies instead of finishing a large volley
[[/List]]

The Quantum Capacitor takes two slots, so it takes a lot of space and is difficult to swap in and out situationally. And because it tends to appear in the mid-to-late game, a build that has invested heavily in weapon slots may find the Quantum Capacitor difficult to justify, or at least face the sunk cost of extra weapon slots that will be little help with a Quantum Capacitor. The extra weapon slots can be used for situational weapons or for "weapon armor": high-coverage, high-integrity weapons like the [[Sigix Broadsword]].

Name: Quantum Companion
Content:
The Quantum Companion is a unique talking melee weapon that is an upgrade to the [[Companion Sword]]. It can be obtained by either using a [[Subatomic Replicator]] on a Companion Sword or by using the Companion Sword for while. The Quantum Companion has all of the special effects that the base Companion Sword has with a higher frequency of occurrence and also has some new unique effects of its own.

[[Heading]]Special Effects[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Quantum Companion Sensors Active.webp|Sensor radius of Quantum Companion[[/Image]]
[[Table]]
Effect|Description|Frequency||
Materialization|The Quantum Companion will materialize in one of Cogmind's weapon slots within a few turns of being detached. If no slots are available, the weapon in the first slot will be detached to make room. Occurs even if the Quantum Companion is destroyed, in which case it will reappear with full integrity. The log message [[GameText]]Quantum Companion materializes via a weapon slot.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Always||
Sensors|After some time in Quantum Companion form, the Quantum Companion will develop 12 range bot detection. Unlike typical sensors, this works on all bots without a [[Signal Interpreter]], even if they have the Scan Cloak trait, and cannot be jammed in any way. However, inactive (dormant/disabled/broken/unpowered) bots will not be detected.|Always||
Surprise Attack|The Quantum Companion will "surprise attack" one additional target on a normal attack. Can only happen if there is at least two hostiles are within melee range. The log message [[GameText]]Quantum Companion surprise attacks [target].[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Common||
Core Loss|The Companion Sword deals between 5-10 core damage directly to Cogmind's core on a normal attack. Can't be reduced by [[Core Shieldings]] or [[Defensive Utilities]]. Only happens when Cogmind attacks something with the Companion Sword.|Uncommon||
Shadow Attack|A shadow clone of the sword attacks a hostile bot at range. Can occur even when not attacking. This attack cannot miss. The log message [[GameText]]Quantum Companion releases a shadow of itself that zips off toward [target].[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens. This attack deals 70-100 phasic damage.[[Comment]]IMPORTANT QUESTION: can this effect occur while a Researcher can see it? If so, would it cause them to notice Cogmind?[[/Comment]]|Uncommon||
Bot Disruption|A bot is instantly disrupted on a normal attack. As with normal disruption, a disrupted bot can be rewired as long as it isn't hacking immune. The log message [[GameText]][target] shuts down.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Rare||
Redirected Attack|When attacked by a projectile, the Quantum Companion will redirect the attack back to the attacker. The log message [[GameText]]Redirected attack with Quantum Companion.[[/GameText]] will appear with this happens.|Rare||
Sever|A part is severed off of a bot on a normal attack. This effect can hit through the Dismemberment immunity, unlike standard Sever critical hits.|Rare||
Sunder|This effect will instantly sunder a bot, similar to the [[Core Stripper]] on a normal attack. All parts are dropped between 1/3 and 2/3 integrity. Affected by the Dismemberment immunity. The log message [[GameText]][target] is sundered.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens. 200 energy required for this effect.|Rare||
Surge of Energy|This effect instantly kills a bot on a normal attack. The log message [[GameText]][target] is pierced by a surge of energy.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens.|Rare||

Teleport|Cogmind is instantly teleported to an empty space next to a visible [[Comment]]IMPORTANT QUESTION: How do the visibility requirements work, exactly? Can you be teleported because one of your drone sees a hostile? Can you be teleported due to having higher vision range due to having a Visual Processing Unit?[[/Comment]] hostile bot at no time cost, through machinery, other bots and even the target itself if necessary. Also sets momentum to maximum, and can be used to trigger an instant sneak attack if the bot hasn't spotted Cogmind yet. The teleport will prioritize closer hostiles, unless some hostiles can be sneak attacked and some cannot, in which case it will prioritize hostiles that can be sneak attacked.[[Comment]]I feel like this last sentence about target priority could be reworded to be clearer, and could also possibly explicitly mention that a teleport will ignore a hostile if there is no empty space next to it.[[/Comment]]
Can happen at any point in time[[Comment]]Can it really? I did a flight run with this, and it always seemed to trigger at the start of my turn (I was never spotted due to this movement, even when it triggered during a wait action).[[/Comment]], and can still happen even if the Companion isn't currently attached, in which case the Materialization effect will be triggered simultaneously[[Comment]]I'm basing this information off of Kyzrati's "swordy run part 2" stream. Not sure if the materialization happens before or after the teleport, but probably before?[[/Comment]]. Be careful, as this effect can very easily send Cogmind into dangerous situations or hinder a tactical retreat. The log message [[GameText]]The surroundings shift and blur.[[/GameText]] will appear when this happens. 25 energy required for this effect.|Rare
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Transformation[[/Heading]]
If a Subatomic Replicator is used on the Quantum Companion, it will transform into the [[Superquantum Companion]]. Unlike the base Companion Sword, this effect does not occur from use alone. This means that it is not possible to use a replicator to get from the base Companion Sword and also get the Quantum Companion. When this happens, the following game log message will appear: [[GameText]]Quantum Companion blips out of existence for a moment, then partially fades back in.[[/GameText]] The Superquantum Companion will also comment on it, saying one of multiple possible [[Companion Sword#upgrading|upgrade lines]].

Name: Quarantine
Content:
Quarantine is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Branch]] off of [[Research]] that appears on either -3 or -2. It is always on the floor that [[Testing]] is not on. Quarantine is a much smaller and generally more manageable map compared to normal Research floors. There are few patrols, no [[Sentry]] or [[Heavy]] guards, and only a few special mini guard areas that can usually be easily avoided. There are unique [[Researcher]] bots that show up on this map that have dangerous effects when getting scanned. Quarantine is home to a large number of unique [[Alien Artifacts]] that can be strong equippable parts or consumable effects not found elsewhere. Unlike most maps, the ambient temperature in Quarantine is -20 rather than 0. This has the effect of giving an additional 20 heat dissipation per turn to all bots on the map. Like all Research branches, [[FarCom]] will trigger [[Maximum Security]] upon entry.
Quarantine is home to the [[Sigix Containment Pod]], a captured [[Sigix]] warrior being trapped in a cage. Carrying the Sigix to the [[Surface]] is required to achieve a W3 [[Wintypes]]. The Sigix always spawns in the vertically opposite corner of the map that Cogmind first spawns on. For example, if Cogmind would spawn in the top-left section of the map, the Sigix would be in the bottom left. The Sigix is locked behind a [[Terminal]] and some Sealed Heavy Doors with 40 armor. After opening or digging past the doors, the Sigix will have some garbled dialogue unless Cogmind has used a [[Core Reset Matrix]] first. There will be a lockdown [[Patrol Squad|patrol squad]] dispatched consisting of an [[I-47 Archangel]] and 3 [[Lightning|Lightnings]] at this point. They do not have active tracking on Cogmind but simply patrol around the area. Behind the doors, one Terminal contains the access code needed to be used on the other Terminal to open the 80 armor Sigix Quarantine Chamber.

[[Heading]]Special Machines[[/Heading]]
There is one special type of machine in Quarantine called the Cryocooling Duct. There is usually at least one of these on every Quarantine floor. The map is affected by how many ducts are destroyed:
[[List]]0: The ambient temperature of the map is -20|1: The ambient temperature of the map rises to 0. All noncombat (green) bots are called to evacuate map and will head toward the nearest exit. This does [[Researcher|Researchers]] and green [[Operator|Operators]] that have already spotted Cogmind, but yellow Operators and [[Watcher|Watchers]] will not exit the map.|2: The ambient temperature becomes +20 which will apply 20 heat to all bots on the map every turn. All combat hostiles will be called to evacuate the map and most forms of squad dispatches will stop happening, including [[Assault Squad|Assaults]] and [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]]. Note: The recall and dispatch prevention does not occur if Maximum Security is engaged. After about 100 turns, 12 [[Quarantine Guard|Quarantine Guards]] will be dispatched to the map. Some will patrol around the map looking for hostiles, while others will guard key spots like exits and the [[Garrison Access|Garrison]] (if any are present).|3+: Ambient heat continues to rise +20 per destroyed machine, but no other special effects occur.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Quarantine[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Quarantine Corpses.png|Autopsy Lab containing a lore Terminal and [[Sigix Corpse|Sigix Corpses]]|Quarantine Cyrocooling Duct.png|Room containing Cryocooling Duct machine|Quarantine Teleport Lab.png|Teleportation Lab containing [[Transdimensional Reconstructor|regular]] and [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor|Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructors]] (right) and [[Dimensional Node Initializer|Dimensional Node Initializers]] (left)|Quarantine CRM.png|Machine holding [[Core Reset Matrix]]|Quarantine SR.png|Lore Terminal and Suspension Chamber holding [[Subatomic Replicator]]|Quarantine Terrabombs.png|Suspension Chambers holding [[Terrabomb|Terrabombs]]|Quarantine ST.png|[[Sigix Terminator]] guarded by [[Alpha 7]] locked behind Terminal|Quarantine Generic Chamber.png|Generic Suspension Chamber room that can contain one of many items|Quarantine Sigix Containment Room.png|Sigix Containment Pod containing room|Fortress Guard.png|[[Fortress]] guarding the corridor to branch exits|Quarantine Main Access.png|Main access exit|Branch Section 7 Protoforge Exits.png|Exits to [[Section 7]] and [[Protoforge]][[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Suspension Chambers[[/Heading]]
Some of the unique parts on this map come in uniquely identifiable prefabs. Others generic chambers can contain any parts from the following list:
[[List]][[Core Cannon]]|[[Core Stripper]]|[[Matter Drive]]|[[Phase Armor]]|[[Phase Redirector]]|[[Sigix Broadsword]][[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is always 1, and possibly 3 exits in Quarantine:
[[List]]Main access exit: There will always be 1 exit that leads to the next main Research or [[Access]] floor. It will always be at a dead end at a tile corridor near the top-middle or bottom-middle of the map.|[[Redacted]]Section 7 and Protoforge exits: These exits only appears some of the time. These exits can only happen after Quarantine, but are not necessarily on the same floor. A large 4 tile doorway will show up on the middle of the map, on the right side of where the map typically ends. It will open up into a 6 tile hallway and a [[Fortress]] will be guarding the path to the exits. These exits will be closed if Cogmind is FarCom aligned.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

Name: Ranger
Content:
Rangers are [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[UFD]] armed with penetrating [[Bolt Gun]]s. Slightly resistant to kinetic damage and slightly vulnerable to electromagnetic damage.
For the rangers dispatched as part of a rescue squad, see [[DRS Ranger]].

Name: Recycler
Content: Recyclers are [[0b10]] [[Wheels|wheeled]] non-combat bots that collected dropped parts and deposit them at a nearby [[Recycling Unit]]. While they are equipped with [[Tractor Beams]] and [[Field Recycling Units]], Recyclers do not actually make use of these parts. Recyclers are a major nuisance for their ability to steal loot before Cogmind can pick it up. If Recyclers are closing in, fire a single shot at them to get them to run away for a while and leave your loot alone. They have the highest salvage potential of any 0b10 non-combat bot, so killing them is a great way to restock on matter.

Name: Recycling
Content:
Recycling is an early game [[0b10]]-controlled [[Branch]] with few active combat hostiles. The 3 ways to enter this branch are by using the [[GameText]]\\\\IAMDERELICT[[/GameText]] code at the Recycling exit in [[Storage]], by entering a Storage [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] and looping back into this floor instead of proceeding to the next depth, or by taking the guarded exit in [[Subcaves]]. There are a few dormant [[Sentry|Sentries]] guarding hallways and several more in rooms with large amounts of rewirable bots. Unlike most 0b10 maps, more combat bots will not be summoned in any scenario. Recycling is unique in that it forces a skipped depth. For example, entering a Storage map on -8 leads to a Recycling map on -8 that leads to a [[Factory]] map on -6 rather than -7 like most branches.
The main benefits to going to Recycling are for [[Scraptown]] or obtaining the unique [[Scrap Engine]] from the scraplab. Because there are no combat reinforcements of any kind, there are few downsides to getting traced at all of the [[Terminal|Terminals]] and [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]] aside from minor [[Alert]] gain. There are a large number of Recycling Units on this map and using [[GameText]]Force(Tunnel)[[/GameText]] on all of them can be very helpful in uncovering the depths of many maps in the floors above. There are commonly a large number of [[Corrupted Parts|corrupted]] [[Authchips]] available for players who want to do a lot of [[Fabricator|Fabrication]]. A small army can be raised off of the rewirable bots in some of the rooms, though tend to be heavily damaged.

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Recycling Corrupted Authchips.png|Collection of corrupted Authchips|Recycling Dormant Rewirable Bots.png|Room of broken, dormant, and rewirable bots|Recycling Damaged Cache.png|Cache of damaged parts|Recycling Damaged Parts Room.png|Room of damaged parts|Recycling Dormant Sentries.png|Dormant Sentries guarding a corridor|Recycling Scraptown Entrance.png|Seemingly empty room leading to the Scraplab|Recycling Main Access Exit.png|3 tile wide corridor leading to main access exit|Recycling Scraplab.png|The Scraplab and the Scraptown exit[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:2]]Scraplab[[/Heading]]
Cogmind can gain access to the Scraplab by entering a particular dead end-seeming rectangular room. Inside are Terminals providing information on the [[Scrap Engine]] and a way to eject the Scrap Engine. Beware that releasing the Scrap Engine will count as a hostile action and cause the Scraptown exit to close and all inhabitants of the Scraplab to become hostile. This also causes [[Zion]] and [[Warlord]] to become hostile to Cogmind. One additional [[Scrapper (3)]] will appear from the exit to attack Cogmind when this happens. If the [[Recycling#Subdweller_attack|Subdweller Attack]] is occurring, the lab will be empty and taking the Scrap Engine will not trigger any hostilities.
[[Heading:3]][[SUBCON Basin]] delivery[[/Heading]]
If the full SUBCON basin is delivered from Subcaves and dropped on the ground, one of the [[Scientist|Scientists]] will drop a [[Tech Extrapolator]] on the ground. This is the only way to obtain one without attacking Scraptown, as the Extrapolators attached to the scientists in the lab will explode after death.
[[Heading:2]][[01-MTF]][[/Heading]]
If 01-MTF is brought from Storage to the Scraplab, a special event will occur. 01-MTF will try to explain something to [[KN-7UR]], but KN-7UR will say that his time is up, and they will begin to fight. Cogmind may choose to help out in the fight. If Cogmind attacks KN-7UR and 01-MTF wins the fight, 01-MTF will drop a 99 charge [[Relay Coupler [Proto]]]. If Cogmind attacks 01-MTF and KN-7UR wins, KN-7UR will drop their [[KN-7UR's Autopenetrator]].
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are two types of exit in Recycling:
[[List]]Main access exit: This will always lead to the [[Factory]] map that is 2 floors above the current depth.|Scraptown exit: The exit through the Scraplab will always lead to Scraptown on the same depth.[[/List]]
[[Image]]Recycling Warlord Attack.png|Derelicts attacking Recycling[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Warlord attack[[/Heading]]
There is a rare Recycling event where the floor is stormed by white colored friendly but uncontrollable [[Warlord]]-aligned Derelicts. They will beeline toward the exit, stopping only to shoot any hostiles they encounter. On exiting the floor, a few squads of the Warlord bots will also spawn on the next map and roam around.[[Heading:2]][[Subdweller]] attack[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind visits Subcaves, then exits to [[Materials]] using the normal exit instead of the Recycling exit, and then visits Recycling later, the map will be attacked by Subdwellers. The standard Scraptown entrance will not open up for Cogmind and the Scraplab will be abandoned. Stealing the Scrap Engine when this is happening will not trigger hostilities.

Name: Recycling Unit
Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Recycling Unit.png|A Recycling Unit[[/Image]]
Recycling Units are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that are primarily used by [[Recycler|Recyclers]] to recycle discarded parts into [[Matter]]. Parts are temporarily stored within the machine until full (10/15/20 total inventory depending on security level), then Recyclers process the parts one at a time to make room for new parts. Cogmind can also insert and recycle parts, then retrieve the Matter generated by hacking the machine. When entering the map, Recycling Units may already contain parts, which can be up to 2 ratings out of depth.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Recycling Unit[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Destruction[[/Heading]]
When a Recycling Unit is destroyed, parts that were in the inventory may sometimes be ejected by the destroyed machine. Each machine tile destroyed has a chance of ejecting one of the parts in inventory at the time of destruction.

[[Heading]]Rigged Engines[[/Heading]]
If a Recycler inserts a rigged engine created by a [[PSU Rigger]] into a Recycling machine, the engine's explosion will immediately go off and blow up the machine.

[[Heading]]Armor Values[[/Heading]]
The armor of a Recycling Unit will indicate what security level it is:
[[Table]]
Security level|Armor||
1|22||
2|32||
3|35
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Recycling[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Retrieving Matter[[/Heading]]
Retrieving Matter from a Recycling Unit is a multi step process. First, parts must be inserted with [[GameText]]Recycle([Part Name])[[/GameText]] (it is impossible for Cogmind to insert unidentified parts, but Recyclers are capable of doing so). Then, the [[GameText]]Recycling(Process)[[/GameText]] hack must be used to turn all parts in inventory into Matter. Finally, the [[GameText]]Retrieve(Matter)[[/GameText]] hack must be used to obtain the recycled Matter. All parts are processed at 100% efficiency [[Comment]]I didn't write 100% efficiency for no reason; not only does the Process hack explicitly say 100%, but testing using Field Recycling Units proves that 100% efficiency is 2 integrity for 1 Matter.[[/Comment]] such that, for an intact part, 2 part integrity = 1 Matter. Damaged parts grant less Matter depending on the difference between their current integrity and their maximum integrity, as the formula that determines Matter yield is roughly [Current Integrity * Current Integrity / Max Integrity / 2] rounded down. For example, an [[Antigrav System]] with 33 out of 55 integrity would yield 33 * 33 / 55 / 2 = 9.9, rounded down to 9 Matter.


[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Fedlink)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has no practical effect if Cogmind is not [[UFD]] aligned. See the UFD page for more details.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Scraphulk)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has no effect if Cogmind is not UFD aligned. See the UFD page for more details.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Scrapoids)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has no practical effect if Cogmind is not UFD aligned. See the UFD page for more details.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Tunnel)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack is most valuable in early floors like [[Materials]]. It can reveal the locations of all 0b10 [[Branch]] maps which can be useful in planning a route through the game.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Mask)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Trojan(Mask) can be used in order to stockpile large numbers of parts on the ground. This is especially useful if planning a flight to grounded propulsion transition, as it is easy to bring parts back to this location and there is no risk of losing the parts due to Recyclers. [[GameText]]Trojan(Mask)[[/GameText]] can also be good if hunting [[Cargo Convoy|Cargo Convoys]] that are heading through the area to avoid the risk of Recyclers picking up the loot.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Trojan(Reject)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack has the effect of piling up a large number of parts in the area where the Recycler is located because parts that are ejected will not be re-inserted into the machine.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Reinforced Walls
Content:
Many areas are sealed off by various types of Reinforced Walls. These walls all have much higher than typical armor values and resistances to most common damage types. The common theme between them all is that they do not have any Thermal resistance. As such, Cld. thermal [[Energy Cannons]] are the ideal way to cut through many of these barriers. Unlike basic walls, reinforced walls will not collapse due to penetrating weapons.
There are two primary types of reinforced walls. Though they have different names, they behave functionally similarly. Orange doors block the main access to the blocked off area. These doors have a higher than normal armor value, but they tend to be lower than reinforced barriers. Reinforced barriers typically surround the remainder of the area to prevent digging in from the back side. In most maps, these have two times the normal armor level of walls. For example, an average Storage wall has an armor value of 24, so the reinforced barriers have an armor value of 48 on this map.
