Name: Reinforcement Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Reinforcement Squad.png|2 Hunters in a reinforcement squad[[/Image]]
Reinforcement squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that are dispatched when a hostile presence is reported in an area. They are similar to [[Investigation Squad|Investigations]], but are triggered in slightly different scenarios, and typically stick around permanently. Reinforcement squads typically consist of a few [[Grunt|Grunts]] or [[Hunter|Hunters]]. [[Heavy|Heavies]] can call unique types of reinforcements that do not stick around forever and are made up of [[Cutter|Cutters]] or [[Specialist|Specialists]]. Reinforcements will roam around the area that they were summoned to permanently. They can be both Enumerated and Recalled at [[Terminal|Terminals]].
An alert will indicate whenever a Reinforcement squad is dispatched. Additionally, the log will display a message like [[GameText]]ALERT: Hostiles spotted, dispatching reinforcements to Terminal F003.[[/GameText]] Depending on the method triggering the reinforcement, a different reason my be given in the alert.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]WAR.Sys Records|Reinforcement Squad[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]How to get Reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Being detected by a Heavy on their [[Active Sensor Suite]]|Being reported by a [[Hauler]] carrying [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] that is attacked|Being reported by an [[Operator]] at their associated Terminal|Being reported by a [[Researcher]] that witnesses Cogmind fire a weapon in their presence|Being reported by a [[U-05 Engineer]] being attacked while trying to perform repairs[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Reinforcement Contents[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Depth|Grunt Squad|Hunter Squad|Heavy Cutter squad|Heavy Specialist squad||
-10|1-2 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|N/A|N/A||
-9|1-2 G-34 Mercenary|N/A|N/A|N/A||
-8|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|N/A|2-4 [[C-17 Slicer]]|2 [[X-57 Shotgunner]] or [[X-62 Marksman]]||
-7|2-3 G-47 Trooper|N/A|2-4 C-17 Slicer|2 X-57 Shotgunner, X-62 Marksman, or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]||
-6|2-3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|2-4 C-17 Slicer|2 X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]||
-5|2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|2-4 [[C-35 Carver]]|2 X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]||
-4|3-4 [[G-67 Veteran]]|2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|2-4 C-35 Carver|2 X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]||
-3|3-4 G-67 Veteran|2 H-77 Assassin|2-4 C-35 Carver|2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]||
-2|3-4 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|2-3 [[H-88 Terminator]]|2-4 [[C-57 Dissector]]|2 X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro||
-1|3-4 G-73 Enforcer|2-3 H-88 Terminator|2-4 C-57 Dissector|2 X-87 Electro
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Heavy reinforcements[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Heavy Reinforcement Squad.png|A Heavy and summoned Specialist reinforcements[[/Image]]
Heavy-summoned reinforcements behave differently than other reinforcements. These reinforcements only stick around for about 150 turns before returning back to a nearby exit as opposed to staying permanently. Heavy reinforcement contents also depend on Cogmind's speed. If Cogmind is on a fast airborne propulsion type like hover or flight, Cutters will be dispatched far more frequently than Specialists. For all slower grounded propulsion types, Specialists are the most common summon type.
Heavy reinforcements are called more frequently if Cogmind is actively moving. If trying to avoid reinforcements, Cogmind should quickly exit the Heavy's sensor radius rather than spend turns moving inside the radius. If the Heavy is on a [[Security Rotation]] and currently moving, it may be a good idea to stand still until the Heavy has moved away to try to avoid reinforcements rather than to continue moving in detection range.

Name: Relay Couplers
Content:
Relay couplers are used with [[RIF]] to enable special bot hacks via [[Datajacks|datajacking]] that particular robot class described in the couplers description.
Relay couplers will fry themselves when attached if you do not have [[RIF]].
Parts: Relay Coupler [NC],Relay Coupler [C],Relay Coupler [Swarmer],Relay Coupler [Cutter],Relay Coupler [Grunt],Relay Coupler [Brawler],Relay Coupler [Duelist],Relay Coupler [Sentry],Relay Coupler [Demolisher],Relay Coupler [Specialist],Relay Coupler [Hunter],Relay Coupler [Heavy],Relay Coupler [Behemoth],Relay Coupler [Programmer],Relay Coupler [Proto]

Name: Relay Interface Framework
Content:
[[Image]]Garrison RIF Installer 1.png|RIF Installer in a Garrison[[/Image]]
Relay Interface Framework, or RIF, is one of the major [[Alignment|alignments]] available to Cogmind in a run. It helps Cogmind to have much more control over [[0b10]] bots, both combat and non-combat. RIF comes with the downside of alienating several key [[Derelict]] factions, namely turning all Derelicts at [[Zion]] and [[Warlord (Location)]] hostile when passing their associated System Quarantine Field Array machines. RIF is also incompatible with the [[Core Reset Matrix]]. If Cogmind has used a CRM then it is not possible to gain RIF. If Cogmind uses a CRM after using RIF, then RIF will be entirely erased. Similarly, if Cogmind has [[Imprint|imprinted]], then the RIF will fail to be installed.
Installing RIF can be done at any [[Garrison]] by walking into a RIF Installer machine. These machines can be hidden behind emergency accesses and Phase Walls, but there are always 1-2 installers available per map. Doing so will grant several unique abilities:
[[List]]Alert Monitor: Know the ambient influence level while in 0b10-controlled areas.
 [[Alert]] is displayed near the top right corner of the HUD, showing both the numeric influence value and the number-letter classification.|Garrison Interface: Gain control over Garrison Access machines, making it easier to hack them, and also easier to escape once inside. Also automatically detects [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] and RIF Installers up to a range of 15.
All standard (non-manual) hacks at Garrison Machines will have a 100% chance to succeed. The 15-radius detection is very handy for finding new Garrisons to enter, as well as finding hidden RIF installers behind walls.|Coupler Protocols: Use [[Relay Couplers]] to interface with their respective robots.
Use [[Datajacks]] with Relay Couplers to perform special hacks at the cost of charges on the Couplers. See [[~/rif|this page]] for the full list of hackable bots as well as unique hacks applicable to each type of bot.|Additional RIF abilities: See [[~/rif|this page]] for the full list of abilities.|Special [[Wintypes|Wintype]] interaction: [[Redacted]]If Cogmind touches the intact 0b10 Conduit machine in [[Command]] while being RIF-aligned, the W4 Assimilated 0b10 win will be achieved without needing to destroy both phases of [[MAIN.C]] as is typically required.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

Name: Repair Station
Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Repair Station.png|A Repair Station[[/Image]]
Repair Stations are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that can repair damaged parts and refit backup parts. They also serve as a base of operations for [[Mechanic|Mechanics]]. As such, they can refill 0b10 aligned Mechanic repair integrity and backup part inventory that are spent as Mechanics repair and refit allied bots.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Repair Station[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Destruction[[/Heading]]
Destroying a Repair Station can drop some of its level-appropriate [[Backup Parts]], though this will damage them, and possibly also the part that was undergoing repair, if any.
Repair Stations differ in shape and armor value, which can be used to see what security level they are:
[[Table]]
Security level|Armor||
1|22||
2|32||
3|35
[[/Table]]


[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Repair Station[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Repairing Things[[/Heading]]
Repair stations can repair most parts in the game. The main exceptions are rating 9* prototypes, [[Alien Artifacts]], Backup Parts, non-part items like [[Traps]], and a variety of other unique parts. Parts that cannot be repaired have a * next to their integrity in the stat view. Parts must first be inserted with the [[GameText]]Scan([Part Name])[[/GameText]] hack. Then, the rating-specific [[GameText]]Repair[[/GameText]] must be performed. Sometimes a part will become [[Broken Part|broken]] if this hack is failed. After the repair is initiated, the machine will take a rating-dependent number of turns to repair, regardless of the amount of missing integrity. Broken parts do take longer to repair, however.
[[Heading:4]]Time to Repair[[/Heading]]
The time to repair a non-prototype non-broken part is equal to [20 + (6 * [rating])]. A broken part will take 140% of that time, a prototype part 160%, and a broken prototype 200%. The final time to repair a part is divided by the level of the Repair Station, and rounded down; Security level 2 Repair Stations repair roughly twice as fast as level 1s do, and level 3 Repair Stations repair three times as fast as level 1s.
The times to repair unbroken parts are as follows:
[[Table]]
Rating|Level 1 Turns|Level 2 Turns|Level 3 Turns||
1|26|13|8||
2|32|16|10||
2*|51|25|17||
3|38|19|12||
3*|60|30|20||
4|44|22|14||
4*|70|35|23||
5|50|25|16||
5*|80|40|26||
6|56|28|18||
6*|89|44|29||
7|62|31|20||
7*|99|49|33||
8|68|34|22||
8*|108|54|36||
9|74|37|24
[[/Table]]
[[Heading:3]]Refit[[/Heading]]
If you have fewer than 2 attached parts in any of Power, Propulsion, Utility, or Weapons when performing this hack, Cogmind will be refitted with Backup Power, Propulsion, Plating, or Lasers respectively for each type of slots. While a maximum of 2 for each slot type can be obtained at a time, more can be obtained through multiple refits by detaching the parts in between each hack.
[[Table]]
Slot|Security Level 1|Security Level 2|Security Level 3||
Power|[[Backup Power I]]|[[Backup Power III]]|[[Backup Power VII]]||
Propulsion|[[Backup Propulsion I]]|[[Backup Propulsion III]]|[[Backup Propulsion VII]]||
Utility|[[Backup Plating I]]|[[Backup Plating III]]|[[Backup Plating VII]]||
Weapon|[[Backup Laser I]]|[[Backup Laser III]]|[[Backup Laser VII]]
[[/Table]]
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Patch)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack is best used to quickly repair things that have low current integrity but have a high maximum integrity. This can restore large amounts of integrity quickly for parts like [[Armor]] and [[Treads]]. [[Storage Unit|Storage Units]] are an especially good choice for this hack due to the unique ability of this hack to repair parts without needing to detach them and wait around. Otherwise, repairing storage units can be quite risky with [[Recycler|Recyclers]] stealing parts while waiting.[[/Spoiler]]

This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Research
Content:
Research is a [[0b10]]-controlled main floor that appears on both -3 and -2. Research maps continue to amp up the difficulty in strength and number of general combat encounters, hacking difficulty, and difficulty in locating exits. Compared to the previous [[Factory]] floors, Research maps are just as big, but are much more maze-like with large numbers of smaller interconnected rooms and big sections of the level entirely disconnected by large chunks of earth. Exploring all of these different rooms is more difficult than before, and finding an exit can be a real challenge.
Unlike factory floors with [[Caves]] available, there are usually no easy exits to dissipate [[Alert]] in Research. The natural alert dissipation that occurs between levels continues to decrease. Purging alert or avoiding generating it in the first place can be a big deal if the player is not prepared to fight off [[High Security]]. [[Infowar]] continues to be important to avoid unnecessary encounters whenever possible, and [[Hackware]] should be used to purge alert and locate exits whenever possible.
As the difficulty increases, the rewards do to match. Many powerful unique parts can be found in Research specific branches [[Testing]] and [[Quarantine]]. There are also more [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] lying around on the floor. Using a [[Component Analysis Suites|Component Analysis Suite]] can pay off to avoid attaching faulty prototypes.
A big change in Research is the final upgrade of Programmers. The 1-2 [[P-70 Sage|Sages]] per [[Extermination Squad|Extermination]] get upgraded to being 2-3 [[P-80 Master|Masters]]. The extra Programmer on average, higher core integrity, and higher damage output make them a serious threat to prepare for. Many builds will live or die based on how well they can handle Exterminations. Look for a way to kill in a single core shot, like using a [[Enh. Nova Cannon]]. Airborne builds can instead make use of recall hacks or get spotted and run away to avoid direct combat.
Other important Research level bot upgrades are [[Heavy|Heavies]] and [[Hunter|Hunters]] upgrading to their highest tier on -2. The [[H-81 Overseer]] deals a frightening 91 damage per volley, becomes even tougher to kill, and gains a visual upgrade to 22 tiles which is further than the telltale 20 tile range of the [[Active Sensor Suite]]. The [[H-88 Terminator]] is also a very formidable opponent. The scary changes here are the upgrade from an [[Imp. Phase Shifter]] to an [[Adv. Phase Shifter]] which makes them even more difficult to hit, and the Scan Cloak (4) trait which makes them invisible on [[Sensor Arrays]] unless using an [[Exp. Signal Interpreter]]. If fighting them head on, using [[Launchers]] to aim indirectly or Treads with [[Special Propulsion Modes#Siege mode|Siege Mode]] can help a lot.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Research[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Research Main Access Exit.png|A 4 tile wide corridor into a main access exit|Research Undefined Exit.png|An unremarkable exit that could lead anywhere|Research Quarantine Exit.png|Unlocked exit to [[Quarantine]]|Research Locked Quarantine Exit.png|Locked exit to [[Quarantine]]|Research Guarded Quarantine Exit.png|Open exit to [[Quarantine]] guarded by a [[B-90 Cyclops]][[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 4 types of main exits on Research floors. Most of them can't be identified via look alone:
[[List]]Main access exits: These always lead to the next main floor, either Research or [[Access]]. These can sometimes be identifiable by a 4 tile wide corridor that leads into a dead end with the exit in the middle. Otherwise, any non-prefab exit could be a main access exit. [[Signal Interpreters]] or [[Terminal]] access hacks are the main ways to identify these types of exits. There will always be 3 of these exits per map.|[[Spoiler]][[Quarantine]] exit: This is the only other type of exit that can be identified. Quarantine exits can sometimes be identified when they appear as a prefab with several locked or unlocked rows of blast doors. There are also otherwise unremarkable exits that can also lead to Quarantine. These exits will always be on the floor that there are no Testing exits on. There will always be 2 exits on the same depth that Quarantine is on.[[/Spoiler]]|[[Spoiler]][[Testing]] exit: These exits are always indistinguishable from any other type of exit. There will always be 2 exits on the same depth that Testing is on.[[/Spoiler]]|[[Spoiler]][[Armory]] exit: These exits are always indistinguishable from any other type of exit. There will only be 1 exit on the depth that Armory is on.[[/Spoiler]][[/List]]
One other type of additional exit is the [[DSF]]. These exits continue on from Factory and have the same auto-lock on hostile sight behavior. Getting inside is difficult.

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]][[Image]]Research Revisions.png|Revision 17++ with Revision allies[[/Image]][[/Spoiler]]
There are 2 major Research-specific events. Both of these events can only be triggered by previous interactions Cogmind have had in [[Branch|branches]] and have major effects on the maps that they occur on:
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]]-3 [[Revision 17 (Alignment)|Revision 17 invasion]][[/Heading]]

If Revision 17 is rescued in [[Cetus]] and the Cetus Manufacturing Module machine survives, they will show up in a new form as [[Revision 17++]] and lead a group of 4 [[Revision|Revisions]] to follow Cogmind shortly after entering the map. More groups of Revisions will show up periodically and attack hostile 0b10 bots. Eventually, the Terminal network will be shut down, and [[Prototype Robot|Prototype]] [[Executioner|Executioners]] and [[Striker|Strikers]] will be dispatched along with assault [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]].
[[Image]]Research Warlord Entrance.png|Warlord making an entrance with friends[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]-2 [[Warlord (Alignment)|Warlord Invasion]][[/Heading]]
If Warlord is aligned with in his [[Warlord (Location)|base]], he will bring huge groups of [[Derelict]] forces to attack Research. All traps on the floor will be disabled after 50 turns, and after 110 that the entire machine network will be turned offline, except for [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]]. Waves of Derelicts will spawn on the left side of the map, while Assaults, [[D-83 Annihilator|D-83 Annihilators]], Strikers, and Executioners spawn from Garrisons and exits.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Researcher
Content:
Researchers are [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[0b10]] non-combat bots equipped with a [[Stasis Beam]] or [[Stasis Projector]] which will immobilize their target while active. Researchers primarily appear in [[Testing]], [[Quarantine]], [[Section 7]], and [[Protoforge]]. However, [[Investigator|Investigators]] can show up on any map at depth -3 or higher in [[High Security]] [[Assault Squad|Assaults]]. When a Researcher spots a hostile bot attacking or gets attacked, they will attempt to stasis and scan any hostile and summon a [[Reinforcement Squad]]. Investigators will scan any hostile bot whether it attacks or not. It is safe to dig into a wall that reveals yourself to the Researcher after the volley. Researchers are also equipped with anti-corruption utilities [[System Guards]] and [[Corruption Screens]].

[[Heading]]Getting Scanned[[/Heading]]
If [[Cogmind]] is scanned in most maps [[Q-Series]] will sometimes be dispatched for future [[Extermination Squad|Extermination Squads]] instead of [[Programmer|Programmers]]. [[Redacted]]Getting scanned in [[Section 7]] can instead trigger [[Intercept Squad|Intercepts]] to start showing up instead.[[/Redacted]]

Name: Revision 17 (Alignment)
Content:
[[Image]]Cetus Saving Revision 17.png|Saving Revision 17 in Cetus[[/Image]]
Rescuing [[Revision 17]] in [[Cetus]] allows for a minor faction [[Alignment|alignment]]. If this is done, [[Revision 17++]] will attack [[0b10]] on the -3 [[Research]] map along with a lot of friendly [[Revision|Revisions]] as allies.This alignment is incompatible with [[Imprint|imprinting]] and Revision will flee from an imprinted Cogmind out of fear of the [[Imprinter]]. In order for the alignment to take effect, Revision 17 must survive until Cogmind exits the map, all 8 [[Cetus Guard|Cetus Guards]] must be destroyed, and the Cetus Manufacturing Module machine must be intact.

[[Heading]]-3 Research Invasion[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Research Revisions.png|Revision 17++ with Revision allies[[/Image]]
[[Image]]Research Suppression Forces.png|Suppression forces dispatched to fight the Revisions[[/Image]]
200 turns after entering the map, Revision 17++ will lead a group of 4 Revisions to follow Cogmind. They are uncontrollable allies but do not generate any alert for Cogmind when attacking. The announcement text [[GameText]]Unknown forces entering zones 8R, 1R, 4T. Local Systems Malfunctioning[[/GameText]] will precede their coming. Squads of 4 Revisions will continue to appear from main access exits every 200 turns. Occasionally a Revision will shout [[GameText]]Recycler![[/GameText]] and turn hostile, although this may also be followed by [[GameText]]##MEMORY:RESET##[[/GameText]] to turn them friendly again. 500 turns after Revision 17 arrives, an alert [[GameText]]Research terminal network lockdown[[/GameText]] will appear, and all Terminals on the map will shut down (other interactive machines are unaffected). Another alert will show up 50 turns later: [[GameText]]Suppression forces dispatched. All non-combat units evacuate.[[/GameText]] After this message, squads of 2 [[Executioner|Executioners]] or [[Striker|Strikers]] and a [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARC]] will start to appear from exits and roam the map, looking for hostiles. They will also spawn every 200 turns.
There are a few other side-effects of this event. One is that explosive machines will explode at random whenever Cogmind is nearby. This can be good when fighting enemies around explosive machines, but be wary of them when walking around the map or else they may surprise you at a bad time. Another is that mapgen is affected. [[Heavy|Heavies]] will not appear on a map that Revision 17 invades.

This event can be a great blessing or a curse depending on a lot of factors. Getting an escort of alert-free allies with other squads of allies roaming the map is great. They will clean up most of the map for you and can net some free prototype bot loot. Blocking Heavy spawns is incredibly useful here as well. The downsides can also be pretty major, however. Losing access to all Terminals by turn 700 can be very bad if Cogmind is on slow propulsion and has no exit intel and no form of terrain scanning. Trying to follow the spawning Revisions or suppression forces can lead to an exit, although it can be a bit unreliable. Another downside is that the Revisions will often create a ton of squads to appear right at the beginning of the event. Sometimes, large groups of [[Operator|Operators]] and alarm traps can all be triggered at nearly the same time. This can result in massive groups of hostiles to appear right in Cogmind's face with unlucky exit or [[Garrison Access|Garrison]] positioning.

Last edited during Beta 16.

Name: Robot Analysis
Content:
Robot analyses are lore entries about a certain class and tier of bot, either [[0b10]] or [[Derelict]]. They also grant minor combat bonuses. Cogmind gains 5% targeting and 10% bonus damage against an analyzed bot, while the analyzed bot suffers a 5% penalty to hitting Cogmind. Not all types of bots have analyses. Strong unique or otherwise hidden bots tend to not have analyses.

[[Heading]]Ways to obtain[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[Terminal]] [[GameText]]Analysis([Bot Name])[[/GameText]] hack.|
[[Spoiler]]Using the [[Data Conduit]][[/Spoiler]]|
[[Spoiler]]Records from [[Zhirov (Location)]] Terminal. [[Alpha 7]], [[Executioner]], [[Striker]], and [[Q-Series]] only.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

Name: SGEMP Prototype
Content: Needed for the [[Redacted]][[Zhirov (Alignment)]] quest.[[/Redacted]]

Name: Samaritan
Content:
Samaritans are [[Treads|treaded]] [[Derelict|derelict]] non-combat bots with a big amount of batteries and two [[Neutrino Core|Neutrino Cores]], which are valuable if you lack spares in [[Caves]]. Slightly vulnerable to EM.
Samaritans will give energy each turn to every robot (and [[Cogmind]]) in range.

Name: Sapper Charge
Content:
Sapper Charges are inventory items. They can be activated to start an 8-turn timer that will cause them to detonate. They can usually be found near [[Sapper|Sappers]], in some cases placed and activated by Sappers to destroy 0b10 machines. When Cogmind is standing on one, pressing > or right-clicking on Cogmind will start its 8-turn explosion timer. Doing so again will interrupt the timer, which can be useful when trying to collect/interrupt one from a Sapper's sabotage attempt or after accidentally activating one. Note that both activation and deactivation take an entire turn, meaning only 7 of the 8 turns can actually be used to escape its explosion radius. Picking up an active Sapper Charge will not halt its countdown, and it can explode from Cogmind's inventory.

Because Sapper Charges' explosions deal thermal damage, they can be use to safely [[Digging|dig]]. They also deal high enough damage to destroy almost any 1-layer door-type obstacles such as [[Reinforced Walls|Sealed Blast Doors]], as well as most machines. The explosion is not attributed to Cogmind, meaning it will not raise [[Alert]] or attribute Cogmind any kills or [[Score#value|value-based score]].


As Sapper Charges are non-part inventory items, [[Recycler|Recyclers]] will not attempt to pick them up. 

This article was last updated during Beta 15.

Name: Savage
Content: Savages are [[Derelict]] [[Treads|treading]] combat bots armed with [[Impact Weapons]]. They are the Derelict versions of [[0b10]] [[Brawler|Brawlers]] and have fairly negligible differences between them. Savages are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Scanalyzer
Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Scanalyzer.png|A Scanalyzer[[/Image]]
Scanalyzers are [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Machines]] that can identify and provide [[Schematic|Schematics]] of scanalyzed parts. Scanalyzers are capable of identifying all parts in the game, including [[Alien Artifacts]]. However, not every item can be scanalyzed to obtain a schematic. Scanalyzers can additionally be used to obtain [[Study|Studies]] for non-[[Prototype Part|prototype parts]] which grant a permanent minor buff to all parts of the same type.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Scanalyzer[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Armor Values[[/Heading]]
The armor of a Repair Station will indicate what security level it is:
[[Table]]
Security level|Armor||
1|22||
2|32||
3|35
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Scanalyzer[[/Hacks]]
[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Identifying Parts[[/Heading]]
Identifying unknown parts is done by using the [[GameText]]Insert([Part Name])[[/GameText]] hack. This hack has no side effects if it fails, and can identify any part in the game. Identifying a [[Prototype Part]] this way will also determine whether it is faulty or not. If a part has no schematic available for downloading, the machine text will indicate [[GameText]]Failed: Components not registered.[[/GameText]]
[[Heading:3]]Downloading Schematics[[/Heading]]
After a part has been inserted, the [[GameText]]Scanalyze[[/GameText]] hack can be used to attempt to download the schematic. This process may fail to complete even if the hack was successful. Additionally, the inserted part may be broken by the scanalyzing attempt even if successful. If this happens, the part must be reinserted again before another download attempt can be made. Broken and faulty parts can be scanalyzed without issue. Higher security level Scanalyzers have a higher schematic downloading chance and a lower chance at breaking the scanalyzed part.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]][[Study]][[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Studies can only be obtained for parts held in inventory. Studies are [[Interactive Machine#Central Database Authorization|Database hacks]] and can trigger a database lockout.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Extract)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack can give up to 1-10 schematics that Cogmind does not already have. This can include Prototype schematics, but only rarely. Only depth-appropriate rating parts can be obtained from this hack.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Schematic
Content: Schematics can be acquired by using [[Scanalyzer|Scanalyzers]] or hacking [[Terminal|Terminals]] (see your status page for access to a list of schematics currently in your possession).

Name: Scientist
Content: Scientists are [[Wheels|two-wheeled]] [[UFD]] non-combat bots found in [[Scraptown]] and [[Recycling]]. They are quite valuable for their [[Tech Extrapolator]], and are defenseless. Vulnerable to EM.

Name: Score
Content:
Score is earned in multiple ways, including progressing through the game, destroying bots, identifying [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]], and many more. The total score earned throughout a run is shown at the end, after which the details of that run, including the different sources of points, can be found in the relevant scoresheet within the "scores" folder in the game files. From the "[7] RECORDS" menu, it is also possible to create a scoresheet dump in which the details of the run so far, including score earned, can be found. Scoresheet dump can be found in the "dumps" folder in the game files.

[[Heading]]Performance[[/Heading]]
The quick overview of overall performance and score in scoresheets, followed by the total score. Each of these categories is always listed in scoresheets, regardless of whether any score was earned in any of them:
[[Table]]Name|Points|X||
Evolutions (X)|X * 500|Evolution thresholds crossed||
Regions Visited (X)|X * 200|Maps visited, excluding [[Scrapyard]]||
Robots Destroyed (X)|X * 5|Functional robots destroyed[[Sup]]12[[/Sup]] that have a value of at least 1, regardless of hostility, alignment or faction||
Value Destroyed (X)|X|Total value destroyed, including most [[0b10]] machines (whether disabled by Cogmind or blue/purple [[Allies]]) and functional non-friendly bots[[Sup]]12[[/Sup]] (destroyed by Cogmind only)||
Prototype IDs (X)|X * 20|Unique [[Prototype Part]] IDs obtained, including any that were lost, for example due to to a minor Data Loss [[Corruption]] effect||
Alien Tech Used (X)|X * 200|[[Spoiler]]Unique [[Alien Artifacts]] attached (actual usage not required)[[/Spoiler]]||
Bonus (X)|X|Total bonus points obtained from various sources[[/Table]]
[[Sup]]1[[/Sup]]Broken/Unpowered robots do not count towards score in any way.
[[Sup]]2[[/Sup]]In each map, no more than 60 robot kills of a single class may contribute to score. (Additional robots are not recorded in any part of the score section, but are still recorded in other sections of scoresheets.)

[[Heading:2]]Value[[/Heading]]
Value is dependent on robot class and type of machine. Purely decorative machines and non-0b10 machines usually have a value of 0, most 0b10 machines have a value of 10, functional [[Garrison Access|Garrison Accesses]] have a value of 100, and some important machines like Garrison Relays and Phase Generators have a value of 200.
The value of common [[0b10 Bots]] is equal to their class number (for example, the [[G-67 Veteran]] has a value of 67), though there are a few exceptions, like the entire [[Duelist]] class. Other combat robot classes' values aren't listed anywhere in-game, but usually reflects their strength fairly well.
[[Assembled]], passive [[Derelict]] bot classes, special bots that can only ever be found unpowered as "statues" and most [[Drone (Group)|Drones]] have a value of 0. Three special bots have a value of 2000, while all unique bots and all other other special bots have a value of 1. Some of those important unique/special bots instead grant score through bonus points.


[[Heading]]Bonus Points[[/Heading]]
Bonus points are obtained from a large variety of sources, almost all of them spoilery. Remember to set your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not want to see potential spoilers! Sources of bonus points that require playing Challenge/Special Modes are listed in the dedicated table further below.
Unlike overall performance score, bonus score categories only appear in scoresheets if point were earned in them. Various [[Achievements]] have the same requirements as some bonus score categories. For categories that require destroying very specific robots or machines, unless otherwise noted, anything will count so long as the corresponding bots/machines are destroyed, and Cogmind does not actually have to personally destroy the bots/machines. The following is a complete(?) list of bonus point sources, more or less in the order they appear in scoresheets (a '?' indicates that the writer of this article is unsure about whether a source stacks or not) :

If an amount of score earned is a decimal numeral (such as in the cases of "High Alert Combat Kills" and "Follower Combat Kills" bonus score categories), that amount of score is rounded down. For example, destroying an [[S-27 Virus]] at Alert level 2 would grant 6.75 points in the High Alert Combat Kills category, which would be rounded down to 6.

[[Heading]]Challenge/Special Modes-Related Score[[/Heading]]
Some sources of score are affected by or exclusive to some Challenge/Special Modes. They are listed here separately, as runs with Challenge/Special Modes active are disqualified from the official leaderboards (though some Special Modes have had and may have temporary special leaderboards when they were/are released). For example, in one run that triggered 105 traps, the player got 1750 Trapped points. In one of my runs, where i triggered 22, i got 1000. But in a different run, where i'd triggered 53, i got only 500 Trapped points.[[/Comment]]

Name: Scrap Engine
Content:
Scrap Engine is a unique [[Derelict]] part that can only be obtained by stealing from the [[Recycling#Scraplab|Scraplab in Recycling]]. It has the capability to create powerful constructs by combining many different parts into one. It can create power constructs of up to 4 slots, propulsion up to 8 slots, and weapons of up to 4 slots. When more of Cogmind's slots are dedicated to constructs, they will also get more powerful overall.
The Scrap Engine can be obtained in one of two ways, with various consequences. The first way is by simply taking it from the Scraplab in Recycling normally. This will cause all the bots in the lab to become hostile to Cogmind, as well as enraging [[Zion]] and [[Warlord (Location)]]. However, if Cogmind visits the [[Subcaves]] beforehand, exits to [[Materials]], and then goes to Recycling, the map will be attacked by [[Subdweller|Subdwellers]]. In the chaos, the Scraplab will have been abandoned, and Cogmind can take the part without causing hostilities.
The Scrap Engine can create combinations of parts that would never be seen normally, such as energy cannons dealing kinetic damage with heat transfer, or 50 speed treads. Modifications to the constructs will only change a few stats at a time, so overall variability is extremely high when using the engine. Modifying a construct with a flight unit may result in a much higher speed, or it may dramatically reduce the integrity and support instead. Every part that is eaten can be a gamble, since the stats that are modified are random every time.

[[Heading]]Processing Parts/Inventory[[/Heading]]
The Scrap Engine can be fed parts by enabling it and standing on top of a part. Once eaten, a part will remain in the Scrap Engine's inventory until it is used for creating a new construct or for modifying an existing one. Up to 10 power, propulsion, protection, and weapons can be stored (counted separately for each part type). This inventory can be used as a pseudo-storage mechanism by preemptively eating a part and disabling the Scrap Engine to prevent use until later. This is more efficient than keeping parts in regular inventory, but is more restrictive since the parts used for modification can't be explicitly selected anymore. If over 10 parts of a given type is fed to the engine, the first part in the engine's inventory will be destroyed.
[[Heading:2]]Broken/Faulty parts[[/Heading]]
The output of the Scrap Engine is not negatively affected by inputting low-integrity, broken, or faulty parts. As such, it may be a good idea to feed these parts to the Scrap Engine instead of throwing them away or letting them become totally destroyed.
[[Heading:2]]Protection parts[[/Heading]]
Rather than going toward creating new constructs, protection is instead used to reinforce the Scrap Engine itself. The first time that a protection item is consumed, the Scrap Engine will turn itself into the [[Arm. Scrap Engine]], gaining more coverage and integrity. Every subsequent armor piece consumed will restore 100 Scrap Engine integrity.

[[Heading]]Creating constructs[[/Heading]]
If 2 power, 3 propulsion, or 4 weapons are stored in the engine's inventory at once, a new construct can be created by combining all of the parts into a new one. Duplicates of a part may be used in new constructions, but at least 2 unique parts must be involved in new construct creation. Note: There is a maximum of 1 power and 1 propulsion construct each at a time, but up to 4 weapon constructs can be created. New constructs are created with a mix of the stats of the original items put into them. The Scrap Engine will preferentially create new constructs as opposed to modifying existing ones.
[[Heading:2]]Naming[[/Heading]]
The names of constructs are generated from a combination of parts processed up to that point. For example, eating an [[Ion Engine]] and a [[Nuclear Core]] may result in a Nuclear-Ion Core. Further modifications may cause the name to change over time.
[[Heading:2]]Type[[/Heading]]
The initial type of a construct will be selected randomly from its original parts. This can cause unusual stats, such as treads much faster than typically seen when created in combination with a faster propulsion type like flight. Like names, the type of a construct can change over time with more modifications. Propulsion constructs gain all natural ability of the propulsion type, like a flight construct granting bot hopping, or a leg construct granting running avoidance bonuses.

[[Heading]]Modification[[/Heading]]
Constructs can be modified when at least 2 different parts are stored in the Scrap Engine's inventory at a given time. For example, 2 [[Aluminum Leg|Aluminum Legs]] would not result in modification, but 1 Aluminum Leg and 1 [[Imp. Aluminum Leg]] would cause a modification, as would 1 Aluminum Leg and 1 [[Flight Unit]].
Each time a construct is modified, 1-5 random stats (generally higher numbers for weapons, lower numbers for power and propulsion) are modified based on the parts that were just processed. Additionally, if there is a slot available, the modified construct may grow in size. The growing chance decreases as the construct gets bigger, so increasing from 1 slot to 2 slots is much easier than increasing from 2 to 3. Additionally, modifying a construct will restore about 1/3 of its integrity.
[[Heading:2]]Multiple slots[[/Heading]]
When parts evolve into multiple slots, some of the stats also scale proportionally. Resource costs always scale in accordance with the number of slots, as will integrity and coverage. Aside from that, primary aspects of the slot type like energy generation, support, and damage will all scale based on slot number. Stats that are percentage based, like overload burnout and critical hit chance, don't tend to change based on slot counts.
One unique interaction between multiple weapon constructs is the ability to merge. Rather than growing into a unique 2 slot weapon construct, sometimes 2 existing constructs will combine into a single multislot construct. The stats of both component constructs will be mixed together into the resultant construct.
[[Heading:2]]Special Abilities[[/Heading]]
Non-standard/special stats/abilities may be given to the constructs based on the type of part eaten. For example, eating a Cld. power source such as a [[Cld. Ion Engine]] may grant the ability to overload the power construct. These special stats/abilities may also be removed at random by further modifications. If a construct has a stat specific to a part type, such as overload on a flight/propulsion type, and changes to a new type that no longer supports it, such as treads, that special stat will be removed.
[[Heading:3]]List of special stats/abilities applicable to constructs[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Slot|Stat/ability|Part to consume|Loss on type change?||
Power|Overload|Any Cld. power source like [[Cld. Ion Engine]]|Never||
Propulsion|Overload|Any Cld. flight or hover unit like [[Surge Thruster]]|Change to Wheel, Leg, or Treads||
Propulsion|Siege Mode|Any 2 slot treads like [[Hvy. Siege Treads]]|Change to non-Treads||
Weapon|Overload|Any Cld. energy weapon like [[Cld. Particle Cannon]]|Change to non-Energy Cannon/Gun||
Weapon|Waypoints|Any guided weapon like [[Gui. Plasma Cannon]]|Never||
Weapon|[[Spoiler]]Entropic damage type, additionally loss of integrity per shot[[/Spoiler]]|[[Spoiler]]Any Vortex weapon like [[Vortex Rifle]][[/Spoiler]]|Never
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Part destruction[[/Heading]]
Unlike most parts, constructs are not always instantly destroyed when they run out of integrity. Any multislot parts are instead reduced in slot count and partially restored in integrity. Though the slot may be hard to regrow again, it does make constructs more resilient than they first might appear. The only exception to this rule is that a Vortex weapon construct will be entirely destroyed if it runs out of integrity due to being fired.
When any construct is forced to shrink in size via damage, fully destroyed, or manually removed, the Scrap Engine will be slightly damaged in the process, reporting that [[GameText]]Scrap Engine damaged due to network destabilization[[/GameText]].

[[Heading]]General Strategies[[/Heading]]
Scrap Engine tends to be a very powerful but often unreliable part. It can generate abnormally powerful constructs, far outstripping anything else available, and then snatch the positive aspects of them away and leave you with a weapon that generates 400 heat per shot. As such, making modifications with a lot of spare parts around is always a good idea to reduce the chance of getting stuck with a hard to use part. On the other hand, if a great construct is created, it may often be worth postponing further modifications until needed to repair integrity. Otherwise, the best qualities may be lost before long.
A good strategy is to approach the modifications with moderation. Going all in on thermal energy cannons may result in a high damaging high meltdown weapon, but may also spike your own heat generation past reasonable levels. Mixing in lower heat generating kinetic guns and cannons will tend to balance your weapons out with more sustainable energy and heat resource costs. Propulsion can be approached similarly. Eating a mixture of hover, legs, and tread propulsion will tend toward middle of the road constructs that aren't amazing at anything in particular, but you will rarely end up with the excessive highs and lows that can occur if only one type of propulsion is focused on. Additionally, being more lenient in what you eat will help keep constructs topped off on integrity.
For a higher risk higher reward approach, mixing extremes like treads and flight can result in some incredibly overpowered propulsion constructs. A primarily treads-orientated propulsion construct only needs a single good flight modification to take the speed down to close to the 40 speed range. However, bad modification can instead lose lots of integrity or support. Doing this is safer with a lot of spare parts to eat in case things go south. Another example of a beneficial extreme is combining high critical rate [[Hypervelocity Weapons]] like [[Hyp. Gauss Cannon]] with meltdown criticals from thermal cannons. It is possible to create an abnormally high meltdown critical % weapon this way, at the risk of losing some weapon damage.
[[Heading:2]]Multi-projectile Weapons[[/Heading]]
[[Flak Gun|Flak Guns]] can produce excellent constructs due to their high projectile count. While some stats get reduced to compensate for the increased projectile count, it is still possible to achieve overall high damage and a high critical percent chance. It is even possible to go beyond the original weapon's projectile count (6 in the case of Flak Guns). Heat transfer is another good stat to apply to a large projectile construct. A high heat transfer combined with a high projectile count can melt bots nearly instantly.
[[Heading:2]]Miscellaneous Tips[[/Heading]]
[[List]]Have a stockpile of parts before equipping the Scrap Engine - Recycling is a good place to get a strong start on constructs due to the large number of different types of parts to eat, and the lack of big threats. If saving Scrap Engine for later, try to create a good sized loot pile ahead of time to get a head start on growing the constructs.|
Don't go all in on EM damage - If all of your weapon slots are a single construct of EM type damage and you run into a [[Programmer]], you're going to have a rough time.|
Be careful of destroying cover - Construct weapons tends to be much more powerful than typical weapons and will blow through walls right and left. This is good in some situations, but it can also leave you wide open to multiple angles of attack.|
Leave a slot open for a [[Launchers]] - Dedicating all of your weapon slots to constructs makes it hard to deal with [[Swarmer|
Swarmers]] or other large groups of hostiles.|
Make careful [[Storage Unit|
Storage]] selections - Larger storage units like [[Hcp. Storage Unit]] and above may be difficult to carry if flight and hover propulsion are eaten. Smaller storage units can be carried more easily without overweight penalties with a bad support modifications.|
Modify constructs with slots open - If trying to grow a construct, make sure that an empty slot is available for growth. This is especially the case for weapon constructs. Even though two weapon constructs may occasionally merge into a single multislot construct, it is more reliable to grow the slot number by keeping one available.|
Don't have more than 3 weapons in engine inventory at a time - If trying to grow a weapon construct in number of slots, having 4 parts in inventory with an open weapon slot will always result in a new construct being created rather than having the existing construct modified. It may take a little longer, but making sure to process only 2 at a time will ensure maximum modifications and the highest chance to grow a weapon construct in slot count.|
Take Alignments - [[Warlord (Alignment)]] and [[Imprint]] can both be the source of great parts to feed the scrap engine. Note that in order to align, Cogmind must have taken the Scrap Engine from a Subdweller-attacked Recycling, otherwise the associated maps will be hostile.[[/List]]

Name: Scrap Shield
Content:
Used by [[Subdweller|Subdwellers]] in the [[Subcaves]]. Can be repaired with a [[Scrap Shield Fragment]], also commonly found in the Subcaves.

Later on in [[Scraptown]], [[Spoiler]]can be returned to a [[Scientist]], which will cause an [[Enh. Scrap Shield]] to be delivered in the [[Caves]].[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Scrap Shield Fragment
Content: Found in the Subcaves. Used to repair a [[Scrap Shield]].

Name: Scraphulk
Content: Scraphulks are large [[Legs|legged]] [[UFD]]-aligned combat bots Cogmind can create by using the [[GameText]]Force(Scrapoids)[[/GameText]] hack at [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]]. They are similar to scrapoids but are much tankier and individually more powerful with their Ovr. cannon weaponry, and can repair their parts and even core with their [[Scrap Suit|Scrap Suits]]. Their unique [[Partition Strike Chip]] allows them to apply salvage with cannons.

Name: Scrapoid
Content: Scrapoids are [[UFD]]-aligned combat bots Cogmind can create by using the [[Scrapoid Pod]] or by using the [[GameText]]Force(Scrapoids)[[/GameText]] hack at [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]]. They have little in the way of defenses, but have high offensive capabilities with their unique Ovr. weaponry, and can repair their parts and even core with their [[Scrap Suit|Scrap Suits]]. They also carry a [[CPS Tube]] and can use it while in combat.

Name: Scrapper (3)
Content: Scrappers are [[Legs|legged]] [[UFD]] bots armed with an [[Ovr. Pulse Rifle]] located mainly in [[Scraptown]].

Name: Scraptown
Content:
Scraptown is a [[Branch]] accessible through [[Recycling]], based in the Old 0b1 Recycling map, that is the home to a large amount of [[UFD|United Federation of Derelicts (UFD)]]-aligned [[Derelict|Derelicts]]. Scraptown contains many different groups of Derelicts and most have various rooms that can appear from run to run. The overall layout of Scraptown is the same each run, but the rooms will contain different combinations of groups each time. There are C-Scrubber machines at the entrance and all exits on this map that will cleanse corruption, and their use is recommended to avoid misfiring and causing accidental hostilities.
The map always consists of an open left area that all bots are free to explore. The map is divided by a giant UFD HQ Gate with [[Triborg]] guarding nearby. The gate has 60 armor and high resistances to all main damage types except for Thermal damage. Realistically, the only options to cut through are [[Plasma Cutters|Plasma Cutter]] or the [[Siege Cannon]]. However, the gate will open automatically if Cogmind becomes UFD aligned. The right side of the map contains many more unique rooms.

[[Heading]]Alignment - [[UFD]][[/Heading]]
Talking to the Scrapper standing next to the UFD registry near the HQ gate will allow Cogmind to become a UFD member and enter the right side of the map. This alignment is only possible if Cogmind is not [[RIF]]-aligned, has not taken [[FarCom]], and has not stolen or attacked the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]].
[[Heading:2]]Sub-Alignment - [[Optimus]][[/Heading]]
After becoming a UFD member, it is also possible to team up with Optimus and the 0bPrime UFD group in the center of the map. This has some additional benefits later in the game, but has the downside of starting a civil war if Cogmind does not quickly exit the map.

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]

Scrap Shield]], delivered in [[Caves]]|Scraptown Scrap Suits.png|[[Scrap Suit|Scrap Suits]] and CPS Tubes available to UFD members|Scraptown T0-NE2.png|T0-NE2, looking for triangle-related artifacts[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading:2]]T0-NE2[[/Heading]]
T0-NE2 is looking for various triangle-related artifacts. If Cogmind finds a [[V3-11A's Pendant]] in [[Subcaves]], they will reward Cogmind with the location of another triangle artifact. Cogmind will be able to find the [[Amulet of Y3-NDR]] in a Caves map.

[[Heading:3]]A0-MCA's Data Center[[/Heading]]
A0-MCA will examine Cogmind's build and give a build rating between F and S. The requirements for getting an S rank are very strict, but if it is met, A0-MCA will reward Cogmind with a free Expert System. Regardless, Cogmind will be given an [[A0-MCA's Component Scanner]]. The requirements for an S build are the following:
[[Image]]Scraptown A0-MCA S Rank.png|An example of a build that achieves as S rank[[/Image]][[List]]Close to the mass support limit (>80% support usage)|
Fast speed (faster than 50)|
Good energy generation (> 5 energy generation per turn, > 2 energy generation per move)|
Good heat dissipation (>10 heat dissipation per turn, >2.5 heat dissipation per move)|
Armor being the highest coverage part|
Core exposure being below 20%|
Weapons that can allow sustained firing (Launchers or Kinetic guns both good choices)[[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Abandonware Association[[/Heading]]
List of available abandonware bot hacks:
[[List]][[GameText]]ERRANTS.EXE[[/GameText]] - Causes a [[Sentry]] to roam around a large area near their guard post instead of staying at their location.|
[[GameText]]HACKBUD.EXE[[/GameText]] - Instantly turns an [[Operator]] into a blue controllable ally.|
[[GameText]]KABOOM.EXE[[/GameText]] - Instantly kills a [[Demolisher]] and creates a weapon-based explosion at their position.|
[[GameText]]MELTYB.EXE[[/GameText]] - Makes a [[Behemoth]] overheat to Critical temperature very quickly, adding several hundred heat per turn, and making easy to meltdown with a thermal weapon. Only works 33% of the time and can only be attempted once per Behemoth.|
[[GameText]]OVRCLOCK.EXE[[/GameText]] - Gives a hacked [[Hunter]] halved volley time, for example, bringing a [[H-55 Commando]]'s volley from 300 to 150. This typically overheats the Hunter very rapidly. Additionally, gives a small chance to break all attached weapons each Hunter volley.|
[[GameText]]POISON.EXE[[/GameText]] - Causes a [[Heavy]]'s core to fail, falling to 0 within a period of about 30 turns. Only works 2 times.|
[[GameText]]REBOOT5.EXE[[/GameText]] - Reboots a [[C-40 Crusher]] for 5-10 turns. Rewiring is possible in this time frame. Only works once per Crusher.|
[[GameText]]REPAIR.EXE[[/GameText]] - Turns any [[Mechanic]] into a purple uncontrollable allied bot.|
[[GameText]]REVENGE.EXE[[/GameText]] - Corrupts any [[Programmer]] within a few turns.|
[[GameText]]SHUTEYE.EXE[[/GameText]] - Instantly breaks any [[Watcher]].|
[[GameText]]TRNCOAT.EXE[[/GameText]] - A Programmer emits a 15 damage 3 tile radius EM damage effect every few turns. Has spectrum and disruption. The programmer itself is hit by the damage.[[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Cartography Club[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Scraptown Cartography Club Solve.png|Steps to solve the Cartography Club Maze (may be mirrored)[[/Image]]
The Cartography Club contains multiple rewards that are locked behind a maze. These items are a [[Mapping Drone Bay]] (not guaranteed), a [[Surveybot 17 Chip]] (not guaranteed), a Terminal filled with various forms of map intel (guaranteed), and a [[Deep Structural Scanner]] (guaranteed). In order to perform steps 4-6, Cogmind must be at least 120 speed. A slower bot can temporarily purge items in order to complete the puzzle since core hover is more than enough speed.
The maze may mirrored horizontally from the example image. The following steps will solve the maze:
[[List]]1: From the entrance, step toward the terminal. A wall will rise in front of Cogmind.|
2: From the Terminal, follow the path left path, bypassing an Explorer blocking the path. A wall will open up at the end of the path.|
3: The Surveybot 17 Chip and Mapping Drone Bay may appear in the section above.|
4: Step into the top left corner. A message [[GameText]]Triggered a sensor switch[[/GameText]] will appear. Head back to the entrance and into the temporarily opened hole in the wall to the right.|
5: Although the wall appears to be blocked off, walk next to the Terminal wall on the opposite side of the entrance heading downward. It will slide open and the Terminal will be accessible.|
6: Head to the top left corner in the room to the right of the Terminal. Another sensor switch will activate, hiding a wall tile blocking access to the Deep Structural Scanner. The wall tile is in the top left corner of the maze.[[/List]]

Sensor Array]]|[[Exp. Signal Interpreter]]|[[Exp. Terrain Scan Processor]]|[[Exp. [[List]]

[[Personal Teleporter v0.10]]|
[[System Spiker]]|
[[Thermal Lance]]|
