[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are two exits from Scraptown, one in the upper-left area and one in the upper-right corner. If Scraptown is on -7, these exits lead to the -5 [[Factory]] map. Otherwise, these exits lead to the -6 Factory map.

[[Heading]]Civil War[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind talks to Optimus, a civil war will eventually happen if Cogmind remains on the map. Optimus will have dialogue 30 and 80 turns after talking, indicating that Cogmind shouldn't stick around too long. After 400 turns or 72 moves, whichever happens sooner, a cutscene will reveal that Optimus has a secret plan that puts Scraptown in danger.
After the civil war has started, about half of the assorted UFD bots will align with 0bPrime and the rest will be hostile to 0bPrime bots (including Optimus and all [[Elite (4)|Elites]]) and Cogmind. During this war, Cogmind is free to smash walls and collect loot on the map.
[[Heading:2]]Civil War Looting[[/Heading]]
The civil war is a great time to loot the various parts on the map that are normally locked  behind aggro. Cogmind can freely kill any hostile bots and dig through walls without penalty. Nearly all parts are available during the civil war, although IN-MT5's Pitchfork schematic cannot be acquired using this method.

[[Heading]]Hostilities[[/Heading]]
The UFD is typically friendly to Cogmind but will turn hostile if Cogmind attacks a bot or digs through any dirt or machine tiles. There are a large amount of bots that will turn hostile to Cogmind, so attacking should not be done lightly. If Cogmind is capable of taking down all of its inhabitants, there are a large number of unique items that are only available by attacking Scraptown.
[[Heading:2]]Attack Mechanics[[/Heading]]
After Cogmind either attacks a bot or destroys a wall or machine tile, every UFD bot will turn hostile to Cogmind with the message [[GameText]]Intruder alert! Defend Scraptown![[/GameText]]. When this happens, the HQ gate will open up by 2 tiles, non-combat bots like [[Scientist|Scientists]] will begin to exit the map, and combat bots will start heading to the center of the map. After that, certain events will occur in a predictable fashion:
[[List]]
~100 turns: 4 [[Scrapper (3)|Scrappers]] will come from the left exit and guard it.|
~105 turns: The message [[GameText]]Triborg tracking relay activated. Stay clear or you only have yourself to blame![[/GameText]] appears. Triborg will gain tracking on Cogmind and pursue throughout the map. A small group of other combat bots will follow along with him. Triborg will shoot through walls like a [[Behemoth]], so hiding is not particularly effective|
~400-600 turns: The message [[GameText]]HQ reinforcements inbound. Hold Tight![[/GameText]] will appear. When this happens, Optimus will gain tracking on Cogmind. About 25 various combat bots will trail after him.|
+100 turns (~500-700 turns): Reinforcements will start to appear from exits on the left and right sides of the map. A large group of bots will appear instantly, and more will trickle onto the map over time. These bots travel in groups like [[Patrol Squad|Patrol Squads]].
|+250 turns (~750-950 turns): The message [[GameText]]Sorry everyone, if you're still alive to receive this, we've run out of nearby reinforcements. Consider running and hiding![[/GameText]]
[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]Attacking Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Maps/Attacking Scraptown]]

[[Heading]]Loot from Murder[[/Heading]]
Some loot can be obtained by killing certain bots on the map:
[[List]]
[[Exp. Recalibrator]]: Dropped by CR-KLE|
Expert System: Dropped by A0-MCA|
[[ID Mask]]: Dropped by Scientist in Chapter 10|
PL-3XN's Ring of Power: Dropped by Explorer in the Fellowship of the Rings
[[/List]]

Name: Scrapyard
Content: The starting point of every game. At the start of every game there is a semi-random fixed spawn of: [[Sml. Storage Unit]], 2 [[Lgt. Treads]], 2 [[Aluminum Leg]], a mix of 2 [[Wheel]] or [[Com. Wheel]], a mix of 2 [[Ion Engine]] or [[Lgt. Ion Engine]], and a mix of 3 [[Lgt. Assault Rifle]], [[Assault Rifle]], [[EM Pulse Gun]], [[Sml. Laser]], [[Med. Laser]]. If the advanced game option quickStart is set, all of the parts will be either collected or equipped.[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]A team of [[T-07 Excavator|Tunnelers]] and [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]] will dig out and finish rooms over time. The rooms themselves do not contain anything of importance.[[Image]]Scrapyard Assembled Event.png|Assembled after ambushing a Tunneler[[/Image]]However, after several thousand turns of waiting, an Tunneler may dig open a small dug out area containing a large number of [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]]. This will prompt a response of a [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARC]] containing 2 [[D-53 Grenadier|Demolishers]] which can be a good early source of [[Cmb. Airjet]] if they are destroyed by the assembled. Waiting around for this event can be fairly risky since there is no way to prepare for the fight and it is very easy to get destroyed by either the demolishers or the assembled.

Name: Search Patrol
Content: Search patrols are a unique type of [[0b10]] aligned [[Patrol Squad|patrol squad]]. They can be dispatched if Cogmind generates a lot of [[Alert]] from non-combat sources. This is primarily caused by being spotted by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or [[N-01 Spotter|Spotters]], guard bots like [[Sentry|Sentries]], or by being spotted by any combat hostile and then running away and losing tracking. If the Alert level is above the typical [[Assault Squad|Assault]] range of level 2/400 influence and Cogmind has gained the majority of the influence from these non-combat sources, there is a chance that one or more search patrols may be dispatched. If a search patrol is announced, influence will drop by 100. This will be accompanied by the alert [[GameText]]ALERT: Heightened foreign activity detected, dispatching search patrol.[[/GameText]] The alert will also indicate if multiple search patrols are to be sent out simultaneously. One or more ARCs will be dispatched after a few more turns. These ARCs behave similarly as regular patrol ARCs and have the same standard patrol contents within them. However, search squads will choose random points on the map to patrol to rather than having a fixed patrol route like all other patrols.

Name: Section 7
Content:
Section 7 is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Research]] [[Branch]] off of either [[Testing]] or [[Quarantine]] on -3 or -2. Compared to the previous branches, Section 7 is a lot tougher and more like a regular Research floor. Patrols are denser, [[Sentry|Sentries]] and [[Heavy|Heavies]] are present on the map, and [[Researcher|Researchers]] are present in higher numbers and have a worse scan effects. However, the [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] unique parts can be quite gamechanging and can include effects like strong weaponry, part integrity regeneration effects, and permanent buffs to Cogmind for the remainder of the game. This map is also home to powerful [[S7 Guard|S7 Guards]] that guard some of the more powerful and unique Artifacts. 
The left side of the map is different each run, but the right half, the "hangar", is always static. The hangar primarily contains large pieces of machinery used for the construction of a ship based after the Leopard, the [[Sigix]] ship that attacked 0b10. It also contains various Alien Artifacts, an LRC cache containing related Artifacts and is where LRC versions are tested, and several dormant prototype bot guards. The top section of this area is locked by Sealed Heavy Doors with 50 armor and strong resistances to all major damage types except for thermal damage.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Section 7[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Section 7 Guarded AA.png|Alien Artifact guarded by [[S7 Guard]]|Section 7 Unguarded AA.png|Unguarded Alien Artifact|Section 7 Guarded Hangar Entrance.png|Middle of map hangar entrance guarded by 2 [[Alpha 7|Alpha 7s]]|Section 7 Unguarded Hangar Entrance.png|Unguarded but locked hangar entrance near top of map|Section 7 Teleporters and Terrabombs.png|[[Terrabomb]] (left) and [[Transdimensional Reconstructor|Normal]] and [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor|Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructors]] (right) in hangar|Section 7 L-Cannon and Matter Drives.png|[[Drained L-Cannon]] (middle) and [[Matter Drive|Matter Drives]] (sides) in hangar|Section 7 Back Room.png|Top-right hangar room with [[Sigix Sheargun|Shearguns]] and [[Sigix Shearcannon|Shearcannon]] guarded by dormant [[Striker|Strikers]]|Section 7 Sigix Exoskeleton.png|Hangar [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] room|Section 7 LRC Lab.png|LRC lab with LRCs [[LRC-V4|V4]], [[LRC-V5|V5]], and [[LRC-V6|V6]] with sealed Alien Atrifacts guarded by dormant [[B-99 Colossus]]|Section 7 Power Cell Terminal.png|Power cell terminal[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Alien Artifacts[[/Heading]]
Some Section 7 hangar artifacts have fixed possibilities, but there are many prefabs that have a random selection of parts available.[[Heading:3]]Unguarded Alien Artifacts[[/Heading]]These Artifacts can be present in Suspension Chambers on the left side of the map with no S7 Guards. Duplicates are permitted on the same map.
[[List]][[Core Reset Matrix]]|[[Integrated Dissipator]]|[[Integrated Mediator]]|[[Integrated Reactor]]|[[Integrity Redistributor]]|[[Microwarp Drive]]|[[Spacefold Activator]][[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Guarded Alien Artifacts[[/Heading]]
These Artifacts can be present in Suspension Chambers on the left side of the map with dormant S7 Guards in the room. These Artifacts can never be duplicated on the same map.
[[List]][[Core Membrane]]|[[Core Physics Calibrator]]|[[Core Regenerator]]|[[Integrated Thermoelectric Network]]|[[Navigation Efficiency Matrix]][[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Fixed Hangar Artifacts[[/Heading]]
There are 3 sections on the top of the map with fixed spawns. The top left chamber can contain 1-3 Terrabombs. The chamber just to the right of that contains 1-4 [[Transdimensional Reconstructor|Normal]] or [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor|Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructors]]. Next on the right is a chamber with a guaranteed [[Drained L-Cannon]] and 0-2 [[Matter Drive|Matter Drives]]. On the far right, hidden behind a large mass of machinery, is a room with 1-3 [[Sigix Sheargun|Sigix Shearguns]] and rarely a [[Sigix Shearcannon]] in the chamber below guarded by a [[Watcher]] and two dormant [[Striker|Strikers]] on the inside, and a further two on the outside. All will be awoken by the Watcher.
[[Heading:3]]LRC Lab[[/Heading]]There are 2 different groups of Alien Artifact spawns in the LRC lab. The Suspension Chambers on the top-right side and the top-left side of the map share a single pool of items. The left side can have anywhere from 1-3 copies of the same Artifact. Neither are guaranteed, but choose from the following pool of items:
[[List]][[Core Expander]]|[[Core Reset Matrix]]|[[Integrated Dissipator]]|[[Integrated Reactor]]|[[Integrity Redistributor]][[/List]]
The LRC cache at the bottom of this area can contain the following items (duplicates allowed):
[[List]][[LRC Armor]]|[[LRC Inertial Stabilizer]]|[[LRC Energy Well]]|[[LRC Insulator]]|[[LRC Matter Compressor]]|[[LRC Storage]][[/List]]
[[Heading:3]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]][[/Heading]]The room at the bottom right of the map is the Exoskeleton. There is a Terminal on the right and the unpowered Exoskeleton at the bottom behind a Suspension Chamber. The Exoskeleton can become the [[Sigix Warrior]] when the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] is carried from Quarantine into this chamber and the Activate Exoskeleton hack is performed. The Warrior will follow Cogmind as a normal ally and can be used for the W3 [[Wintypes|Wintype]]. When fighting, the Sigix Warrior will sometimes log the message [[GameText]]Synergy achieved. Target locked: {target}[[/GameText]]. When this occurs, both the Warrior and Cogmind will gain a 15% targeting bonus against the target.
If a [[Core Reset Matrix]] is used, the log message [[GameText]]Sigix Exoskeleton lights up in response to your presence[[/GameText]], and attempting to walk into it will add [[GameText]]Exoskeleton opens, ready for integration override sequence[[/GameText]]. Repeating the movement will force Cogmind into the Exoskeleton and strip all parts. Cogmind will receive innate buffs to energy storage, energy generation, and heat dissipation depending on how many slots were "consumed" as a part of this process. The final slot distribution is 1 power slot, 3 propulsion slots (with an nondetachable Sigix Exoskeleton part), 3 utility slots, and 2 weapon slots that are filled with (detachable) Sigix Shearguns. Evolution can occur as normal from this point on. Most parts will be well protected with the extremely high coverage of the Exoskeleton, but as a tradeoff Cogmind takes 25% of all damage dealt to the Exoskeleton additionally as core damage. Some additional benefits are an 18-radius perfect robot, terrain, and item detection info, a distance from exit indicator, and spawns of [[Assembled (7)|Assembled]] from the ground in main 0b10 floors and [[Command]].
If either Cogmind wearing the Exoskeleton or the Sigix Warrior are spotted by a hostile, [[Maximum Security]] will immediately be engaged.
[[Heading:3]]Power Cell[[/Heading]]
One of the machines in the hangar is the Power Cell. It is a heavily armored and extremely explosive machine, with a 20 radius 250 entropic damage explosion that will instantly destroy all hostiles in range. One of the [[Lab]] orders that are accessible when using the [[Data Conduit]] will provide a manual explosion code. The Power Cell Monitoring Terminal will accept this code and start a 20 turn countdown before the machine explodes.
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is only one exit in Section 7. The main access exit that leads to the next Research or [[Access]] floor can be found at a dead end of a 4 tile corridor near either the top-middle or bottom-middle of the map.

Name: Security Rotation
Content: Event occurring on 0b10 floors containing [[Heavy|heavies]]. During a security rotation, heavies will move to a new [[Security Squad|security]] position, and any heavies that have been eliminated will be replaced.

Name: Security Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Security Squad Heavy.png|A Heavy guarding a busy intersection[[/Image]]
Security squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that guard a single location and do not move unless alerted to hostiles. While they are called squads, security bots nearly always work alone and do not come in groups. Security bots tend to be guarding busy exits, corridors, [[Interactive Machine|interactive machines]], and part stockpiles. These squads are primary composed of [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], [[Heavy|Heavies]], and [[Sentry|Sentries]]. They tend to be present on the map when Cogmind enters, and don't appear in greater numbers as time goes on. The main exception to this is Heavies, which may be replenished by the [[Security Rotation]] event, although there will typically never be more than the initial number of Heavies on a map. Security squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], but only within a very limited radius of 20 tiles.

[[Heading]]Security Contents[[/Heading]]
The following bots can be contained within Security Squads in standard 0b10 floors:
[[Table]]
Depth|Behemoth|Heavy|Sentry||
-10|N/A|N/A|N/A||
-9|N/A|N/A|[[Y-45 Defender]]||
-8|N/A|[[H-61 Shepherd]]|Y-45 Defender||
-7|N/A|H-61 Shepherd|[[Y-54 Guardian]]||
-6|[[B-75 Beast]]|H-61 Shepherd|Y-54 Guardian||
-5|B-75 Beast|[[H-71 Marshal]]|[[Y-64 Sentinel]]||
-4|[[B-86 Titan]]|H-71 Marshal|Y-64 Sentinel||
-3|B-86 Titan|H-71 Marshal|[[Y-72 Warden]]||
-2|[[B-90 Cyclops]]|[[H-81 Overseer]]|Y-72 Warden||
-1|[[B-99 Colossus]]|H-81 Overseer|Y-72 Warden[[/Table]]
[[Heading:2]][[Garrison|Garrison]] security contents[[/Heading]]
Garrisons can have unique Security contents contained within special checkpoint walls:
[[Table]]
Depth|Demolisher + Protector|Grunt|Hunter|Melee|Saboteur|Sentry|Specialist|Swarmer||
-9|N/A|2-3 [[G-34 Mercenary]]|N/A|2 of [[L-31 Rogue]] or [[B-36 Bruiser]]|2-3 [[E-15 Imp]]|1-2 Y-45 Defender|N/A|3-4 [[S-10 Pest]]||
-8|[[D-53 Grenadier]] + [[I-25 Savior]]|2-3 [[G-47 Trooper]]|1-2 [[H-55 Commando]]|2 of L-31 Rogue or B-36 Bruiser|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-45 Defender|1-2 [[X-57 Shotgunner]] or [[X-62 Marksman]]|3-4 S-10 Pest||
-7|D-53 Grenadier + [[I-36 Angel]]|2-3 G-47 Trooper|1-2 H-55 Commando|2 of L-31 Rogue or [[B-48 Gladiator]]|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-54 Guardian|1-2 X-57 Shotgunner, X-62 Marksman, or [[X-67 Chaingunner]]|3-4 [[S-27 Virus]]||
-6|D-53 Grenadier + I-36 Angel|2-3 [[G-50 Soldier]]|1-2 [[H-66 Slayer]]|2 of [[L-41 Fighter]] or B-48 Gladiator|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-54 Guardian|1-2 X-62 Marksman, X-67 Chaingunner, or [[X-72 Disruptor]]|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-5|[[D-63 Destroyer]] + [[I-47 Archangel]]|2-3 G-50 Soldier|1-2 H-66 Slayer|2 of L-41 Fighter or [[B-60 Warrior]]|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-64 Sentinel|1-2 X-67 Chaingunner, X-72 Disruptor, or [[X-77 Beamer]]|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-4|D-63 Destroyer + I-47 Archangel|2-3 [[G-67 Veteran]]|1-2 [[H-77 Assassin]]|2 of L-41 Fighter or B-60 Warrior|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-64 Sentinel|1-2 X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or [[X-82 Rainmaker]]|3-4 S-27 Virus||
-3|D-63 Destroyer + I-47 Archangel|2-3 G-67 Veteran|1-2 H-77 Assassin|2 of [[L-61 Swordsman]] or [[B-74 Champion]]|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-72 Warden|1-2 X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or [[X-87 Electro]]|3-4 [[S-43 Plague]]||
-2|[[D-83 Annihilator]] + I-47 Archangel|2-3 [[G-73 Enforcer]]|1-2 [[H-88 Terminator]]|2 of L-61 Swordsman or B-74 Champion|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-72 Warden|1-2 X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro|3-4 S-43 Plague||
-1|D-83 Annihilator + I-47 Archangel|2-3 G-73 Enforcer|1-2 H-88 Terminator|2 of L-61 Swordsman or B-74 Champion|2-3 E-15 Imp|1-2 Y-72 Warden|1-2 X-87 Electro|3-4 S-43 Plague
[[/Table]]
A [[C-30 ARC]] may also be a part of a Security Squad, with 3 unpowered ARCs next to it. The active ARC will have standard contents for a [[Patrol Squad]] ARC.
[[Heading:2]]Unique [[Armory]]/[[Testing]]/[[Quarantine]]/[[Protoforge]] security contents[[/Heading]]
These maps have unique Security contents within "nooks" in the wall. There can between 1-3 of the same type of bot contained within.
[[Table]]
Depth|Brawler ([[Spoiler]]Armory[[/Spoiler]] only)|Duelist ([[Spoiler]]Armory[[/Spoiler]] only)|Grunt|Hunter|Programmer|Saboteur ([[Spoiler]]Armory[[/Spoiler]] only)|Sentry|Specialist|Swarmer||
-4|B-60 Warrior|L-41 Fighter|G-67 Veteran|H-77 Assassin|[[P-70 Sage]]|E-15 Imp|N/A|X-72 Disruptor, X-77 Beamer, or X-82 Rainmaker|S-27 Virus||
-3|B-74 Champion|L-61 Swordsman|G-67 Veteran|H-77 Assassin|[[P-80 Master]]|E-15 Imp|Y-72 Warden|X-77 Beamer, X-82 Rainmaker, or X-87 Electro|S-43 Plague||
-2|N/A|N/A|G-73 Enforcer|H-88 Terminator|P-80 Master|N/A|Y-72 Warden|X-82 Rainmaker or X-87 Electro|S-43 Plague
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Special security-summoning events[[/Heading]]
There are a few events that may trigger additional security guards to spawn on the map.
[[Heading:2]][[Cargo Convoy]] interruption[[/Heading]]
100 turns after a Cargo Convoy is disrupted, Heavies will begin to appear at 0b10-controlled exits and [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]]. Every further 100 turns that pass, another Heavy will enter the map and head toward a nearby exit.
[[Heading:2]][[High Security|High]] or [[Maximum Security]][[/Heading]]
About 80 turns after entering High or Maximum Security, 4 Sentries will spawn from all Garrisons and 0b10-controlled exits.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:2]][[Quarantine]] Cryocooling Duct failure[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Quarantine Guards.png|Quarantine Guards dispatched from a Garrison[[/Image]]
Cryocooling Duct machines may be sometimes found in Quarantine. These machines the ambient temperature of the map by default, but if 2 are destroyed, the ambient heat will rise up to +20. If this happens, all combat bots will be withdrawn from the map, and 12 [[Quarantine Guard|Quarantine Guards]] will be dispatched after about 100 turns. These bots will guard various high traffic parts of the map, while others patrol the map. A few will guard exits, as well as a Garrison, if one is present.[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Seismic Detector
Content:
The Seismic Detector is an unusual piece of [[Infowar]] that can detect nearby seismic activity with a radius of 22. In-game, this is represented by flashing orange to yellow colors. More intense activity is indicated by a bright yellow color, while less intense activity fades down to a dark orange. There are several major components of seismic activity that can be detected with this part:
[[List]]
Robot movement detection: Bots that move on [[Wheels]], [[Legs]], or [[Treads]] will cause varying amounts of seismic activity. Wheel movement is indicated by dark orange color and is typically only 1-2 tiles long. Leg movement is indicated by a bright orange color and can typically be 2-4 tiles long. Tread movement is indicated by a bright yellow color and is typically 3-4 tiles long. Bots that are [[Hover Unit|hovering]], [[Flight Unit|flying]], or not moving do not create any seismic activity.|
Active machine detection: Certain machines create seismic activity. Note that [[Interactive Machine|Interactive Machines]] such as [[Terminal|Terminals]] do not create any seismic activity, but many non-interactive machines do, especially in [[Factory]].
[[Comment]]TODO: Could make a full list of machines that can be detected.[[/Comment]]|
Explosion detection: Explosions create very large areas of intense bright yellow seismic activity.[[/List]]
[[Image]]Seismic Detector Activating.webp|The Seismic Detector being activated[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Analysis[[/Heading]]
Seismic Detector can be used both as a primary yet somewhat limited source of infowar or with a combination of other infowar parts effectively.
[[Heading:2]]Pros/Cons[[/Heading]]
[[List]](+) Swappable single slot: Other sources of infowar such as [[Sensor Arrays]] and [[Terrain Scanners]] can take 2 slots to use to maximum effectiveness, while the Seismic Detector only requires 1 slot and can be easily swapped during combat.|
(+) Long range: 22 range is one of the largest ranges of infowar in the game for bot detection in the game and is 6 tiles longer than the default sight range.|
(+) Machine detection (sometimes): While inconsistent at best, the Seismic Detector can occasionally give a rough idea of the size and position of rooms due to seismic activity-generating machines inside of them.|
(+) Non-jammability: Unlike Sensor Arrays, Seismic Detectors can't be jammed by [[Watcher|Watchers]] or [[Heavy|Heavies]] and is also immune to the map-wide scrambling effect of the Phase Generator in [[Garrison|Garrisons]] and [[Command]].|
(+) Detection of [[Investigation Squad|Investigation]] and [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcement Squads]]: Since these squads typically contain all grounded bots like [[Grunt|Grunts]] and [[Hunter|Hunters]], these squads can be detected and avoided from far away.|
(-) Difficulty to decipher: It takes some time to learn how to interpret seismic readings. It is also hard to keep track of all the movement going on in busy areas. ARCs can often blend in with non-combat wheeled bots.|
(-) Inability to detect hovering/flying bots: While the Seismic Detector can point out squads of grounded bots including [[Carrier|Carriers]] in [[Patrol Squad|Patrol]] and [[Assault Squad|Assault Squads]], it will fail to detect other common [[Programmer]] or [[Swarmer]] patrol squads. Other problematic bots that will fail to be detected are Watchers and [[Operator|Operators]].|(-) Inability to detect guards: [[Sentry|Sentries]], [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], and other types of [[Security Squad|Security Squads]] are all immobile under normal circumstances and cannot be detected.[[/List]]
[[Heading:2]]General Strategy/Usage[[/Heading]]
If being used as the main source of bot detection, Cogmind should be prepared to deal with bots that the Seismic Detector can't detect. Swarmers, Programmers, Sentries, and Behemoths are the primary combat bots that fall under this category. While most of these bots are fairly common to encounter anyway, lack of Behemoth detection is a major shortcoming. Combat builds are typically more suited than stealth builds to handle its limitations as a solo infowar part. While the bot detection is quite powerful, absolute stealth is not an option. For flight especially, running into Programmers and Swarmers unexpectedly can often lead to dangerous situations.
The Seismic Detector is very good at helping Cogmind avoid Investigations and Reinforcements. [[Spoiler]]The downside of Force hacks summoning an Investigation squad is less of a downside if the Investigation can be avoided. [[UFD]] alignment often wants to perform a lot of Force hacks, so Seismic Detector makes a good combo.[[/Spoiler]]
[[Heading:3]]Good Part Combos[[/Heading]]
Some other infowar utilities have traits that synergize well with the Seismic Detector.
[[Heading:4]]Sensor Arrays[[/Heading]]
While it may seem redundant, Seismic Detector can be paired effectively with Sensor Arrays, both with or without [[Signal Interpreters]]. In both cases, Seismic Detector boasts a superior range and an inability to be jammed or scrambled.
Seismic Detector and interpreter-less sensors can cover large weaknesses of each other. Normally, an interpreter with a high enough rating is required to detect Hunters. However, if a bot shows up with seismic activity but not on the sensor, it is either within a Heavy's jamming range or a Hunter. Conversely, bots that show up on sensors but not the Seismic Detector are either hovering or flying or are stationary. All bots are detectable with this combination of 2 parts, and both utilities both be swapped off during combat. One downside of this combo is that the class of bots is never known for certain and must be guessed based on behavior.
For sensors with an interpreter, there is still one advantage of Seismic Detector that is worth mention. [[H-88 Terminator|H-88 Terminators]] are a particular scary bot to fight and are found in large numbers in -2 and -1. They require an [[Exp. Signal Interpreter]] to be seen on sensors, which is a rare part to find on the ground. The Seismic Detector will detect these Hunters as long as they are moving.
[[Heading:4]]Terrain Scanners[[/Heading]]
One of the biggest weaknesses of the Seismic Scanner is the inability to detect Sentries and Behemoths. Since their positions are fixed and often buried in a nook within walls, good terrain scanning can locate these bots even when the Seismic Detector cannot. This requires a decently rated [[Terrain Scan Processors|Terrain Scan Processor]] as the base scanning speed is too low to consistently locate these spots.
[[Heading:4]][[Transmission Jammers]][[/Heading]]
While Transmission Jammers are universally useful, being able to jam Watchers is particularly useful since many bot types may not always be detected ahead of time, avoiding scenarios where a Watcher alerts a yet unnoticed Behemoth or nearby squad.
[[Heading:4]][[Cloaking Device|Cloaking Devices]]/[[Visual Processing Units]][[/Heading]]
Both of these parts serve a similar effect in terms of Seismic Detector synergy. Having a sight advantage can allow Cogmind to visually spot bots that the Seismic Detector wouldn't pick up. The bots can then either be fought or avoided after their location has been identified.

[[Heading]]Examples of seismic activity[[/Heading]]

Name: Sensor Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Sensor Drone|Sensor Drones]].

Name: Sentry
Content:
Sentries are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] or [[Armor|armored]] [[Treads|treaded]] [[0b10]] bots that stand guard around exits, main corridors, and side rooms with machines or item stockpiles inside them. They wield dual Kinetic and Thermal guns at each tier. Sentries tend to be slightly more durable than most other bots at their depth. Sentries typically stand guard alone as a [[Security Squad]].
Sentries have no particular weakness, and so most weapon types can be used to dispatch them. Electromagnetic damage is efficient at killing the higher tier bots, and EM is good in general at increasing the chances of looting their treads and armor.
While combat bots will want (or will be forced) to fight Sentries head-on, airborne builds may want to avoid them or at least avoid getting shot by them. One way to do this is to use a [[Terminology#Partial Spot|partial spot]] to lure the Sentry out of their position. After that, Cogmind may be able to use the guarded machine or exit, or grab the loot without being spotted. A fast Cogmind may also be able to use the long memory of Sentries to their advantage while being spotted regularly. It is possible to lead Sentries far out of position and then leave them in the dust to grab their guarded loot.
[[Gallery]]Sentries.png|All Sentry variants and colors|Sentry Guarded Stockpile.png|A Sentry guarding a stockpile of parts, sitting in a recognizable "Sentry nook"[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Squads[[/Heading]]
Sentries may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Garrison Squad]]|[[Security Squad]][[/List]]
Additionally, Sentries will appear at [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] and 0b10 exits during [[High Security]] and [[Maximum Security]].
Bots: Y-45 Defender,Y-54 Guardian,Y-64 Sentinel,Y-72 Warden,Cetus Guard,Armor Guard,Quarantine Guard,Protovariant Y,S7 Guard,M Guard,M Shell/Atk

Name: Shieldings
Content: Shieldings protect the core or parts of a given type from damage and critical strikes. They have no coverage; instead, they take damage when an attack hits whatever they're protecting.
Groups: Core Shieldings,Power Shieldings,Propulsion Shieldings,Utility Shieldings,Weapon Shieldings

Name: Siege Mode
Content: Siege mode is an alternate state toggleable on all mutilslot treads. The transition in and out of siege mode takes 7 turns. During the transition, and for as long as the mode is active, [[Cogmind]] is immobile and the the treads cannot be disabled or removed. While in siege mode, non-melee attacks have +15% accuracy, coverage for all armor and heavy treads is doubled, any treads in siege mode get a free 25% damage reduction, no weapons suffer from recoil effects, and Cogmind is immune to instant part destruction from critical hits. [[Spoiler]][[Megatreads]], [[Tri-treads]],[[/Spoiler]] and any treads containing the word "siege" in the name are capable of high siege mode which instead gives +25% accuracy and 50% damage reduction.

Name: Sigix Containment Pod
Content:
The Sigix Containment Pod can be found in [[Quarantine]]. It has no gameplay effect by itself, but it enables the W3 [[Wintypes|Wintype]] and provides 5000 bonus score if carried to a win.
[[Redacted]]The Sigix Containment Pod can be put in the [[Sigix Exoskeleton]] in [[Section 7]] to create an allied [[Sigix Warrior]].[[/Redacted]]

Name: Sigix Corpse
Content: Provides 2000 bonus score if carried to a win.

Name: Sigix Exoskeleton
Content:
[[Image]]Section 7 Sigix Exoskeleton.png|The Exoskeleton room in Section 7[[/Image]]
The Sigix Exoskeleton is an [[Alien Artifacts|Alien Artifact]] that is only found in [[Section 7]]. Initially it is found on an unpowered [[Sigix Warrior]] named Sigix Exoskeleton in the bottom right corner of the hangar. If Cogmind has used a [[Core Reset Matrix]] (CRM), it is possible to enter the Exoskeleton, which dramatically alters gameplay for the rest of the current run.

[[Heading]]Unique effects[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Additional Core Damage[[/Heading]]
Roughly 1/3 of all damage dealt to the Sigix Exoskeleton is also dealt to Cogmind's core.
[[Heading:3]]Alien Weapon Damage Boost[[/Heading]]
All non-AOE attacks from Sigix weapons is doubled. However, this effect does not stack with things like [[Particle Chargers]]. The full list of affected weapons is as follows: [[Core Cannon]], [[Core Stripper]], [[Modified Sigix Sheargun]], [[Sigix Broadsword]], [[Sigix Shearcannon]], and [[Sigix Sheargun]]
[[Heading:3]][[Assembled]] Absorption[[/Heading]]
While the Exoskeleton is damaged, Assembled can be absorbed to repair it by 30 integrity when standing next to Cogmind.
[[Heading:3]]Core Dependence[[/Heading]]
Cogmind's core becomes dependent on the Exoskeleton. Even if Cogmind still has remaining core, if the Exoskeleton is destroyed the game will instantly be loss.
[[Heading:3]]Enhanced Hypermatrix Pings[[/Heading]]
Whenever entering a new floor with Assembled spawns available (all main 0b10-controlled floors, [[DSF|DSFs]], and [[Command]]), 6-8 Assembled will appear near Cogmind. Additionally, the Exoskeleton provides the CRM's hypermatrix ping detection and Assembled summoning ability at all times rather than only while at 1/3 core.
[[Heading:3]]Damage Reduction[[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton provides a 50% damage resistance to all conventional damage types. This effect stacks with most [[Defensive Utilities]], but not with [[Resistance Devices]].
[[Heading:3]]Deactivation-Proof[[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton cannot be deactivated by any means. This includes manual deactivation as well as [[Heat]]-based side-effects.
[[Heading:3]]Infowar[[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton provides extremely powerful sensor intel in an 18 tile radius. Perfect bot detection, terrain scanning, part detection, and hidden door detection is granted within this radius.
[[Heading:3]]High Coverage[[/Heading]]
While not exactly a unique ability, the Exoskeleton has a uniquely high 30,000 coverage which dwarfs every other item's coverage in the game. Most typical forms of armor are entirely unhelpful with the Exoskeleton equipped.
[[Heading:3]][[Maximum Security]] Triggering[[/Heading]]
As soon as Cogmind is spotted by any combat hostile in most [[0b10]]-controlled maps, Maximum Security will be immediately engaged. One notable exception is that Maximum Security will not be triggered in Command. Non-combat [[Watcher|Watchers]] and [[Operator|Operators]] whose associated [[Terminal]] hasn't be destroyed will also trigger this effect.
[[Image]]Exoskeleton4x.png|Cogmind's new look[[/Image]]
[[Heading:3]]New Appearance[[/Heading]]
Cogmind will take on the Sigix Warrior artwork, or the uppercase X character in ASCII mode.
[[Heading:3]]Slot Fixing[[/Heading]]
When Cogmind enters the Exoskeleton, all slots will be reset to a total of 1 Power, 3 Propulsion, 3 Utility, and 2 Weapon slots. However, Cogmind gets some boosts in exchange for the slots. Cogmind gains 100 fixed energy capacity, and every slot above the new 9 total slot count provides 3 innate energy generation and 5 heat dissipation. Not counting [[Core Expander|Core Expanders]], a typical -3 Section 7 provides 36 energy and 60 dissipation while a -2 Section 7 provides 42 energy and 70 dissipation. Slots can be evolved as normal after entering the Exoskeleton, including using Core Expanders. As a side-note, a [[Core Physics Calibrator]] cannot remove the 3 propulsion slots and force removal of the Exoskeleton.
[[Heading:3]]UI Intel[[/Heading]]
There are 4 new pieces of intel located at the bottom of the inventory UI:
[[List]]Threats: Counts the number of active hostiles within sensor radius.|Components: Counts the number of parts on the floor within sensor radius.|Ping number: Counts the number of active but untriggered Assembled hypermatrix pings.|Tor distance: Lists the distance to the Tor, the Sigix spaceship. The number in thousands place varies based on the map, but up to the hundreds place, it roughly indicates how many tiles Cogmind must travel to get to the nearest [[Surface]] exit.[[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Unique Interactions[[/Heading]]
Cogmind becomes indistinguishable from a Sigix Warrior to some NPCs. [[Warlord]] will turn aggressive upon seeing Cogmind during the -2 [[Research]] attack or when summoned via Command cave seals. [[MAIN.C]] has unique encounter dialogue and a special phase 2 encounter after the outer shell is defeated, summoning 4 additional [[M Shell/Atk]] and 4 [[M Shell/Def]]s to his side. The [[Architect]] will recognize Cogmind, but also has unique encounter dialogue.

Name: Sneak Attack
Content:
Sneak attacks are a [[Game Mechanics|game mechanic]] where melee attacks performed on bots in certain circumstances where they are not expecting an attack. Sneak attacks will deal double damage and cannot miss. Bots are vulnerable to a sneak attack in the following circumstances:
[[List]]
Hostile combat/non-combat bot (yellow-red): The bot must be unaware of the bot performing the attack. If fast enough, multiple sneak attacks can be performed until the bot has a turn to react.|
Neutral non-combat bot (green/white): If the bot hasn't been attacked yet, the first attack is always a sneak attack.|
Friendly bots (blue/purple/white): All attacks are sneak attacks.
[[/List]]

Name: Spacefold Activator
Content:
Spacefold Activators are attachable non-consumable utility [[Alien Artifacts]] that allow moving through up to 3 solid objects, at a cost of Cogmind's core integrity equal to 1% of maximum for each space traveled. They can be found exclusively in the western side of [[Section 7]] as unguarded Artifacts.

Note that the core integrity cost is for every space traveled during a spacefold, and not for every solid object, meaning that the tile that Cogmind ends up on also counts. For example, a spacefold through 2 walls would cost 3% core integrity, 2% for the wall and 1% for the tile Cogmind ends up on.

[[Heading]]Uses[[/Heading]]
There are many Alien Artifacts or even regular items that can replace some of the Spacefold Activator's uses or at least allow for the same overall results, without the high core integrity cost. However, a Spacefold Activator is capable of a more versatile range of movements than any single one of those items, while also being precise, consistent and only taking up one slot.

[[List]]Spacefolds can be used to bypass Reinforced Barriers, Sealed Heavy Doors and other difficult-to-destroy obstacles, without causing any [[Alert]] gain or requiring hacking. Since none of those obstacles are ever larger than 3 tiles, the only cases where spacefolds fail is when those obstacles contain a solid object within, such as allied [[Derelict|Derelicts]] imprisoned within small cells in [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. As with some other travel methods, going past Sealed Heavy Doors and the like may cause 0b10 to eventually open them to allow combat robots to chase down Cogmind, especially if there is no other way through, which can make it possible for allies to go through as well.|

Spacefolds can be used to quickly get out of rooms or corridors when patrols or other dangers are approaching and into safer or more strategic locations, without creating any additional paths for those dangers to reach said locations. This is much faster than digging through walls, especially if there are multiple layers of solid objects in the way, and won't destroy any [[Interactive Machine|interactive machines]] that might have been in the way.|

Spacefolds can allow for longer-range safe [[Digging|digs]]. While a [[Microwarp Drive]] allows for an even longer safe digging range and a lower core integrity loss, Spacefold Activators only take up one slot and cannot cause Cogmind to go farther than expected. [[Comment]]I don't know how spacefolding affects cave-ins, but if the only thing that matters is dug-out tiles traversed and "not-dug-out-but-diggable" spaces don't matter, then it should be possible to do stuff like an eight-tile dig, by digging five tiles to create a "waypoint", then digging once to the side to create a spot where you can spacefold to the waypoint, making the full movement = Dug-out-tile -> 3-tile spacefold -> "waypoint" -> 3-tile spacefold -> destination.[[/Comment]]

[[/List]]

Name: Special Melee Weapons
Parts: Dirty Datajack,Detonator,Splice Injector,Master Link

Name: Special Propulsion Modes
Content:
Certain [[Treads]] and [[Legs]] can be toggled into alternate states with special characteristics.

[[Heading]]Treads[[/Heading]]

[[Heading:2]]Siege mode[[/Heading]]
All multislot treads can be toggled into siege mode. The transition into and out of siege mode takes 7 turns. During the transition, and for as long as the mode is active, [[Cogmind]] is immobile and the treads cannot be disabled or removed.
While in siege mode:
[[List]]
Non-melee attacks have +15% accuracy.
|Coverage for all armor and heavy treads is doubled.
|Any treads in siege mode get a free 25% damage reduction.
|No weapons suffer from recoil effects.
|Cogmind is immune to instant part destruction from critical hits.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]High siege mode[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]][[Megatreads]], [[Tri-treads]],[[/Spoiler]] and any treads containing the word "siege" in the name are capable of high siege mode, which instead gives +25% accuracy and 50% damage reduction.

[[Heading]]Legs[[/Heading]]

[[Heading:2]]Martial mode[[/Heading]]
A few exoskeleton legs can be toggled into martial mode. The transition into and out of martial mode takes 3 turns. During the transition, and for as long as the mode is active, Cogmind movement speed is halved and the exoskeleton cannot be disabled or removed.
While in martial mode:
[[List]]
Will automatically use an active melee weapon to attack any hostile that moves into an adjacent position at 33% of the normal time cost (no follow-ups).
|10% chance to use the melee weapon to deflect each incoming projectile. A second melee weapon adds 5%; each melee weapon after that adds 2%. Melee weapons that successfully deflect a projectile have a 50% chance to take 1 damage each time.
|Immune to knockback.
|No ranged weapons suffer from recoil effects.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Shielding mode[[/Heading]]
A few legs can be toggled into shielding mode. The transition into and out of shielding mode takes 4 turns. During the transition, and for as long as the mode is active, Cogmind is immobile and the legs cannot be disabled or removed.
While in shielding mode:
[[List]]
Coverage for this leg is doubled.
|This leg gains a 50% chance to glance any projectile that would otherwise hit it, instead taking no damage.
[[/List]]

Name: Specialist
Content:
Specialists are a [[Bot Groups|Bot Group]] of [[Legs|legged]] [[0b10]] combat bots with many different themes between each variant. The best description of Specialists are glass cannons. They typically have high offensive output and little in the way of protection. Higher tier Specialists have some the highest damage output of any standard 0b10 bots in the game. Some Specialists also are unique users of [[VSS Leg|VSS Legs]] and its higher rating variants which allow them to walk at a higher speed than most legs (90 vs 120).
Specialists have no specific weaknesses or immunities, so generally any damage type or strategy can work against them. A few have strong cooling and [[Coolant Injectors]] so heat transfer strategies may fall flat against certain Specialists. However, the same cooling parts can also be looted and taken advantage of by Cogmind. Since Specialists are capable of dealing so much damage, they tend to be high priority targets to kill off first.
[[Gallery]]Specialists.png|All Specialist variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]][[Squad|Squads]][[/Heading]]
Specialists may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Assault Squad]] - Only if Cogmind has allies|[[Cargo Convoy]] - Within the escorting [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]]|[[Patrol Squad]] - [[Armory]] and [[Garrison|Garrisons]] only|[[Reinforcement Squad]] - only from [[Heavy]]-summoned Reinforcements|[[Security Squad]] - [[Armory]], Garrisons, [[Quarantine]], and [[Testing]] only[[/List]]
Bots: X-57 Shotgunner,X-62 Marksman,X-67 Chaingunner,X-72 Disruptor,X-77 Beamer,X-82 Rainmaker,X-87 Electro,Protovariant X

Name: Speed Boosting Utilities
Parts: Rocket Booster,Asb. Metafiber Network,Zio. Metafield Generator,ST Field Compressor

Name: Splice Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Splice Drone|Splice Drones]].

Name: Squad
Content:
Squads are groups of one or more robots that work together as a single group. The majority of the squads in the game are [[0b10]]-aligned and thus hostile to Cogmind, but there are also [[Derelict]] squads that can be either friendly or hostile to Cogmind depending on the circumstances. Some 0b10 squad types can be recalled using a low success rate Recall hack at a [[Terminal]], but all squad types can be located using an Enumerate hack. The numbers of all squad types, although not their compositions or locations, can be revealed with the Enumerate(Squads) hack.
Typically, one bot per squad is designated as the [[Squad Leader]]. Squad leaders are the only bots that have the AI or order type active. All other bots are set to follow the squad leader. If the squad leader is destroyed, the other bots in the squad will either end up wandering around randomly, or leaving the map if their squad leader was already leaving the map.

[[Heading]]Types of 0b10 Squads[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[Assault Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to target Cogmind directly. Unlike most squads that walk to their target, all Assault contents are contained with a faster wheeled [[C-45 Heavy ARC]]. Only get dispatched if Cogmind has [[Alert]] level 2 or higher (400 influence).|
[[Coupling Squad]] - Dispatched periodically by 0b10 on any floors where [[Garrison Access|Garrisons]] are available. Consist of a single [[Programmer]] carrying multiple [[Relay Couplers]] to restock a Garrison.|
[[Demolisher Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to eliminate large groups of hostiles, particularly [[Assembled]].|
[[Extermination Squad]] - Dispatched periodically by 0b10 in [[Factory]] and beyond. They consist entirely of Programmers and will always head directly to Cogmind.|
[[Garrison Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 Garrisons when combat occurs near that Garrison. Bots will roam around the area where the attack occurred, then return after 200-300 turns.|
[[Spoiler]][[Intercept Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 directly to Cogmind only in a few special circumstances. Intercept squads consist of powerful [[Prototype Robot|Prototype]] bots designed to quickly neutralize Cogmind.[[/Spoiler]]|
[[Investigation Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to investigate an area of interest for 300-400 turns, then they exit the level.|
[[Patrol Squad]] - Patrol between two points of interest at varying speeds. Most patrols appear at the beginning of a map and will not be replenished. However there are also temporary patrols that are occasionally dispatched to roam around the map for a while before returning through an 0b10-controlled exit.|
[[Reinforcement Squad]] - Dispatched by 0b10 to permanently reinforce an area of interest. Similar to investigations but do not leave their post and will patrol around the area they are summoned to forever.|
[[Security Squad]] - Stand guard at intersections, on top of exits, and in rooms with part stockpiles or Machines. Will typically not move unless they are alerted of a hostile.|
[[Surveillance Squad]] - Patrol between two points of interest similar to a Patrol squad, but made up of a single [[Watcher]] instead of combat bots.|
[[Transport Squad]] - [[Hauler]] guarded by 0-2 [[Grunt|Grunts]] that transport parts from place to place. Empty Haulers may pick up parts fabricated at a [[Fabricator]].
[[/List]]
Subpages: Assault Squad,Coupling Squad,Demolisher Squad,Extermination Squad,Garrison Squad,Intercept Squad,Investigation Squad,Patrol Squad,Reinforcement Squad,Security Squad,Surveillance Squad,Transport Squad

Name: Stasis Trap
Content:
Stasis Traps are [[Traps]] found in 0b10-controlled areas, and are especially common in [[Garrison|Garrisons]]. They are uniquely the only trap type to temporarily remain after being triggered, the only extractable trap type that cannot be stored inside [[Trap Extractors]], as well as the only trap type to be extractable [[I]]after[[/I]] being triggered (but before being depleted).

[[Heading]]Triggering[[/Heading]]
While the probability of triggering traps is based on current [[Propulsion]] type, the probability of triggering Stasis Trap is the opposite of regular Traps :
[[Table]]
Mode|Probability| Min. depletion on move
|| Overweight | 100% | N/A
|| [[Treads]] | 0% | 30
|| [[Legs]] | 25% | 15
|| [[Wheels]] | 50% | 10
|| [[Hover Units|Hover]] | 60% | 7
|| Core | 60% | 6
|| [[Flight Units|Flight]] | 80% | 5
[[/Table]]
Note that this means non-overweight threaded builds are "immune" to hostile Stasis Traps.

[[Heading]]Effects and depletion[[/Heading]]
Upon being triggered, Stasis Traps create a stasis field on the tile they occupy, which cancels the evasion bonus from [[Flight Units|Flight]]/[[Hover Units|Hover]]/[[Reaction Control Systems]] of robots inside and prevents them from moving away until the field is depleted, usually by the victim's repeated movement attempts. These traps pose no threat whatsoever on their own, but with bad timing can be can cause Cogmind to get stuck in exposed locations as nearby dangers approach the area. However, the stasis field also reduces all incoming damage by 25%.
The stasis field's strength starts at 100 minus whatever one movement of the victim would deplete, and can be escaped in one of five ways:
[[List]]
Attempting to move away from the stasis field will cause it to deplete by an amount equal to ([current mass support] - [current mass]) OR a minimum dependent on propulsion type (see table above), whichever is larger.
This means that detaching heavy parts can significantly speed up field depletion.
Note that attempting to move away always takes 1 turn, regardless of current movement speed, with the exception of the movement that finishes depleting the field.
Because of this, a spare Threads part can work as a makeshift [[Stasis Canceller]].
|Taking damage while in a stasis field will reduce that damage by 25% and deplete the stasis field by [damage absorbed].
|Using a Stasis Canceller and moving away from the trap will deplete it instantly.
|If the Stasis Trap is friendly, using a Trap Extractor will extract it and its stasis field, conserving whatever was left of the field strength.
|If an explosion occurs and destroys the Stasis Trap itself, the stasis field will also disappear, and the corresponding [[Mechanics Achievements|Mechanics Achievement]] "Short-term Sacrifices" will be unlocked if it wasn't already.
[[/List]]


If a Stasis Trap is activated by an EM explosion, a failure to hack using a [[Melee Datajacks|Melee Datajack]], is triggered and evaded using a [[Reaction Control Systems|Reaction Control System]] or if its victim is destroyed before the stasis field is depleted, the Trap will still generate its stasis field even without a victim inside. In this state, projectiles and explosions cannot interact with the stasis field itself (but can still destroy the Stasis Trap), and it is possible to move into the stasis field, which does not partially deplete it.


[[Heading]]Special Interactions[[/Heading]]
Below is an incomplete list of special interactions with Stasis Traps:
[[List]]Cogmind is capable of swapping with allies already in Stasis Traps, which frees the ally but traps Cogmind instead.

[[Comment]]When Stasis Traps are activated by EM explosions, they will always create a stasis field, even if there is no victim on the tile. The effects of this should be explained, including whether certain projectiles can pass through or not, whether the damage of those projectiles is affected, and so on.[[/Comment]]

|[[Spoiler]]A [[Field Manipulator]] allows taking greater advantage of Stasis Traps' defensive ability.[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]



Last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Sterilization
Content:
Sterilization is a special [[0b10]] response to Cogmind destroying too many combat bots on a single map. When activated, the ambient heat of the floor will be increased forever until Cogmind exits the map. As the heat increases, any remaining bots, parts on the ground, machines, and traps will all melt. Occasionally, machines will explode before they melt.
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Sterilization System[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Triggering[[/Heading]]
The number of bots to kill to trigger Sterilization depends on the map.
[[Table]]
Map|Bots to kill||
[[DSF]]|8||
[[Materials]]|50||
[[Storage]]|75||
Most other maps|130
[[/Table]]
[[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Wastes]], [[Protoforge]], and [[Command]] can not be Sterilized.
[[Redacted]]
[[Heading:2]][[Protoforge#advanced_fortification_protocols|Advanced Fortification Protocols]][[/Heading]]
If advanced fortification protocols have been engaged in the Protoforge map, the number of kills required to trigger Sterilization is doubled.
[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Timeline of Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]]0: Non-combat bots start evacuating the map and head to 0b10-controlled exits, log messages [[GameText]]ALERT: Persistent threat exposed, engaging [map] sterilization system.[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]ALERT: All non-combat units evacuation[[/GameText]].|
100: Combat bots start evacuating the map and head to 0b10-controlled exits, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: All combat units evacuate.[[/GameText]]|
300: Ambient heat increases by 10, log message [[GameText]]ALERT: Ambient heat levels +10.[[/GameText]]|
450: Ambient heat increases by a further 10|Etc. +10 heat for every 150 turns.[[/List]]
Note: Unlike most other maps, in [[Access]] bots are not evacuated. The evacuation-related alerts will not appear and the bots will continue to stay on the map as usual.
[[Heading:2]]Rapid Sterilization[[/Heading]]
DSFs have a unique rapid sterilization system that works much quicker than normal sterilization. Ambient heat increases begin only 20 turns after the initial announcement and occur every 15 turns after that.

[[Heading]]Part Melting[[/Heading]]
After Sterilization is triggered, parts will begin to melt every 30-40 turns and be destroyed instantly. Parts that are 200 integrity or greater are safe from melting. Parts with a lower integrity are more likely to melt than those with higher integrity. For example, [[Treads]] and [[Armor]] tend to last longer or be immune to melting altogether, while fragile processors will melt almost instantly. Parts only melt when within a 20-tile radius around Cogmind, so with a good enough speed, timing, and luck, it is possible to grab parts that would otherwise melt quickly in the heat.

Name: Storage
Content:
Storage is an early game [[0b10]]-controlled [[Branch]] with no unique rewards but plenty of good prototype parts. Storage maps tend to be fairly cramped just like [[Materials]] maps but with fewer patrols and many more [[Y-45 Defender|Sentries]] guarding individual rooms and corridors. There is an unusually high number of [[A-02 Transporter|Haulers]] in these maps. Destroying them for their loot is highly recommended on -9 and -8. On -7 however, many of the Haulers will begin summoning [[Reinforcement Squad|Reinforcements]] that can cause trouble. The majority of the [[Prototype Part|Prototype Parts]] at this point in the game will be weapons or flight units, so players trying to prepare for a flight transition should consider visiting Storage on -9 or -8. Combat players should also consider Storage as a good way to stock up on early game weaponry. -7 Storage is considered generally inferior to [[Caves]] because Caves has the advantage of [[Alert]] reduction as well as unique branch rewards.
Storage is notable for the large number of prototype parts available. Unique shell and vaults contain many useful early game loot. Vaults can also contain out-of-depth parts. Storage is also notable for the mostly guaranteed [[Garrison Access|Garrison]]. It is the only way to enter a Garrison on -9.

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]][[Gallery]]Storage Locked Vault.png|Locked vault of non-prototype parts|Storage Trapped Vault.png|Unlocked vault full of high rating parts with a row of traps in the way|Storage Drone Bay Vault.png|Locked vault full of drone bays|Storage Locked Large Vault.png|Large locked vault|Storage Grunt Vault.png|Unlocked vault full of friendly [[G-34 Mercenary]] and one [[G-47 Trooper]] Grunts that activate automatically|Storage Shell Prototypes.png|Shell with prototype parts|Storage Shells Non Prototype.png|Shells with non-prototype parts|Storage Main Exit.png|Storage main access exit|Storage Recycling Entrance.png|Entrance to [[Recycling]][[/Gallery]]
All of the special loot in Storage comes in the form of vaults and shells. The shells will only contain standard floor rating non-prototype and prototype parts. However, some of the vaults contain very out of depth prototype parts. The single item locked vault and the vault full of traps can contain rating 5* prototypes that are far out of depth compared to the normal Storage depths. These vaults can contain great items like [[Cld. Plasma Cannon]], [[Exp. Targeting Computer]], and even a semi-unique part [[Lgt. Regenerative Plating]]. Shells must be broke open by a weapon, while vaults must be hacked open via [[Terminal]]. Some vaults will already be open on entering the map.
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of exits in Storage:
[[List]]Main access exits: These always lead to the next main floor, either [[Materials]] or [[Factory]]. There is only one of these types of exits on the map and it will always be in the opposite corner of the map that Cogmind starts at.|[[Spoiler]][[Recycling]] exit: There is only one of these types of exits on the map and it will be in one of the remaining corners that the starting point and main access exit aren't in. This exit is blocked off by a [[Terminal]] with no Open hack. The only way past is to enter the special manual hack \\\\IAMDERELICT.[[/Spoiler]][[/List]]
[[Image]]Storage Derelict Unlocked Vault.png|Unlocked vault raided by friendly [[Thug (5)|Derelicts]][[/Image]][[Image]]MTF Vault.png|Unlocked vault raided by [[01-MTF]][[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
Most of the events in Storage are driven by vault prefabs. There are several events that can occur:
[[List]](++) [[01-MTF]] raid: 01-MTF will join as an uncontrollable ally for the duration of the map. Will follow into the next map, but will leave permanently upon exiting the map unless exiting to [[Spoiler]]Recycling[[/Spoiler]]|
(+) [[Armory]] raid message: A Derelict will tell Cogmind the depth of Armory.|
(+/-) [[Thug (5)|Derelict]] raid: 2 Derelicts will have already opened and raided a large open vault. Several parts will be missing from the normal vault contents. When discovered, the 2 Derelicts will turn into uncontrollable allies and two [[Assault Squad|Assault]] [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARCs]] will be summoned to the vault.[[/List]]

Name: Storage Unit
Content:
Storage Units are utility parts that expand a bot's inventory size by their listed amount. Cogmind has 5 innate inventory spaces. Most other bots have exactly 1 built-in innate inventory space, some have as many as 12, and some have none. Most bots do not carry items, however.
Storage Units do not stack; the inventory size bonus from only one storage unit is applied.

[[Heading]]List of Storage Units[[/Heading]]
[[PartGroupTable]]
Storage Unit|
Overview/Size|
Overview/Rating|
Overview/Integrity|
Overview/Coverage|
Effect/Effect
[[/PartGroupTable]]

[[Heading]]Special Immunity[[/Heading]]
Storage Units have special immunity to nearly all part-severing and instant destruction effects in the game, including [[Corruption]] part rejection, thus making it impossible to suddenly lose nearly all your inventory due to stepping on a [[Blade Trap]] or being shot by a [[Heavy]]. The most notable exception is the [[Compactor]] wielded by [[C-40 Crusher|C-40 Crushers]], which has unique destructive and part-severing effects that can affect Storage Units.

This article was last updated during Beta 15.
Parts: Sml. Storage Unit,Med. Storage Unit,Lrg. Storage Unit,Hcp. Storage Unit,Huge Storage Unit,Cargo Storage Unit,Humpback,Lgt. Humpback,Vmp. Humpback,Lightpack 2.0,Cep. Antigrav Storage Unit

Name: Strategy
Content: Strategy guides to complete various content. Also see [[aoemica's Flight Guide]].

Name: Strategy/Bosses
Content: Strategy guides to kill the 3 bosses in the game achieve +s on the scoresheet.

Name: Strategy/Bosses/Defeating Architect
Content:
[[Image]]Access_0 Entrance.png|Hostile Entrance to Access_0[[/Image]]
[[Access_0]] is one of the hardest maps in the game that requires Cogmind to deal with numerous powerful threats on the map that gives very little breathing room for fixing a build that is starting to fall apart. Assuming [[MAIN.C]] is defeated in [[Command]], there is a large amount of preparation that can be done after all of the bots have become disabled. [[Command#command_cache_contents|MAIN.C's cache]] can provide some incredibly powerful parts, and the rest of the map can have plenty of goodies to grab. Since Access_0 is a very combat-oriented map, make sure to bring backups of essentials like power, propulsion, weapons, and armor. While there are some part caches in Access_0 itself, their contents are not particularly reliable and shouldn't be counted on to provide crucial backups. A more consistent source of parts are the drops from the [[Enhanced Bot|Enhanced Bots]] and the [[A Bots]], assuming weapons with neutral salvage can be used at least some of the time. There tend to be abundant legs and mediocre-quality power above all else from the [[Enhanced Grunt|Enhanced Grunts]] and [[Enhanced Hunter|Enhanced Hunters]]. The Grunt's [[Neutron Cannon|Neutron Cannons]] can serve in a pinch, but aren't impressive due to their middling damage and short range.

[[Heading]]Propulsion Selection[[/Heading]]
All propulsion types can be used to win in Access_0, although some are definitely better suited to the map than others. Hover and legs are nice middle ground propulsion that can have a lot of power and still retain maneuverability. Treads are the best heavy combat type with lots of coverage and integrity, but they may get stuck fighting in bad situations with no good way to reposition. Wheels are much more more niche than treads due to the rarity of good lategame wheels. Flight is the easiest to use to take down all of the pads but can struggle the most to finish off the Architect in the final fight due to lack of integrity.
[[Heading:2]][[Flight Units|Flight]][[/Heading]]
Flight builds should be extremely quick at this point in the game (sub 20 speed) and are able to outrun every bot on the map. Flight does not have the integrity for prolonged fighting. Typically flight builds should destroy the pads first and then try to lure the Architect away from all of the other bots for a quick kill. Evasion utilities in [[Phase Shifters]] and [[Reaction Control Systems]] work well to minimize the number of attacks that land. More expensive defensive utilities like [[Shield Generators]] or [[Force Fields]] also combine well with evasion utilities but may be tough to support. A bots are a major threat to this playstyle, as their remote force fields can prolong the final encounter to the point that Cogmind is unable to finish off the Architect. Destroy critical weapons like the [[Hyp. Multirail]] can be good for taking out a few enhanced bots or removing hover units off of key A bots so they don't catch up as quickly for the final fight. A strong final Architect-killer weapon is a must for this strategy.
[[Heading:2]][[Hover Units|Hover]][[/Heading]]
Hover builds tend to be the hardest to put together but can end up with a strong mix of speed, offensive, and defensive capabilities. Using a [[Zio. Metafield Generator]] or [[ST Field Compressor]] can help to outrun groups of bots or reposition more easily. However, a strategy entirely based on running away tends to fare much worse for hover builds due to the lower speed and ability to get trapped with the inability to hop in tight 1 tile corridors. Hover builds should choose their fights carefully and can reposition in combat to avoid getting outnumbered. Unlike Flight builds, Hover builds usually have the energy and mass support to use both evasion utilities and other defensive utilities like Force Fields. This combination can cut down significantly on attrition while exploring the map.
[[Heading:2]][[Legs]][[/Heading]]
Leg builds finally start to trend into the area where having a reliable way to "shoo" (deal 80 core damage to trigger the teleport) the Architect is a requirement. Legs can take advantage of the movement bonuses to dodge (5/10/15 extra evasion per tile moved in a row) and use evasion utilities to avoid most shots while running in a straight line. However, extensive repositioning is quite expensive, even for faster leg builds. [[Infowar]] like [[Terrain Scanners]] or [[Drone Bays]] can help locate the pads quicker and reduce damage taken from the Architect coming back repeatedly. One option for legs is a "siege legs" build, where an extra pair of treads are used in addition to the standard legs. This requires 2 extra propulsion slots above what Cogmind already needs to support for the full effect. However, it is not worth attaching treads if it will place Cogmind overweight. One of the bigger benefits of this strategy is that the Enhanced Hunters can't continually knock Cogmind back into collapsed tiles due to the knockback cancellation ability of treads. Additionally, siege mode can be used for tough encounters.
[[Heading:2]][[Wheels]]/[[Treads]][[/Heading]]
Wheels and treads are the slowest Access_0 propulsion types, and as such, need to be the most prepared for heavy combat. Lots of armor and strong weaponry are required for these builds. Wheel builds tend to have lower propulsion slots and higher utility slots, necessitating more utility slots being taken up by armor to compensate. Treads usually have 6-8 propulsion slots and can afford to run less armor in utility slots due to the higher propulsion coverage. Terrain scanning and drones are especially recommended for these builds to reduce the pad finding time. They will end up needing to shoo the Architect repeatedly throughout the level and fight every bot they meet.
[[Heading:2]][[Sigix Exoskeleton]][[/Heading]]
The Exoskeleton plays a little differently from the other propulsion types. Due to its incredible amount of builtin infowar, it is quite easy to find and destroy all of the Architect's pads. With the [[Sigix Shearcannon]] it is quite easy to destroy every bot on the map in a few volleys. An Exoskeleton-boosted [[Core Cannon]] can kill the Architect from full integrity, which allows skipping the pad destroying altogether. With weaker weapons like [[Sigix Sheargun|Sigix Shearguns]] or a [[Sigix Broadsword]], the Exoskeleton tends to play like a hover build without much shooing power, taking a few specific encounters and killing A bots, but mostly running from the Architect in favor of searching and destroying the pads.

[[Heading]]Key Weapon Roles[[/Heading]]
Some weapon types excel at some situations and not in others. Entropic, Kinetic, Pierce, Slashing, Thermal, Vortex damage-dealing weapons all tend to be good all-around in Access_0. Electromagnetic damage is decent in a few key places, while Impact and Explosive damage tend to be subpar. However, there are some particularly useful weapons for specific circumstances. Ratings below include (-) = not suitable for role, (~) = passable for role, (+) = good for role, (++) = great for role. Ratings are a combination of how good the weapon is at killing something, its + or - salvage potential, and resource costs of use.

[[List:Ordered]]The Core Cannon is very strong vs most bots in Access_0 but costs too much core to use consistently, it will often result in early death by core.|Critical hits can disarm or destroy propulsion/weapons of some coring immune bots but not kill directly. Mostly niche use for flight/hover.|A6 is neutral to EM and annoying to kill otherwise, but all other A bots are 75% resistant.|Vortex Lances are the strongest melee weapon here but they have limited uses and should be used sparingly. A bots and the Architect final fight are the best uses for the Vortex Lance as a primary weapon.|Multirails are reasonable Architect shooers, but they have a very high matter upkeep. A [[Desublimator]] or other matter regenerating utilities are recommended to allow Multirails to shoo over a long period of time.|The Cep. Plasma Driver is a slightly worse Architect shoo due to its 1/3 chance of dealing less than the 80 damage required.|The Sigix Shearcannon has incredible firepower but it comes with a caveat. Cogmind must typically be within 2-4 tiles of the target in order to gain maximum damage potential. Otherwise the weapon's arc will cause some projectiles to miss, with higher percentages of projectiles missing at further distances. This weapon is best suited for faster propulsion types, although even treads can make good use if it in some situations.|Vortex weaponry is quite powerful and good at killing all in Access_0. However, it is not good to use for fighting everything as they have limited usages. A bots and the final Architect kill tend to be the most important uses.|These launchers have very strong killing power and Architect shooing potential. However, the incredibly high matter cost makes them not a good choice for regular usage. One or two [[Prc. Matter Filter|Prc. Matter Filters]] along with a Desublimator may make this a more reliable option, but it may be a bad idea to rely too heavily on launchers without other good options due to the risk of running out of matter entirely.|The Alpha Cannon Mk. II does not need any particle charging in some situations but does in others. It naturally kills 120 integrity Enhanced Grunts/Hunters in 2 hits with its base 65 damage. A bots and Enhanced Sentries have 150 core integrity which takes 3 hits. However, an Adv. Particle Charger ups the damage to 81. This turns those 3 hits into a 2 hit kill. This also matters for the Architect, where 81 damage will guarantee the shoo on a single core hit instead of requiring 2 hits.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Other useful parts[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]]Targeting[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]], for ranged combat, or [[Melee Analysis Suites]] for melee. Targeting is the most important combat utility to use in Access_0. The Architect and Enhanced Hunters all run [[Exp. Phase Shifter|Exp. Phase Shifters]] which dramatically reduce chance to hit ranged attacks. Running 2-3 targeting utilities is extremely recommended to maintain a high chance to hit, although melee builds are able to get away with fewer.
[[Heading:2]]Core chance to hit boosters[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Core Analyzers]] and [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]]. Next to targeting, these are the best offensive utilities to use. Core Analyzers are superior, but they both work together. An Armor Integrity Analyzer should be used over the second Core Analyzer if there is space.
[[Heading:2]][[Weapon Cyclers]]/[[Actuators]][[/Heading]]
Weapon cycling is another great way to increase the damage done. Keep in mind they do require extra weapon energy/heat upkeep as the full volley will be fired more quickly than without. A [[Mni. Quantum Capacitor|Mni.]] or [[Quantum Capacitor|Regular Quantum Capacitor]] is good for any single powerful energy cannon, especially ones that can shoo the Architect in a single core hit.
[[Heading:2]][[Kinecellerators]]/[[Particle Chargers]][[/Heading]]
Nearly mandatory for some weapon types and less important for others. In some cases, like with the Omega Cannon and an Adv. Kinecellerator, it can be the difference between a single core hit Architect shoo and a double core hit Architect shoo.
[[Heading:2]][[Shield Generators]] and [[Force Fields]][[/Heading]]
Force fields are one of the best ways to reduce damage in the game as long as their heavy energy demands can be met. Airborne propulsion may want to use Shield Generators for their lesser energy requirements and lighter mass.
[[Heading:2]][[Phase Shifters]]/[[Reaction Control Systems]][[/Heading]]
All around good ways to reduce damage taken. Reaction Control Systems can only effectively be used by airborne propulsion types and legs.
[[Heading:2]][[Microwarp Drive]][[/Heading]]
This is especially useful for grounded propulsion types. The Microwarp Drive can be used to travel large distances very quickly in order to get to a specific pad location, reposition for a fight, or even just move around much quicker than normal. The core cost is prohibitive for constant warping, but this item can save a lot on overall build attrition with good use.
[[Heading:2]]Scouting Infowar[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Terrain Scanners]] with [[Terrain Scan Processors]], [[Drone Bays]], [[Visual Processing Units]], [[Structural Scanner]] or [[Deep Structural Scanner|DSS]] variant, [[Triangulator]], or [[IFF Parsers]]. All of these provide extra bot or map intel which can be used for locating pads more easily, finding shortcut digs that can be taken, or avoiding some bots. The Structural Scanner is more useful for airborne propulsion than grounded propulsion since it works instantly and can be used to dodge groups of hostiles if running away. It doesn't typically help find the pads sooner like the others.
[[Heading:2]][[ECM Suites]][[/Heading]]
For airborne propulsion only. This can help take some pressure off by causing groups of followers to much more quickly lose tracking of Cogmind.
[[Heading:2]][[Triangulator]][[/Heading]]
This typically niche item has a unique ability in that it allows for tracking hostiles at 24 range even if they can't be seen via other sensor methods. The Architect has scan cloak 5 which prevents all other detection methods. Using the Triangulator can pinpoint the way the Architect is coming from at long range which can greatly help in determining pad locations.
[[Heading:2]]Matter generating utilities[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Desublimator]], [[Field Recycling Units]], [[Matter Filters]], [[Tractor Beams]], and [[Matter Compressors]]. For any kinetic based weapons or weapons that cause a lot of negative salvage like the Potential Cannons, having ways of stockpiling matter or restocking up on matter mid-map can be entirely essential to avoid losing the run due to running out of matter. The Desublimator can be found off of Enhanced Hunters only on this map, but the others can be brought over from earlier maps.
[[Heading:2]]Energy support[[/Heading]]
Specifically, [[Energy Wells]], [[Power Amplifiers]], and [[Energy Filters]]. All of these utilities can be used to maintain expensive energy cannons and force fields through prolonged combat. Energy wells can be dropped on the ground to instantly absorb the energy needed to keep firing, while the others must be attached to help.
[[Heading:2]][[Remote Datajacks]][[/Heading]]
If the Data Conduit is used, Cogmind will be given intel for instant kill codes for all A bots that must be used with a Remote Datajack.
[[Heading:2]][[Terrabomb]][[/Heading]]
Although a little niche, Terrabombs do great at opening up a large part of the map to check for nearby pads. This is a double-edged sword since any nearby groups of enemies will spot you instantly, and the Architect can potentially start shooting from out of weapon range.
[[Heading:2]][[Sigix Terminator|Regular]] or [[Supercharged Sigix Terminator]][[/Heading]]
This single-use weapon is best used after taking down all of the pads in order to kill or at least severely cripple the Architect for the final fight. If airborne, this can also be used to kill off a lot of the bots following behind in a big mass.
[[Heading:2]][[Transdimensional Reconstructor|Regular]] or [[Hpw. Transdimensional Reconstructor]][[/Heading]]
There is almost always one of these on the map somewhere, and the Architect drops one when defeated. However, using one of these to escape can be an issue if defeating the Architect with a weapon with knockback like a kinetic cannon because it may be dropped too far away to pick up to exit the map in time. Potential Cannons also have a habit of destroying them when dropped on the ground. Keeping a spare is a way to escape with a non-Architect killing win if all hope is lost instead of dying in Access_0.
[[Heading:2]][[Core Reset Matrix]][[/Heading]]
There are several Alien Artifacts on the map and using the Core Reset Matrix ahead of time allows for locating them right away on entering the map. Sometimes being able to head for a Core Regenerator or Integrity Redistributor right away after entering the map is the difference between a loss and a win.
[[Heading:2]][[Integrity Redistributor]][[/Heading]]
Useful to prevent essential parts of the build from breaking or just generally to repair everything at once. Limited parts with very high value such as [[Shieldings]] or non-regenerative armor like [[Zio. Shade Armor]] or [[Exp. Powered Armor]], as well as unique parts that are essential to the build, should be taken off preemptively at low integrity in order to use a Redistributor on them at a later time.
[[Heading:2]][[Core Regenerator]][[/Heading]]
Most helpful if using core-hungry Alien Artifacts like the Core Cannon, Microwarp Drive, or an Integrity Redistributor. It provides 400 (or more core with [[LRC Armor]] that can be used as more fuel for these parts, or even just extra integrity to stay alive. Sometimes it is better to use before entering the map if core is low enough.
[[Heading:2]][[Navigation Efficiency Matrix]][[/Heading]]
While this artifact can be very painful to use from the random teleportation, it does have some good usages in Access_0. When teleporting, all of the Enhanced bots lose tracking on Cogmind. This can be used on airborne propulsion to avoid getting large groups of Enhanced bots following behind, or on grounded propulsion to attempt to reposition or even avoid fighting groups of enemies. It is a mixed bag since it can just as easily teleport Cogmind into an even worse position than before.

[[Heading]]Stages of the map[[/Heading]]
There are several distinct stages of the map where different strategies can be used. Some playstyles may skip certain stages entirely, like how a flight build will typically not stick around for the initial map fight, while grounded propulsion builds will have to fight.
[[Heading:2]]Initial fight[[/Heading]]
Cogmind is confronted by the Architect, A8, and 2 dormant Enhanced Grunts. Rarely, a patrol of more Enhanced Grunts or Enhanced Hunters spawns close enough to also join in here. Flight will typically ignore this part and skip straight to hunting for the pads to destroy. Hover can kill all the bots and shoo the Architect right away or move deeper into the level and try to fight the bots one-on-one instead. Grounded propulsion usually need to fight right at the starting position, so be prepared with strong weaponry to begin with. Siege up right at the entrance of the map if using treads. Targeting the Architect for a shoo is usually the best approach, followed by A8, and finally the Enhanced Grunts. If lacking any good Architect shooing weapons, focusing A8 first may be preferable so A8's Remote Force Field won't be able to protect the Architect.
[[Heading:2]]Searching for the pads[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Access_0 Subspace Access Node.png|Subspace Access Node layout[[/Image]]
This stage is where the vast majority of the time spent in Access_0. This part involves running or actively fighting the Architect, Enhanced bot guards and patrols, and the A bots as they appear. Infowar utilities are most useful at this time. The general strategy for combat here is to shoo the Architect and then start heading in the direction that it came from. Since it typically comes from the closest pad, that is the best way to get in the right general area.
