To navigate the map effectively, you will need something that can dig through machinery and/or walls. Without digging, you may not be able to fully explore the map. [[Mining Laser|Mining Lasers]] and [[Mining Claw|Mining Claws]] can both be obtained in Materials frequently. They can dig through the 20 armor Twisted Machinery but not the 28 armor walls. All Subdweller weaponry can dig through machinery, though only the [[Sub. Beam Cannon]] can dig through walls.

[[Image]]../part_art/Sub. Machine Gun.png|Sub. Machine Gun[[/Image]]
[[Image]]../part_art/Sub. Beam Cannon.png|Sub. Beam Cannon[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Weapons[[/Heading]]
Weapons basically fall under tiers based on how many hits it takes to kill a Subdweller on core. The fewer hits it takes the better they are.
[[List]]
3+ hit tier: [[EM Pulse Gun]], [[Hvy. Riot Gun]] (Note: 2x projectiles) [[Lgt. Assault Rifle]], [[Riot Gun]] (Note: 2x projectiles) [[Sml. Laser]]|
2-3 hit tier: [[Assault Rifle]], [[Barrage Gun]], [[Battle Rifle]], [[Hvy. Assault Rifle]], [[Med. Laser]]|
2 hit tier: [[Mak. Laser]], [[Lgt. Cannon]], [[Sub. Laser]], [[Sub. Machine Gun]]|
1-2 hit tier: [[Battle Cannon]], [[Hvy. Battle Rifle]]|1 hit tier: [[Sub. Beam Cannon]]
[[/List]]
One note about the Sub. Beam Cannon: Since it can kill Subdwellers in a single hit, it is better to fire a volley with only it instead of mixing with other weapons. Otherwise, if you hit core with your weapon that needs to hit twice to kill, you will have wasted extra 

[[Heading:3]]Melee[[/Heading]]
Melee weapons dropped from [[Scrap]] in Subcaves are usable since they can kill a Subdweller with 1 hit on core. Melee can be tricky to get to work on this map due to lack of true chokepoints. If you can engage Subdwellers in good positions, melee is often better than multiple weaker ranged weapons.

[[Heading:3]][[Launchers]][[/Heading]]
Launchers are of somewhat questionable value in Subcaves. While it may be tempting to explode groups of Subdwellers, there is a mechanic where an additional Subdwellers may pop out of any dug tile. The risk of this is not very high, though if you use launchers heavily you will find yourself dealing with a few extra bots throughout the map. In my opinion, the best use of Launchers is not on the Subdwellers but on the [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] that guard the [[Recycling]] exit since killing all of them one by one is usually a big hassle.

[[Image]]../part_art/Scrap Shield.png|Scrap Shield[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]][[Scrap Shield]][[/Heading]]
The Scrap Shield is one of the best parts for this map. Its massive coverage and ability to regenerate using [[Scrap Shield Fragment|Scrap Shield Fragments]] really helps keep Cogmind alive. It is a bit rare since most of the time Subdwellers drop only shield fragments instead of the shield itself. The largest downside of this part is the requirement to drop your storage unit on the ground since it takes up 2 slots. If you find one early into the map, dropping unnecessary backups and using the Scrap Shield to clear most of the map will massively reduce the risk of dying. Later on, it's often not worth dropping accumulated loot on the floor and letting it get eaten by subatomizers. If you do use a Scrap Shield, only drop your storage unit if it is undamaged, since it will likely be eaten otherwise. Otherwise, keep it in your inventory to attach before leaving the map.

[[Heading]]Materials Preparation[[/Heading]]
Since core is the big lose condition for Subcaves, the amount of time you want to spend in Materials should be carefully considered. You can try to max out exploration in Materials, head into [[Mines]], and then come to Subcaves afterward. This can be done, but it is much more risky than taking the Subcaves exit as soon as you find it. Depending on what route you want to take, one strategy might be to try to pull off one [[Spoiler]][[GameText]]Trojan(Skim)[[/GameText]] to try to identify the depth of [[Recycling]].[[/Spoiler]] Another option is just to take the exit as soon as you find it. It's a good idea to at least obtain a Seismic Detector, a better storage unit, and a digging tool before heading inside. Most other parts can be obtained from within Subcaves.

Name: Strategy/Maps/Wastes
Content:
[[Wastes]] is a very dangerous [[0b10]] map that can easily demolish slower builds with [[C-40 Crusher|Crushers]]. Airborne builds have a fairly easy time escaping this map, but grounded builds will need a plan to escape intact.

[[Heading]]Airborne builds[[/Heading]]
If Cogmind is airborne there are lots of options available. Beelining for the exit is a good strategy when allies aren't wanted or if the EMP is on. If the EMP is off, there are most likely allies on the map. Search for [[Derelict]] allies in the larger square openings on the top and bottom of the map where they can appear. They can usually take out all of the Crushers unaided. Fast speed can also allow easy kiting of Crushers around the map. Crushers do not have the most intelligent movement and can often be baited to moving to one side of the corridor. After this, quickly cross to the other side and pass out of reach. Circling back may be needed to avoid groups of Crushers.

[[Heading]]Grounded Builds[[/Heading]]
Dealing with Crushers on slower builds is a much more daunting task. Crushers are slow moving but incredibly tanky and difficult to kill through conventional means. The high integrity of [[Damper Plating]] and low core exposure of only 15% makes kills inconsistent. One good strategy to kill them are critical destroy weapons such as a [[8R-AWN's Boregun]] and [[Hypervelocity Weapons]]. While the armor can't be destroyed with a crit, the core and compactor exposure are about 23% combined, and getting a single critical hit will either kill or disarm the Crusher immediately. To avoid corruption when the EMP is on, put on a [[Damper Plating]] and/or a [[Dynamic Insulation System]] as soon as possible after killing a Crusher. Another strategy is a meltdown build. 3 or more thermal guns can overheat the Crushers and cause them to melt.
[[Image]]Wastes Crusher Lure.png|Crusher loop strategy[[/Image]]Fighting Crushers head on without enough firepower can usually result in essential parts of the build getting crushed onto the floor. One way to reduce the risk is to fight the Crushers in a circle around the starting corner of the map. Dig a tunnel around the starting area and shoot Crushers through it like the image on the right. The walls in the map have 28 armor, so a thermal cannon or kinetic cannon are ideal for digging. [[Adv. Assault Cannon|Adv. Assault Cannons]] and [[Hvy. Ion Cannon|Hvy. Ion Cannons]] are both capable of doing the dig, although higher rating parts will do it better. Once the path is dug, Crushers are forced to take the long path around, giving plenty of time to get free shots off. However, this technique is a little risky as it is possible to get totally surrounded by multiple Crushers.
Sometimes the best option is simply to detach all parts and make a run for it. If the EMP is off, dropping parts in the corner of the map preemptively is a good idea. If the Derelict allies are on the map, they can clear out most of the Crushers for you so you can go back and pick up your parts later. Even if there are no allies around, being able to pick the parts that you want to take is a lot better than having all your parts crushed and being stuck with potentially only junk.

[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading]][[RIF]][[/Heading]]
Using RIF along with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] and [[Relay Coupler [NC]|NC Couplers]] makes each Crusher non-hostile for 3 charges a pieces. This makes the Crushers trivial to loot for maximum salvage, although the EMP can still make the process be quite annoying. Since there are 6 Crushers, the total cost is 18 charges for the whole map. Ramming these bots when neutralized this way is safe to do if running low on matter.
[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Strategy/Maps/Zion Deep Caves
Content:
[[Zion Deep Caves]] is an optional challenge [[Branch]] that serves as a series of checklists. Each section of the map plays out in a similar way each time, and there are some requirements to deal with them in a consistent way. Here is a general checklist of things that will be useful throughout the map:
[[List]]
Propulsion/Weapon/Armor + backups: Lots of fighting is required in this map. Having backups of these more important parts will keep the build in fighting shape.|
[[Launchers]]: These can be used for the [[Z-Imprinter]], [[Z-Light (5)|Z-Lights]], and especially for the [[Assembled]] in the wall. Multiple backups are recommended.|
[[Electromagnetic Weapons]]: EM is the most effective way to fight [[Golem|Golems]]. EM traps like [[EM Surge Trap|EM Surge]] or [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bombs]] can also be used, but having at least 1 EM weapon is best to be safe. Another alternative is [[Impact Weapons]], though it can be a bit tough to get Golems into melee range.|
(Optional) [[AS-neutralizer No. 17b]]: Completely neutralizes the threat of the Assembled wall.|
(Optional) Allies: Make the opening Z-Imprinter fight much easier to handle. [[A8]]'s grunt code (used at the [[Terminal]] at the entrance to the deep caves) and various friendly Zion bots make great allies.|
(Optional) Dead [[Imprinter]]: Killing the Imprinter in Zion prevents her from showing up in this map. She has no weapons in Zion so taking her out there can be an easy way to skip a big threat on this map.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Starting Area[[/Heading]]
There isn't much threat here. There can be groups of 3 Assembled that can be easily dispatched by any weapons, although Launchers are most effective.
[[Image]]ZDC Allies.png|Fighting the Z-Imprinter with allies[[/Image]][[Image]]ZDC Imprinter Launcher.png|Aiming past the Imprinter with a Launcher[[/Image]]

[[Heading]]Z-Imprinter[[/Heading]]
After entering the main open area of the map, the Z-Imprinter will spawn and head directly to Cogmind's location. 2 Z-Lights will follow the Imprinter but are much slower and will take some time to arrive. The Z-Imprinter has high evasion, 150 core integrity, and deals a large amount of damage every volley. Allies are highly recommended for this fight to help destroy her quicker and to draw fire from you. A [[Tactical Coordination Suite]] can really help out with an ally damage. [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]] or multislot treads with [[Special Propulsion Modes#Siege mode|Siege Mode]] are also recommended to be able to hit the Imprinter more frequently.
For Cogmind's build, any non-EM and non-Impact damage types will work. To get the [[Zio. Metafield Generator]], +Salvage is recommended by using guns with the best available type of [[Salvage Targeting Computers|Salvage Targeting Computer]]. Although it doesn't deal much damage, EM can be used to apply +Salvage if allies are providing enough damage output otherwise. If salvage isn't needed, using [[Explosive Launchers]] will be very effective here. Rather than aiming directly at the Imprinter, aim the launcher at a wall or at the end of its range so that the Imprinter is still hit close to the source. This will maintain a high accuracy while still dealing the bulk of the damage to the Imprinter. This technique can also be used against the Z-Lights to good effect.
After the Z-Imprinter is dead, take care that your allies don't spot the Z-Technicians by the Z-Power machine. They will almost assuredly miss into the machine and end up nuking themselves, and if you're not careful, Cogmind. Beware its large 15 tile radius.
[[Heading]]Z-Light Guards[[/Heading]]The top and bottom of the map have groups of 3 Z-Light guards. There are 2 groups on the top and one on the bottom. All of these are optional encounters. To avoid them, dig through the center of the Z-Facility and hang near the left side of the area. Enter the tunnel near the top side to avoid getting spotted by the bottom group. However, the top Z-Lights are often worth fighting because of the large number of special Zionite parts they guard. It is possible to reach the first alcove on the top right without getting spotted, but the remainder are all guarded
If Cogmind still has strong allies like Enhanced Grunts alive from the Z-Light encounter, it is possible to just charge in and fight them all at once. They are not as dangerous as the Z-Imprinter, but in large numbers they can still pack a large punch. Using Launchers is very effective on these bots since despite their evasion, they have relatively low core integrity. Using a [[Transmission Jammers|Transmission Jammer]] to lure them 1 at a time can also be an effective strategy if fighting with non-launcher weapons to preserve salvage. Without using a jammer, all 6 bots will be alerted simultaneously and come running right away.

[[Heading]]Exit Area[[/Heading]]
Same as the starting area, the only threat here is small groups of 3 Assembled.

[[Heading]]Golems[[/Heading]]
Golems are incredibly tanky enemies with an extreme damage output and the source of many lost runs. In order to claim a GOLEM Unit or the Exiles item, Cogmind must fight or at least run past them. With a 10% core exposure, 200 core integrity, and 15% damage resistance to non-melee damage types, trying to kill with core damage is completely impractical. The best approach is EM damage or Impact. Golems only require an average of 118 damage to corrupt them to death compared to thousands of damage with non-EM weapons. Using [[Zio. Weapon Casing|Weapon Casings]] looted earlier is helpful to preserve EM cannon integrity and avoid running out of weapons.
Due to uneven calculations for line-of-sight and weapon range, it is possible to shoot the Golems once before you are spotted at 16 range. See the Golem 1/2 spots below for reference. This allows Cogmind to wait 2 turns before shooting to avoid any movement accuracy penalties, since every turn counts particularly hard when fighting a Golem. If using EM traps, short ranged EM weapons, or Impact weapons, see the lure images for reference. This will get Cogmind spotted, likely get shot at for 1 volley, and then draw the Golem in closer. This can avoid misses or misfires opening the GOLEM Unit chambers and accidentally triggering the wall early. However, keep in mind that if Cogmind misses or if the Golem misfires into one of the chambers, the wall will open instantly. Luring the Golems out of range where they can attack the GOLEM Unit containers is recommended. The Exiles item will typically require fighting the top Golem, but getting a GOLEM unit typically requires fighting both Golems, or at least luring a Golem closer and grabbing the unit if it drops.
[[Gallery]]ZDC Golem Spot 1.png|16 range Golem 1 spot (safe with Cogmind misses)|ZDC Golem Spot 2.png|Golem 2 spot (unsafe with Cogmind misses)|ZDC Golem Lure 1.png|Golem lure 1|ZDC Golem Lure 2.png|Golem lure 2|ZDC Golem Trap 1.png|Golem trap 1|ZDC Golem Trap 2.png|Golem trap 2[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Impregnable Wall[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]ZDC Wall Activation Zone.png|Approximate wall activation zone[[/Image]]
The Assembled wall is an indestructible wall containing 35 [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] and 2 [[Assembler|Assemblers]] that will automatically open up when Cogmind gets too close to it, or if any of the GOLEM Unit chambers are destroyed. See the image on the right for a range reference. This range encompasses the GOLEM Unit containers, so fighting the wall is required to grab them.
Fighting the wall practically requires Launchers to avoid becoming overwhelmed. Any kinds of launchers work, although explosive launchers are better due to their higher base damage. Trying to use launchers at a range where they won't miss and take out the GOLEM unit containers is ideal. Otherwise it can be slightly annoying up to even deadly to have a large number of growing Golems running around. They grow slowly, but trying to deal with the Assembled and growing Golems at the same time can be a recipe for disaster. Alternately, the [[AS-neutralizer No. 17b]] can be used here to almost entirely eliminate any threat of the wall. The Assemblers will still need to be destroyed, but the rest of the Assembled will become useless.

[[Heading]]Loot[[/Heading]]
After everything else is cleaned out, all that's left is claiming the loot. Wall Chambers will drop [[GOLEM Unit|GOLEM Units]] when destroyed. They will turn into a Golem in a few turns, so grab them quickly. They can drop their GOLEM Unit upon being destroyed (standard loot rules), so applying positive and negative Salvage affects Golem reformation. Using melee weapons is recommended to avoid missing into other containers and spawning further Golems.
The Exiles item will normally require fighting both the wall and the top Golem. One alternative to grab it is using the Zion special item [[Phasing AFG]]. By using it, the item can be pulled in without any fighting on the left side of the map.

Name: Strategy/Wintypes
Content: Strategies about obtaining particular [[Wintypes]].

Name: Strategy/Wintypes/W8 Fortifying 0b10
Content:
After defeating [[MAIN.C (Shell)]] in [[Command]], the [[Command#w8_fortifying_0b10surrender|surrender option]] may be selected instead of continuing to fight MAIN.C. A [[Core Reset Matrix]] or being [[Warlord (Alignment)|Warlord aligned]] while [[Warlord]] is alive will prevent this option from being selected.
Cogmind, MAIN.C, and the newly allied [[0b10]] bots must face off against waves of [[Enhanced Q-Series]]. These bots are mostly randomized, but there are some common qualities to them. They all have [[Adv. Dynamic Insulation System|Adv. Dynamic Insulation Systems]] which makes EM damage not a very reliable way to kill. They typically have another damage resistance utility or armor, although Kinetic and Thermal damage is usually effective. A 4+ [[Ballistic Cannons]] or [[Multirail]] stack is a good set to deal a lot of damage to these bots. The overall build requirements tend not to be too strict here. Cogmind does need to be able to put out a decent amount of damage and manage to keep a build well intact from backup parts and from Q-Series or 0b10 bot loot. MAIN.C does have a tendency to wander off and get overwhelmed at times, so try to keep up with him.
One consideration when doing this event is whether or not to go to the cache. Since Cogmind only gets 100 moves and about 40 more turns after that, it may be worth calculating the path ahead of time. If MAIN.C gets overwhelmed in the first fight, single-handedly fighting a large group of Q-Series, the event can end in failure right at the very beginning. A [[Microwarp Drive]] can help greatly here since one warp only counts as one move for the purposes of the counter.

[[Heading]]Useful parts vs. Enhanced Q-Series[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:2]][[Point Defense Systems]][[/Heading]]
Some of the Enhanced Q-Series carry powerful [[Launchers]] that are blocked by this utility.
[[Heading:2]][[Tractor Beams]][[/Heading]]
There aren't typically a lot of turns to spend running around collecting matter in this event. Being able to restock remotely can help save a lot of time and damage dealt to Cogmind.
[[Heading:2]][[Matter Compressors]]/[[Energy Wells]][[/Heading]]
Resource storage is always useful in extended combat encounters like this.
[[Heading:2]][[Launchers]][[/Heading]]
While these should be used sparingly to avoid friendly 0b10 fire that can trigger an accidental betrayal, sometimes large groups of Enhanced Q-Series will wander into the MAIN.C room at about the same time. It is very nice to be able to attack these groups simultaneously.
[[Heading:2]][[Phasing AFG]]/[[Portable AFG]][[/Heading]]
Drawing loot piles closer to Cogmind can also save a lot of otherwise wasted time trying to travel a long distance to get some good loot.

Name: Strategy/Wintypes/W9 Defending 0bPrime
Content:
Assisting the [[UFD]] forces in their [[Protoforge]] assault is a task that is initially extremely challenging but can be made much easier with lots of preparation. The minimal readiness UFD will be utterly annihilated by [[0b10]] forces, leaving Cogmind up against a huge amount of bots with little assistance. On the other hand, the maximal readiness UFD can put up a solid fight against 0b10 and can even win fights well enough to plant multiple [[UFD Drillbomb|UFD Drillbombs]]. The ideal scenario is to have at least 120 Fedlink [[UFD#resource_mechanics|resources]] when beginning the event and to avoid the civil war in [[Scraptown]] which would otherwise weaken the UFD forces.

[[Heading]]Primary Strategies[[/Heading]]
There are two main strategies for this event: Stealth based and combat based.
[[Heading:2]]Stealth Bombing[[/Heading]]
Stealth is the easier option of the two to beat the event. With maximal UFD forces, Cogmind has to do little to no fighting in order to help complete the event. Instead, focus on remaining out of sight and planting Drillbombs. However, helping out the UFD forces here and there with launchers, especially guided ones like a [[Mni. Smartbomb Launcher]], can be an easy way to help out the UFD without risking too much damage. [[Flight Units|Flight]] is the ideal propulsion type for stealth thanks to its high speed, allowing for easily sneaking to Drillbomb planting locations and retreating back to friendly bots when caught in a bad position. [[Hover Units|Hover]] is still a good option since it tends to be more capable of taking on fights when needed. The lack of inventory is one of the biggest issues for flight, with a [[Med. Storage Unit]] being required to carry a single Drillbomb without any backups available. However, thanks to the massive number of Strikers that appear during this event, there will always be spare flight units.
Although rather slow, [[Impulse Thruster Array|Impulse Thruster Arrays]] have good support and integrity. Hover is much worse off here, as the only dropped hover propulsion, [[Imp. Antigrav System|Imp. Antigrav Systems]], from [[P-80 Master|P-80 Masters]] is not very impressive. The lab area has plenty of great hover units to stock up on before or during the event as needed.
[[Heading:2]]Combat[[/Heading]]
Heavy combat builds are also more than capable of completing the event, even at lower UFD resource levels. One major boon to combat builds is the amount of loot and matter generated from the attack. It's very difficult to run out of crucial build elements like power, propulsion, and weapons, although the choice of parts may not always be the most desirable. Combat builds can choose between helping out with some Drillbomb planting or fully committing fighting the 0b10 waves. If Cogmind can fight up to the exit, camping nearby and using launchers at each new 0b10 wave can be a very effective strategy.
Mass Executioner spawns guarantee a limitless supply of good offensive processors. Their [[Adv. Kinecellerator|Adv. Kinecellerators]] are also a good option for any kinetic builds. They pair well with the [[Helical Railgun|Helical Railguns]] dropped by Executioners and Ovr. weaponry dropped by the [[Scrapoid|Scrapoids]] and [[Scraphulk|Scraphulks]]. While some [[Ovr. Medium Treads]] are available from Elites, they are not all that good for the depth, so it can be problematic to restock on [[Treads]]. [[Wheel|Wheels]] builds can get the [[Ovr. Huge Scrapsphere]] from Scrapoids. [[Legs]] builds have the best options available between [[Enh. Biometal Leg|Enh. Biometal Legs]] from Executioners and [[Ovr. Armored Exoskeleton|Ovr. Armored Exoskeletons]] from Scraphulks.

[[Heading]]General Strategies[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Protoforge Alternate Dig Path.png|A good alternate path to dig out of the Protoforge area[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]]Eliminate the [[Garrison Access]][[/Heading]]
The [[Prototype Robot|Prototype Robots]] spit out from the Garrison can be a nuisance to the UFD forces. While they are not as numerous as the main [[Assault Squad|Assault]] forces, they are additional dispatches that tend to be tougher than usual bots. Shutting down or destroying the Garrison before starting the event begins is a good idea. While technically possible to do after starting the assault, running down the [[Superfortress]] hallway to shut the Garrison is pretty risky.
[[Heading:2]]Dig to Improve UFD Routing[[/Heading]]
The layout of the left part of the forge area can be quite variable from run to run. Sometimes there are multiple great routes for planting Drillbombs without having to fight off many 0b10 forces. Sometimes the map ends in a giant single hallway chokepoint where it is nearly impossible for the UFD to make any progress. Don't be afraid of digging tunnels to create alternate routes to sneak past enemy forces. Being able to dig through the Forge [[Reinforced Walls#protoforge|Reinforced Barriers (80 armor)]] is often useful since the rooms on the left side tend to back up against the Forge in multiple locations other than just the entrance.
[[Heading:2]][[Launchers|Launcher]] It Up[[/Heading]]
Don't shy away from using Launchers during the event. Launchers are always a good tool against large groups of enemies, but some of their downsides costs are high [[Matter]] use and [[Alert]] generation. During the event, there is so much matter generated that it's impossible to ever run out. Alert during the event is irrelevant and will not cause any additional responses. Keep in mind that alert will still travel to the next map if planning to exit through the main exit instead of taking the win.
[[Heading:2]]Useful Event Items[[/Heading]]
[[List]][[Cloaking Devices]]: Help traverse the map and plant Drillbombs without being spotted. [[Cep. Cloak Mesh]] is available on the map in the lab area.|
Digging parts: Digging parts strong enough to dig through the Forge Plexus area Reinforced Barriers are highly useful for getting around a chokepoint.|
Good Launchers: Protoforge Launchers in particular are some of the most powerful options in the game and can easily wipe out squads to turn the tide in favor of the UFD forces.|[[Active Sensor Suite|Regular]] or [[Exp. Active Sensor Suite]]: The [[Investigation Squad|investigation]]-summoning effect of this part is not active during the event, leaving only the upside of powerful, long ranged and unjammable sensors.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Loot the Lab?[[/Heading]]
The back lab area of the map can provide lots of good items but may not always be worth going for. With a good build going into the map, there is a chance that going to the lab leads to losing the build instead of improving it. If alert is an issue, consider how likely it is that High Security will trigger before leaving, which will lock the event out altogether and possibly even kill the run.
If going into the lab, the other question is when? Going in before the event is a little safer since there aren't going to be any assaults wandering through the Superfortress hallway or prototypes dispatched from the Garrison, and there is the possibility that Superfortress is still dormant. After the event is begun, getting back there is more challenging, but at least there won't be any [[Extermination Squad|Extermination]] or [[Assault Squad|Assault Squads]] dispatched to the back of the lab. Depending on the UFD readiness, spending an extended amount of time in the lab can result in the UFD forces becoming overrun.

Name: Striker
Content: Bot

Name: Study
Content:
Studies are a collection of minor buffs that can be hacked for at a [[Scanalyzer]]. [[Power]], [[Propulsion]], and [[Weapons]] all have unique buff effects based on the type of part. Studies can only be obtained for non-[[Prototype Part|prototype parts]], but once obtained, will apply to all parts matching a given type. Studies are great for commonly looted parts that can be obtained many times throughout a run and for parts that can be used in large numbers.

[[Heading]]Study effects[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[Light Power|Light]], [[Micro Power|Micro]], or Mini Power: +1 supply|
Other power sources: +2 supply|
[[Treads]]: Penalty / 2|
[[Legs]]: -15 time/move|
[[Wheels]]: -10 time/move|
[[Hover Unit|Hover]]/[[Flight Unit|Flight Units]]: +1 support/slot|
Weapons: +10% accuracy
[[/List]]

[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading]][[Core Reset Matrix]] Interaction[[/Heading]]
Using the Core Reset Matrix will remove knowledge of all studies.
[[/Spoiler]]

Name: Style Achievements
Content:
[[Comment]]                       ---NOTE FOR EDITORS---
Once Beta 16 releases, if you decide to update any of the Achievements pages, please consider whether it would be better to separate the new achievements from the old ones or not.
I think that, ideally, whatever you choose to do, that decision should be applied to all Achievements pages, for the sake of consistency.[[/Comment]]

Style [[Achievements]] are earned by reaching high statistics in some categories which usually require using an associated playstyle, or by using some rare items and/or their mechanics. Most of them will be simply eventually be obtained by players as they become familiar with the more common mechanics of the game and figure out playstyles that utilizes them or discover some of the less common mechanics of the game. 12 of the 46 Style Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Style Achievement indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements with similar[[Comment]]TODO: Figure out a way to say "Achievements with almost exactly the same requirements, with the only difference being that one achievement requires doing thing A while the more difficult achievement requires doing thing A+B.", but use fewer words to say this.[[/Comment]] requirements, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.

[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Heading]]Combat[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Turtlemind: Have 2% or less core exposure.
|Can't Touch This: Absorb 1,500 damage using shields ([[Shield Generators]]/[[Force Fields]].
|Executioner: Have 7 weapon slots.
|Perfect Aim: Have +40% targeting accuracy for ranged weapons via utilities.
|More Dakka Please: Fire 10 kinetic projectiles in a single volley.
Strategy: Equip two "Flak" weapons and fire them both in one volley.
|Gunslinger: Destroy 3 robots with a single volley using secondary targeting.
|Gun Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by guns.
|Cannon Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by cannons.
|Launcher Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by [[Launchers|launchers]].
|Melee Specialist: Destroy 100 hostiles with at least 90% of damage across an entire run dealt by melee weapons.
|Shocking Conclusion: [[Corruption|Corrupt]] 50 hostiles.
|Pyromaniac: Cause 20 hostiles to [[Meltdown|meltdown]].
|Guerrilla Style: Trigger reprogrammed (or placed) [[Traps|traps]] on 30 hostiles.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Tank: [[Spoiler]]Reach a mass of 150.[[/Spoiler]]
Strategy: Either wait for it to happen on its own while you're playing a heavy combat build, or equip either a [[Humpback]] or a [[Cargo Storage Unit]] and a few other parts.
|Friend Of Zion: [[Spoiler]]Summon 10 [[Imprint#roster_hacks|Zionite dispatches]].[[/Spoiler]]
|Heroic Deeds: [[Spoiler]]Summon a [[Z-Hero|Hero of Zion]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Flight/Hover[[/Heading]]

|Speed Demon: Reach a speed of 10 spaces per turn.
|Supersonic: Reach a speed of 20 spaces per turn.
Strategy: Only possible by having either at least 5 [[Overload#propulsion|overloaded]] [[Flight Units]] or 15 overloaded [[Hover Units]].
|Dodgeball, But With Guns: Reach 75% evasion.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Various 2[[/Heading]]

|Sniper: [[Spoiler]]Destroy a visible hostile from more than 20 spaces away with a gun or cannon.[[/Spoiler]]
|Dramatic Entrance: [[Spoiler]]With no hostiles in sight and no pursuers, destroy an enemy combat bot with explosives.[[/Spoiler]]
|Decoder Ring: Obtain 50 pieces of intel from one or more [[0b10 Decoder Chips]].
|Freeware: [[Spoiler]]Receive 10 pieces of [[Imprint#intel_hacks|Zionite intel]].[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

|Pwned: Hack 50 hostiles.

This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Subcaves
Content:
Subcaves is a tough early game [[Branch]] that is guaranteed to appear on -10 every run, with exits being available from [[Materials]] and [[Mines]]. It is a dangerous map, containing a large number of [[Subdweller|Subdwellers]] that will attack Cogmind on sight with relatively powerful weapons. A few [[0b10]] patrols may roam the map, engaging wild [[Derelict|Derelicts]].
Unlike most maps, some areas may not be accessible in Subcaves without digging. 20 armor machinery strewn throughout the map can block passage to important areas. [[Artisan|Artisans]] will grow the machinery even more. Another unique bot present, [[Cobbler|Cobblers]], scoop up matter and produce random parts with their [[Cobbler Unit]].

[[Heading]]Unique Mechanics[[/Heading]]

[[Heading:2]]Subdweller Uncovering[[/Heading]]
Each tile that is destroyed by any means has a chance of revealing a Subdweller. [[Launchers|Explosive Launchers]] should not be used much, if at all, to avoid dealing with extra hostiles. Any means of destroying terrain can trigger this effect.

[[Heading:2]]Subatomizers[[/Heading]]
Leaving partially damaged parts on the ground will cause "Subatomizers" to show up. They are invisible and gradually destroy any damaged parts left on the ground for too long. Full integrity parts are unaffected.

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Maps/Subcaves]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Subcaves Recycling Exit.png|An exit to [[Recycling]], guarded by 4 dormant [[S-10 Pest|Swarmers]] and 2 [[Autobeam Turret|Autobeam Turrets]]|Subcaves 4L-MR0's Lab.png|4L-MR0's Lab, with a unique prototype in a Testing Chamber|Subcon Basin Container.png|[[SUBCON Basin]] holding machine|Subcaves V3-11A's Pendant.png|V3-11A with their [[V3-11A's Pendant|Pendant]]|Subcaves Clippy Terminal.png|"Clippyterm" Terminal with unique lore and intel|Subcaves Disabled Subdwellers.png|Collection of 3 broken Subdwellers|Subcaves Scrap Room.png|[[Scrap]] and machinery encased in Earth tiles|Subcaves Traps.png|Collection of installed hostile [[Piercing Trap|Piercing]] and [[Shrapnel Trap|Shrapnel Traps]][[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]4L-MR0 Prototypes[[/Heading]]
The unique Artisan named 4L-MR0 has a variety of unique [[Prototype Part|Prototypes]] available in their lab. Only one part can be found this way per run. The possible 4L-MR0 prototypes are:
[[List]]
[[Arachnoskeleton]]|
[[Cargo Legs]]|
[[Flightbrick]]|
[[Gun Armor]]|
[[Meta Core]]|
[[Power Bank]]|
[[Powered Cannon]]|
[[Rainbow Chip]]|
[[Tower Shield]]
[[/List]]
[[Heading:3]]Subdweller Attack[[/Heading]]
Sometimes, 4L-MR0's lab has been attacked by Subdwellers. When this happens, 3 Subdwellers will appear in the lab instead of 4L-MR0.
[[Heading:3]]Broken Subdwellers[[/Heading]]
A collection of 3 broken Subdwellers can found in Subcaves. Sometimes, they will spring to life when Cogmind comes near or attacks. If this happens, one of the Subdwellers will drop one of the 4L-MR0 prototypes. This can allow for a second prototype to be found in a single run.
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 3 types of exits in Subcaves:
[[List]]
Recycling exit: There is always 1 Recycling exit in Subcaves, guarded by dormant Swarmers and Autobeam Turrets. This exit can skip -9, -8, and -7 depending on the location of Recycling.|
Materials exits: These always lead to -8 Materials. These exits always skip -9 entirely. There are always 2 exits to Materials. All unguarded exits lead to Materials.|
[[Scraptown]] exit: The lost [[Scientist]] and the group of [[Federalist|Federalists]] can both reveal a shortcut to Scraptown.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]Subcaves Subdweller Attack.png|Subdwellers attacking, with allied Thugs and Guerrilla[[/Image]]
[[List]]
(++) Lost Scientist: A Scientist can appear as Cogmind enters the map. The Scientist will tell Cogmind that they got separated from the rest of their [[UFD]] group. They will periodically indicate the general direction of a secret exit to Scraptown. If they survive to the location of the shortcut, they will reveal the exit that goes directly to Scraptown.|
(+) Cobbler Follower: A dormant Cobbler will wake up and begin to follow Cogmind around.|
(~) Subdweller attack: An allied [[Guerrilla (7)|Guerrilla]] will show up upon entering the map. Shortly after, several Subdwellers will appear and attack, with [[Thug (5)|Thugs]] appearing as allied backup.
[[/List]]

Name: Superfortress
Content:
Superfortress is a massive and deadly bot that stands guard in the center of [[Protoforge]]. It is arguably the most powerful robot in the game, capable of regenerating core integrity and parts as well as assembling large numbers of allies to its defense. It is initially dormant but can [[Protoforge#dormancy|wake up]] for a variety of reasons.
[[Heading]]Part Assembling[[/Heading]]
Superfortress will assemble any destroyed non-weapon parts periodically. One destroyed part will be assembled roughly every 10 turns, although this number is variable. Weapons are instead periodically broken down and assembled instantly. As long as Superfortress has a least one weapon remaining, there will be no prioritization of reassembling weapons. However, if Superfortress runs out of weapons entirely, it will immediately reassemble a full set of weapons.
[[Heading:2]]Weapon Reassembling[[/Heading]]
Superfortress initially has no weapons attached. Upon waking up, it will assemble a random selection of weapons. Superfortress will assemble 4 weapon slots worth of weapons each time it assembles weapons.
Typical weapons are from the following list:
[[Table]]
Part|Slots||
[[Cep. Heavy Railcannon]]|2||
[[Cep. Helical Railcannon]]|1||
[[Cep. Miniperforator]]|1||[[Cep. Plasma Driver]]|1||
[[Cld. Nova Cannon]]|1||
[[Enh. Hardcell Cannon]]|1||
[[Graviton Cannon]]|1||
[[Hvy. Hardcell Cannon]]|2||
[[Null Cannon]]|1||
[[Omega Cannon]]|2
[[/Table]]
When there are 10 or more bots in line of sight, Superfortress may assemble a [[Launchers|Launcher]] instead of one of its typical weapons. The available launchers are from the following list:
[[List]]
[[Cep. Arcsight Missile Launcher]]|
[[Com. Tesla Bomb Launcher]]|
[[Enh. Gamma Bomb Array]]|
[[Fusion Bomb Launcher]]|
[[Gamma Bomb Array]]|
[[Gamma Driveblaster]]|
[[Ragnarok Missile Launcher]][[/List]]
[[Heading]]Robot Assembling[[/Heading]]
When Superfortress is under fire or there are multiple  hostiles in line of sight, it will assemble allies to fight for it. The more hostiles are in line of sight, the more likely it is that Superfortress will assemble a new ally each turn. This can make it very difficult to maintain a numbers advantage over Superfortress. Bots assembled can be from the following list:
[[List]]
[[Decapitator]]|
[[Executioner]]|
[[H-88 Terminator]]|
[[Hotshot]]|
[[Immortal]]|
[[P-80 Master]]|
[[Striker]]|
[[X-77 Beamer]]|
[[X-82 Rainmaker]]|
[[X-87 Electro]]
[[/List]]
[[Heading]]Killing Superfortress[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Bosses/Defeating Superfortress]].

Name: Superquantum Companion
Content: The Superquantum Companion is a unique talking melee weapon that is an upgrade to the [[Quantum Companion]]. It can be obtained by using a [[Subatomic Replicator]] on the Quantum Companion. The Superquantum Companion has [[Quantum Companion#special_effects|all of the effects]] that the Quantum Companion does, but the frequency of all effects is increased.

Name: Supersonic Drone Bay
Content: Deploys a [[Trailblazer]].

Name: Surface
Content: The surface is not a real map in the game, but exiting to the surface is one way to win the game. Many of the game's wintypes require getting to a surface exit. See [[Wintypes]] for more information.

Name: Surge Thrusters
Parts: Surge Thruster,Imp. Surge Thruster,Adv. Surge Thruster,Exp. Surge Thruster

Name: Surgeon
Content:
Surgeons are wheeled [[Derelict]] non-combat bots. They are the Derelict counterpart of the [[0b10]] [[Mechanic]] class of bots. Like Mechanics, they repair ally core and part integrity and have the same set of limitations that Mechanics do on repairs. They also have an inventory of 2 [[Backup Power III]], 4 [[Backup Propulsion III]], 2 [[Backup Plating III]], and 4 [[Backup Laser III]] that they will refer on allies with empty slots.

[[Heading]]Integrity Repaired[[/Heading]]
The amount of integrity that can be repaired by Surgeons depends on the bot type. The Surgeon (4) can repair 1700 integrity and the Surgeon (6) can repair 2300 integrity.

Name: Surgeon (4)
Content: Surgeon variant with an [[Imp. Field Recycling Unit]].

Name: Surgeon (6)
Content: Surgeon variant with an [[Adv. Field Recycling Unit]].

Name: Surveillance Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Surveillance Squad.png|A Watcher surveillance squad[[/Image]]
Surveillance squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that roam the map looking for hostiles to report to 0b10 combat bots. They consist only of a single [[Watcher]]. This is a [[W-16 Scout]] on -10 and -9, a [[W-25 Informer]] on -8 through -5, and a [[W-44 Eye]] on -4 through -1. They can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]]. They patrol between two points at a slow pace, then turn back around when they reach the end. The [[Garrison Access]] hack [[Spoiler]]Trojan(Watchers)[[/Spoiler]] reports where all Watchers are at all times.

Name: Swarm Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Swarm Drone|Swarm Drones]].

Name: Swarmer
Content:
Swarmers are a [[Bot Groups|bot group]] of [[Flight Units|flying]] [[0b10]] combat bots with one [[Ballistic Guns|Ballistic Gun]] that are always seen in groups. They are individually weak and non-threatening, but annoying in groups. Swarmers have a slight Explosive damage weakness. This, combined with their evasiveness, high core exposure, and low core integrity, make explosive [[Launchers|Launcher]] a great idea to use against them. Trying to pick off 6 Swarmers one by one may take much longer and result in a lot more damage dealt to Cogmind.
Swarmers have a very low memory (20 actions). While they may pursue airborne builds quickly compared to most other bots, it can be easy to lose them after turning the corner in a corridor or hallway near max range. This strategy is more effective when used with [[ECM Suites]].
[[Gallery]]Swarmers.png|All Swarmer variants and colors[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Squads[[/Heading]]
Swarmers may appear in the following squads:
[[List]][[Cargo Convoy]]: Escorts that lead the way ahead of the rest of the convoy|[[Garrison Squad]]|[[Patrol Squad]]|[[Security Squad]] - [[Armory]], [[Garrison|Garrisons]], [[Quarantine]], and [[Testing]] only[[/List]]

Name: TF Node
Content:
[[Image]]TF Node.png|A TF Node in a [[Factory]] junction[[/Image]]
TF Nodes are blue one-tile non-interactive machines that can appear in most [[0b10]]-controlled maps. They appear at junctions in locations similar to where [[Sentry|Sentries]] would be placed. They are more numerous in larger maps, although they are not guaranteed to be present on any given map. They serve no purpose when active, but they can drop [[Sensor Arrays]] and [[Signal Interpreters]] when destroyed. No parts may drop when destroyed, but usually at least one of the two will drop. The parts contained within depend on the depth:
[[Table]]
Depth/Map|Sensor Array|Signal Interpreter||
-10 to -9|[[Sensor Array]]|[[Signal Interpreter]]||
-8 to -5|[[Imp. Sensor Array]]|[[Imp. Signal Interpreter]]||
-4 to -1|[[Adv. Sensor Array]]|[[Adv. Signal Interpreter]]
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]

Name: Tech Extrapolator
Content:
The Tech Extrapolator is an item associated with the [[United Federation of Derelicts]], used by [[Scientist|Scientists]] to develop new parts. While attached, it can produce part schematics based on items that are seen on the ground or attached to other bots. Parts must be identified by Cogmind, but once they have been seen they can not be forgotten by the Tech Extrapolator, even if Cogmind forgets due to corruption or use of a [[Core Reset Matrix]]. A list of Tech Extrapolator only parts can be found at [[Tech Extrapolator Parts]].

[[Heading]]Obtaining[[/Heading]]
The Tech Extrapolator can be obtained by one of two methods:
[[List]][[SUBCON Basin]] delivery: A filled SUBCON Basin may be delivered from [[Subcaves]] to the Scraplab in [[Recycling]]. A Scientist will reward Cogmind with an Extrapolator.|Killing [[Scraptown]]: Tech Extrapolators are dropped from Scientists in Scraptown. Note: Tech Extrapolators dropped from Scientists in the Scraplab in Recycling will self-destruct.[[/List]]

Name: Terminal
Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Terminal.png|An 0b10-controlled Terminal[[/Image]]
Terminals are typically [[0b10]]-controlled [[Interactive Machine|Interactive Machines]] that [[Cogmind]] can hack for a large variety of benefits. Unlike other interactive machines, non-limited 0b10 Terminals do not list all possible "authorized" hacks and instead only show a selection of hacks chosen from a large pool. Hacks not listed can still be performed through manual or indirect hacking, though this will incur a -15% penalty per security level to the base success rate of hacks. Some [[Branch|Branches]] have [[Derelict]]-controlled Terminals. 0b10 Terminals are also sometimes guarded by an [[Operator]], which if alerted will lock down the Terminal and call for a [[Reinforcement Squad]] unless it or the Terminal is disabled/destroyed.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Terminal[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Types of 0b10 Terminals[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Type|Average Size|Armor|Direct hacks|Other Notes||
Standard security level 1|Small|18|Few available direct hacks|N/A||
2|Medium|25|More available direct hacks|N/A||
3|Large|30|Lots of available direct hacks|N/A||
Terminals inside [[Garrison|Garrisons]]|Small|18|One of Access(Emergency), Download(Navigation), Download(Registry), or Download(Security)|Terminal is always security level 2||
Door-type/Lore Terminals|1 tile|18|Usually one direct hack, to open the relevant door or get relevant lore record|Terminal is always security level 1||
Cave outpost Terminal|1 tile|18|Random mix of flavor (useless) and intel "Report" hacks, with flavor reports always grouped on top of the list and intel reports grouped on the bottom of the list ending in X|Terminal is always security level 1
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]]Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[Hacks]]Terminal[[/Hacks]]

[[Heading:2]]Operator [[Data Core]][[/Heading]]
Moving over a destroyed Operator's Data Core will automatically collect and it extract its dynamic key, which provides a one-time bonus that multiplies to the base success rate of all direct and indirect hacks by 1.5 if their base success rate was positive, or raise the base success rate to 0% if it was negative. The dynamic key can only be used within 40 turns before it expires at its Operator's Terminal.

[[Heading:2]][[Multitool]][[/Heading]]
Using a Multitool on a Terminal's interactive tile removes all direct hacks and causes tracing to begin immediately, but applies a modifier to indirect hacks. This modifier can range from -20% to +50%. Multitool is best used with a lot of [[Defensive Hackware]] to increase the number of hacks that can be safely performed after modification.

[[Heading:2]]Additional Details/Usage Tips[[/Heading]]
[[Heading:3]]Grayed Out Direct Hacks[[/Heading]]
[[GameText]][Local Emergency Access][[/GameText]], [[GameText]][Purge Alert][[/GameText]] and all [[GameText]][Traps][[/GameText]] hacks appear greyed out in direct hacks if they are currently useless. In other words, if a Terminal has a greyed out direct [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]] hack, then there are no [[Traps]] within the Terminal's range.
[[Heading:3]]Grouped Direct Hacks[[/Heading]]
If either [[GameText]][Disarm Traps][[/GameText]] or [[GameText]][Reprogram Traps][[/GameText]] is available as a direct hack, then [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]] will also be a direct hack on that Terminal. If [[GameText]][Purge Alert][[/GameText]] is available as a direct hack, then [[GameText]][Check Alert][[/GameText]] will also be a direct hack on that Terminal. If there is a direct [[GameText]][Recall][[/GameText]] hack available, then the corresponding [[GameText]][Status][[/GameText]] hack will also be available on that Terminal.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Access(Branch)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Certain branch entrances are not revealed by this hack because they are either unknown to 0b10 or considered more secret/secure. The full list of these branches is: [[Lab]], [[Protoforge]], [[Section 7]], [[Scraptown]] and [[Subcaves]].
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Access(Emergency)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack reveals emergency accesses within a radius of 20 tiles of the Terminal. Within a Garrison, this reveals all emergency accesses as well as phase walls throughout the entire map.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Alert(Check)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
[[Alert]] is reported in the alphabet form rather than as the exact precise number. For example, the Terminal reports alert level 1-A at 200 influence.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Alert(Purge)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
The base success rate of this hack goes down by 10% after each successful hack. This reduction only applies for the current map.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Enumerate()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
Enumerate hacks reveal the current position of all bots of the matching type across the map. These positions can be enabled/disabled in the intel console window. These positions will not update in realtime. If the hack is performed again, all existing intel positions of the same type will be cleared before being added again, so the intel does not stack.
[[Spoiler]][[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Force(Sabotage)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Adds an additional 50 alert if the hack succeeds but is unsuccessful in sabotaging a machine. Adds 100 alert if the hack succeeds and sabotages a machine. Additional alert from the explosive machine does not get added like when Cogmind shoots a machine to blow it up. This can reduce alert gained in maps with huge explosive machines such as [[Hub_04(d)]]. In fact, Hub is the best place to use this hack, as blowing up a random machine is seldom useful in most other maps, and the only valid targets within the map are the Network Hubs themselves.[[/Spoiler]]

[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Layout(zone)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Reveals the map in a 31x31 area around the map. That is, 15 tiles in each cardinal direction from the center tile of the Terminal[[Comment]]Since it's a 31x31 area, should it be 16 tiles "from the center tile of the terminal" or 15? It depends on whether we count the terminal tile or not.[[/Comment]]. Note that this hack cannot reveal a part of the map if it is not structurally connected (at least not within the 31x31 area) to the Terminal. Earth tiles are the only thing that can cause such a disconnect. For example, in a scenario with two rooms with only one layer of Earth tiles between them, and the shortest then a Terminal within one of the two rooms would only be able to reveal the other room if there was some structural connection from the Terminal to that room within 15 tiles from the Terminal. Otherwise, the room would not be mapped by the hack despite being very close to the Terminal. Potentially shorter structural connections can be created via terrain destruction.

[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Inventory()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
All stockpiles matching the hack type on the floor are revealed. This is all groups of items within a 2x2-3x3 area, even if not all tiles in the square are filled out. Occasionally, a stockpile named after one item only actually has one of that item and has other different parts. This data can be enabled/disabled in the intel console window.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Prototypes[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
The number of prototype IDs received is 2 on a security level 1 terminal, 3 on a level 2, and 4 on a level 3. Duplicate prototype IDs cannot be received from a single hack. This hack never starts greyed out as a direct hack, even if no new prototype IDs are available.
[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Recall()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
The base success rate of these hacks go down by 10% after each successful hack, even if there were no squads of the corresponding type to recall. This only applies to hacks of the same type, not all Recall hacks. This reduction only applies for the current map.

[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Traps()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
The range at which Traps may be located, disarmed or reprogrammed is based on "move distance" from the Terminal rather than "direct distance". If moving to a Trap array from the Terminal's position would require too many moves, then that Trap array isn't in the Terminal's range. Creating new paths by destroying terrain can increase the range of a Terminal's Traps hacks.

[[Heading:3]][[GameText]]Schematic()[[/GameText]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
Direct schematic hacks may contain parts/bots with a rating/tier up to 3 higher than that of the base floor. For example, in -6 Factory, standard floor parts may be rating 5, but schematics up to rating 8 may be offered.[[Comment]]I've seen a Hvy. Dispersion Rifle direct schematic hack in -5/Factory and a Cld. Q-thruster in -4/Factory, which confirms the "3 ratings higher than that of the base floor" but i haven't noticed the "3 rating higher" with non-prototype parts, so i'm not sure if you could find a non-prototype rating 8 part or a tier 8 bot hack on a terminal in -6/Factory. I'd assume so, but i'd prefer to find proof.[[/Comment]]
When entering a map, if you already have a schematic that's supposed to appear on a Terminal, that schematic hack may be re-rolled.[[Sup]][[Terminal#references|[1]]][[/Sup]]

[[Heading]]References[[/Heading]]
[[List:Ordered]]
[[https://www.gridsagegames.com/blog/2018/11/debugging-mapgen-seed-divergence/|Kyzrati's blog]]: "recalling that schematic hacks at Terminals would favor the player by usually re-rolling if the randomly chosen schematic happened to be one they already had."[[/List]]

Name: Terminology
Content:
This is a list of terminology, or potentially things that do not merit a full page. Also check out [[Acronyms]].
[[Heading:3]]Partial Spot[[/Heading]]
Partial spotting is when you move through a (hostile) bots field of vision while its not its turn. The bot will investigate where it saw you, look a few tiles further then head back to whatever it was doing.

Name: Testing
Content:
Testing is a [[0b10]]-controlled [[Branch]] off of [[Research]] that appears on either -3 or -2. It is always on the floor that [[Quarantine]] is not on. Testing is a much smaller and generally much more manageable map compared to normal Research floors. There are few patrols, no [[Sentry]] or [[Heavy]] guards, and only a few special mini guard areas that can usually be easily avoided. There are unique [[Researcher]] bots that show up on this map that have dangerous effects when getting scanned. There are also powerful special and unique items that are not obtainable anywhere else. Even among normal parts, there is a much higher than usual chance of finding [[Prototype Part|Prototype Parts]] on the ground. Like all Research branches, [[FarCom]] will trigger [[Maximum Security]] upon entry.
Testing is home to the [[SGEMP Prototype]] that [[Zhirov]] asks for when you see him in his [[Zhirov (Location)|lab]]. It is guarded by 2 [[Striker|Strikers]] and an [[Alpha 7]]. The SGEMP always spawns in the vertically opposite corner of the map that Cogmind first spawns on. For example, if Cogmind would spawn in the top-left section of the map, the SGEMP would be in the bottom left. With the [[Phasing AFG]] and [[Portable AFG]], it is possible to retrieve the SGEMP without getting spotted at all. Otherwise the primary methods of obtaining are fighting the bots head-on or grabbing it and making a run for it.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Testing[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Testing Guard Corridor.png|Guard corridor that can have 1-3 guard bots|Testing Rewirable Protovariant.png|Rewirable Protovariant|Testing Hostile Protovariant.png|Awake and hostile Protovariant|Testing Dormant Protovariant.png|Dormant hostile Protovariant|Testing Unpowered Protovariant.png|Unpowered Protovariant that won't activate|Testing Superbehemoth.png|Dormant [[Superbehemoth]] with Researcher|Testing Firing Range.png|Shooting range with prototype weapons and rewirable bots|Testing SGEMP.png|SGEMP with Striker and Alpha 7 guards|Testing Potential Cannons.png|Potential Cannons and Energy Wells|Testing Regen Armor.png|Vault with [[SHELL Armor]] and other regenerative armor|Testing Generic Vault.png|Generic Testing Shell that has many item possibilities inside|Testing Terrabomb Derivative.png|[[Terrabomb Derivative]] with Researchers|Fortress Guard.png|[[Fortress]] guarding the corridor to branch exits|Testing Main Access.png|Main access exit|Branch Section 7 Protoforge Exits.png|Exits to [[Section 7]] and [[Protoforge]][[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]][[Protovariant|Protovariants]][[/Heading]]
There can be up to 2 Protovariants on a Testing map. These are prototype superpowered versions of different bot classes that have a very strong loadout of high rating prototype parts. They are fearsome foes with high damage output and are quite difficult to take down compared to most bots but have incredible loot. They can spawn in one of 4 states: Unpowered, Dormant, Active, or Disabled/rewirable. Protovariants can be of the following types:
[[List]][[Protovariant D]]: Demolisher|[[Protovariant G]]: Grunt|[[Protovariant H]]: Hunter|[[Protovariant L]] Duelist|[[Protovariant P]]: Programmer|[[Protovariant X]]: Specialist|[[Protovariant Y]]: Sentry[[/List]]
In Testing there is a special hack that can appear on [[Terminal|Terminals]]: [[GameText]]Control(Protovariants)[[/GameText]]. If successfully performed, it will turn a Protovariant on the map hostile to everything. The Protovariant can make quite a mess of 0b10 bots, but may cause more trouble than it's worth. Researchers will report the bot repeatedly when they see it attack. There is a special assault [[C-45 Heavy ARC|Heavy ARC]] that gets dispatched to the Protovariant's location when this hack is performed. This Heavy ARC contains an [[Investigator]] inside that will scan Cogmind even without being provoked. Sometimes a Protovariant will enter the out of control state even if Cogmind does not perform the [[GameText]]Control(Protovariants)[[/GameText]] hack.
[[Heading:2]]Testing Shells[[/Heading]]
The majority of unique Testing items appear in Reinforced Shells. There are no identifying features that indicate the contents of these Shells. The list of unique Testing items contained within are:
[[List]][[2N-1CE's Frost Array]]|[[AEGIS Remote Shield]]|[[Cld. Nova Cannon]]|[[Disintegrator]]|[[Exp. Hardlight Generator]]|[[Ghost Barrier]]|[[Hpw. Disruptor Cannon]]|[[Hvy. Quantum Rifle]]|[[Hyp. EM Gauss Rifle]]|[[Hyp. Multirail]]|[[Myomer Exoskeleton]]|[[Null Cannon]]|[[Omega Cannon]]|[[Perforator]]|[[Portable AFG]]|[[System Mapper]]|[[Tachyon Dispersion Ray]]|[[Warp Gun]]|[[Z-bomb Delivery System]][[/List]]
There are 2 unique prefabs that do not contain any of the above items and have their own list. One prefab has 1-2 [[Potential Cannon|Potential Cannons]] or [[Imp. Potential Cannon|Imp. Potential Cannons]] (not necessarily the same type) and several [[Imp. Energy Well|Imp]], [[Adv. Energy Well|Adv.]], or [[Exp. Energy Well|Exp. Energy Wells]]. The other shell is locked behind Sealed Heavy Doors and has a special Researcher behind. The Terminal can be hacked to open the doors, but the Researcher will make it difficult to break the Shell without getting scanned. However, penetrating the heavy doors first will allow safely killing the Researcher. It is also possible to dig in to the back of the prefab directly into the Shell area. The shell will always contain [[SHELL Armor]] and 3 random pieces of [[Lgt. Regenerative Plating]], [[Med. Regenerative Plating]], or [[Hvy. Regenerative Plating]]. The Terminal on the inside of the shell contains schematic for some of the regenerative platings.
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is always 1, and possibly 3 exits in Testing:
[[List]]Main access exit: There will always be 1 exit that leads to the next main Research or [[Access]] floor. It will always be at a dead end at a tile corridor near the top-middle or bottom-middle of the map.|[[Redacted]]Section 7 and Protoforge exits: These exit only appears some of the time. [[Quarantine]] must have been first on the world map, so these exits can only show up when Testing is on -2. A large 4 tile doorway will show up on the middle of the map, on the right side of where the map typically ends. It will open up into a 6 tile hallway and a [[Fortress]] will be guarding the path to the exits. These exits will be closed if Cogmind is FarCom aligned.[[/Redacted]][[/List]]

Name: Thermal Generators
Content:
Thermal Generators are devices that generate energy based on the user's surplus heat. They are relatively heavy compared to most devices, but have relatively low coverage as well.
Energy is based on surplus heat (above 0) and is generated [[I]]before[[/I]] any heat dissipation is applied. As a result, they can generate energy from the user's passive heat generation before that heat is dissipated, and more importantly the heat generated by ranged weapons, especially [[Thermal Weapons]]. Energy generated from high-heat volleys can synergize well with [[Shield Generators]] and [[Force Fields]].

Name: Thief
Content:
Thieves will sometimes appear in [[Caves]] maps, usually either waiting in ambush or suddenly appearing from outside Cogmind's field of view.


[[Heading:2]]Behavior[[/Heading]]
Thieves dash towards the closest visible enemy robot and try to steal one of that robot's parts using their [[Tearclaws]]. If successful, the Thief will flee, carrying the stolen part in their inventory. If a Thief in the process of fleeing is or goes outside Cogmind's field of view, they will exit the map.

When trying to steal parts, Thieves might ignore unarmed robots and instead target Cogmind or combat robots.

[[Heading:2]]Strategies[[/Heading]]
Thieves are incapable of taking parts on the ground, so dropping important parts you don't want to lose keeps them safe from them. However, this strategy can backfire if there are [[Dirty Bomb Trap|Dirty Bomb Traps]] or [[Decomposer|Decomposer]] nearby, or if Cogmind or other robots carry  [[Launchers]] or [[Electromagnetic Weapons]] capable of triggering chain reactions in power sources.

Moving behind combat allies or swapping with them to place them closer to the Thieves can prevent your own parts getting stolen, at the cost of your allies'.

In order to actually destroy Thieves, Launchers can work well when aimed at walls next to the Thieves, though at close range the collateral damage might not be worth it. Targeting utilities can help actually hit them while they are approaching, and a Stasis Beam/Projector can prevent a single Thief from attacking or escaping while also making them easier to hit, at the cost of making them take 50% less damage.

[[Blade Trap|Blade Traps]], [[Segregator Trap|Segregator Traps]] and [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] can work well in disarming or stopping Thieves, provided you have enough time to place them, for example before attacking a Thief ambush.

If Cogmind is fast enough, fleeing is also an option, for example to lead the Thieves into 0b10 robots, [[Warlord]]-aligned derelicts or traps.

Name: Thug
Content: Thugs are a [[Bot Groups|bot group]] of [[Legs|legged]] [[Derelict]] combat bots armed with thermal weaponry, uniquely [[Beamcaster|normal]] and [[Hvy. Beamcaster|Hvy. Beamcasters]]. They are the Derelict version of the [[0b10]] [[Grunt]] class. Thugs in [[Mines]] are notable for being significantly stronger than the typical Grunts at that depth, and their Beamcasters are one of the strongest standard weapons available in early Materials depths. Thugs are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: Transdimensional Reconstructors
Content:
Transdimensional Reconstructors are one of the most common [[Alien Artifacts]] and can be found in a great variety of locations from different sources.

Attaching a Transdimensional Reconstructor consumes it and teleports the user and any part they might be standing on to an approximate distance of 32/64 from current position, depending on the range of the Transdimensional Reconstructor variant used. The direction of teleportation cannot be controlled. If a Slip Node is present on the map, Transdimensional Reconstructors will always teleport to one, regardless of the Reconstructor's range.

Using a Transdimensional Reconstructor also deteriorates core integrity by 5-10% of current. Parts, including any the user is standing on, are unaffected. The resulting damage does not appear in scoresheets.

[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Spoiler]][[Lore]]0b10 Records|Transdimensional Reconstructor[[/Lore]][[/Spoiler]]

Name: Transmission Jammers
Content:
Transmission jammers are parts allowing to limit consequences of your activity by blocking enemy signals. Need [[Line of Sight|LoS]] to enemy to work.
[[Heading:2]] List of effects [[/Heading]]
[[List:Ordered]]Block [[Distress Signals|distress signals]]|Stop [[Heavy]] reinforcements calls|Prevent [[U-05 Engineer|engineers from calling reinforcements]]|When paired with [[Transport Network Coupler|TNC]] block [[Hauler|hauler's reinforcements call]] [[/List]]

[[Heading]] Tips [[/Heading]]
Most jammers have short range, so attention needed to keep enemies in range. [[Watcher]] and [[Heavy]] bots require special attention due to their big visual range.
Significantly decreases chances of small confrontation snowballing into big fight.
Limits consequences of mistakes during stealth, if you can deal with bot that spotted you. Gives significantly more freedom to stealth builds able to take on small groups of enemies.
If you can destroy [[Extermination Squad|extermination squad's]] leader without the rest of the squad seeing you, they might wander away.
Jammers allow you to force 1-v-1 fights via [[Line of Sight|LoS]] manipulation. Works best versus stationary bots like [[Caves|caves outposts]]. Alternatively, good jammer paired with strong [[Cloaking Devices|cloaking device]] or [[Exp. Transmission Jammer]] on it's own allow forcing 1-v-1 fighting by surpassing enemy's visual range.

Name: Transport Squad
Content:
[[Image]]Transport Squad.png|A Hauler guarded by 2 Grunts[[/Image]]
Transport squads are [[0b10]] aligned [[Squad|squads]] that carry parts from one location to another and can be found on most 0b10 controlled maps. They typically consist of a single [[Hauler]] and 0-2 guard [[Grunt|Grunts]] that escort them. Haulers that are guarded have [[Prototype Part|prototypes]] inside them, but some unguarded Haulers may still have prototype parts. If a Hauler that carries prototype parts is attacked, they will summon a [[Reinforcement Squad]] to their location on depths -7 and higher. Typical transport squads all start on the map, and more of them do not appear if destroyed. Transport squads can be Enumerated at [[Terminal|Terminals]], and a [[Transport Network Coupler]] or [[Modified TNC]] will reveal their current positions. The Modified TNC will also show the contents of all Haulers. Similarly, the Manifests hack shows all of the contents of all Haulers on the map, as well as any associated guards. This can be useful to determine that certain guarded/unguarded Haulers are worthwhile to try to loot. The

[[Heading]][[Cargo Convoy]][[/Heading]]

Cargo Convoys are a unique type of transport squad that appear in main [[Factory]] and [[Research]] maps. They are much more heavily guarded than typical Transport squads, but the parts they carry are also much higher rating than usual. If attacked, they will trigger a special response where [[Heavy|Heavies]] guard all of the exits on the map.

Name: Traps
Content:
Traps are most often found in groups called arrays, and appear in a variety of layouts including rows, blocks or sparser "minefields". They are, however, usually triggered individually.


[[Heading]]Lore[[/Heading]]
[[Lore]]0b10 Records|Traps[[/Lore]]

[[Heading]]Arrays[[/Heading]]
Trap arrays vary in size, Trap type, and layout formations. Each Trap array contains 1-6 Traps, and is composed entirely of the same Traps. The type of trap that an arrays will be made of depends on the location. For example, [[EM Surge Trap|EM Surge Traps]] cannot appear in [[Materials]]. Trap arrays appear in several types of formations:
[[List]]Door Trap - A 1-Trap array formation where the only trap is directly adjacent to a Door or an Emergency Access door.
|Rows - Found in corridors, usually perpendicularly to the corridor's direction. The Traps will form one or more rows across the corridor, though some tiles of some of the rows may be skipped. When spotting a single trap in a corridor, it is usually fairly simple to guess the approximate location of other Traps in the array.
|Minefield - Usually found in open areas or inside rooms. The Traps are strewn about chaotically, making their locations very unpredictable.
|Prefab - Some prefabs contain Traps in preset formations or random but unusual formations. This can result in unexpected behavior, such as each of the Traps of a prefab being part of its own separate array.  
|Other - Some Trap formations are uncommon and maybe unique to certain maps, making them difficult to recognize and categorize.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Triggering[[/Heading]]
Moving over a trap does not always trigger it. The chance is instead determined by the form of [[Propulsion]]:
[[Table]]
Mode|Probability|Probability ([[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]])
||
 Overweight | 100% | 100%
||
 [[Treads]] | 100% | 0%
||
 [[Legs]] | 75% | 25%
||
 [[Wheels]] | 50% | 50%
||
 [[Hover Units|Hover]]/Core | 40% | 60%
||
 [[Flight Units|Flight]] | 20% | 80%
[[/Table]]
Stasis Traps are a special case and their chance to trigger for each Propulsion type is the opposite of regular traps (Flight ex: 100 - 20 = 80%).
Note there are also multiple undocumented circumstances under which a trap may be triggered, not simply regular movement. Some other ways to trigger traps include: 
[[List]]When corrupted, it is possible to accidentally trigger allied traps when moving over them, with a [corruption %] chance of triggering.
|Attempting to install a trap at a location that already contains a trap unknown to Cogmind will fail to install the new trap and trigger the old one, regardless of the old trap's faction.
|It is possible to manually trigger known traps at Cogmind's current position, although doing this will attribute any explosions from explosive traps to Cogmind, unlike the methods listed above.
|Failure to reprogram a Trap using a [[Melee Datajacks|Melee Datajack]] can rarely cause it to trigger.
|EM explosions have a chance to trigger any traps they hit. [[Sub]](Note: The writer of this is not sure if an EM explosion attributed to Cogmind would cause explosive traps triggered that way to also be attributed Cogmind)[[/Sub]][[/List]]

Once triggered, the trap at that position is spent and will not trigger again. (Some traps exhibit special behavior in this regard.)


[[Heading]]Detection[[/Heading]]
Cogmind has a 1% chance to detect each trap in view, checked every turn, and each active Trap Scanner and allied [[Drone Bays|Drone]] has a separate chance to detect Traps.
Some other ways to detect traps include:
[[List]]
Successfully hacking [[GameText]][Locate Traps][[/GameText]]/Traps(Locate) at [[Terminal|Terminals]] will reveal all nearby trap arrays.
|In [[Garrison|Garrisons]], hacking Download(Registry) will locate all traps within the Garrison, among other things.
|[[Spoiler]]Using the [[GameText]]locate_traps[[/GameText]] on [[Operator|Operators]] with [[RIF]] in combination with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] will reveal all trap arrays within a range of 30.[[/Spoiler]]
|Collecting a pre-expiry [[Operator]] [[Data Core]] will reveal the location of nearby trap arrays.
|Nearby allied Operators in range will reveal hidden traps within your field of vision.
|Some [[0b10 Decoder Chips]] are capable of passively detecting traps over time.
|Sources of Derelict intel can provide the location of all traps across an entire map.
|Using the [[GameText]]find_chute[[/GameText]] on a [[K-01 Serf]] with a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] will reveal the closest [[Chute Trap]].[[/List]]


[[Heading]]Removal[[/Heading]]
The simplest way to remove one or more traps is to destroy the section of floor housing them, for example using a [[Launchers|Launcher]]. Arrays of hostile traps can be permanently disarmed one array at a time via terminal hacking or [[Spoiler]][[RIF]]-hacking Operators[[/Spoiler]], and disarming traps on an individual basis is a possible side effect of attempting to hack one with an active melee [[Datajacks|Datajack]]. Successfully hacking [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] or [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]] using a melee Datajack will always disarm them.


[[Heading]]Reprogramming[[/Heading]]
Traps can be reprogrammed through various means, including:
[[List]]
Successfully hacking [[GameText]][Reprogram Traps][[/GameText]]/Traps(Reprogram) at terminals will reveal and reprogram a nearby trap arrays within range.
|[[Spoiler]]Using the [[GameText]]reprogram_traps[[/GameText]] on Operators with a Datajack in combination with RIF will reveal and reprogram the nearest trap array within a range of 30.[[/Spoiler]]
|Attempting to moving into a known hostile trap with an active melee Datajack will instead make Cogmind attempt to hack it, with a base 10% to successfully do so, increased by [[Offensive Hackware]]. Successfully hacking a Trap will usually reprogram it, though this may sometimes disarm it. Successfully hacking [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] or [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]] using a melee Datajack will always disarm them.
|Having an active [[Trap Reconfigurator]] [[Exiles Vault Prototypes|Exile prototype]].
[[/List]]
From the [[https://www.gridsagegames.com/cogmind/manual.txt|official manual]]:
By default traps are programmed to trigger on detection of any foreign robot, a setting that can be modified via hacking. Known traps may be reprogrammed with an active melee Datajack by bumping them, and entire arrays of traps can be reprogrammed at once from nearby terminals. Reprogrammed traps will no longer recognize Cogmind or allies as a threat, instead reacting to local combat robots. As part of the new programming, each trap's sensitivity will also be set dangerously high, ensuring it will trigger whenever a hostile moves over it, regardless of propulsion.


[[Heading]]Collection[[/Heading]]
An enterprising Cogmind can, with the use of a [[Trap Extractors|Trap Extractor]], extract and store or pick up friendly traps for their own use. However, [[Chute Trap|Chute Traps]], [[Alarm Trap|Alarm Traps]] and [[Ambush Trap|Ambush Traps]] cannot be extracted to begin with. Stasis Traps also exhibit special behavior; they can be extracted but cannot be stored inside a Trap Extractor, and they can still be extracted even after they were triggered, as long as the stasis field they produce hasn't been depleted.

Last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Treads
Content:
Treads have the highest support and the lowest speed. They are the most durable propulsion, but lower-tier units will still often be destroyed and replaced. They are commonly used by (and available from) [[Hauler|Haulers]] as well as heavy combat 0b10 bots, including [[Sentry|Sentries]], [[Heavy|Heavies]], and [[Behemoth|Behemoths]].

The slow movement speed of treads means [[Cogmind]] generally cannot outrun bots and will be forced to fight most encounters that it cannot avoid. Replacement treads can be difficult to obtain under duress since they are mostly equipped by powerful combat bots, and the best multislot treads are not commonly used by other bots until later in the game. In exchange, treads' high coverage and integrity (especially on mid- to late-game multislot treads), along with recoil reduction, allow them to support a combat bot and protect other parts. Treading bots that lack enough spare treads may choose a [[I]]half-track[[/I]] configuration, filling some propulsion slots with treads and some with [[Wheels]], as described in that article.

All multislot treads are capable of [[Special Propulsion Modes#siege mode|Siege Mode]], and some are capable of High Siege Mode. Most tread builds will transition entirely to multislot treads as soon as practicable, for their improved resilience and siege mode capability. A common place to make this transition is in [[Cetus]] after looting [[Centrium Heavy Treads]] from the [[Cetus Guard]].

While on treads, Cogmind is immune to damage from ramming hostile bots, and instead has a chance to crush them (unless they are large or huge or have greater than 50 core integrity). The chance to crush varies for each type of tread.

When active, treads confer immunity to knockback and reduce the accuracy penalty from recoil when firing large volleys.
