Name: Wins Achievements
Content:
[[Comment]]                       ---NOTE FOR EDITORS---
Once Beta 16 releases, if you decide to update any of the Achievements pages, please consider whether it would be better to separate the new achievements from the old ones or not.
I think that, ideally, whatever you choose to do, that decision should be applied to all Achievements pages, for the sake of consistency.

In addition, consider whether to make a section dedicated to the Challenge Modes achievements that Beta 16 will remove/adapt.[[/Comment]]

Wins [[Achievements]] are earned by winning the game under certain conditions. 10 of the 37 Wins Achievements have hidden descriptions that are only revealed after completing them. The borders of Wins Achievements indicate whether they are earned by winning with a specific ending, winning under certain conditions, or winning while a challenge mode is active. The borders of Achievements for winning under certain conditions also indicate their difficulty compared to other achievements with similar requirements, with more "intense" borders meaning higher difficulty.


[[Comment]]This warning is supposed to be there for all articles about achievement types, including those that do not have any Redacted-level spoilers.[[/Comment]]
(The visibility for the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements is set to at least "Spoilers", and may be set to "Redacted" for achievements where that would be relevant. Remember to change your spoilers settings to "None" if you do not wish to see the explanations, strategies and descriptions of hidden achievements you have not yet obtained!)

[[Heading]]Endings[[/Heading]]
These Achievements are earned by winning the game with a specific ending. Currently, only 7 of the 9 endings have Achievements tied to them. Each ending is mutually exclusive with all other endings, meaning only one of these achievements can be obtained per run.

[[List]]Epsilon Run: [[Spoiler]]Win and escape to Epsilon Eridani.[[/Spoiler]]
|Commander 0b11: [[Redacted]]Win and begin establishing 0b11[[/Redacted]].
|Home At Last?: [[Spoiler]]Win and rendezvous with the fleet.[[/Spoiler]]
|Payload Armed: [[Spoiler]]Win and nuke Complex 0b10 from orbit.[[/Spoiler]]
|MAIN.CPP: [[Redacted]]Win and take control of Complex 0b10.[[/Redacted]]

|Stardust: [[Redacted]]Win and destroy Tau Ceti IV.[[/Redacted]]
[[Comment]]TODO: This is one of the achievement with a description that i just guessed. I know it to be fairly accurate, but it isn't the same as the actual achievement's description. Once the description is corrected, please remember to delete the warning for it at the top of the page.[[/Comment]]

|Planet Killer: [[Redacted]]Win and escape the artificial singularity.[[/Redacted]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Winning under certain conditions[[/Heading]]

[[Comment]]Note : Some of these Achievements' descriptions aren't hidden (in-game or here), but mention by name some spoiler-tier stuff, such as imprinting.
Normally, these names would be contained within a Link tag.
However, because those Achievements' descriptions are not hidden by the game (the descriptions themselves aren't spoiler-tier), these names should not be contained within a Link tag, because that would cause them to appear spoilered to anyone with a spoiler setting of "None".[[/Comment]]

[[List]]Derelict Escape: Win while imprinted.
|Winner's Signature: [[Redacted]]Win after getting scanned by a [[Researcher]] in [[Section 7]].[[/Redacted]]
|Data Run: [[Spoiler]]Win after interfacing with the [[Data Conduit]].[[/Spoiler]] 
|Inspector Gadget: Win while only evolving utility slots. Gaining non-utility slots through other means also disqualifies.
|Straight Shot: Win without visiting any [[Branch|branches]] ([[Garrison|Garrisons]]/[[Wastes|Waste]]/[[DSF]] okay).
|Pacifist: Win without destroying a single robot.
|Speedrunner: Win in less than 2,000 turns.
|Expert Speedrunner: Win in less than 1,000 turns.
|By A Hair: [[Spoiler]]Win with less than 5% of core integrity.[[/Spoiler]]
|True Flier: Win without attaching any propulsion except [[Flight Units|flight]].
|Mad Max: Win with 200 hostiles destroyed and without attaching any propulsion except [[Wheels|wheels]].
|Victory By Combat: Win with 400 hostiles destroyed.
|Hardcore: Win with 400 hostiles destroyed but no more than 4 utility slots.
|Death Machine: Win with 600 hostiles destroyed.
|Partners In Destruction: Win fighting alongside the Warrior.
|One Last FU: Win after entering an [[Access]] [[Garrison|garrison]].
|The Little Core That Could: Win without attaching any propulsion.
|True Cogmind: Win 25 times.
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Winning with challenge modes[[/Heading]]
These achievements are unlocked by winning the game with any ending while their respective challenge mode is active. Challenge modes are activated by starting a new run while the corresponding challenge mode option in the advanced.cfg file is set to 1.

When the next batch of achievements is eventually added, Challenge mode Achievements be removed.

[[List]]
Grand Amoeba: Win the Devolution challenge mode.
|Look Ma, No Swapping!: Win the Fragile Parts challenge mode.
|Unstoppable: Win the Gauntlet challenge mode.
|Stunt Win: Win the Inhibited Evolution challenge mode.
|I Don't Need Leftovers: Win the No Salvage challenge mode.
|Light Traveler: Win the Pure Core challenge mode.
|This Only Looks Like Junk: Win the Scavenger challenge mode.
|Terminals Are For Geeks: Win the Simple Hacker challenge mode.
|Attach With Care: Win the Sticky Parts challenge mode.
|Best of the Best: Win the Super Gauntlet challenge mode.
|Master Trapper: Win the Trapped challenge mode.
|Super Mutant: Win the Unstable Evolution challenge mode.[[/List]]


This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Wintypes
Content:
W0 "Escaped": Take a [[Surface]] exit on -1.
W1 [[Redacted]]"Establishing 0b11": Take a Surface exit on -1 after destroying both phases of [[MAIN.C]] in [[Command]].[[/Redacted]]
W2 [[Spoiler]]"Heading to fleet": Take a surface exit on -1 after using a [[Core Reset Matrix]].[[/Spoiler]]
W3 [[Spoiler]]"Destroyed 0b10": Take a Surface exit on -1 while carrying the [[Sigix Containment Pod]] in inventory. [[Redacted]]May also be performed by taking the exit with the [[Sigix Warrior]].[[/Redacted]][[/Spoiler]]
W4 [[Redacted]]"Assimilated 0b10": Stand next to the unbroken 0b10 Conduit machine in MAIN.C's room in Command after either killing both forms of MAIN.C or with [[RIF]].[[/Redacted]]
W5 [[Redacted]]"Destroyed Tau Ceti IV": In [[Access_0]], obtain the [[A2 Data Core]] by killing [[A2]] and perform Gate Tests 138-A and 138-B once, then test 138-C twice on the Gate Controls terminal with an intact Singularity Gate machine.[[/Redacted]]
W6 [[Redacted]]"Escaped singularity": In Access_0, destroy all 4 Subspace Access Nodes, destroy the [[Architect]], and take the surface exit within 10 turns.[[/Redacted]]
W7 [[Redacted]]"Establishing Free Derelict Territories": In Command, destroy both forms of MAIN.C with [[Warlord]] still alive and not shut down.[[/Redacted]]
W8 [[Redacted]]"Fortifying 0b10": Choose the Surrender option after destroying MAIN.C's outer shell, then destroy enough [[Enhanced Q-Series]] while keeping MAIN.C alive.[[/Redacted]]
W9 [[Redacted]]Defending 0bPrime: Align with [[UFD]] and [[Optimus]] in [[Scraptown]], install [[GameText]]Force(Fedlink)[[/GameText]] in [[Protoforge]], and help plant 10 [[UFD Drillbomb|UFD Drillbombs]].[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Ending animations[[/Heading]]
See the following video: [[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XR2RoB6gKWA]]

Name: Wizard
Content: Wizards are a [[Bot Groups|bot group]] of [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[Derelict]] combat bots armed with [[Riot Gun|standard]] or [[Hvy. Riot Gun|Hvy. Riot Guns]]. They are the Derelict version of the [[0b10]] [[Programmer]] class. Like Programmers, they can hack hostiles to reboot or assimilate them, remove system corruptions, and remove certain hacks from allied bots. However, in contrast to Programmers, Wizards have plenty of [[Hackware]] and can actually hack [[Terminal|Terminals]] when allied to Cogmind in some circumstances. Wizards are common bots that show up in many different types of Derelict encounters and events.

Name: XL Autogun Array
Content: After the XL Autogun Array falls to around 50% integrity, a log message [[GameText]]XL Autogun Array falls apart.[[/GameText]] will be shown. When this occurs, the Array will be destroyed and 4 [[XL Autogun Subcomponent|XL Autogun Subcomponents]] will appear on the floor around Cogmind.

Name: XL Autogun Subcomponent
Content: 4 of these are created when the [[XL Autogun Array]] falls apart.

Name: Y-54 Guardian
Content: The Y-54 Guardian appears in the early [[Factory]] and is the only standard [[Sentry]] to use multi-projectile weapons. This can make [[Hardlight Generators]] more viable on the floors where Guardians appear, since a hardlight generator reduces each projectile's damage by a set value, and thus is more effective against weapons that fire more projectiles.

Name: YASD
Content:
"Yet Another Stupid Death (commonly abbreviated to YASD) is used when a player has done something, usually avoidable, that leads to their hero's demise." - [[https://nethackwiki.com/wiki/Yet_Another_Stupid_Death|NetHack Wiki]]

Cogmind is full of silly ways to die. Here are just a few. A lot of them are harsh teachers of lessons best learned the hard way.

Note: this page is heavily opinion-based; your mileage may vary.

[[Heading]]General[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Trying to run away or reposition with slow movement speed, either because you missed the warning or because you think you know better. When the game says [[GameText]]MOVEMENT SPEED EXTREMELY SLOW![[/GameText]] in all caps, take heed.
|Fighting next to a bunch of explosive machines. Or in the middle of a bunch of explosive machines. They seem to always explode when you're within range.
|Fighting next to a bunch of explosive machines, but with a melee weapon! Too bad it does knockback... BOOM
|Actually fighting a bunch of explosive machines, for example, because you forgot to turn off Force Melee before moving in one's direction.
|Digging too far and getting crushed by a cave-in. Sometimes it's worth rolling the dice.
|Attaching a risky prototype that fries a vital part.
|Forgetting to watch your heat. It does core damage if it gets too high...
|Forgetting to watch your corruption.
|Getting your squishy [[Infowar]] destroyed because you forget to swap it out in combat.
|Spending too much time around a [[Heavy]], especially as a frail flight build.
|In general, getting spotted on a fragile build by bots you can't outrun (think [[Swarmer|Swarmers]], [[Programmer|Programmers]], and especially [[Cutter|Cutters]]).
[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Location-Specific[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Going to the [[Mines]] without a launcher. [[GameText]]Infestation in the Mines, dispatching Demolisher response squad.[[/GameText]]
|Going to the [[Subcaves]] unprepared.
|Going to the Subcaves unprepared, "but I got swarmed last time, so this time I'll bring a launcher!"
|Forgetting that parts self-destruct in the [[Caves]]. Hope you brought spares.
|Misfiring in a Caves branch, aggroing the inhabitants. Bonus points if it's [[Zion]] or [[Warlord (Location)]] and you [[I]]almost[[/I]] made it to the [[Spoiler]]Quarantine Array[[/Spoiler]].
|Visiting [[Zion]] or [[Warlord (Location)]] when you have [[RIF]].
|Aggroing the friends of [[Warlord]] while you fight off the [[Spoiler]]0b10 invasion[[/Spoiler]].
|Killing or trying to kill [[Data Miner]] and accidentally sitting in the [[Spoiler]]gamer chair, i.e., Data Conduit[[/Spoiler]]. [[Spoiler]][[Tracker|Trackers]] can be dealt with, if you're prepared.[[/Spoiler]]
|Going too far in the [[Zion Deep Caves]] without a plan to deal with [[Golem|what's inside]].
|The many ways of going into [[Testing]] or [[Quarantine]] on [[FarCom]] (unless you're prepared, of course). Perhaps you needed to desperately dive for an exit. Perhaps you forgot the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles']] warning. Or perhaps you chose to roll the dice.
|Having a bot destroy the terminal at the [[Surface]] exit in [[Access]]. The closer you were to the terminal, the sillier it is.
[[/List]]

Name: YOLO Cannon
Content: Rarely on firing, the YOLO Cannon will explode with the log message [[GameText]]YOLO Cannon suddenly explodes.[[/GameText]] When this occurs, the YOLO cannon and up to 3 other random parts will instantly be destroyed. Cogmind will also lose half of the current core integrity when this effect happens.

Name: Z-Courier
Content: [[Imprint]]-aligned derelict [[Hauler]] variant. Delivers resupplies via the [[Imprint]] roster.

Name: Z-Drone
Content: Created by a [[Z-Drone Bay]]. Slightly better than a [[Mini Drone]], with a makeshift cloaking device.

Name: Z-Drone Bay
Content: Deploys [[Z-Drone|Z-Drones]].

Name: Z-Experimental
Content: Z-Experimental bots are a class of [[Legs|legged]] [[Imprint]] aligned combat bots equipped with a staggering amount of prototype parts, powerful unique weapons, and unique [[Armor]] with resistance to most conventional damage types. Appears in the [[Imprint]] Roster [[Redacted]]and also can come out of [[Command]] cave seals if Cogmind is Imprinted[[/Redacted]]. When summoned via roster, they have a special ally behavior where they will stop fighting and run back to Cogmind if they fall out of Cogmind's line of sight or are too many tiles away.

Name: Z-Heavy
Content: Z-Heavy bots are a class of [[Legs|legged]] [[Imprint]] aligned combat bots equipped with many unique Zionite-specific prototype parts with powerful unique weapons. Appears in the [[Imprint]] Roster [[Redacted]]and also can come out of [[Command]] cave seals if Cogmind is Imprinted[[/Redacted]]. When summoned via roster, they have a special ally behavior where they will stop fighting and run back to Cogmind if they fall out of Cogmind's line of sight or are too many tiles away.

Name: Z-Hero Parts
Parts: 12-ASH's Boomstick,1C-UTU's Sword "Choppy",1C-UTU's Sword "Lootmaker",7V-RTL's Ultimate Field,99-TNT's Nukerbomber,AD-0RF's Magmablaster,CL-ANK's Mallet,ME-RLN's Wand,ME-RLN's Chromatic Screen,NK-0LA's Tesla Doomcannon,P1-3CE's Gatling Flakker

Name: Z-Imprinter
Content: See [[Zion Deep Caves]].

Name: Z-Light
Content: Z-Light bots are a class of [[Hover Units|hovering]] [[Imprint]] aligned combat bots equipped with many unique Zionite-specific prototype parts with powerful unique weapons. Appears in the [[Imprint]] Roster [[Redacted]]and also can come out of [[Command]] cave seals if Cogmind is Imprinted[[/Redacted]]. When summoned via roster, they have a special ally behavior where they will stop fighting and run back to Cogmind if they fall out of Cogmind's line of sight or are too many tiles away.

Name: Z-Technician
Content: Harmless zion [[Derelict|derelict]] [[Operator]] variants found stationary in [[Zion Deep Caves]].

Name: Zeronet Interface
Content: The Zeronet Interface, dropped from any Unchained, allows for full tracking of every bot on 0b10-controlled floors for ~900 turns (counted from the moment it drops ie. with or without being attached), before the chip fries itself in an UC-ID check. When the check fails, the following log message is shown: [[GameText]]"INVALID UC-ID CHECK!" Zeronet Interface fries itself.

Name: Zhirov (Alignment)
Content:
[[Image]]Testing SGEMP.png|The SGEMP room in Testing[[/Image]]
Aligning with [[Zhirov]] is a minor [[Alignment|alignment]] that can be started in [[Zhirov (Location)|Zhirov's Lab]]. After entering and exiting the Terminal room on the left side of the map, Zhirov will ask Cogmind to steal the [[SGEMP Prototype]] from [[Testing]] and bring it to [[Access]]. If this is done, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up in Access and give Cogmind full map intel. They will follow Cogmind but will all teleport out if Zhirov falls below roughly half core integrity. They also leave if Cogmind enters [[Command]]. If a [[Core Reset Matrix]] is used prior to Access but Cogmind still carries the SGEMP, Zhirov and his allies will turn hostile and fight Cogmind to the death
There is a second part of this quest that continues in [[Command]]. [[Redacted]][[Image]]ModifiedSGEMP.gif|Zhirov detonating the modified SGEMP in Command, disabling MAIN.C[[/Image]]
After destroying the first form of [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C]] in Command, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up and attack MAIN.C. Zhirov will activate the Modified SGEMP and disable all 0b10-aligned bots on the map. This also affects [[Warlord (Command)]], but no other Derelicts. This does stop Cogmind from getting the score bonuses of defeating [[MAIN.C]], as well as the + on the scoresheet.[[/Redacted]]

Name: Zhirov (Location)
Content:
Zhirov is a [[Caves]] [[Branch]] that appears on -5 or -4 and is home to the eponymous bot [[Zhirov]]. This is a safe map with no hostile spawns and only friendly bots, although Cogmind should be wary of [[Corruption]] triggering misfires that anger Zhirov. Detaching all ranged weapons is advised.
This map initially appears to be a small section of caves with only an exit. Approaching the left wall will cause the cave walls to slide away to reveal some Cloak Generators and some larger Sealed Heavy Doors blocking the way. These Cloak Generators surround the entire outside of Zhirov's lab. Continuing to the left will cause the doors to slide down and reveal Zhirov himself who will greet you. [[Perun]] and [[Svarog]] guard just above and below the entrance on the left side.
There are a large collection of [[Terminal|Terminals]] to the left of Zhirov. The first terminal going counterclockwise contains some lore records and the depths of, [[Quarantine]], [[Testing]], and [[Command]]. The second contains Analyses for [[Q-Series]], [[Striker|Strikers]], [[Executioner|Executioners]], and [[Alpha 7|Alpha 7s]]. The third contains 4 Prototype ID Banks. The fourth contains Schematics for an [[Assault Drone Bay]], [[Exp. Heat Sink]], [[Exp. Optical Array]], and [[Imp. Arc Thrower]]. This is the only way that Assault Drone Bays can be obtained. In the room just below this, there is a series of 3 Terminals that describe Zhirov's past since arriving on Tau Ceti IV.
Near the center area there are two [[Alien Artifacts]] with explanatory Terminals. The left will either be an [[Integrated Reactor]] or an [[Integrated Dissipator]]. The right will always be a [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]].
At the bottom of the map are some broken bots and an assorted collection of parts. None of these parts are guaranteed, although there will always be some available. The list of available parts is as follows:
[[List]][[Adv. Myomer Leg]], [[Cld. Gravmag System]], or [[Cld. Nuclear Pulse Thruster]]|[[Fusion Reactor]] or [[Hvy. Antimatter Reactor]]|[[Adv. Energy Well]], or [[Adv. Power Amplifier]]|[[Exp. Core Shielding]], [[Exp. Power Shielding]], [[Exp. Propulsion Shielding]], [[Exp. Utility Shielding]], or [[Exp. Weapon Shielding]]|[[Particle Accelerator]], [[Prc. Matter Filter]], or [[Imp. Matter Compressor]]|[[Adv. System Shield]] or [[Adv. Hacking Suite]][[/List]]
[[Image]]Zhirov Explosions.webp|Zhirov leaving with flair[[/Image]]
Unlike the Cloak Generators in [[Zion]], these machines are the real deal. If destroyed, there are some major consequences that follow. Zhirov and friends will immediately turn aggressive and begin to attack. A large group of friendly [[Enhanced Grunt|Enhanced Grunts]] wil teleport in and start attacking Zhirov. Zhirov will attempt to teleport out when his core integrity gets to about half. He will first say [[GameText]]Looks like we have to say goodbye to this place, and you[[/GameText]]. This will rig a large number of explosions to go off in about 10 turns. This happens even if the Cloak Generators are already intact and Zhirov is attacked.

[[Heading]][[Zhirov (Alignment)|Alignment - Zhirov]][[/Heading]][[Image]]Testing SGEMP.png|The SGEMP room in Testing[[/Image]]
After entering and exiting the Terminal room, Zhirov will ask Cogmind to steal the [[SGEMP Prototype]] from Testing and bring it to [[Access]]. If done, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up in Access and will give Cogmind perfect map intel and follow until Zhirov falls below half core integrity. If a [[Core Reset Matrix]] is used prior to Access but Cogmind still carries the SGEMP, Zhirov and his allies will turn hostile and fight Cogmind to the death instead.
There is a second part of this quest that continues in [[Command]]. [[Redacted]]After destroying the first form of [[MAIN.C (Shell)|MAIN.C]] in Command, Zhirov, Perun, and Svarog will show up and Zhirov will activate the Modified SGEMP and disable all 0b10-aligned bots on the map.[[/Redacted]]

[[Heading]]Fighting[[/Heading]]
Fighting Zhirov and gaining anything from the encounter is not an easy task. Although he has some nice loot, his tendency to teleport out at the slightest hint of danger and explosive aftermath even on a successful kill is very frustrating to deal with. One option is to loot Perun and Svarog while ignoring Zhirov and simply exiting the map safely. These 2 can still have some good parts, although they have nothing as lucrative as Zhirov with the guaranteed inventory drops of [[Deep Network Scanner]], [[Quantum Router]], a [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]], and a [[Zhirov Special]]. Only Zhirov can set off the traps and cause the group to leave.
The best way to safely grab all the loot is with [[Master Tearclaws]] that can be looted from [[Master Thief|Master Thieves]]. These Tearclaws can strip all 3 bots of their parts with little risk of explosives. Just make sure Zhirov doesn't fall below 80 core integrity. The Tearclaws can even remove the inventory items without requiring Zhirov to actually be destroyed. The idea is to shoot one of the bots from just outside of one of the rooms and then retreat behind one of the doorways. This will let you safely use the melee Tearclaws while only getting attacked by 1 bot at a time.

Name: Zhirov Special
Content:
The Zhirov Special is an inventory item similar to a [[Sapper Charge]]. It can be activated to start a 10-turn timer that will cause it to violently explode. It can be obtained by destroying [[Zhirov]] or having a [[Master Thief]] steal it from his inventory. When Cogmind is standing on it, pressing > or right-clicking on Cogmind will start its 10-turn explosion timer. Doing so again will interrupt the timer, which can be useful in scenarios such as the player accidentally activating it. Note that both activation and deactivation take an entire turn, meaning only 9 of the 10 turns can actually be used to prepare for or escape its high-damage 20-radius explosion. Picking up an active Zhirov Special will not halt its countdown, and it can explode from Cogmind's inventory.
The explosion is not attributed to Cogmind, meaning it will not raise [[Alert]] or attribute Cogmind any kills or [[Score#value|value-based score]].

[[Heading]]Avoiding Damage[[/Heading]]
While the Zhirov Special's very high explosive damage should preferably be avoided, its large explosion radius makes escaping somewhat difficult. Without a high movement speed or conveniently-shaped [[Reinforced Walls]] that could contain the explosion, other type of movement such as teleportation would be required to avoid the explosion.
If attempting to escape the explosion through high movement speed, consider making sure the area is clear of [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] beforehand or using a [[Stasis Canceller]]. If using a [[Transdimensional Reconstructors|Transdimensional Reconstructor]] for that purpose, make sure to not stand on the Zhirov Special when teleporting, as the Transdimensional Reconstructor would bring it along.
Alternatively, using an explosive damage-reducing utility such as an [[Exp. Shock Absorption System]] preferably paired with a [[Force Fields|Force Field]] or similar damage reduction effect can help cut the damage significantly.

[[Heading]]Usage Strategy[[/Heading]]
As the Zhirov Special's explosion does not raise Alert, it can be used to destroy most structures, machines and robots with few consequences. Keep in mind that [[Launchers|Launcher]] misfires due to [[Corruption]], explosive [[Traps]] and [[Demolisher|Demolishers]] are all capable of destroying the Zhirov Special. [[Cutter|Cutters]] can also interfere, and in the worst-case scenario their [[Concussive RPG]]s can knock back the Zhirov Special away from your target.
As the Zhirov Special is a non-part inventory item, [[Recycler|Recyclers]] will not attempt to pick it up. 

This article was last edited during Beta 15.

Name: Zion
Content:
Zion is a [[Caves]] [[Branch]] that appears on -7 or -6 and is the home to a large number of [[Derelict]] [[Zionite|Zionites]]. It is a general safe haven for all types of Derelict bots and has a ton of lore available by talking with all sorts of Zionites. Similar to Caves, [[Scrap]] and [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]] can appear on the ground here. Aside from one relatively harmless event, there are no hostile bots that appear on this map unless Cogmind attacks or attempts to enter while aligned with [[RIF]] or after becoming hostile to the [[UFD]]. The System Quarantine Field Array at the entrance of the map will cleanse all [[Corruption]]. It is strongly recommended to detach any ranged weapons until cleansing corruption to avoid any misfires that will turn the map hostile. RIF-aligned or UFD-hostile Cogmind can only go as far as triggering the cleanse at the quarantine array. Going any further will turn Zion hostile.
Zion maps are randomly generated but will always have the same overall appearance. There is a small Caves-like section on the east containing the spawn point and exit to Proximity Caves. To the left is the Quarantine Array machine guarded by 2 friendly [[Marauder (6)|Marauders]]. The bulk of Zion is contained within a large hollow square shape. All of the unique prefabs are contained within this area of the map. To the top left is the locked entrance to the [[Zion Deep Caves]]. Below that is a [[Tinkerer]] next to the Conduit Teleporter, 4 [[Mutant (6)|Mutants]], the [[Imprinter]], and some more Tinkerers next to the Imprinting Machine.

[[Heading]]Alignment - [[Imprint|Imprinting]][[/Heading]]Walking into the Imprinting machine will allow Cogmind to Imprint which has some major gameplay effects. The main change is that Cogmind can no longer use normal hacks at [[Terminal|Terminals]] and can now only use a specific set of randomized Zionite hacks. The 4 Mutants that guard the Imprinter will also turn purple and begin to follow you. There is an additional unique effect in [[Command]]: [[Redacted]]When the Command cave seals are opened, powerful Zionite bots will pop out along with various other Zionite-aligned Derelicts. These Zionites will be controllable (blue) rather than purple if a [[Core Reset Matrix]] is used.[[/Redacted]] This alignment has the following incompatibilities:
[[List]][[FarCom]]: The Imprinter will warn a FarCom-aligned Cogmind against trying to use the machine. If the machine is used anyway, the Zionites will take it as an attack and turn hostile.|RIF: A RIF-aligned Cogmind will turn Zion hostile when attempting to enter in the first place.|[[Revision 17]]: Revision 17 will be afraid of an imprinted Cogmind and will not attack -3 [[Research]].|[[Scraptown]] hostilities: Zion will become hostile to Cogmind who has become hostile to the UFD.|[[UFD]]: If Cogmind is a UFD member, The Imprinter will tell Cogmind that the imprinting machine vetting process will take a while and to come back another time.|[[Warlord]]: Warlord will be disappointed in an imprinted Cogmind and will not attack -2 Research.[[/List]]

[[Heading]]Fighting[[/Heading]]
Fighting Zion can be a risky feat for an unprepared Cogmind, but not particularly challenging if going in with a plan. The majority of the [[Zionite|Zionites]] are initially unarmed, although they can scavenge through the Twisted Machinery tiles in order to find several (usually weak) types of guns or melee weapons. Zionites will also appear out of the machinery tiles and instantly attack. This will only happen if Cogmind is within a few tiles of some machinery, so using explosive weaponry on these tiles is highly recommended to avoid unnecessarily fighting extra bots. It is not possible to destroy this machinery beforehand, as destroying too many of these tiles will cause Zion to turn hostile. After attacking, use launchers to take the machines out at range to avoid getting sneak attacked.
One of the largest benefits and threats to fighting Zion is the [[Z-Hero]] spawn. There is a chance that a hostile Hero will spawn at the Caves exit and roam around the map. It is important to have a plan to deal with some of the stronger Heroes like [[99-TNT]] and [[P1-3CE]], even if that plan is only to spot them first and run to avoid getting spotted in return. Other heroes like [[ME-RLN]] are easier to kill. All of them can provide incredibly strong unique loot. Another big reason to fight is the [[Imprinter Data Core]] that will guarantee access to the [[Zion Deep Caves]] if no other methods are available. One thing to note is that the Imprinter will not stick around long after attack. 300 turns after Cogmind angers Zion, the Imprinter will disappear and it will not be possible to get her Data Core. Starting hostilities by attacking her is recommended for this reason.

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Zion Cloak Generator.png|A Cloak Generator machine (they don't do anything)|Zion Visual Enhancement Terminal.png|Bot with a "Visual Enhancement" hack|Zion Visual Enhancement Hack.gif|Effect of using previous "Visual Enhancement" hack|Zion Butterfly Terminal.png|Derelict talking about "Symbols and butterflies" with Terminal hack|Zion Butterfly Hack.png|Effect of using previous "Symbols and butterflies" hack|Zion Broken Bots.png|A Derelict analyzing broken [[0b10]] bots|Zion Broken Bots 2.png|More broken bots with various parts strewn around|Zion Decoder Chips.png|Stash of [[0b10 Decoder Chips]]|Zion Warlord Parts Stash.png|Stash of Warlord Derelict parts|Zion Mak Stash.png|Stash of Makeshift parts|Zion Launcher Cache.png|Derelict with stash of [[Launchers]]|Zion Programmer Couplers.png|Derelict with stash of [[Relay Coupler [Programmer]|Programmer Couplers]]|Zion Processor Stash.png|Derelict with stash of Processors|Zion Authchip Stash.png|Derelict with stash of [[Authchips]]|Zion SDI Derelict.png|Derelict that gives [[Self-destruct Interrupter|Self-destruct Interrupters]]|Zion Hacking Drone Bay.png|Derelict that gives a [[Hacking Drone Bay]]|Zion Craig With Stick.png|CR-A16 who gives their [[CR-A16's Pointy Stick|Pointy Stick]]|Zion Deep Caves Code.png|Derelict that gives the codes to the Deep Caves Terminals|Zion Mobile Refinery.png|Derelict that has created the [[Mobile Refinery Mk. CCLXVII]]|Zion PAFG.png|Derelict that has created the [[Phasing AFG]]|Zion Storm Laser.png|Derelict that has created the [[Storm Laser]]|Zion Bomb Factory.png|Derelict that has created the [[Bomb Factory No. 2]]|Zion RU-N14.png|RU-N14 with their [[RU-N14's Throwing Claymores|Throwing Claymores]]|Zion V3-CT5.png|V3-CT5 with their [[GAL Module]]|Zion Schematic Archives.png|Tinkerer with [[Schematic Archive|Schematic Archives]]|Zion Schematic Terminal.png|Terminal with Derelict weapon [[Schematic|Schematics]]|Zion Megawrench.png|Megawrench repair Derelict that will fully repair all attached parts, including faulty prototypes|Zion Allies 1.png|Group of friendly Derelicts that will follow Cogmind when spoken to|Zion A8.png|[[A8]] appearing with a code that summons [[Enhanced Grunt]] allies|Zion Caves Exit.png|Proximity Caves exit|Zion Deep Caves Exit.png|Zion Deep Caves exit[[/Gallery]]
There are a wide variety of encounters in Zion. A few are useless, some are more niche, but most are going to have a use in many builds. Every game has a half dozen or so of these encounters available and it is likely that most builds will get something nice out of the trip.
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There are 2 types of exits in Zion:[[List]][[Proximity Caves]] exit: This exit is on the top right side of the map near where Cogmind spawns.|[[Zion Deep Caves]] exit: This exit is on the top left side of the map protected by locked blast doors. The doors can be unlocked with a random Derelict event that will provide the hacking codes or with the same codes obtained by using the [[Imprinter Data Core]]. Additionally, the doors can be broken into with a very powerful Impact weapon ([[Impact Mace]] with high speed momentum required), an overloadable Thermal cannon like a [[Cld. Particle Cannon]], or by using a [[Plasma Cutters|Plasma Cutter]]. The Sealed Blast Doors have an armor value of 45 with 0% thermal resistance but many other strong resistances.[[/List]][[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[List]](+/-) [[Hunter]] attack: A Hunter disguised as a Derelict will sneak up to the gates of Zion and attack the Marauder guards. This will usually result in the quarantine array being destroyed and the Hunter losing the fight. The dropped parts can be collected by Cogmind but will quickly self-destruct.[[/List]]

Name: Zion Deep Caves
Content:
The Zion Deep Caves, or ZDC, is a [[Branch]] off of [[Zion]] that seems to serve as a sort of base of operations for the [[Imprinter]] and the [[Zionite (Group)|Zionites]]. This is a very combat oriented map that requires a lot of preparation to complete entirely. It is possible for a very fast flight build to sneak in, grab one or two things, and escape, but the presence of the perfect-tracking 24 speed [[Z-Imprinter]] makes things tough.

[[Heading]]Layout[[/Heading]]
The bulk of the map has a predefined layout except for the right starting point and middle-left exit area which are slightly different every time. These two random areas are mostly empty but can contain small groups of [[Assembled (4)|Assembled]] and a disabled [[Surveybot 24]]. To the left of the starting area are a big Z-Facility machine, a huge explosive Z-Power, and some [[Z-Technician|Z-Technicians]] working on the machine. Above and below are [[Z-Light (5)|Z-Light]] guards. On the top and left side there are Zionite item stashes. To the left side of the exit area is a collection of assorted broken Derelict bots and highly damaged parts. There is an [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] item near the top of the area. The far left is an Impregnable Wall which contains a large amount of Assembled and 2 [[Assembler|Assemblers]]. The wall is guarded by a [[Golem]] above and below. There are also some Wall Chambers that drop [[GOLEM Unit|GOLEM Units]] when destroyed. The units will start regrowing into hostile Golems.
[[Heading:2]][[Z-Imprinter]][[/Heading]]
After entering the center portion of the map, there will be an alert [[GameText]]NEW_ZION: Z-Facility proximity alert.[[/GameText]] When this happens, the Z-Imprinter will appear at the exit and head directly to Cogmind, with 2 [[Z-Light (5)|Z-Lights]] following behind.
[[Heading:2]]Impregnable Wall[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]ZDC Wall Activation Zone.png|Approximate wall activation zone[[/Image]]
The Impregnable Wall on the far left side of the map cannot be destroyed by any method. However, a small portion of the wall in the center will open automatically when Cogmind enters a nearby area or if one of the wall chambers containing GOLEM Units is opened.

[[Heading]]Rewards[[/Heading]]
While quite challenging, there are some very strong unique rewards on this map. GOLEM units are only available here and can provide a strong build in a-box. [[Asb. Focal Cannon|Focal Cannons]] will tear through most anything in the game quite easily. The [[Asb. Combat Suite]] is a unique part that combines [[Phase Shifters]], [[Ranged Targeting Utilities]], and [[Core Analyzers]] in a single slot. The [[Surveybot 24 Chip]] is the strongest type of [[Terrain Scan Processors|Terrain Scan Processor]] in the game. [[Zio. Weapon Casing|Weapon Casings]] can protect late-game super-weapons from harm. The [[Zio. Biocell]] is an early way to gain a mostly identical [[Exp. Energy Well]] early in the game.

[[Heading]]Strategy[[/Heading]]
See [[Strategy/Maps/Zion Deep Caves]]

[[Heading]]Notable Locations[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]ZDC Assembled Flower.png|A small group of Assembled|ZDC Surveybot.png|[[Surveybot 24]]|ZDC Exit.png|Exit to Caves[[/Gallery]]
[[Heading:2]]Exits[[/Heading]]
There is only one type of exit in Zion Deep Caves. An exit to Proximity Caves will appear in the middle-left area of the map.

[[Heading]]Events[[/Heading]]
[[Image]]ZDC 5H-AD0.png|5H-AD0 greeting Cogmind[[/Image]]
[[List]](++) [[5H-AD0]]: When entering, 5H-AD0 will join Cogmind in investigating the map. They will leave after exiting the map or when they fall below approximately half core integrity. They are a huge assistance in fighting most of the enemies in the map, particularly the Z-Imprinter.[[/List]]

Name: Zionite
Content:
Zionites are weak [[Derelict]] bots with a truly random assortment of makeshift parts (loadout not being awful not guaranteed), living mostly in [[Spoiler]][[Zion]][[/Spoiler]] with useful tips. Can also be found in a variety of events.
Zionites have a decent core exposure and low core integrity, but can overwhelm through numbers.

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Advanced Movement
Content:
The following is a collection of some advanced movement techniques that are useful for flight. Flight is the fastest and most maneuverable propulsion type in the game, so make sure you use these traits to your advantage. Generally, these types of techniques help to avoid taking unnecessary damage. Flight doesn't often have a lot of integrity to spare, so every avoided attack can make a big difference in a run.

[[Heading]]Attack Dancing[[/Heading]]
Attack dancing is a strategy that takes combines flight's high move speed with the low time cost of [[Actuators|Actuator]]-boosted melee attacks in order to maximize evasion bonus and reduce damage taken in combat. It works best with a full evasion stack of a [[Phase Shifters|Phase Shifter]] and a [[Reaction Control Systems|Reaction Control System]]. The general technique is to take one or two swings at a bot (depending on both your and your target's volley time) and then take moves backwards before the bot gets a chance to attack. By doing this, you decrease the ranged targeting bonus your opponent gets by you being close to them (from +15% to +12% or less depending on moves) as well as gain the movement avoidance bonus from flight which can be quite substantial (up to 19% at 5 speed).
This technique is most useful in the later depths of the game due to its numerous build requirements and benefits scaling with speed. It is a little niche since it only works well in 1v1 encounters, such as very powerful lategame enemies like top tier [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], [[Prototype Robot|Prototype Robots]], or [[Redacted]]bosses[[/Redacted]]. Against standard combat encounters, it may be more difficult to pull off due to layout or being fired at by multiple bots at once. Continuous attacks are more effective in most cases.
The specifics for this technique are as follows:
[[List]]
Determine your base volley time. For example, a [[Nanosword]] with [[Femtoactuators]] or 2 [[Nanoactuators]] has a volley time of 125. Follow-ups can impact this time a little bit, but ignore that for now.|
Determine your opponent's average volley time. For example, a [[B-99 Colossus]] has a volley time of 350.|
Determine how many attacks you can perform per one of their attacks. In this example, you can get 2 125 TU swings inside of the Colossus's 350 volley time, but not the 3rd.|
Perform your 1-2 attacks before the bot gets a chance to move.|
Move away from the bot for as many moves as you can. You may want to consider overloading at this point.|
Once the enemy has made their attacks with reduced accuracy, go back to them and continue attacking.|
Repeat
[[/List]]
If you want to get min-max this technique, you can try to calculate the exact sub-turn time units and determine how safe you are to get follow-up attacks. In most cases this added delay is not a major factor, but if your volley time + 2 moves is very close to your target's volley time or you have a lot of melee weapons and an [[Actuator Arrays|Actuator Array]], you may want to consider skipping an attack in order to align your attacks better so you don't get take an extra volley with reduced evasion.

[[Heading:2]]Machine Dancing[[/Heading]]
A variant of attack dancing is to use map layouts, particularly machines, to continuously attack an enemy without ever giving them a chance to attack. In this case, your attack and movement speed combined need to be less than the opposing bot's movement speed instead of their volley time. By performing your attack and then retreating around a corner where the bot can't hit you, you can get an unlimited number of attacks off without being hit in return. This requires weapons with 0 delay and/or super high speed and generally only works against slower targets like [[Sentry|Sentries]].

[[Heading:2]]Examples|Attack Dancing Examples[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Attack Dancing.webp|Attack dancing against a [[Behemoth]] with a [[Nanosword]] (note how many projectiles miss)|Machine Dancing.webp|Machine dancing against a [[Sentry]] with a [[Longsword +1]][[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Bot Looping[[/Heading]]
Bot looping is a technique that can be used to lose persistent pursuers like [[Programmer|Programmers]], [[Hunter|Hunters]], and [[Sentry|Sentries]]. Rather than running away from hostiles that are actively tracking you into the unknown or a busy corridor, this strategy revolves around using a known safe loopable area to force them to lose tracking. The key element of a potential loop is that the area must be large enough for you to loop without them spotting you. Ideally, the loop should also have no other hostiles nearby. If you have a suitable area, just run around the loop in circles for as long as you need to until the bots have lost tracking on you. [[ECM Suites]] help reduce the amount of time looping takes, though they are not required to perform this technique.
Note: When looping multiple bots at the same time, don't get too far ahead in order to keep them as grouped up as possible. If you go too far ahead you might end up splitting the squad into two and get pincered. If you are over halfway through the loop, that's when some of the bots in the back may turn around and decide to go the other way. If this happens, you might end up having to go a different route or else running past one of the pursuers.

[[Heading:2]]Examples|Bot Looping Examples[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Extermination Looping.webp|Looping an [[Extermination Squad]] of [[Programmer|Programmers]] around some rooms in [[Research]][[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Bot Luring[[/Heading]]
Bot luring is a technique that pulls hostiles out of position so you can do something in the area they were previously in. For example, you may want to grab an item from a cache, interact with a machine, kill a guarded [[Hauler]], or pass through a corridor. The gist of this technique is to get noticed by some way so that the target bot(s) are chasing you instead of hanging around the area you want to go to. [[Security Squad|Guards]] can be [[Partial Spot|partial spotted]] which can avoid taking an extra volley. If you do this, make sure to overload all overloadable propulsion to decrease the chance of getting hit while performing this technique. Some other methods of gaining attention are to shoot a long-ranged weapons like [[Ballistic Cannons]] at them or to get intentionally spotted by a [[Watcher]]. If you are trying to get noticed by visual range alone, try to do it in a way that machines are blocking the line of fire to avoid extra shots.

[[Heading:2]]Examples|Guard Luring Examples[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Guard Luring.webp|Luring a [[Sentry]] out of a room in order to safely grab an item from the floor|Patrol Luring.webp|Luring a [[Patrol Squad|patrol]] of [[Grunt|Grunts]] into a room to safely bypass a corridor[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Greenbot Armor[[/Heading]]
Greenbot armor is a technique that involves hiding behind green [[0b10 Non-combat Bots]] in such a way that hostile bots won't be able to shoot through them to hit you. This technique is most effective when horizontally or vertically aligned with the bot you don't want to shoot you since other alignments usually allow for some kind of firing angle. While it works best in 1-tile wide corridors, this isn't the only place this works. Most frequently, [[Security Squad|Guards]] are the best targets of this technique, especially [[Sentry|Sentries]] and [[Heavy|Heavies]].
The primary reason to use this technique is to be able to run past a bot standing in an inconvenient location without being shot at. Busy corridors naturally have lots of non-combat bots pathing through it. In a pinch, you can always drop a part to try to lure a [[Recycler]] or destroy a wall to lure an [[U-05 Engineer|Engineer]].

[[Heading:2]]Examples|Greenbot Armor Examples[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Greenbot Armor.webp|Using non-combat bots to safely make it to an exit[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]]Kiting[[/Heading]]
Kiting is a technique that combines superior movement speed of flight with [[Visual Processing Units]] and long-ranged weaponry like [[Ballistic Cannons]]. By taking advantage of your range and backing up when the bot you are shooting at comes close, you can reduce or even completely negate damage taken by fighting squads. Any weapon with a range longer than the bot you're fighting can be used, although you can fire more times before having to reposition with a larger difference between you and your opponent. [[Weapon Cyclers]] also help to maximize the number of volleys you can perform in your window of opportunity. Since airborne and leg-based bots get avoidance bonuses while moving, [[Targeting Computers|Targeting]] or a [[Weapon Mount]] help you hit more shots while kiting.
In order to kite successfully, you need wide open corridors or paths in which to fire down. Some maps are better for this than others. For example, [[Factory]] is great with its tendency to produce many long open corridors, while [[Research]] is much more labyrinthine, favoring smaller and closer rooms. Depending on the layout, you may be able to loop through another path in order to keep shooting down your kiting corridor after you've ran out of space.

[[Heading:2]]Examples|Kiting Examples[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Sentry Kiting.webp|Kiting a [[Sentry]] with a [[Tri-rail Accelerator]] to take no damage[[/Gallery]]

[[Heading]][[Sneak Attack]] Preparation[[/Heading]]
Sneak attacks are a great way to get the drop on troublesome combat and non-combat bots alike, though they are a little more difficult to achieve than simply walking up to a bot and hitting it. Even on flight's fast speed, you may not always get the drop. One of the best techniques to get a sneak attack is to allow a bot to [[Partial Spot]] you and then come in or out of the room they are in. It's better to move back and forth around a corner rather than just pressing the wait key until they show up. For faster bots, you may need the extra time. For slower bots, it's still nice to get a tiny bit of extra momentum damage. You can also use this technique on [[Watcher|Watchers]] if you predict where they are headed. Just move back and forth next to the door and smack them when they peek in.

[[Heading:2]]Examples|Sneak Attack Examples[[/Heading]]
[[Gallery]]Watcher Sneak Attack.webp|Sneak attacking a [[Watcher]][[/Gallery]]

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Alignments
Content:
Flight is quite flexible and can work with any [[Alignment]] in the game, although some are more natural pairings than others. Throughout the entirety of the run, including extended endgame [[Wintypes]], flight builds appreciate using allies as both extra damage and distractions to take fire away from Cogmind. Lots of unique alignment-specific rewards are fantastic boons for flight builds, from unique parts, to special map events, to gameplay-altering mechanics.

[[Heading]][[FarCom]][[/Heading]]
[[Image]]FarCom Sensors.png|FarCom sensors revealing nearby hostiles[[/Image]]
FarCom is undeniably the best alignment for a basic escape win and reaching the [[Surface]] with its no slots-required, 18 range unjammable sensors. This is about as good as a [[Lrn. Sensor Array]] with an [[Exp. Signal Interpreter]] for free, although with a slight downside in that they only detect combat bots. The [[Exiles Vault Prototypes]] can be hit or miss for flight. However, nearly all seeds have at least one item that is worth taking. The punishment in [[Research]] [[Branch|Branches]] is quite sizeable, however, since those maps are the locations of some of the best parts in the game.

[[Heading:2]]Good Vault Prototypes[[/Heading]]
The following is my personal tier list of vault prototypes for flight builds:

[[Heading:3]]S Rank[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[Field Lobotomy Kit]] - Great tool for getting out of many dangerous situations and stealing high powered enemies for yourself, look out for [[Heavy|Heavies]] and [[Behemoth|Behemoths]] as good targets|
[[Flying Fortress v7]] - Very strong unique flight unit with tons of support and integrity|
[[Longsword +1]] - Above average slashing weapon that stays useful throughout the run, notable for its + targeting
[[/List]]

[[Heading:3]]A Rank[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[Modified TNC]] - Flight can take full advantage of this by hunting [[Hauler|Haulers]] across the whole map|
[[Lightpack 2.0]] - Capable of storing incredible amounts of parts at a low mass cost, albeit unreliably|
[[XL Autogun Array]] - Great high damage gun that isn't restrictively heavy for flight, make sure to wear [[Weapon Shieldings]] to keep it from falling apart
[[/List]]

[[Heading:3]]B Rank[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
[[AWS/Gauss]] - Good early-game gun with an above average range, perfect for kiting|
[[Cloak of Protection]] - A bit difficult to use, but decent armor and a great [[Cloaking Devices|Cloaking Device]]|
[[Firepult]] - Heavy and hard on heat but capable of eliminating large squads of bots and even powerful enemies like [[Behemoth|Behemoths]] with ease|
[[Gui. Plasma Cannon]] - Great for sniping bots around corners with the FarCom sensors|
[[PSU Rigger]] - Flight's speed makes it easy to set up traps for enemies and then lure them into place|
[[Trap Reconfigurator]] - Most useful with an [[Operator]] ally or when frequently using the [[GameText]]Traps(Locate)[[/GameText]] [[Terminal]] hack
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Stealing[[/Heading]]
Stealing from the Exiles in the case of multiple good vault items can be a worthwhile consideration. Losing FarCom is not the end of the world, and flight is well suited to deal with the consequences of [[Master Thief|Master Thieves]] in [[Caves]]. As long as Cogmind is faster than the 34 speed of the Master Thieves, it is possible to kite them and avoid getting attacked and stolen from. Just be careful not to get trapped in a corner with no way out.
Note: The XL Autogun Array has a unique mechanic where it splits into [[XL Autogun Subcomponent|Subcomponents]] when damaged. Taking these parts is not considered stealing, so you can blow it up with a [[Launchers|Launcher]] to steal these lesser guns as well as take another item without truly "stealing".

[[Heading]]Spoilers/Redacted Warning[[/Heading]]
All following factions contain mid to lategame spoilers.

[[SpoilerExpandable]]
[[Heading]][[Data Conduit]][[/Heading]]
Using the Data Conduit is a high risk but high reward play. Starting with the negatives, [[Intercept Squad|Intercepts]] are a huge punishment as [[Tracker]] [[Immobilizer|Immobilizers]] and [[Linked Autogun|Linked Autoguns]] will rapidly disassemble an unprepared flight build. Having a plan to deal with Intercepts is the first and foremost priority for any flight build. This can be to swap to treads to engage in combat, to use allies to fight them for you, or to simply locate and exit each map before they spawn. Outrunning them is a temporary possibility, but it is quite challenging to support a 15 or faster speed build indefinitely. [[Combat Programmer|Combat Programmers]] are still a nuisance, but are much more easily managed and can be outrun without too much trouble.
Most of the rewards of the Data Conduit like machine intel, bot analyses, and prototype IDs are beneficial, but not especially worth the trouble for a flight build in my opinion. Intercepts are simply too high of a price for most runs, especially runs that don't plan on going for extended wintypes. Flight's great maneuverability is greatly diminished when there is a fixed amount of moves to spend on each map. However, its extended-winning capabilities are where the Data Conduit shines:
[[Heading:2]]Extended Endgame Potential|Extended Endgame Potential Data Conduit[[/Heading]]
[[RedactedExpandable]]
Data Conduit's main extended potential with flight is the boss-slaying [[L-Cannon]]. Capable of deleting both bosses with only a few shots, the L-Cannon has unparalleled power in the game. Flight is very well suited to escort the [[LC Capacitor]] from [[Lab]] into [[Section 7]] to obtain the L-Cannon. After that, it's mostly a matter of surviving all the way to [[Command]] and finding a safe spot to fire at [[MAIN.C]]. The LC Capacitor's high mass and slot count can be fairly hard to support, so make sure you have plenty of spare support when entering Lab. Unlike slower propulsion types, the integrity shouldn't be a major concern as long as it remains powered.
Without being able to acquire the L-Cannon, the Data Conduit is largely a net-negative effect for flight. Intercepts make it difficult to acquire a solid build on standard 0b10 floors that is capable of killing MAIN.C. [[Protoforge]] becomes more or less inaccessible due to its unfortunately large number of required steps to even make it to the back side where the parts are. In addition to that, [[Access_0]] will be swarming with [[Enhanced Programmer|Enhanced Programmers]] as a result of using the conduit. They are slow and easy to shake, but their [[Adv. Remote Force Field]] makes it very difficult to fight anybody on the map.[[/RedactedExpandable]]

[[Heading]][[Imprint]][[/Heading]]
Imprint's ally-summoning and intel-granting capabilities work great with a propulsion type fast enough to visit all the [[Terminal|Terminals]] on the map before the Terminal lockdown. [[Zionite (Group)|Zionite-aligned]] allies are very great disposable distractions with high firepower. Although recall hacks are not possible once imprinted, summoning a squad of bots like [[Z-Light|Z-Lights]] into an [[Extermination Squad]] is just about the next best thing. Z-Lights in particular drop some good loot in the form of [[Zio. Light DM Reactor|Zio. Light DM Reactors]], which is a great flight engine. Later, [[Z-Experimental|Z-Experimentals]] can drop the [[Zio. Shade Armor]], which is one of the best pieces of armor in the game. Imprint typically suffers from high [[Alert]] by summoning allies and losing the ability to pull off [[GameText]]Alert(Purge)[[/GameText]] hacks. However, flight can easily avoid [[Assault Squad|Assaults]], which is the biggest downside of alert.
The Zionite intel hacks can be a mixed bag of usefulness. One of the strongest unique intel hacks is the prototype schematics hack which provides 8-12 random prototype schematics. Odds are, at least one or two schematics will be useful in some way for flight. The standard component schematics hacks provide 12-16 non-prototype which can also be quite useful. Keep an eye out for [[Flight Arrays|Flight Array]] schematics which are fairly high-value fabs. The floor-wide trap install intel can be of great use for any flight trapper build.
[[Heading:2]]Extended Endgame Potential|Extended Endgame Potential Imprint[[/Heading]]
[[RedactedExpandable]]
[[Image]]Command Doom Corridor Lure Setup.png|Imprint seals set up to take out the Doom Corridor[[/Image]]
Imprint is a great faction with lots of endgame potential in [[Command]], primarily thanks to the [[Command#Imprint Seal|Imprint seal contents]]. Hacking open one of the Command cave seals unleashes a large number of Zionites, potentially including multiple Experimentals. Typically, they are purple uncontrollable allies that will wander across the map, kill everything they see, and rack up a ton of alert. However, using a [[Core Reset Matrix]] will turn the Z-Lights, [[Z-Heavy|Z-Heavies]], and Z-Experimentals all blue controllable allies. Since the Imprint seals require succeeding at the base 0% cave seal-opening hack, make sure to bring plenty of [[Hackware]] into Command.
Avoiding [[High Security]] after summoning a seal is essential. These seals are incredibly powerful, easily capable of smashing through standard patrols. However, doing so will surely result in a catastrophic high security trigger. While the Imprint army is strong, they do not last long under the unrelenting waves of assaults. Try to avoid generating alert whenever possible in the last few maps of the game to allow the most leeway when summoning seals. Don't fight when not absolutely necessary, use [[ECM Suites]] to avoid bot forget alert, and avoid summoning combat allies.
With a CRM and [[Strategy/Bosses/Defeating MAIN.C#Lure Strategy|good positioning]], an Imprint seal is easily capable of taking out the [[Command#Doom Corridor|Doom Corridor]] (see image). After that, take the army through to [[MAIN.C]] and take him out. Sometimes, Cogmind doesn't need to do a single point of damage in order to win. The Experimentals are by far the strongest and most important part of the Imprint seals, so do everything you can to keep them safe.
After defeating MAIN.C, the remnants of the Imprint army can be looted and used to construct a build for [[Access_0]]. Most of the Imprint bot parts are better for builds with higher support. However, some standout parts include Zio. Shade Armor, the [[Zio. Biocell]] and [[Zio. Biocell Array|Biocell Array]], the [[Zio. Weapon Casing]], and the [[Exp. Weapon Cycler]].
[[/RedactedExpandable]]

[[Heading]][[Revision 17 (Alignment)]][[/Heading]]
Aligning with [[Revision 17]] is relatively minor compared to other alignment options. There is only an effect on a single map in the game. However, The -3 [[Research]] invasion makes the map nearly free to explore, with [[Revision 17++]] and his [[Revision|Revisions]] clearing out most squads on the map. [[Terminal|Terminals]] get locked down after a few hundred turns, but that is still plenty of time to explore the map before then. Other machine types are free to use, at least as long as R17 and co. haven't blown them up along the way.
After the lockdown begins, [[Executioner|Executioners]] and [[Striker|Strikers]] are dispatched in squads to take down the Revisions. Use your Revision allies to take relatively free loot from the [[Prototype Robot|Prototype Robots]], including things like [[Exp. Core Analyzer|Exp. Core Analyzers]] and [[Exp. Optical Array|Exp. OpticalArrays]] from Executioners and [[Exp. Reaction Control System|Exp. Reaction Control Systems]], [[Impulse Thruster Array|Impulse Thruster Arrays]], and [[Plasma Lance|Plasma Lances]] from Strikers.

[[Heading]][[Relay Interface Framework]][[/Heading]]
RIF is an alignment that tricky to use on flight to say the least, since it is the antithesis of how most flight builds play. Rather than running from danger, RIF flight dives into [[Garrison|Garrisons]] filled with hostiles, either fighting through [[Garrison|Garrisons]] themselves or using [[Relay Couplers]] to hack [[0b10]] bots for their own purposes. Lots of combat is required in order to get more than the basic single RIF install. Garrisons are very hostile to flight with many forced combat encounters, few to no escape routes, and [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] galore, so they are not for the faint of heart.
[[Heading:2]]General Tips[[/Heading]]
Below are some RIF-related tips. Some apply to any ally-herding build, but are especially helpful for RIF since it is easy to assimilate and end up with a large number of allies.

[[Heading:3]]Fabricate Allies[[/Heading]]
Use [[Fabricator|Fabricators]] to bring your own allies into Garrisons to avoid unnecessary attrition to Cogmind. [[Programmer|Programmers]] are one of the best offensive choices thanks to their hacking capabilities, corruption purging, and EM damage capable of quickly corrupting most bots. [[Hunter|Hunters]] and [[Sentry|Sentries]] also make good choices thanks to their durability. For defensive bots, [[Mechanic|Mechanics]], [[Operator|Operators]], [[Hauler|Haulers]], and [[Protector|Protectors]] are all helpful. Of particular note for flight is the Operators' ability to instantly spot traps on the ground, helping to avoid inconvenient [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]].

[[Heading:3]]Assimilate Allies[[/Heading]]
Rather than deal with investigations and finding Fabricators, use Relay Couplers to steal bots that you meet instead. Flight is the best propulsion for army massing thanks to its high maneuverability. Place allies out of the way in rooms until you need them, or lure hostiles into your army to turn the numbers in your favor. Full assimilation is an expensive 13 charges, so there is a practical limit to the amount of assimilation you can do per floor. However, this limit is quite high even outside of Garrisons, since each [[Garrison Access]] usually contains 3 or 4 coupler and can have even more with a [[GameText]]Trojan(Restock)[[/GameText]].

[[Heading:3]]Position Allies Well[[/Heading]]
Flight can easily scout out areas ahead of the rest of the army, unlike slower builds. When you discover enemies squads, lead them backwards into your own allied bots around the corner rather than being ambushed yourself. Make heavy use of the stay command to park allies in favorable positions instead of allowing them to always follow you blindly and get into trouble. While it is impossible to be in complete control of the situation completely whenever allies with questionable survival instincts are in the mix, flight's high speed enables finer control than simply allowing them to follow you at all times. Careful ally usage can often lead to a snowball effect that makes it even easier to maintain additional allies over time. Just watch out for [[Demolisher Squad|Demo Squads]] if you have too many allies.

[[Heading:3]]Use "Floorventory"[[/Heading]]
Though your inventory slots may be limited, the floor is wide open. Inside Garrisons there are no [[Recycler|Recyclers]] to steal your loot, so you can drop parts on the floor for safekeeping. Use this technique to bring the maximum number of Relay Couplers to hack any bot you see inside the Garrison. Just remember to come back and pick up your parts before you leave the map.

[[Heading:3]]Learn All RIF Hacks[[/Heading]]
While assimilating or overwriting bots is always tempting, RIF can do much more than this alone. Consider other offensive or utility-focused options, such as engine explosion hacks like [[GameText]]overload_power[[/GameText]] or [[GameText]]amplify_resonance[[/GameText]], disruption hacks like [[GameText]]scatter_targeting[[/GameText]], [[GameText]]focus_fire[[/GameText]], or [[GameText]]disrupt_area[[/GameText]], and intel hacks like [[GameText]]show_paths[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]find_garrison[[/GameText]].
Non-combat bots have their own extensive range of special hacks as well. Some of the hacks I find useful are [[GameText]]map_walls[[/GameText]] on [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]], [[GameText]]drop_inventory[[/GameText]], [[GameText]]recall_reinforcements[[/GameText]], and [[GameText]]locate_stockpiles[[/GameText]] on [[Hauler|Haulers]], [[GameText]]reprogram_traps/locate_traps[[/GameText]], [[GameText]]recall_investigation[[/GameText]], [[GameText]]purge_threat[[/GameText]] on [[Operator|Operators]], [[GameText]]deconstruct_machine[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]hold_bot[[/GameText]] on [[K-01 Serf|Serfs]], [[GameText]]map_earth[[/GameText]] and [[GameText]]randomize_corridors[[/GameText]] on [[T-07 Excavator|Tunnelers]], all the hacks on [[Researcher|Researchers]] (seriously these hacks are all good), and [[GameText]]map_route[[/GameText]] from [[Watcher|Watchers]]. Check out the full list of hacks on the [[~/rif.html|RIF Page]].

[[Heading:2]]Extended Endgame Potential|Extended Endgame Potential RIF[[/Heading]]
[[RedactedExpandable]]
RIF is a great alignment to take down MAIN.C in [[Command]]. While it provides no cave seal support, a large RIF-stack can bring an army of allies into the big fight, easily outgunning MAIN.C. Your best options are fully or at least partially kinetic-based bots like [[Hunter|Hunters]], [[Sentry|Sentries]], [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], [[Striker|Strikers]], [[Executioner|Executioners]], and [[Alpha 7]]. If you can save a few [[Relay Coupler [Proto]|Prototype]] and [[Relay Coupler [Behemoth]|Behemoth Couplers]], you can try to assimilate most or even all of the surface exit in Command. This is a powerful collection of bots that will wipe the floor with MAIN.C, as long as the Doom Corridor is taken care of ahead of time.
[[Combat Programmer|Combat Programmers]] are RIF-immune and must be dealt with in a non-hacking way. However, [[M Guard|M Guards]] are not immune and can be assimilated. Their [[AEGIS Remote Shield|AEGIS]] provides great remote force field support for allies. One good strategy is to park an army outside of the Doom Corridor, lure the Combat Programmers out, and then rush in and assimilate the M Guards while the fighting is going on. Just make sure the M Guards don't get an opportunity to fire their launchers on your army before being hacked.[[/RedactedExpandable]]

[[Heading]][[United Federation of Derelicts]] (UFD)[[/Heading]]
There are a lot of potentially useful rewards from [[Scraptown]] for flight builds including the [[Companion Sword]], [[LU-1G1's Laser Shovel]], Infowarlord's items, Cartography Club parts and intel, and many of the Science Guys prototypes, although many of the rewards are locked behind aligning with [[Optimus]] and starting the the civil war. There is little reason to not align with Optimus, but sticking around for the civil war is questionable if planning to [[Redacted]]start the UFD invasion of [[Protoforge]][[/Redacted]].
The benefits for choosing to align with UFD but not help complete his objective is a little more dubious. There are plenty of unique rewards available from the map itself, although skipping several depths can severely hinder a mid-Factory flight build. Summoning [[Scrapoid|Scrapoids]] or [[Scraphulk|Scraphulks]] from [[Recycling Unit|Recycling Units]] can be helpful, but it is not as easy as summoning bots with Imprint. The disadvantage of UFD summons is the [[Investigation Squad]] that will come shortly after. This can often result in freshly summoned bots going up against the squad and being damaged or destroyed in the process. A [[GameText]]Recall(Investigation)[[/GameText]] or carefully planning escape routes without being spotted can work around this downside.

[[Heading:2]]Extended Endgame Potential|Extended Endgame Potential UFD[[/Heading]]
[[RedactedExpandable]]The true benefit of UFD for flight is much easier looting of Protoforge by reduced patrol size, and especially by triggering the [[Protoforge#W9 Defending 0bPrime/UFD Assault|UFD Assault on Protoforge]]. Flight can easily max out on fedlink support by hitting up many Recycling Units per floor, especially with using [[Wastes]] to loop Factory maps. After starting the event, use the UFD army to [[Strategy/Bosses/Defeating Superfortress#UFD Army|take down Superfortress]] and you will have a much easier time of looting the back half of the map. After that, you can lure troublesome bots like [[V-Series]], back to the main assault force rather than dealing with them yourself since the area will be a lot more open, though keep an eye out for roaming 0b10 assaults passing through.
Using the UFD army to defat Superfortress results in a single +, but looting Protoforge sets you up for even further success for the other 2 bosses. Though there is no cave seal support in [[Command]] from UFD, Protoforge will always contain the parts required to make a super powerful endgame melee build with multiple top-tier melee weapons and utilities nearly guaranteed to spawn to help take down [[MAIN.C]]. This includes [[Femtoactuators]], [[Exp. Force Booster|Exp. Force Boosters]], [[Cep. Weapon Articulator]], [[Cep. Melee Reflex Suite|Cep. Melee Reflex Suites]], [[Exp. Jetlance|Exp. Jetlances]], [[Cep. Deflector Sword|Cep. Deflector Swords]]. The flight propulsion units of [[Cep. Fieldthrust Drive|Cep. Fieldthrust Drives]] and [[Exp. Biomechanical Wings]] are also some of the best in the game, although a swap to hover at this stage in the game can also be a good idea. The usual [[Executioner]] and [[Striker]] loot is great as usual as well.[[/RedactedExpandable]]

[[Heading]][[Warlord (Alignment)|Warlord]][[/Heading]]
Warlord is a great alignment for flight thanks to its minimal requirements and great reward in the form of the [[Warlord (Alignment)#-2 Research Assault|-2 Research Assault]] and [[Redacted]]unique Warlord [[Command#Warlord Seal|Command cave seal contents]][[/Redacted]]. The rewards on the [[Warlord (Location)|Warlord map]] itself are also quite good for flight, especially [[Vortex Lance|Vortex Lances]] and the prototype hackware and flight units, although they don't specifically require alignment. The -2 event does unfortunately shut down the machine network after a few turns, which can be a big downside for fabbing-based builds. However, the prototype [[Striker]] and [[Executioner]] loot alone should make up for that, not to mention looting most of the rest of the floor becoming trivial with a large number of allies. Most patrols should be wiped out easily, and with any kind of bot-sensing infowar, the assaults should be fairly easy to dodge.
The major downside to Warlord-alignment is the increased [[Patrol Squad]] density in [[Access]]. The total number of squads comes from 20 up to 28 across the whole map which can very noticeably affect difficulty stealthing across the map. Make sure to pack extra [[Infowar]] for Access to get to your desired exit. [[Cloaking Devices]] and [[ECM Suites]] are especially helpful to avoid getting spotted or to deal with getting spotted after the fact respectively. Fighting is always an option too, but it's easy for things to turn hairy with so many bots wandering around.

[[Heading:2]][[Encrypted Comm Array]] (ECA)[[/Heading]]
The ECA is an added bonus to the Warlord alignment that is rather tricky to maximize for flight. The 2 ways to boost the ECA rating are to smash up machines inside [[Garrison|Garrisons]] or to sterilize [[DSF]] maps, neither of which are conducive to typical flight playstyles. Offensive gunstack-oriented flight builds or heavy ally-fabricating builds can make some good headway in these areas, and it is not impossible by any means to do so. However, the easiest way to build up ECA rating is to do so on treads before swapping over to flight. Fully-exploring a few Garrisons on -8 through early Factory can boost the rating up pretty high, even if not contributing any more after swapping to flight.

[[Heading:2]]Extended Endgame Potential|Extended Endgame Potential Warlord[[/Heading]]
[[RedactedExpandable]]As previously mentioned, the Command cave seals provide a great boon to flight builds. [[Warlord (Command)]] himself is an extremely powerful bot, capable of clearing the [[Command#Doom Corridor|Doom Corridor]] almost single-handedly or taking down [[MAIN.C]] as long as the [[A7]] poison hack is applied. Even if Warlord is shut down during phase 1, a full seal is capable of taking down MAIN.C without much assistance from Cogmind. Decent ECA support makes this even easier to do. [[Troll|Trolls]], [[Knight|Knights]], [[Hydra|Hydras]], and [[Marauder|Marauders]] are some of the better MAIN-C-killing bots to get from the seal. If you are counting on the assistance, make sure to have a seal safely planned to open after taking care of the Doom Corridor, since the [[M Guard]] launchers are sure to take out most of the weaker bots by itself.[[/RedactedExpandable]]
[[/SpoilerExpandable]]

[[Heading]]Overview[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Alignment|Difficulty|Surface win help|Extended win help||
[[Spoiler]]Data Conduit[[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Hard|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Low|[[CellStyle:Good]]High||
FarCom|[[CellStyle:Good]]Easy|[[CellStyle:Good]]High|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Low-Moderate||
[[Spoiler]]Imprint[[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate-Hard|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Low-Moderate|[[CellStyle:Good]]High||
[[Spoiler]]RIF (heavy)[[Sub]]1[[/Sub]][[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Hard|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate-High||
[[Spoiler]]RIF (light)[[Sub]]2[[/Sub]][[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Easy|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Low||
[[Spoiler]]UFD (base)[[Sub]]3[[/Sub]][[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Easy-Moderate|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Low||
[[Spoiler]]UFD (Optimus)[[Sub]]4[[/Sub]][[/Spoiler]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Moderate|[[CellStyle:Good]]High||
