[[Spoiler]][[List:Ordered]]
Heavy RIF refers to going into Garrisons and continuing to try to get RIF installers on flight|
Light RIF refers to only getting a single RIF install before transitioning to flight|
Base refers to not aligning with Optimus and not helping in his mission|
Optimus refers to aligning with Optimus and helping in his mission|
Base refers to either not getting ECA or getting it before transitioning to flight|
ECA refers to continuing to try to earn ECA bonus on flight
[[/List]][[/Spoiler]]

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Builds
Content:
This page contains some suggestions for build types at multiple parts of the run. Most flight builds come together in [[Factory]] or later since [[Materials]] depths are very rough to fly through thanks to their cramped layout forcing many encounters with hostile [[0b10]] bots. Many flight builds start out as stealth and become either hybrid stealth or transition later into a fully combat-oriented approach into the run. They may start off with similar slot distributions and common parts in Factory before transitioning into a more unique form, though there are plenty of unconventional flight build ideas with uncommonly used parts or slot distributions. One of flight's advantages is its ease of making heavy use of [[Fabricator|Fabricators]] or hunting [[Cargo Convoy|Cargo Convoys]] to pick up rarer components that are essential to the builds.

[[Heading]]Stealth[[/Heading]]
Stealth is a natural pairing for a fast propulsion type like flight. Use speed and robot detection or other [[Infowar]] to explore the map, pick up loot, hack machines, and get to exits without doing much fighting. It is the most common flight playstyle thanks to its high effectiveness. While stealth flight is great for beginners, it is by no means a beginner-only strategy. Some more advanced flight builds can start off as stealth flight and use early Factory floors to put together a different build in inventory.

[[Heading:2]]Analysis|Analysis Stealth[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Easy to assemble: Most parts are easy to find in Materials, once you are flying, you can easily scout the map for better parts to upgrade|
Easy to play: Stealth through levels and avoid encounters with Infowar like [[Sensor Arrays]] and [[Visual Processing Units]]|
Great at [[Interactive Machine]] hacking: Use your [[Hackware]] to hack for exits, grab [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Machine Hacking/Schematics Reference|useful part schematics]], and then [[Fabricator|fabricate]] them|
Best avoiding combat: Even if running [[Armor]], stealth builds are typically not tanky enough to engage in much combat due to prioritization of non-combat related parts and general fragility. Pack a [[Launchers|Launcher]] to deal with troublesome [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] or [[Cutter|Cutters]] in a pinch|
Great for [[Fabricator|Fabricating]] other builds: Builds that make heavy use of rarer fabricated parts work very well with stealth flight as a stepping stone|
Pairs well with [[FarCom]]: Free sensors combo very well with stealth to free up 2 utility slots
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Early Factory Stealth[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/4 Prop Early Flight Hacker.png|4 propulsion hacker with storage|builds/3 Prop Early Flight Hacker.png|3 propulsion hacker with no storage|builds/4 Prop Flight Stealth.png|4 propulsion stealth (no hackware)[[/FanartGallery]]
This is a basic flight build you can evolve into just after entering Factory. The typical slot distributions are 3 or 4 propulsion slots with the remainder in utility. The 4th flight unit can help to support a relatively heavy [[Med. Storage Unit]] for long-term hauling or extra backups at the cost of active utility slots. If using FarCom, you can skip the Sensor Array and [[Signal Interpreters|Signal Interpreter]] for other parts. You can shoot for more or fewer slots of [[Hackware]], though prioritizing hackware over additional slots of [[Infowar]] or [[Armor]] may make your build more fragile and worse at stealthing.

[[Heading:2]]Late Factory Stealth Flight[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Late Factory Stealth Flight.png|Balanced stealth hacker hybrid|builds/Late Factory Greedy Hacker Flight.png|Greedy hacker|builds/Late Factory Hauler.png|Greedy early hauler ([[Hcp. Storage Unit]])|builds/Late Factory Flightbrick.png|Early flightbrick[[/FanartGallery]]
Stealth flight continuing later in the game has a few routes available. In late Factory, I will evolve a 2nd slot of power unless I have a strong single power like an [[Imp. Fusion Compressor]] available or [[Spoiler]]get an [[Integrated Reactor]] from [[Zhirov (Location)]][[/Spoiler]], 5-7 slots of propulsion, and the remainder in utility slots. More than 2 weapon slots are more effectively allocated to utility instead. In most situations, it is better to avoid combat rather than try to end it quicker.
At this stage, I prefer a jack-of-all-treads stealth/hacking hybrid build since it offers a good mix of both aspects. Greedy flight builds that prioritize hackware above all else can certainly excel as well, though they are much more fragile. On the other hand, they have enough hacking power to easily recall troublesome squad dispatches, especially [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]]. [[Mass Support Devices]] can be combined with powerful energy sources like the Imp. Fusion Compressor to support large amounts of storage in Factory. If you're running flimsier build like this, take care to pack extra backups of your most essential parts like power to avoid finding yourself with 0 energy in a bad spot. A less common approach is to start leaning into flightbrick: A strategy that prioritizes coverage and evasion to deal with hostiles. Stealth when you can, or run past enemies while avoiding most damage with your evasion if you can't, then [[ECM Suites|ECM]] them away.

[[Heading:2]]Access Stealth Flight[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Access Hybrid Stealth Flight.png|Balanced stealth hacker hybrid|builds/Access Greedy Hacker Flight.png|Greedy hacker|builds/Access Hauler Flight.png|Hauler with Hcp. Storage Unit|builds/Access Flightbrick.png|Flightbrick with full evasion[[/FanartGallery]]
Stealth in the later parts of the game becomes harder to pull off. [[Patrol Squad]] density increases each depth, Exterminations become more frequent, and [[Research]] and [[Access]] layouts may force you to run past squads with no alternate paths. Continue to add more flight units for more speed and support when you need to, especially prioritizing [[Cooled Flight Units]] so you can escape combat quickly. More infowar and hackware are other great parts to add onto your build. Most of my builds end up with 2 slots of power, 7-9 slots of propulsion, and the rest of the slots in utility.
The same general archetypes I listed in the late Factory section also apply here. Balanced stealth/hacker hybrid, greedy hacker, hauler, and flightbrick each are some of the more standard approaches to stealth. Again, my personal preference is the balanced hybrid since I feel it offers the most flexibility for both normal wintypes and extended gameplay. Hauler builds are a particularly good option as a transitionary build when planning to become combat flight later. You can carry all of the tools for your swap in your inventory and then attach them when you're ready to fight, dropping your storage to make more space.

[[Heading]]Gunstack[[/Heading]]
Gunstack is a heavily combat-oriented approach to flight. The idea behind this build is to combine the good firepower of many weapon slots with the high mobility of flight. [[Kinetic Guns]] are the weapon of choice for this build since they have a decent amount of coverage and integrity and are not very resource intensive. While most guns are not very long ranged, their 18 range can be used to [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Advanced Movement#Kiting|kite]] a few shorter-ranged bots like [[Grunt|Grunts]]. Grabbing [[Scanalyzer]] [[Study|Studies]] for common guns like [[Autogun|Autoguns]] that drop from [[Swarmer|Swarmers]] can have a lot of value since you will often be using them. Guns tend to die fairly quickly in combat on flight, so be prepared to burn through a lot of them. You also don't have much room for storage, so take note of good kinetic gun stockpiles so you can return to them later.

[[Heading:2]]Analysis|Analysis Gunstack[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Easy to assemble: Parts are easy to find in Materials, any kinetic guns will do well|
Relatively difficult to play: Little room for storage and infowar leaves you more likely to suffer attrition and run out of essential parts|
Fairly combat capable: Note that even though gunstack is better than most flight builds at fighting, it still doesn't have a ton of integrity to fight everything that comes its way head-on like treads builds.|
Pairs well with [[FarCom]]: Free sensors makes it a lot easier to plan and prepare for combat encounters, especially helpful if you are planning on going into [[Garrison|Garrisons]]|
[[Spoiler]]Pairs well with [[RIF]]: While [[Garrison|Garrisons]] are quite dangerous, you can use [[Relay Couplers]] to distract hostiles and draw fire away from yourself while contributing meaningful damage[[/Spoiler]]|
[[Spoiler]]Pairs well with [[Encrypted Comm Array]]: Garrisons are extra dangerous without RIF, but getting the ECA is a good way to prepare for extended endgame as well as being able to summon some allies in main floors in a pinch[[/Spoiler]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Early Factory Gunstack[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Early Flight Gunstack.png|4 propulsion 4 weapons gunstack[[/FanartGallery]]
You can play a treaded Materials tank while carrying flight units up until Factory. Many of the parts you need are going to be the same both before and after you transition, so you don't have the usual problem of carrying a bunch of stuff you can't use through Materials. One way to get an early [[Core Analyzer]] for this build is to fight the Heavy-summoned [[X-62 Marksman]] in -8 Materials. Being able to hit core more frequently is especially important for a build like this that doesn't have tons of integrity to spare. [[Visual Processing Units]] are a great option to spot hostiles before they see you if you are not using FarCom. Both of these options help you plan out attacks on enemy patrols and sometimes take them out in a single volley without alerting the rest of their squad.
At this point in the run, you'll have very good damage output with 4 weapons and should be able to take out most bots without much trouble. Use your free rein of early Factory to improve your build and grab [[Study|studies]] for common parts. Studies are highly valuable on guns that are dropped by common enemies, like [[Autogun|Autoguns]] and [[Hvy. Machine Gun|Hvy. Machine Guns]] from [[Swarmer|Swarmers]], [[Gauss Rifle|Gauss Rifles]], [[Coil Gun|Coil Guns]], and [[KE Penetrator|KE Penetrators]] from [[Hunter|Hunters]], and [[Flak Gun|Flak Guns]], KE Penetrators, and [[Railgun|Railguns]] from [[Sentry|Sentries]].

[[Heading:2]]Late Factory Gunstack[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Late Factory Gunstack.png|5 weapon gunstack[[/FanartGallery]]
Generally, you want to prioritize additional propulsion and utility slots at evolutions in Factory depths as opposed to more weapons. Rating-appropriate guns increase in mass relative to your propulsion carrying capacity, so more than 4 or 5 weapon slots may end up being difficult to sustain. However, if you make use of intentionally lower-tier guns like Autoguns from lower-tier Swarmers, there is a little bit more wiggle room in support. Still, it's nice to add more offensive or defensive utilities, or even an extra piece of Infowar or Hackware on this kind of build. Flight arrays do die quicker that prototype flight units, but their additional mass support, especially when studied, and lower resource costs help you stay on a single power slot for longer.

[[Heading:2]]Access Gunstack[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Access Flight Gunstack.png|6 weapon gunstack[[/FanartGallery]]
By the last depths of the run, you should ideally have full set of 5 or 6 guns with plenty of offensive utilities to support them. Prioritize multiple Targeting Computers and Core Analyzers very heavily to hit core as much as possible. [[Recoil Stabilizers]] are also a great choice if you can manage to find them, though they do get destroyed rather easily. [[Executioner|Executioners]] have fantastic loot for this type of build and are present in a few maps and from special Derelict-related events in the lategame, such as the [[Warlord (Alignment)#-2 Research Assault|Warlord Assault]] and [[Revision 17 (Alignment)#-3 Research Invasion|Revision 17 Invasion]]. They offer [[Exp. Targeting Computer|Exp. Targeting Computers]], [[Exp. Core Analyzer|Exp. Core Analyzers]], [[Exp. Optical Array|Exp. Optical Arrays]], and [[Helical Railgun|Helical Railguns]]. [[Adv. Kinecellerator]] is another good part for this build in theory, though it is heavy and somewhat fragile, so it won't last a long time unless you can consistently outrange your opponents.
Late into the run, the #1 enemy of your build is the [[H-88 Terminator]]. Their 25% kinetic damage resistance, [[Adv. Targeting Computer]], and [[Adv. Phase Shifter]] result in them being quite annoying to fight. They often tank multiple of your volleys while wearing your build down in return. The one positive of fighting Hunters is that they drop plenty of kinetic guns to restock up on, though the price is often lots of integrity to your other parts. I recommend avoiding or running from them whenever possible unless you have some allies that can provide cover for you. By comparison, most other bots at this depth are quite easy to take out at max range. As always, be careful and intentional about your positioning since the easiest way to lose your build is to slowly get worn down by getting shot by a few bots at once.

[[Heading]]Cannon Kiter[[/Heading]]
The general idea of cannon [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Advanced Movement#Kiting|kiters]] is to take advantage of the long range of powerful [[Kinetic Cannons]] when coupled with flight's high speed and the enhanced vision of [[Visual Processing Units]] to strike enemies when they can't hit you back. A [[Weapon Mount]] helps the cannon serve as armor and provides a large targeting bonus in a single slot. Other offensive utilities like [[Weapon Cyclers]], [[Core Analyzers]], and [[Kinecellerators]] are also useful. This build is a good evolution for an early flight hacker since you can stealth around and use the hackware to hack for key parts to fabricate later.
This is a build that is best in the latter half of Factory and beyond. Earlier in the run there are not many good choices of powerful kinetic cannons that make the build worthwhile. That's not to say that you can't run a kinetic cannon or two on flight, but it's not worth focusing too hard on it as it's unlikely to have high firepower. However, a relatively early standout cannon is the [[Antimatter Cannon]] with its high damage and low recoil. They are rare parts, but perform well enough for early Factory.

[[Heading:2]]Analysis|Analysis Cannon Kiter[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Moderate difficulty to assemble: A few rarer parts like the Weapon Mount and good cannons may need to be fabricated, while good utilities like [[Exp. Core Analyzer]] may require branch visits|
Moderately difficult to play: Offensive parts take up a lot of slots and support which makes it hard to play stealthily, going without storage may be required to support everything which limits crucial backups|
Maneuverable in combat: Use your high movement speed to fight enemies at maximum range to avoid taking damage|
Loves long open corridors: You can freely take out most bots in longer corridors with your superior range, even faster moving bots like [[Programmer|Programmers]]|
Can be matter intensive: Prolonged fights may end up consuming your backup supplies, so make sure you stay topped up
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Late Factory Cannon Kiter[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Late Factory Fly-rail.png|Fly-rail ([[Tri-rail Accelerator]])|builds/Late Factory Hyp. Cannon Sniper.png|Hyp. Cannon[[/FanartGallery]]
[[Hypervelocity Cannons]] like the [[Hyp. Mass Driver]] have the advantage of being able to kill bots in a single core hit with their very high critical chance. However, they can be inconsistent thanks to having only a single low damage projectile that absolutely needs to roll the critical hit to kill. As such, they are also unhelpful against bots that are coring immune such as [[Heavy|Heavies]] and [[Behemoth|Behemoths]], although both of them are threatening for this build no matter what weapons you have. A step up from those is the [[Tri-rail Accelerator]]. This fantastic 2 slot cannon shoots 3 moderately high damage projectiles. It lacks one-shot potential like Hyp. cannons, though it more than makes up for it in its consistently high damage and good chance to hit core with multiple projectiles.
Most standard patrol bots, Programmers, and [[Sentry|Sentries]] should be easily taken out within a few hits at range, most reliably with the Tri-rail Accelerator. While you're in control of your positioning and with some kind map layouts, it's possible to avoid taking damage from most encounters. Even Sentires tucked deep inside rooms can often be taken out without retaliation with some careful engagement and digging. Visual Processing Units are key to maintaining your range advantage and get the first strike. A [[Triangulator]] is a niche alternative that has a slightly longer range at 24 tiles and can be swapped at will. However, the downside that you must be tracked before it works is a fairly significant issue for general use.

[[Heading:2]]Access Cannon Kiter[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Access Fly-rail.png|Lategame fly-rail|[[Spoiler]]builds/Access Omega Cannon Kite.png[[/Spoiler]]|[[Omega Cannon]][[/FanartGallery]]
Late cannon kiting options in the game involve a myriad of spoiler parts, including [[Cep. Heavy Railcannon]], [[Cep. Helical Railcannon]], [[Cep. Miniperforator]], [[Omega Cannon]], and [[Perforator]]. Still, the Tri-rail Accelerator serves as a viable option even when compared to these lategame unique parts thanks to its multiple projectiles and high damage from a single weapon. Stacking more offensive utilities on top of an already good weapon is the best way to scale up to endgame levels since you only really have a few single 2 slot cannons as options. There are a few other basic cannons that are potential choices, like [[Hvy. Hardcell Cannon]] and [[Hvy. Linear Accelerator]], though they are both significantly worse than all of the other options. [[Com. Linear Accelerator]] deserves a special mention as being the lightest of lategame cannons and has some stacking potential.
[[Kinecellerators]] are pretty heavy for an offensive utility and are a little on the fragile side with their high coverage. However, with good positioning and fight taking, they, along with the rest of the build, should rarely get hit, and increasing the minimum damage helps to ensure one or two hit kills on many lategame enemies.
Cannon kite builds also perform quite well on hover. Flight is ideal early into the run for maximum maneuverability and map exploration. However, for extended endgame encounters, the better support and survivability of hover make it a more appealing choice. This is especially the case if you can take your build into [[Protoforge]] and loot the map effectively due to the incredible power of hover units available there. Even though this is a flight guide, it's still worth a mention that builds can be jump started from flight.

[[Heading]]Melee[[/Heading]]
Fully kitted out melee builds are one of the most powerful flight builds with incredible damage output by the end of the game. They are capable of taking out all sorts of powerful lategame bots if geared properly. Of course, hurling yourself in the face of hostile bots does have some downsides. A lot of melee coverage winds up being in propulsion and offensive utilities, and both of which can be hard to replace. Fortunately, bots don't have much time to attack you back when you are capable of killing them in a single hit. To attain this level of power, you will likely have to do a lot of [[Fabricator|fabrication]] of high rating parts or obtain them through other means like raiding [[Cargo Convoy|Cargo Convoys]].
[[Sneak Attack|Sneak attacks]] are one of your most powerful tools to get kills without taking damage yourself. See [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Advanced Movement#Sneak Attack Preparation|this page]] for some sneak attack strategies. Using tricks like waiting around corners, using [[Partial Spot|partial spotting]], or using allies like [[Drone (Group)|Drones]] to distract hostiles are very worthwhile. Another effective melee strategy is to use [[Transmission Jammer|Transmission Jammers]] to pull only a single bot from a squad at once. This is especially more valuable at higher depths where the squad sizes are larger and are more likely to enter a room to allow other bots inside to hit you.
There are 3 main types of melee weapon types, all of which are useful in the right situations. You can usually run whatever you find on the floor, though if you are planning on Fabricating lategame weapons, you should aim for the top fabbable weapons [[Nanosword|Nanoswords]] or [[Plasma Lance|Plasma Lances]]. Generally, slashing and piercing weapons are good for all purposes while impact weapons are more niche. See [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Weapons#Melee Weapons|this page]] for more details.

[[Heading:2]]Analysis|Analysis Melee[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Moderate-high difficulty to assemble: The best melee builds often require hacking for and fabricating multiple high rating prototype parts|
Moderate-high difficulty to play: Melee requires a lot of careful positioning and is often restricted to door fighting to avoid taking lots of damage in combat|
Glass cannon: While offensively very capable, you have to give up your innate flight avoidance bonuses and tank hits at close range in order to engage in combat|
Loves rooms: Melee weapons, especially [[Impact Weapons]], are ideal for fighting inside rooms right next to the door to reduce the number of hostiles you have to fight at once
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Late Factory Stealth/Melee[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Late Factory Stealth Flight Melee Swap.png|Stealth flight melee swap[[/FanartGallery]]
In the midgame, melee is best as a utility that is used by other build types rather than a full build by itself. Stealth flight frequently makes use of melee in order to take out problematic [[0b10 Non-combat Bots]] like [[Hauler|Haulers]], [[Operator|Operators]], and [[Watcher|Watchers]] while generally avoiding direct combat encounters. In a pinch, you can always use melee to take out an annoying [[Programmer]], especially with something like a temporary [[Nanoactuators]] swap over sensors.

[[Heading:2]]Access Melee[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Access Flight Melee Plasma Lance.png|2 weapons Plasma Lance|builds/Access Flight Melee Nanosword.png|4 weapon Nanoswords[[/FanartGallery]]
The example builds above are more of "peak melee" builds that will often require heavy fabrication or targeted looting of good parts. Melee builds without enough firepower to quickly destroy hostiles like this will find themselves quickly running out of integrity. It is possible to get by with less stacked offensive utilities, especially with [[Research]] [[Branch]] loot, though the above examples are the types of loadouts I usually keep in mind as a goal.
My endgame melee checklist is targeting (either through [[Melee Analysis Suites]] or [[Weapon Mount]]), [[Core Analyzers]] and/or [[Armor Integrity Analyzers]], 50% actuating (either [[Femtoactuators]] or 2 Nanoactuators), [[Utility Shieldings|Utility Shieldings (preferably Exp. with multiple backups)]], and evasion ([[Reaction Control Systems]] at a minimum, [[Phase Shifters]] too if possible). Most of these parts will stay in inventory as I stealth until I'm ready to transition into full melee.
The biggest decision to make for flight builds is whether to stay on two weapons or evolve more. Staying on 2 weapon slots is well suited for pierce damage like Plasma Lances, boosting a smaller number of melee weapons to their fullest potential. Four or more weapons is better suited for slashing, specifically Nanoswords, thanks to their low mass and coverage keeping them from becoming a weak point of the build. Many melee weapon work incredibly well with [[Actuator Arrays]] to produce a very high damage-output volley.
Hover is worth a mention here as an alternative to flight melee. Hover has a lot more support and integrity than flight ever will, with the tradeoff of losing a large amount of speed. If you plan to make the swap, you can use flight to work your way toward this build and then swap to hover once you collect enough hover units. If you are doing this strategy, [[Protoforge]] is a great map to go to thanks to its large collection of powerful hover.

[[Heading]][[Launchers|Launcher]] kiter[[/Heading]]
Launcher kite builds combine either long ranged or guided Launchers with flight's naturally high speed in order to take out bots without taking damage in the process. There are relatively few Launchers that fit in this category, but when well executed, these builds can easily take out dozens of bots without being touched. In some cases, flight is even able to handle taking down waves of [[High Security]] long enough to [[Sterilization|sterilize]] a floor. Launchers tend to be somewhat layout dependent for maximum effectiveness, so they aren't so powerful in all situations and maps.

[[Heading:2]]Analysis|Analysis Launcher Kiter[[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Moderate difficulty to assemble: Only a few long ranged and guided launchers exist, they may have to be fabricated|
Moderate-high difficulty to play: Careful positioning is required to avoid unnecessary damage and matter and energy may be an issue in combat if not properly managed|
High damage output: Launchers generally have above average damage output|
Messy fighter: Launchers are not known for their finesse, so be prepared to fight off extra [[Reinforcement Squad|reinforcements]] from hitting [[U-05 Engineer|Engineers]]|
High matter upkeep: You may need to kill lots of non-combat bots, especially [[Recycler|Recyclers]], to stay topped up on matter
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]]Late Factory Launcher Kiter[[/Heading]]
[[FanartGallery]]builds/Factory Flight Mni Smartbomb Kiter.png|[[Mni. Smartbomb Launcher]]|builds/Factory Flight Lrn Missile Kite.png|[[Lrn. Missile Launcher]] + [[Launcher Loader]]|builds/Late Factory Gui EMP Kiter.png|[[Gui. EMP Blaster]] + Launcher Loader[[/FanartGallery]]
The three weapons shown above are the 3 best options for flight kiting. The Mni. Smartbomb Launcher and Gui. EMP Blaster are both guided weapons that can be fired around corners without any risk of getting attacked. The Lrn. Missile Launcher has a great 20 tile range that allows you to outrange nearly all standard 0b10 bots. Guided weapons are much more flexible in how they can be used thanks to their 100% accuracy and ability to shoot around corners. Just be careful of blowing up walls and exposing yourself in the process. The Lrn. Missile Launcher's superior range is nice in some cases, though it is more more restricted to wide open areas.
The Launcher Loader is a fantastic launcher kite part that gives you twice the normal damage output, allowing you to kill in less time and avoid repositioning so much. It does have some high costs in being a rare part that usually be [[Fabricator|fabricated]], a mass of 12, and an energy upkeep of 10. If you can't support one, consider a [[Weapon Cyclers|Weapon Cycler]] instead for a lower but significantly easier to support damage increasing utility. There aren't a lot of other ways to increase launcher effectiveness aside from cycling since most other combat utilities don't affect AOE damage. [[Launcher Guidance Computers]] are good for the Lrn. Missile Launcher, though they don't provide any benefits for the guided launchers. [[Energy Filters]] and [[Matter Filters]] can help to keep resource costs down.

[[Heading]]Unconventional builds[[/Heading]]
Here are a few ideas of more unconventional builds:
[[List]]
[[Lightpack 2.0]] hauler: Uses Lightpack 2.0 to haul an absurd number of parts to the lategame. Some good examples of parts are [[Authchips]] and [[GOLEM Unit|GOLEM Units]].|
[[RIF]]-stacker: Prioritizing utility slots and [[Relay Couplers]] over anything else, can use as few as 2 propulsion slots|
[[Traps|Trap]] master: Uses [[Trap Scanners]] and carries [[Trap Extractors]] full of traps to hit hostiles[[/List]]

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts
Content:
A collection of thoughts and recommendations on good parts to aim for on flight builds. Each slot has its own page:
[[List]]
[[aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Power|Power]]|
[[aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Propulsion|Propulsion]]|
[[aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Utilities|Utilities]]|
[[aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Weapons|Weapons]]
[[/List]]
Subpages: aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Power,aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Propulsion,aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Utilities,aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Weapons

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Power
Content:
Power is never exciting, but it is a necessity to all builds. The majority of energy on my flight builds typically ends up powering flight units and [[Mass Support Devices]]. In order to save mass for other essential parts, it's better to use lighter engines. It doesn't do much good to dedicate an engine that's so heavy that flight units take up all the energy needed to support it in the first place. As such, one of the most important stats for flight builds is the amount of energy that is generated compared to the mass of the engine, or the energy:mass ratio. Heat generation is also an important factor secondary factor, although it is usually easier to solve a heat problem than a support one.

[[Image]]../part_art/Backup Power VII.png|Backup Power VII, the best Backup Power[[/Image]]
[[Heading]][[Backup Power]][[/Heading]]
Backup Power is a class of relatively unassuming power that has surprising effectiveness. This is primarily due to the [[Backup Power VII]]'s incredible energy:mass ratio of 3:1. Backup Power is not very durable, can't be repaired, and can be difficult to obtain since it is only available via [[GameText]]Refit[[/GameText]] hack on a [[Repair Station]]. Backup Power VII in particular requires a level 3 Repair Station and succeeding at a base 8% success rate, so [[Hackware]] is highly recommended. Despite these downsides, Backup Power VII is a solid low mass option.

[[Heading]][[Fusion Compressors]][[/Heading]]
Fusion Compressors are unique power sources that have high energy generation at the cost of very high heat and an unusual matter cost. Fusion Compressors, especially the [[Imp. Fusion Compressor]], can support a relatively energy-hungry flight build off a single engine. If using these, take care not to run out of matter, since doing so can spell disaster. The easiest way to restock on matter is to kill non-combat bots like [[Recycler|Recyclers]] and [[Hauler|Haulers]]. In [[Caves]], look for [[Scrap]] piles to restock on matter instead.

[[Image]]../part_art/Graviton Reactor.png|Graviton Reactor, a heavy but powerful engine[[/Image]]
[[Heading]]High Mass High Energy Power[[/Heading]]
This category applies to a few mid to lategame prototype engines such as the [[Graviton Reactor]], [[Zero-point Reactor]], and [[Zio. Light DM Reactor]]. Non-prototype standard engines are often heavy and don't provide enough energy to properly support themselves. Engines in this group might not be quite so mass-efficient as lighter engines, but one advantage they have is slot compression. For example, the Graviton Reactor generates an impressive 24 energy at the cost of 15 mass. This is the energy equivalent of a [[Mic. Antimatter Reactor]] + a [[Mic. Neutrino Core]], which when combined, take up 13 mass. So at the cost of 2 extra mass, the Graviton generates the same energy in a single slot. While parts like these tend to be higher rating prototypes and are not readily available, in some cases they can help delay or prevent the need to evolve a second power slot altogether.

[[Image]]../part_art/Lgt. Fission Core.png|[[Lgt. Fission Core]], a midgame light engine[[/Image]]
[[Heading]][[Light Power]][[/Heading]]
Light Power is the standard class of flight engine in the early game. They are reasonably lighter than non-light power sources, though they do give up some integrity and energy storage for the privilege. Light power is best in [[Factory]]-depths, with engines like the [[Lgt. Deuterium Engine]], [[Lgt. Nuclear Core]], [[Lgt. Angular Momentum Engine]], [[Lgt. Fission Core]], and [[Lgt. Neutrino Core]] all serving as viable power sources. However, in later depths, light engines become more difficult to use. For example, the rating 9 [[Lgt. Quantum Reactor]], while technically a "light" reactor, is still 15 mass, as much as 2 endgame flight units support alone! Micro power sources are much more desirable later on for their energy:mass ratios.

[[Heading:2]][[Mak. Power Source]][[/Heading]]
For all intents and purposes, the Mak. Power Source is like an early light engine. They run a little hot for their rating, but they are a perfectly serviceable engine.

[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading]][[Meta Core]][[/Heading]]
This [[Subcaves]]-exclusive engine is among the best in the game. The durability of this part is off the charts, while the energy generation rivals the mid-lategame [[Mic. Antimatter Reactor]]. Flight can also make great use of its provided temporary slots for extended periods of time.

[[/Spoiler]]

[[Image]]../part_art/Mic. Antimatter Reactor.png|[[Mic. Antimatter Reactor]], the best standard micro engine[[/Image]]
[[Heading]][[Micro Power]][[/Heading]]
Micro power sources are the bread and butter power sources of flight players. They have low total mass, low coverage so they don't die so quickly, and have some of the best energy:mass ratios in the game. Their overall energy generation is not particularly impressive, but they are always a solid pick.

[[Heading]]Personal Power Tier List[[/Heading]]
Parts are sorted alphabetically within ranks. This tier list is not a strict comparison, since comparing a rating 3 and a rating 9 engine directly based on stats doesn't make a lot of sense. This list is about general usefulness of parts based on all stats while also taking into account the depths that they become available.

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Good Parts/Propulsion
Content:
Good flight units are the key to the most successful flight builds. While it is possible to scrape by with any low integrity non-prototype [[Swarmer]]-tier flight units, builds relying heavily on these types of parts struggle greatly due to their fragility. [[Prototype Part|Prototype]] flight units have a large number of benefits over non-prototypes. However, that doesn't mean that non-prototypes aren't worth using. [[Flight Arrays]] and [[Surge Thrusters]] have good niches, and even typical non-prototype parts like the basic [[Flight Unit]] can be used in a pinch. Any flight unit is better than an empty slot.

[[Heading]]Effect of Rating[[/Heading]]
Higher rating parts have higher support and integrity at the cost of higher energy and heat upkeep. Unlike other propulsion types, higher rating parts are not always a superior choice. It is entirely possible to make a build off of early-game prototypes like [[Imp. VTOL Module|Imp. VTOL Modules]] and use them throughout the entire run, never opting to swap them out for higher rating parts. While this results in a lower total support limit, the tradeoff is that upkeep is very low, potentially avoiding the requirement of a 2nd power source or [[Cooling Utilities]]. Instead, these slots can be used to maximize the number of utility slots for other purposes like hacking.

[[Heading]]Prototype Flight Units[[/Heading]]
Prototype flight units are highly valuable to a flight player. Most importantly, prototypes are 2-4 times more durable than standard flight units due to their lower coverage and higher integrity. For example, compare a rating 2 flight unit [[VTOL Module]] vs a rating 2* prototype [[Imp. Flight Unit]]. The Imp. Flight Unit has an integrity:coverage ratio of 2.67, while the VTOL module has .83, meaning the Imp. Flight Unit will survive roughly 3 times as long under fire.

[[Heading]]Comparing Flight Units[[/Heading]]
Comparing different flight units can be a difficult task. There are many different stats that all help determine how "good" a flight unit is. Depending on your current build, some stats may be more important than others. A build that is already struggling with energy may be better off with a slower, less expensive flight unit rather than a higher rated one. Another build may be ready to upgrade to a larger storage unit and cares only about getting enough support to stay underweight. Some of the more important stats to consider are below:
[[Heading:2]]Durability[[/Heading]]
This typically scales up with rating, and prototype parts are generally much more durable than non-prototype ones. A flight build that goes overweight while in combat is often in a very rough spot, so maintaining good flight units that won't instantly fold in combat is important. Consider the integrity:coverage ratio as an overall indicator of durability.

[[Heading:2]][[Overload#Propulsion[[/Heading]]
Overload is only available on a few different types of flight units, namely [[Cooled Flight Units]] and [[Surge Thrusters]]. Having a few overloadable flight units is extremely valuable for a flight build to be able to zoom out of bad situations as quickly as possible. Getting all the way to the minimum 5 speed is not particularly important since it's completely unsustainable. However, getting a few overloads can make a big difference in damage taken.

[[Heading:2]]Speed[[/Heading]]
Faster builds have many more options than slower builds. Being able to run away once spotted, lure bots out of position, or even just generally explore the map become easier the faster the build.However, with increased speed comes increased upkeep costs. It is a balancing act to consider both speed and upkeep in a build.

[[Heading:2]]Support[[/Heading]]
Fairly self explanatory. Support costs scale fairly linearly through rating. Many flight builds are constantly pressing against the upper edge of their support limits. Even if there isn't anything heavier you want to carry, getting a little extra leeway against [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] is never a bad idea.

[[Heading:2]]Upkeep[[/Heading]]
Energy cost and heat generation are the 2 upkeep considerations. Some flight units are more expensive on upkeep than others. These upkeep costs tend to scale through ratings, but some flight units are outliers in some ways, either high or low.
There are two types of upkeep for flight units: active and per move. Active upkeep is fixed no matter what the speed is, and this tends to be the more important part of upkeep for slower builds. Typical flight units scale from .5 to 1.5 energy per turn, and 1-3 heat per turn, or 0 heat in the case of cooled flight units. On the other hand, per move upkeep is more important for faster builds. Move flight units have a fixed .5 energy and 1 heat per move cost, although a few unique parts have variable numbers here.

[[Heading]]Notable Flight Units[[/Heading]]

[[Image]]../part_art/Biomechanical Wings.png|Biomechanical Wings[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]][[Biomechanical Wings]][[/Heading]]
These flight units have extremely low upkeep and coverage at the cost of very low integrity. Biomechanical Wings can be stacked in large numbers with low upkeep costs. However, they essentially require [[Propulsion Shieldings]] because a hit from most bots will destroy them even from full integrity.

[[Heading:2]][[Cooled Flight Units]][[/Heading]]
Cooled Flight Units, such as the [[Cld. VTOL Module]], have slightly lower support than other prototypes for their rating. However, they generate 0 heat by default and additionally provide the ability to [[Overload#propulsion]] for a temporary boost of speed and support. Overloading is a great way to quickly escape from hostiles after being spotted.

[[Image]]../part_art/Diametric Drive.png|Diametric Drive[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]][[Diametric Drives]][[/Heading]]
Diametric Drives have a relatively low energy cost and high speed for their rating. However, they are on the upper end of the heat generation spectrum at +3. These parts are difficult to stack in large numbers due to high cooling requirements, but work well with Cooled Flight Units that help balance out the heat.

[[Heading:2]][[Exp. Cesium-ion Thruster|Exp. Cesium-ion]] and [[Exp. Q-thruster|Exp. Q-thrusters]][[/Heading]]
These 2 flight units are unique in their abnormally low base Time/Move. They have slightly below average support and expensive upkeep for the support they provide. Additionally, their low base speed ends up making full speed movement even harder to support. Their best niche is not in a large stack of flight units, but rather keeping the speed down for a small number of dedicated flight units. For example, they work well for the Inspector Gadget [[Achievements|Achievement]] that restricts Cogmind to only 2 propulsion slots.

[[Image]]../part_art/Nuclear Pulse Array.png|Nuclear Pulse Array, a the lowest rating flight array[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]][[Flight Arrays]][[/Heading]]
Flight Arrays, such as the [[Nuclear Pulse Array]], are 2 slot non-prototype flight units that have better than average integrity and support. They have relatively low upkeep costs and run a bit slower than their single slot counterparts due to only one application of the "Mod/Extra" stat. Mixing one or two arrays into a flight build is usually a good idea to improve support while lowering the overall upkeep costs of the build. They make great [[Study]] targets from [[Scanalyzer|Scanalyzers]] since they get 2 additional support. Notably, the [[Impulse Thruster Array]] can be looted off of [[Striker|Strikers]] which appear in many large scale [[Derelict]] vs [[0b10]] battles.

[[Spoiler]]
[[Heading:2]][[Flightbrick]][[/Heading]]
This unique Subcaves-exclusive prototype is a great addition to any flight build. Its 3 temporary utility slots can provide great benefit throughout its lifespan, which is quite long due to its incredible 1800 integrity. The biggest drawback of the Flightbrick is its high upkeep costs, although it is still possible to support the Flightbrick at high speeds.

[[/Spoiler]]

[[Image]]../part_art/Flying Fortress v7.png|Flying Fortress v7[[/Image]]
[[Heading:2]][[Flying Fortress v7]][[/Heading]]
The Flying Fortress v7 is a unique [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] part that has an unparalleled 12.5 support per slot which makes it great for hauling around big storage units or other heavy parts. It has  high integrity, coverage and upkeep costs. However, its 800 integrity may not last as long as it may first sound. The relatively low speed for a flight unit and high coverage make it somewhat vulnerable in the long run. Using Propulsion Shieldings can significantly improve the lifespan of this part.

[[Heading:2]][[Surge Thrusters]][[/Heading]]
Surge Thrusters are non-prototype flight units with very low support, but high coverage, integrity, and base speed. These can be looted off of [[Cutter|Cutters]], although fighting Cutters is not something to be taken lightly.
While Surge Thrusters are not very durable, one unique use of them are as makeshift propulsion armor due to their high coverage compared to other flight units. Since they are expensive to run, they don't need to be turned on at all times. Instead, keep them powered off to serve as armor at all times. Then, when needed, they can be turned on and overloaded to escape danger ASAP. Make sure to carry backups of them since they get destroyed rather quickly. Surge Thrusters make good Scanalyzer Study targets due to their low support. Although they only get an additional +1 per thruster, it can help make them a bit more competitive of an option.

[[Heading]]Personal Flight Unit Tier List[[/Heading]]
Parts are sorted alphabetically within ranks. This tier list is not a strict comparison, since comparing a rating 3 and a rating 9 flight unit doesn't make a lot of sense. This list is about general usefulness of parts based on all stats, while also taking into account the depths that they become available.
