Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Machine Hacking/Terminals
Content:
[[Image]]../game_sprites/Terminal.png|A Terminal machine[[/Image]]
While most other machines have one or two purposes, Terminals are the true hacker's playground with dozens of different types of hacks available. For new players, it can be easy to become overwhelmed with options. However, not all hacks are created equal. For example, bot analyses are helpful, but finding an exit is much more important of an issue to worry about first. Generally, try to focus on hacks that will help you right now over speculative hacks that might help you later. The best way to learn and get a feel for hacking style is by trying out hacks and seeing how useful they feel.
Terminal hacks typically fall under a few general categories:

[[Heading]]Map Intel Hacks[[/Heading]]
These types of hacks give you unchanging information about the current map. The earlier into the level you can perform these types of hacks, the better you can take advantage of the intel.

[[Expandable]]Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Access(Branch) / Access(Main)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
These two hacks are among the best and most important in the game. Locating exits should be a priority in each new map you enter. There's nothing worse than blindly scrambling around the map, desperately hoping you'll find an exit while you are fleeing from multiple squads. Flight tends to have an easier time of finding exits naturally than other propulsion types. Still, I still consider these hacks crucial, especially in [[Research]] and [[Access]], both of which often have massive and sprawling maps.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Access(Emergency)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A significantly less useful hack than the 2 previous Access hacks. Revealing nearby emergency doors is nice, but there are other methods of doing this. Allied [[Operator|Operators]] and a [[Structural Scanner]] both reveal emergency doors without costing you a hack. [[GameText]]Layout(Zone)[[/GameText]] can also reveal some emergency doors since you can see the empty spaces of the corridor, though it won't reveal 1 tile doors.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Index([Machine Type] / Machines)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This series of hacks provides map-wide intel about the locations of a particular type of [[Interactive Machine]]. They are quite useful, although some machine types are not as valuable as others. [[GameText]]Index(Fabricators)[[/GameText]] also competes with [[GameText]]Network(Status)[[/GameText]] on Fabricators, especially since the latter provides loaded schematics in addition to machine locations. In my opinion, the most valuable hack is Terminal locations since they are the most generically useful machine type. Conveniently, it is also the easiest hack of the bunch to perform. While hacking for all machine types with an [[GameText]]Index(Machines)[[/GameText]] is fantastic if you can afford to do it, a base 0% hack is quite a steep asking price. This hack is not very useful to go for without a large stack of hackware.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Inventory(Component / Prototype)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
These 2 hacks provide intel about part stockpiles across the map which is of moderate use. Since flight is good at exploring most if not all of each floor, this often won't tell you a lot of data about things you would miss. However, it certainly doesn't hurt to have a list of parts you can be on the lookout for. While prototype intel is nice to have, there are only a few prototype stockpiles per map, so quite frequently you will not be able to pull anything useful out of it. Non-prototype parts are less valuable, but there's a higher chance you will find something you want to grab.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Layout(Zone)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A solid and reasonably easy hack to perform that reveals the nearby map layout. Map intel has many uses like finding digs or escape routes to escape pursuers, and even though the range of this hack is quite limited, having immediate intel is quite nice. This hack reveals emergency accesses longer than 1 tile, although keep in mind that occasionally they can be 1 tile wide.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Map Intel[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Access(Branch)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]] (Desired exit)
[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]] (Undesired exit)|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map||
Access(Main)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]] (Desired exit)
[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]] (Undesired exit)|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map||
Access(Emergency)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, multiple times per map||
Index(Fabricators)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Index(Garrisons)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Index(Machines)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Index(Recycling Units)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Index(Repair Stations)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Index(Scanalyzers)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Index(Terminals)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map||
Inventory(Components)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map||
Inventory(Prototype)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, once per map||
Layout(Zone)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, multiple times per map
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]]Robot Intel Hacks[[/Heading]]
These types of hacks give information about the current positions of bots on the map. Since most types of bots are mobile, the value of this kinds of intel decreases over time.
[[Expandable]]
Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Assaults / Coupling / Exterminations / Garrison / Intercept / Investigations / Reinforcements)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This collection of hacks has extremely limited value. Each of the associated [[Squad]] types are either temporary around a location, or else they will hunt you down until they find you, and they all come announced via map-wide alert message. There is an occasional use for them, like for [[Extermination Squad|Exterminations]], where there may be multiple squads roaming around the map and it is hard to keep track of them all. However, it is almost always better to attempt to recall a squad if you know or have a hunch that they're still around instead of trying to check its location.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Guards)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack may at first sound promising because [[Security Squad|Guards]] never move. However, it has a pitifully low range of 20 that makes it functionally useless. There are a few other sources of guard intel like [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]] that do provide map-wide guard locations that are actually useful.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Maintenance)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
While initially relatively unassuming, this is one of the best enumerate hacks in the game, especially in higher depths like [[Research]]. The reason why is not because of the locations of the individual bots on the map. Rather, the reason is that there are so many non-combat bots that are revealed by this hack that it paints a picture of what the whole level is like, providing a rough full map layout. For example, when Research is a horseshoe shape with no connecting center section, this hack will reveal it by the concentration of the bots. The empty black space in the map with no maintenance markers anywhere nearby are most likely solid earth, while areas packed with markers will indicate busy corridors. This hack may take some getting used to, but when used and interpreted correctly, it can provide a ton of info in a single hack.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Patrols)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This is another great enumerate hack that provides a lot of valuable info. [[Patrol Squad|Patrols]] typically make up the bulk of the hostiles that Cogmind must either fight or avoid on a given map, so knowing where across the map is always helpful. Since patrols are always moving, this hack loses some value over time. However, even hundreds of turns later, the patrol intel still gives you a general idea of where patrols are concentrated on the map. If you have 5 patrol pings in the top right corner of the map, it's a pretty safe bet that it will still be busy forever.
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Squads)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Unlike most enumerate hacks, this indicates the types of all squads on the map rather than indicating their positions. This is a typically low-value hack since most temporary squads can be kept track of by yourself and there isn't a whole lot you can do about knowing exactly how many permanent squads are hanging around. Perhaps the main use of this hack is checking whether there are temporary squads like exterminations or reinforcements before trying to recall them.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Surveillance)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This is one of the less useful enumerate hacks. [[Watcher|Watchers]] are common, but not as common as maintenance bots as to provide a decent layout of the map purely from this intel. On top of that, there isn't a whole lot to do with respect to Watcher locations. Unlike patrols, you can run up to a Watcher at no risk if you know there are no squads nearby, or with little risk with a [[Transmission Jammers|Transmission Jammer]].

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Enumerate(Transport)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This is another less useful enumerate hack. While it can be used in conjunction with a [[GameText]]Manifests[[/GameText]] hack to try to locate [[Transport Squad|Transport Squads]] containing useful parts, it isn't so hard to kill any random [[Hauler]] for its [[Transport Network Coupler]] or use a [[Spoiler]][[GameText]]Trojan(Haulers)[[/GameText]] hack at a Fabricator[[/Spoiler]] to get a superior effect. The best use for this is to find a Hauler to kill for its TNC, which you can then use to find the rest.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Robot Intel[[/Heading]]

[[Table]]
Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Enumerate(Assaults)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Coupling)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Exterminations)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Garrison)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Guards)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Intercept)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Investigations)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Maintenance)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map||
Enumerate(Patrols)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map, situationally more||
Enumerate(Reinforcements)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Never||
Enumerate(Squads)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Practically never||
Enumerate(Surveillance)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Practically never||
Enumerate(Transport)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, multiple times per map
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]]Database Hacks[[/Heading]]
These types of hacks provide Cogmind with permanent analysis or schematic information about a target. While direct hacks can always be performed, after succeeding at one of these hacks, there will be a 25% chance that future indirect database hacks trigger a database lockout. These hacks are depth and Terminal level restricted, so the better higher-rating parts require higher level and lategame Terminals.

[[Expandable]]
Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Analysis([Bot Name])[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This series of hacks obtains a [[Robot Analysis]] for a particular type of bot, providing a slight accuracy and damage bonus against and a slight accuracy penalty for the bot. The effect is not very significant so I will rarely go out of my way to pull an indirect analysis. However, it doesn't hurt to grab as a direct hack against common nuisances like [[Operator|Operators]], [[Programmer|Programmers]], and [[Watcher|Watchers]] if it shows up. Since each new tier of bot (like [[P-70 Sage]] vs. [[P-80 Master]]) requires a new analysis, it is difficult to keep up throughout the whole run. That is one of the other reasons why I pick only a few specific analysis targets.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Schematic([Part Name])[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This series of hacks obtains a [[Schematic]] for a part that can be used at a [[Fabricator]]. Fabrication is a very powerful tool in Cogmind's disposal, but in order to use that power, schematics must be obtained. Hacking for schematics is by far the most reliable way to achieve desired results, but it is extraordinarily difficult to hack for high rating parts late in the game. These hacks are by far the most difficult hacks in the game, with highly negative base success rates popping up for highly rated parts. You will need to pull out all the stops in order to succeed at a 9* part.
I tend to leave schematic hacking for late into a floor rather than earlier. By then, I can plan out which Terminals I need to hit based on my desired schematics, bringing [[Operator]] allies or attaching temporary additional hackware to have the best chance at success. [[Spoiler]]Blowing [[Hub_04(d)|Hubs]] and [[GameText]]Trojan(Botnet)[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]] helps too; every little bit counts when trying to pull off such difficult hacks. Of course, high tier prototype hackware is extra useful here, though it is hard to come by. Your best bet is to fill all free utility slots with any kind of hackware you can get your hands on.
For a reference of good parts to hack for, see [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Machine Hacking/Schematics Reference|this page]].

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Prototypes[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This is a middling hack that gives a few random prototype IDs. Since there are so many prototype parts, the average value of a few IDs is not particularly high. I rarely go out of my way to do this hack, especially indirectly. If I have lots of hackware, I will occasionally take direct Prototypes hacks. However, you usually have something better to do unless you really are a fantastic hacker.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Database[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Analysis([Bot Name])|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]] indirect
[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]] direct|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per floor||
Schematic([Part Name])|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, multiple times per floor||
Prototypes|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]] indirect
[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]] direct|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per floor
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]]Recall Hacks[[/Heading]]
These hacks deal with recalling temporarily summoned [[Squad|Squads]] back to an [[0b10]]-controlled exit.

[[Expandable]]
Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Recall(Assault / Investigation / Extermination / Reinforcements)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Recall hacks are some of the most powerful hacks in that they have a tangible effect on bots on the map. Being able to eliminate squads without having to destroy them is a strong ability. All recall hacks behave pretty similarly; if the appropriate squad type is bothering you, hit recall to send them away. I find that [[Extermination Squad|exterminations]] are my most recalled squad type since they tend to be the biggest nuisance in the longer term. Having to juggle multiple exterminations or trying to kill them with a poorly combat-equipped flight build can easily end in disaster, but recalling is a surefire way of getting them off your tail. Since all recall hacks have quite low success rates, with an increasing difficult upon each successful hack, it's worth looking for direct hacks between multiple Terminals. Some other nice recall examples are recalling [[Investigation Squad|investigations]] to free up a [[Fabricator]] when used without an [[Authchips|Authchip]] or recalling [[Reinforcement Squad|reinforcements]] from a heavy.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Recall[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Recall(Assault)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, multiple times per map||
Recall(Extermination)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, multiple times per map||
Recall(Investigation)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per map||
Recall(Reinforcements)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per map
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]][[Alert]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
These hacks deal with checking and purging alert.

[[Expandable]]Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Alert(Check)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A pretty low value hack for flight. Alert level is not a huge concern for most flight builds. Even if you are running high alert, it is not too difficult to avoid or run away from [[Assault Squad|assaults]]. A non-hack method of checking alert would be to use a [[Datajacks|Datajack]] on an [[Operator]] and use the [[GameText]]check_alert[[/GameText]] hack. Alternately, you can just wait and see if assaults are being dispatched to you. No assaults mean alert level is below level 2, which is all that really matters most of the time.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Alert(Purge)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Purging alert, on the other hand, is a little more useful than checking alert. If assaults are coming by then it's time to drop a few purges. Sometimes it's worth doing preemptively if you do something like smashing a few Garrisons or blowing up a large explosive machine array. Usually though, I don't bother with this hack until after I've already got the assault dispatch message.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Alert[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Alert(Check)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Rare, usually only once per map||
Alert(Purge)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per map
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]][[Traps|Trap]] Hacks[[/Heading]]
These hacks deal with locating an interacting with traps.
[[Expandable]]
Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Traps(Disarm)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A rarely useful hack that disarms a single array of traps. This effect is mostly inferior to locating traps, since this effect only targets a single array of traps when there may be more than one nearby. This effect is most useful if you are running with a squad of white/gray allies since you do not share trap intel with them, unlike blue/purple allies. By just locating traps, it is likely that those allies will still step on known traps, which is especially painful if they are explosive ones. This can occasionally also be useful in cramped corridors when there is no easy way around the traps and blowing them up with an explosive launcher is inconvenient.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Traps(Locate)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A simple but effective hack to locate all nearby traps. While this effect can be replicated by having an allied [[Operator]], those may not always be around when you need them. With a reasonable amount of hackware, I will go for this hack nearly every time I see it offered directly. Especially consider this hack when walking around places with huge explosive machine arrays, lest you find out that there's a trap the hard way.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Traps(Reprogram)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A more difficult but generally superior hack to disarming traps. This hack generally requires knowledge of traps ahead of time or else you might end up wasting a hack to no effect, so use an Operator buddy or Traps(Locate) first to find what you need.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Trap[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Traps(Disarm)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Rare, situationally multiple times per map||
Traps(Locate)|[[Range]]4|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, multiple times per map||
Traps(Reprogram)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per map
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]]Miscellaneous Hacks[[/Heading]]
These hacks don't fit into any particular category.
[[Expandable]]
Show/hide hacks|
[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Manifests[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This useful hack provides intel about the contents of all [[Hauler|Haulers]] on the map. Haulers can contain all sorts of goodies for all build types, but flight is particularly adept at running across the whole map and looting all Haulers. If you see a big prototype stockpile from this hack, grab a [[Transport Network Coupler]] [[Spoiler]]or install a [[GameText]]Trojan(Haulers)[[/GameText]][[/Spoiler]] and start hunting. This is especially useful if you are considering hunting [[Cargo Convoy|Cargo Convoys]], since their loot is revealed when they are on the map. This hack also reveals the number of guards for each Hauler, so you can easily eliminate some Haulers as not worth hunting down.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rank|Hack Rank Miscellaneous[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]
Hack|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
[[Spoiler]]Control(Protovariants)[[/Spoiler]]|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Rare, usually only once if at all
||Manifests|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

[[Heading]]Spoiler Hacks|Spoiler Hacks Terminal[[/Heading]]
[[Expandable]]
Show/hide hacks|
Thoughts about select Force/Trojan hacks:

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Force(Sabotage)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This generally unimpressive hack explodes a random machine on the map, something that tends to be of little relevance most of the time. The odds that it will do nothing beneficial for you are quite high unless you are in [[Hub_04(d)]], where it has a niche use. In this map, the only explosive machines are the Network Hubs, so a successful hack will always result in at least one destroyed Hub.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Force(Search)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This low value hack locates all interactive machines in a moderately sized 31 tile radius at the cost of a summoned investigation squad. I don't rate this hack very highly since you can always explore the map yourself or use a myriad of other ways to gather information about the map around you. Locking the machine and summoning an investigation is a bit too high of a price to pay.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Assimilate)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack to assimilate an [[Operator]] is one of the best hacks in the game. You should nearly always be able to beat Operators to their Terminals, so there should be multiple opportunities to use this hack each floor. Operators make fantastic allies for their hacking bonus and trap-locating abilities. Try to keep at least one around at all times if possible and use this hack to get more.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Botnet)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack is a somewhat divisive hack among Cogmind players. Its effect is simple; Botnet provides a small hacking bonus to hacks on all other machines on the floor. With a base value of 6% and diminishing returns, two of them isn't even worth a single [[Hacking Suite]]. Not to mention, a hack you spend on a Botnet is a hack you spend not doing anything else. Still, it is a hacking bonus that has no slot or ally requirements. It can help turn a Terminal you have little use for into a successful hack on a later Terminal that you really do care about. One of its best uses is in squeezing every single percentage point you can muster into hacking for a high level schematic or trying to quickly locate an exit. I typically install at least one or two per map and don't go more than that unless I have a fantastic hackware stack with nothing better to do.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Detonate)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This niche hack turns nearby explosive machines into proximity mines. Luring squads into big explosive machine arrays and then blowing them up is always a fun time, although it can be punishing to use too much since you are assigned all [[Alert]] that comes from the explosions. Additionally, make sure to look out for collateral damage when using this hack. It's easy for explosive machines to take out a useful interactive machine, nuke a part stockpile you may have wanted on the ground, or blow away your cover.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Disrupt)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Disrupt is a nice hack to have active when forced to enter combat, but isn't commonly worth the low success rate and the potential tradeoff of other hacks. Lowering the targeting of nearby hostiles is useful not only for engaging in combat but also for running away from combat. This can be used both proactively to prepare to engage a troublesome [[Extermination Squad]] or reactively when on the run.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Operators)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
This hack to locate Operators is a great choice for flight players. One of its best uses is in combination with [[GameText]]Trojan(Assimilate)[[/GameText]] to locate Operators ripe to assimilate. Even if not planning to assimilate, this intel has other uses. Locating Operators gives you some hint as to where Terminals on the map are. Additionally, it's always nice to have a heads up about Operator positioning in case you end up with a [[Watcher]] jamming your sensors.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Skim)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
Skim is a uniquely powerful hack that can give you information about not only the current map, but future floors as well like [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]] do. This lets you "bank" intel on an earlier depth and get the reward later, which can help to snowball your build toward success. The cost of this is hack is high with 5 successful hacks on 5 untraced Terminals being required. The information can also be quite random and often is unhelpful, doing things like confirming depths of maps you already knew about. However, the upsides can be quite high with high rolls of exit locations and map layouts. In later parts of the game (Research and beyond), this sort of map intel can be incredibly valuable thanks to increased difficulty in exploring the map. If you have decent hacking capabilities (4+ hackware) I would recommend trying to get one Skim off per floor.

[[Heading:2]][[GameText]]Trojan(Track)[[/GameText]][[/Heading]]
A relatively unimpressive hack that reveals all bots in a small radius nearby. The best niche of this hack is being able to track enemies through Watcher or [[Heavy]] sensor jamming. However, the range of 6-10 tiles (based on security level) is so unimpressive that you will often bump into hostiles just out of range.

[[Heading:2]]Hack Rating|Hack Rating Spoiler[[/Heading]]
[[Table]]Hack Rating|Usefulness|Personal hack frequency||
Force(Sabotage)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]] (Hub)
[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]] (Rest)|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Never unless Hub, then multiple times per map||
Force(Search)|[[Range]]1|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Practically never||
Trojan(Assimilate)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, multiple times per map||
Trojan(Botnet)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once or twice per map (1-2)||
Trojan(Detonate)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Rare, situationally multiple times per map||
Trojan(Disrupt)|[[Range]]3|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Neutral]]Infrequent, situationally multiple times per map||
Trojan(Operators)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, once per map||
Trojan(Skim)|[[Range]]5|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Good]]Frequent, multiple times per map||
Trojan(Track)|[[Range]]2|5[[/Range]]|[[CellStyle:Bad]]Rare, situationally multiple times per floor
[[/Table]]
[[/Expandable]]

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Map Strategy
Content:
[[Heading]][[B]][[Color:Red]]WIP[[/Color]][[/B]][[/Heading]]
These are a collection of thoughts about strategies on a per-map basis for select maps.
Subpages: aoemica's Flight Guide/Map Strategy/Factory,aoemica's Flight Guide/Map Strategy/Materials

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Map Strategy/Factory
Content:
[[Image]]Factory.png|An example Factory map[[/Image]]
[[Factory]] is the second main [[0b10]] [[Location]] and spans the most floors of all main maps, from -7 to -4. Factory's large size, low [[Patrol Squad|patrol]] density, open corridors, well connected layout with multiple paths make it great for flight.

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Map Strategy/Materials
Content:
[[Image]]Materials.png|An example Materials map[[/Image]]
[[Materials]] is the earliest main [[0b10]] [[Location]] in the game and is one of the more difficult maps for flight. First off, there are no starting [[Flight Units]] in [[Scrapyard]], so you can't become flight until you find at least one of them. The general map design is not very favorable for flight either. [[Patrol Squad|Patrols]] and [[Sentry|Sentries]] are fairly common on -9 and -8, and the cramped map layout often railroads you directly into them. Running past them results in you taking a few hits as you go by, but trying to fight with a flimsy build is even worse. Given the very low integrity of early flight builds, it's easy to get shot out of the sky very early on if you try to switch too early. That's not to say that Materials flight is impossible, but it is definitely an uphill battle and does not prepare your build well for the rest of the game. For these reasons, I highly recommend not trying to attach any flight units in any Materials depths maps, including [[Mines]] and [[Storage]].
Instead, I suggest treating Materials as a time to prepare your flight build to be the best it can be on -7 [[Factory]]. Stock up on some [[Lgt. Treads]] and weapons and tank your way through. Use a [[Lrg. Storage Unit|Lrg.]], [[Hcp. Storage Unit|Hcp.]], or [[Huge Storage Unit]] to carry good flight parts that you find along your way. Try to balance your backup combat parts with your flight parts, since running out of treads or weapons is a real threat when the rest of your build is flight. I try to keep at least two backup weapons and combat propulsion (treads/legs/wheels) in inventory unless I'm about to head to into Factory.
[[Heading]]Factory Checklist[[/Heading]]
A good way to prepare for Factory is to have a checklist for your build. You may not want or need all of the items on it, but it is good to help give you an idea of what to aim for. Here is an example [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Builds#Stealth|stealth flight]] checklist in Factory:
[[Table]]
Part type|Example parts (best first)|Ideal number|How to obtain (aside from floor)||
[[Power]]|[[Lgt. Deuterium Engine]], [[Lgt. Nuclear Core]], [[Lgt. Ion Engine]]|1 to attach and 1 as backup|Lgt. Nuclear Core from [[G-47 Trooper]]||
[[Propulsion]]|[[Imp. VTOL Module]], [[Imp. Flight Unit]], [[VTOL Module]], [[Flight Unit]]|3-4 to attach and 1-2 as backup|
[[Hauler|Haulers]], worst case [[Swarmer|Swarmers]]||
[[Armor]]|[[Imp. Light Armor Plating]], [[Reflective Plating]], [[Lgt. Armor Plating]]|1 to attach or swap as needed|[[Y-45 Defender]]||
[[Hackware]]|[[Hacking Suite]], [[System Shield]]|1-3 Hacking Suite and 0-1 System Shield to attach|[[O-16 Technician]]||
[[Infowar#Robot Detection|Robot Detection]]|[[Imp. Sensor Array]] + [[Imp. Signal Interpreter]] (if not [[FarCom]])|1 Sensor and 1 Interpreter to attach|[[TF Node]]||
[[Visual Processing Units|Visual Processing Unit]]|[[Adv. Visual Processing Unit]], [[Visual Processing Unit]]|1 to attach|[[W-16 Scout]]||
[[Explosive Launchers|Explosive Launcher]]|[[Mni. Grenade Launcher]], [[Missile Launcher]], [[Imp. Grenade Launcher]]|1 to swap as needed|[[D-53 Grenadier]] from [[Mines]] infestation event||
[[Melee Weapons|Melee Weapon]]|[[Katana]], [[Hvy. Mace]]|1 to attach|[[L-41 Fighter]]
[[/Table]]

[[Heading]][[Routing]] decisions[[/Heading]]

[[Heading:2]][[Mines]][[/Heading]]
Mines is available on -10 and -9 and doesn't have too much of note by itself. However, it is required to reach the [[Exiles (Location)|Exiles]] and gain [[FarCom]]. Look for a message that [[GameText]]Something is scanning the area.[[/GameText]] to identify the Exiles depth as you enter the map since the Exiles will only be on one Mines depth. Mines can be quite risky due to the [[Assembled]] infestation event. I recommend checking out some basic strategies for [[Mines#Surviving the Assembled Infestation|Surviving the Assembled Infestation]].
[[Heading:2]][[Subcaves]][[/Heading]]
Subcaves is only available on -10

Name: aoemica's Flight Guide/Routing
Content:
Routing is the art of planning which [[Branch]] maps you are going to go to throughout the course of a run. There are all sorts of benefits in different branches in the game, and many overlap in depth, so you must make a conscious decision about which maps to pick. Sometimes, this must be done off of imperfect information because you don't know which branch is at the end of a certain [[Caves]] depth. In other cases, you may learn the depth of an upcoming map like through a [[Derelict Log]] or [[Spoiler]][[GameText]]Force(Tunnel)[[/GameText]] from a [[Recycling Unit]][[/Spoiler]] and make other decisions to support that map choice later. Overall, routing is quite dynamic from run to run and isn't something that you can plan with 100% certainty from the beginning.
Routing ties heavily into [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Alignments|Alignments]]. Most alignments require you to visit a certain map which may be on a different depth each run. If you're shooting for a certain alignment, you have to make sure you don't accidentally miss it by taking a random exit or the wrong branch on the depth they're at. For example, [[Caves]] branch ends can be one of 2 different maps. If you don't know which is which, you may need to take both Caves exits to be sure you don't miss it. Some alignments trigger active hostilities with factions on certain maps, so it often makes sense to plan to avoid actively hostile branches unless you're ready to fight your way through.

[[Heading]]Maps[[/Heading]]
The following is a brief overview of each map including depths, alignment potential, and unique loot that is especially helpful from a flight perspective.

[[Heading:2]][[Mines]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -10 to -9|
Summary: Cramped, hostile branch. [[Assembled]] infestation can be deadly. Flight is difficult.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: [[Exp. Sensor Array]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Exiles (Location)]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -10 to -9|
Summary: Friendly branch, home to the [[Exiles (Group)|Exiles]]. Most loot can only be obtained through alignment.|
Alignment: [[FarCom]]|
Rewards: Many [[Exiles Vault Prototypes]], see [[aoemica's Flight Guide/Alignments#good_vault_prototypes|this ranking]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Storage]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -9 to -7|
Summary: Cramped, hostile [[0b10]] branch. Many [[Patrol Squad|Patrols]], [[Sentry|Sentries]], [[Hauler|Haulers]] and [[Prototype Part|Prototype]] stashes. Flight is difficult.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: Many prototype [[Flight Unit|Flight Units]], especially from Haulers.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Garrison]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -9 to -1|
Summary: Cramped, hostile 0b10 branch. Few combat bots patrolling, many guards that will pop out at inconvenient times. Forced combat and lots of [[Stasis Trap|Stasis Traps]] can destroy unprepared flight builds. Flight is very difficult.|
Alignment: [[RIF]]|
Rewards: Potentially out of depth parts, though not prototypes.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Caves]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -7 to -4|
Summary: Fairly open semi-hostile branch. 0b10 guards and patrols the area but [[Derelict]] guards are also present sometimes.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: 0b10 output [[Terminal]] intel, [[Core Expander]], [[Derelict Log|Derelict Logs]], [[Dirty Datajack|Dirty Datajacks]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[DSF]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -7 to -2|
Summary: Cramped, hostile branch. [[Heavy]] in center will likely summon [[Cutter|Cutters]]. Can be difficult to fully loot map with Heavy + summoned squads.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: Large selection of in-depth parts, sometimes hidden prototypes.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Wastes]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -7 to -4|
Summary: Cramped, hostile 0b10 branch filled with [[C-40 Crusher|Crushers]], frequently with [[Corruption]]-inflicting EMP. Easy to fly past or kite Crushers to death.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: Frequent out-of-depth parts up to 2 ratings high, though they are damaged and may be broken or faulty.
[[/List]]
[[SpoilerHidden]]All remaining branch maps are considered spoilers.[[/SpoilerHidden]]
[[SpoilerExpandable]]

[[Heading:2]][[Subcaves]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -10|
Summary: Cramped, hostile Derelict branch filled with traps and [[Subdweller|Subdwellers]] Flight is very difficult.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: [[Flightbrick]], [[Meta Core]], [[Rainbow Chip]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Recycling]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -9 to -7|
Summary: Cramped, hostile 0b10 branch with many dormant bots, especially [[Sentry|Sentries]].|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: [[Scrap Engine]], [[Tech Extrapolator]] (from [[SUBCON Basin]] quest).
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Scraptown]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -9 to -7|
Summary: Friendly map of Derelicts with many possible prefabs and items, home of the [[United Federation of Derelicts]]. Half of the map with the best rewards is locked behind alignment.|
Alignment: [[UFD]]|
Rewards: Too many to fully list. Some especially good rewards are [[Scraptown#Abandonware Association|Abandonware Association]], [[Scraptown#Cartography Club|Cartography Club]], [[Companion Sword]], and [[Scraptown#Infowarlord's Domain|Infowarlord]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Data Miner (Location)|Data Miner]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -7 or -6|
Summary: Friendly branch with helpful Terminals, home to the [[Data Miner]].|
Alignment: [[Data Miner (Location)#Alignment|Data Miner Alignment]] or [[Data Conduit]]|
Rewards: [[Schematic|Schematics]] including [[Combat Drone Bay]], [[Warlord (Location)#Warlord's Stash|Warlord Stash Code]], prototype [[Hackware]] (if killing Data Miner).
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Zion]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -7 or -6|
Summary: Friendly map of Derelicts with many possible prefabs and items, home to [[Imprinter]]. Map rewards themselves do not require alignment.|
Alignment: [[Imprint]]|
Rewards: [[A8]]'s [[Enhanced Grunt]] code, assorted allies, [[CR-A16's Pointy Stick]], [[Hacking Drone Bay]] (mainly for Imprint), high rating prototype Processors/Hackware, [[RU-N14's Throwing Claymores]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Extension]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -6 to -4|
Summary: Hostile 0b10 map with wide open corridors through the bottom and cramped rooms along the top. Contains special Transfer Stations. Heavily guarded with many locked up and rewirable friendly Derelicts.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: allied [[A7]], other assorted Derelict allies
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Cetus]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -6 to -4|
Summary: Hostile map with forced [[Cetus Guard]] encounters. Can easily run from guards if necessary.|
Alignment: [[Revision 17 (Alignment)]]|
Rewards: up to 5 fabricated [[Enhanced Grunt]] allies with A7 code.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Archives]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -6 to -4|
Summary: Hostile map with forced [[Sentry]] encounter.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: Plentiful [[Operator]] parts, particularly [[Imp. Hacking Suite|Imp. Hacking Suites]] and [[Imp. System Shield|Imp. System Shields]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Hub_04(d)]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -6 to -4|
Summary: Cramped, hostile 0b10 map that is well covered by [[Heavy|Heavies]]. Contains multiple highly explosive Network Hubs and a Transfer Station machine.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: Exploding Network Hubs provides permanent hacking bonuses.
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Warlord (Location)]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -5 or -4|
Summary: Friendly map of Derelicts with many possible prefabs and items, home to [[Warlord]]. 0b10 assault will begin some time after entering the map so expect to help the fight or run through combat.|
Alignment: [[Warlord (Alignment)]]|
Rewards: [[Executioner]] and [[Striker]] loot, [[Exp. Cloaking Device]], prototype flight units and hackware, rewirable allies, [[RU-N14's Throwing Claymores]] [[Spectral Analyzer]], Terminal prototype IDs and intel, [[Vortex Weapons]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Zhirov (Location)]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -5 or -4|
Summary: Friendly map of Derelicts with a small collection of possible items, home to [[Zhirov]].|
Alignment: [[Zhirov (Alignment)]]|
Rewards: Adv. tier hackware, [[Cld. Nuclear Pulse Thruster|Cld. Nuclear Pulse Thrusters]], Exp. tier [[Shieldings]], [[Integrated Dissipator]] or [[Integrated Reactor|Reactor]], [[Transdimensional Reconstructor]].
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Armory]][[/Heading]]
[[List]]
Depths: -4 or -3|
Summary: Hostile 0b10 map with long corridors split by cramped rooms and tons of patrols. Flight is difficult without good long-ranged weapons.|
Alignment: None|
Rewards: Large [[Authchips|Authchip]] cache, many [[Fabricator|Fabricators]]
[[/List]]

[[Heading:2]][[Testing]][[/Heading]]
